quiz_title: SQ topic 14

questions.raw_html_question: Tom's brother suffers from phenylketonuria (PKU), a recessive disorder. The brothers' parents do not have PKU. What are the chances that Tom, who is normal for this trait, is a carrier of PKU?
questions.question: Tom's brother suffers from phenylketonuria (PKU), a recessive disorder. The brothers' parents do not have PKU. What are the chances that Tom, who is normal for this trait, is a carrier of PKU?
questions.comments: The parents must both be carriers of PKU . Tom, who is not affected, has a 1/3 chance of not being a carrier and a 2/3 chance of being a carrier. To figure this out, realize that the fact that Tom’s parents must both be carriers means they are both heterozygous for the disease-causing allele. If we represent the disease causing allele of this gene as “d”, and the non-disease causing allele of this gene as “D”, that means Tom’s parents are both Dd. Therefore, each of the children of Tom’s parents would have an equal chance of having inherited one of the following: DD, Dd, dD or dd. Because Tom does not exhibit the disease, we can rule out dd. That means he is DD, Dd or dD. If he is Dd or dD, he is a carrier of the disease. If he is DD, he is not a carrier of the disease. Therefore there is a 2/3 chance that he is a carrier (i.e. has a “d” allele).
questions.raw_html_comments: The parents must both be carriers of PKU . Tom, who is not affected, has a 1/3 chance of not being a carrier and a 2/3 chance of being a carrier. To figure this out, realize that the fact that Tom’s parents must both be carriers means they are both heterozygous for the disease-causing allele. If we represent the disease causing allele of this gene as “d”, and the non-disease causing allele of this gene as “D”, that means Tom’s parents are both Dd. Therefore, each of the children of Tom’s parents would have an equal chance of having inherited one of the following: DD, Dd, dD or dd. Because Tom does not exhibit the disease, we can rule out dd. That means he is DD, Dd or dD. If he is Dd or dD, he is a carrier of the disease. If he is DD, he is not a carrier of the disease. Therefore there is a 2/3 chance that he is a carrier (i.e. has a “d” allele).

questions.raw_html_question: Radish flowers may be red, purple, or white. A cross between a red-flowered plant and a white-flowered plant yields all-purple offspring. The part of the radish we eat may be oval or long, with long being the dominant characteristic. The flower color trait in radishes is an example of which of the following?
questions.question: Radish flowers may be red, purple, or white. A cross between a red-flowered plant and a white-flowered plant yields all-purple offspring. The part of the radish we eat may be oval or long, with long being the dominant characteristic. The flower color trait in radishes is an example of which of the following?

options.text: a multiple allelic system
codominance
sex linkage
full dominance
incomplete dominance

questions.comments: Radishes that are heterozygous for this flower color gene display a phenotype that is intermediate to the phenotype of radishes that are homozygous for either allele. Such an intermediate phenotype is characteristic of alleles that exhibit incomplete dominance. In contrast, “codominance” is when the traits of both alleles are expressed. For example, cows that are heterozygous for red and white hair color alleles produce some hairs that are red and some that are white. So, they express both the red and white phenotypes. If the cow hair color alleles were instead incompletely dominant, cows that were heterozygous for the hair color gene would make all pink hairs.
questions.raw_html_comments: Radishes that are heterozygous for this flower color gene display a phenotype that is intermediate to the phenotype of radishes that are homozygous for either allele. If the cow hair color alleles were instead incompletely dominant, cows that were heterozygous for the hair color gene would make all pink hairs.

questions.raw_html_question: In a particular plant, leaf color is controlled by gene locus D. Plants with at least one allele D have dark green leaves, and plants with the homozygous recessive dd genotype have light green leaves. A true-breeding dark-leaved plant is crossed with a light-leaved one, and the F1 offspring is allowed to self-pollinate. The predicted outcome of the F2 is diagrammed in the Punnett square shown in the figure below, where 1, 2, 3, and 4 represent the genotypes corresponding to each box within the square. Which of the boxes marked 1-4 correspond to plants with dark leaves?
questions.question: In a particular plant, leaf color is controlled by gene locus D. Plants with at least one allele D have dark green leaves, and plants with the homozygous recessive dd genotype have light green leaves. A true-breeding dark-leaved plant is crossed with a light-leaved one, and the F1 offspring is allowed to self-pollinate. The predicted outcome of the F2 is diagrammed in the Punnett square shown in the figure below, where 1, 2, 3, and 4 represent the genotypes corresponding to each box within the square. Which of the boxes marked 1-4 correspond to plants with dark leaves?

options.text: 1 and 2
2 and 3
1 only
4 only

questions.comments: Plants with at least copy of the D allele will have dark leaves. F2plants represented by box 1 are DD, and thus have dark leaves. F2plants represented by box 2 are Dd, and thus have dark leaves. F2plants represented by box 3 are dD, and thus have dark leaves. In contrast, F2 plants represented by box 4 are dd, and thus have light green leaves.
questions.raw_html_comments:
Plants with at least copy of the D allele will have dark leaves. F2
plants represented by box 1 are DD, and thus have dark leaves. F2
plants represented by box 2 are Dd, and thus have dark leaves. F2
plants represented by box 3 are dD, and thus have dark leaves. In contrast, F2 plants represented by box 4 are dd, and thus have light green leaves.

questions.raw_html_question:
Drosophila (fruit flies) usually have long wings, but mutations in the BT
gene can result in bent wings and mutations in the VG gene can result in vestigial wings. If a homozygous bent wing fly is mated with a homozygous vestigial wing fly, which of the following offspring would you expect? Note that flies that have one wild-type allele and one mutant allele of the BT
gene are represented by +bt, and flies that have one wild-type allele and one mutant allele of the VG gene are represented by +vg.
questions.question: Drosophila (fruit flies) usually have long wings, but mutations in the BTgene can result in bent wings and mutations in the VG gene can result in vestigial wings. If a homozygous bent wing fly is mated with a homozygous vestigial wing fly, which of the following offspring would you expect? Note that flies that have one wild-type allele and one mutant allele of the BTgene are represented by +bt, and flies that have one wild-type allele and one mutant allele of the VG gene are represented by +vg.

options.text: 1/2 bent and 1/2 vestigial flies
3/4 bent to 1/4 vestigial ratio
1/2 bent and vestigial to 1/2 normal
all +bt +vg heterozygotes
all homozygous + flies

questions.comments: The cross is as follows: btbt++ X ++vgvg. All the progeny will thus inherit one wild-type and one mutant allele of the BT gene and one wild-type and one mutant allele of the VG gene. All of the offspring will thus be +bt+vg, or heterozygous for both genes.
questions.raw_html_comments: The cross is as follows: btbt++ X ++vgvg. All the progeny will thus inherit one wild-type and one mutant allele of the BT gene and one wild-type and one mutant allele of the VG gene. All of the offspring will thus be +bt+vg, or heterozygous for both genes.

questions.raw_html_question: What is the difference between “genotype” and “phenotype”?
questions.question: What is the difference between “genotype” and “phenotype”?

options.text: Genotype refers to individuals that are haploid. Phenotype refers to individuals that are diploid.
Genotype refers to alleles that exhibit complete dominance, whereas phenotype refers to alleles that exhibit incomplete dominance.
Genotype refers to which genes, or which alleles of a particular gene, are carried by an individual. Phenotype refers to the traits exhibited by an individual.
Genotype refers to individuals resulting from a monohybrid cross, whereas phenotype refers to individuals resulting from a dihybrid cross.

questions.raw_html_question: Radish flowers may be red, purple, or white. A cross between a red-flowered plant and a white-flowered plant yields all-purple offspring. The part of the radish we eat may be oval or long, with long being the dominant characteristic. If true-breeding red long radishes are crossed with true-breeding white oval radishes, the F1 will be expected to be which of the following?
questions.question: Radish flowers may be red, purple, or white. A cross between a red-flowered plant and a white-flowered plant yields all-purple offspring. The part of the radish we eat may be oval or long, with long being the dominant characteristic. If true-breeding red long radishes are crossed with true-breeding white oval radishes, the F1 will be expected to be which of the following?

options.text: red and oval
white and long
purple and oval
red and long
purple and long

questions.comments: The fact that a cross between radishes with red and white flowers yields all-purple offspring tells us that the red and white alleles of the flower color gene must exhibit incomplete dominance, so that a red/white heterozygote has a phenotype intermediate to that of red/red or white/white homozygotes. Therefore, all the F1 progeny from a cross between a plant that is true breeding (homozygous) for the red allele and a plant that is homozygous for the white allele will be heterozygous for the flower color gene, and therefore purple. In contrast, the long allele of the radish shape gene is dominant over the oval allele. Therefore, a cross between a plant that is homozygous for the long allele and a plant that is homozygous for the oval allele will result in all F1 progeny being heterozygous for the radish shape gene, and thus having long radishes. Therefore, all the F1progeny will have long, purple radishes.
questions.raw_html_comments:
The fact that a cross between radishes with red and white flowers yields all-purple offspring tells us that the red and white alleles of the flower color gene must exhibit incomplete dominance, so that a red/white heterozygote has a phenotype intermediate to that of red/red or white/white homozygotes. Therefore, all the F1 progeny from a cross between a plant that is true breeding (homozygous) for the red allele and a plant that is homozygous for the white allele will be heterozygous for the flower color gene, and therefore purple. In contrast, the long allele of the radish shape gene is dominant over the oval allele. Therefore, a cross between a plant that is homozygous for the long allele and a plant that is homozygous for the oval allele will result in all F1 progeny being heterozygous for the radish shape gene, and thus having long radishes. Therefore, all the F1
progeny will have long, purple radishes.

questions.raw_html_question: The pedigree below is for a family, some of whose members exhibit the dominant trait, W. Affected individuals are indicated by a dark square or circle. What is the genotype of individual II-5?
questions.question: The pedigree below is for a family, some of whose members exhibit the dominant trait, W. Affected individuals are indicated by a dark square or circle. What is the genotype of individual II-5?

options.text: WW or ww
WW
Ww
ww
ww or Ww

questions.comments: The dominant trait is W. Affected individuals are represented by dark squares or circles and unaffected individuals are represented by open squares or circles. An individual (I-2) who is Ww is shown as being affected. Thus, we know that the dominant allele, W, causes individuals to be affected. Therefore, any individual that is WW or Ww will be affected. Because II-5 is not affected, this individual must be ww.

questions.raw_html_question: A man who can roll his tongue and a woman who cannot roll her tongue have a son who can roll his tongue (R = can roll tongue; r = can't roll tongue). The son is curious about whether his father is homozygous or heterozygous for the tongue-rolling trait. Which of the following facts would allow him to know?
questions.question: A man who can roll his tongue and a woman who cannot roll her tongue have a son who can roll his tongue (R = can roll tongue; r = can't roll tongue). The son is curious about whether his father is homozygous or heterozygous for the tongue-rolling trait. Which of the following facts would allow him to know?

options.text: His father's mother cannot roll her tongue.
The son's sister is a tongue roller.
The son submits his own blood sample to a local genotyping lab, and they establish that he is heterozygous for the trait.
His paternal grandfather and his paternal grandmother can both roll their tongues.
The son's own daughter cannot roll her tongue.

questions.comments: If his father's mother cannot roll her tongue, then she must be rr. Therefore, his father must have inherited an r allele and must therefore be heterozygous.
questions.raw_html_comments: If his father's mother cannot roll her tongue, then she must be rr. Therefore, his father must have inherited an r allele and must therefore be heterozygous.

questions.raw_html_question:
A = big apples;
R = red apples; a = small apples; r = yellow apples. You have one tree that produces big yellow apples and another tree that produces small red apples. When the two are crossed, you find that half of the new trees produce big red apples and half produce big yellow apples. What are the genotypes of the parents?
questions.question: A = big apples;R = red apples; a = small apples; r = yellow apples. You have one tree that produces big yellow apples and another tree that produces small red apples. When the two are crossed, you find that half of the new trees produce big red apples and half produce big yellow apples. What are the genotypes of the parents?

options.text: AaRr and AaRr
Aarr and aaRr
AaRr and aarr
AArr and aaRr
AARr and Aarr

questions.comments: Trees that produce big yellow apples could be AArr or Aarr. Trees that produce small red apples could be aaRR or aaRr. Because all the offspring are big, the big parent must be homozygous for A. Because half the apples are red and half are yellow, the red parent must be heterozygous for red. The conclusion is that the cross must be AArr x aaRr.
questions.raw_html_comments: Trees that produce big yellow apples could be AArr or Aarr. Trees that produce small red apples could be aaRR or aaRr. Because all the offspring are big, the big parent must be homozygous for A. Because half the apples are red and half are yellow, the red parent must be heterozygous for red. The conclusion is that the cross must be AArr x aaRr.

questions.raw_html_question: Two true-breeding stocks of pea plants are crossed. One parent has red, axial flowers and the other has white, terminal flowers; all F1 individuals have red, axial flowers. The genes for flower color and location assort independently. If 1,000 F2 offspring resulted from the cross, approximately how many of them would you expect to have red, terminal flowers?
questions.question: Two true-breeding stocks of pea plants are crossed. One parent has red, axial flowers and the other has white, terminal flowers; all F1 individuals have red, axial flowers. The genes for flower color and location assort independently. If 1,000 F2 offspring resulted from the cross, approximately how many of them would you expect to have red, terminal flowers?
questions.comments: Plants that are “true breeding” are homozygous for the gene that controls the character being studied, meaning that they have two copies of the same allele of that gene. The fact that all the F1 plants have red, axial flowers means that the red allele of the flower-color gene is dominant and the axial allele of the flower-type gene is dominant. If we represent the red and white alleles of the flower color gene as R and r, respectively, and the axial and terminal alleles of the flower type gene as Tand t, respectively, the cross the original parent plants was: RRTTx rrtt. Therefore, the all the F1 plants will be RrTt. A cross between two F1 plants (RrTt X RrTt) will yield an equal mix of F2 progeny with the following genotypes for the flower color gene: RR, Rr, rR and rr. The ¾ of the plants that are RR, Rr or rR will have red flowers. The cross between two F1 plants will yield an equal mix of F2 progeny with the following genotypes for the flower-type gene: TT, Tt, tT and tt. The ¼ of the plants that are tt will have terminal flowers. Therefore, ¾ X ¼ = 3/16 of the plants will have red, terminal flowers. 3/16 X 1,000 = 187.5, which is approximately 190.
questions.raw_html_comments:
Plants that are “true breeding” are homozygous for the gene that controls the character being studied, meaning that they have two copies of the same allele of that gene. The fact that all the F1 plants have red, axial flowers means that the red allele of the flower-color gene is dominant and the axial allele of the flower-type gene is dominant. If we represent the red and white alleles of the flower color gene as R and r, respectively, and the axial and terminal alleles of the flower type gene as T
and t, respectively, the cross the original parent plants was: RRTT
x rrtt. Therefore, the all the F1 plants will be RrTt. A cross between two F1 plants (RrTt X RrTt) will yield an equal mix of F2 progeny with the following genotypes for the flower color gene: RR, Rr, rR and rr. The ¾ of the plants that are RR, Rr or rR will have red flowers. The cross between two F1 plants will yield an equal mix of F2 progeny with the following genotypes for the flower-type gene: TT, Tt, tT and tt. The ¼ of the plants that are tt will have terminal flowers. Therefore, ¾ X ¼ = 3/16 of the plants will have red, terminal flowers. 3/16 X 1,000 = 187.5, which is approximately 190.

questions.question: In a certain plant, the alleles A, B, and C are completely dominant to the alleles a, b, and c. A plant with the genotype AABbcc will have the same phenotype as a plant with the genotype _____.

questions.raw_html_question: Pea flowers may be purple (P) or white (p). Pea seeds may be round (R) or wrinkled (r). What proportion of the offspring from the cross PpRr x PpRr will have white flowers and wrinkled seeds?
questions.question: Pea flowers may be purple (P) or white (p). Pea seeds may be round (R) or wrinkled (r). What proportion of the offspring from the cross PpRr x PpRr will have white flowers and wrinkled seeds?
questions.comments: Pp × Pp would produce 3/4 purple and 1/4 white. Rr × Rr would produce 3/4 round and 1/4 wrinkled; (1/4)(1/4) = 1/16 would have white flowers and wrinkled seeds.
questions.raw_html_comments: Pp × Pp would produce 3/4 purple and 1/4 white. Rr × Rr would produce 3/4 round and 1/4 wrinkled; (1/4)(1/4) = 1/16 would have white flowers and wrinkled seeds.

questions.raw_html_question: It is far more common to find human genetic disease caused by _____ alleles than by _____ alleles because _____.
questions.question: It is far more common to find human genetic disease caused by _____ alleles than by _____ alleles because _____.

options.text: recessive ... dominant ... harmful recessive alleles can survive in the heterozygote without any selection pressure against them
dominant ... recessive ... dominant alleles have an evolutionary advantage over recessive alleles
recessive ... dominant ... even when homozygous, recessive alleles usually do not cause as much damage as dominant alleles
dominant ... recessive ... dominant alleles became dominant because they aid the survival of the organism carrying them
None of the listed responses is correct.

questions.comments: Lethal dominant alleles are much less common than lethal recessive ones because the effects of lethal dominants are not masked in heterozygotes.
questions.raw_html_comments: Lethal dominant alleles are much less common than lethal recessive ones because the effects of lethal dominants are not masked in heterozygotes.

questions.raw_html_question: What do we mean when we use the terms monohybrid cross and dihybrid cross?
questions.question: What do we mean when we use the terms monohybrid cross and dihybrid cross?

options.text: A monohybrid cross is performed for one generation, whereas a dihybrid cross is performed for two generations.
A monohybrid cross results in a 9:3:3:1 ratio whereas a dihybrid cross gives a 3:1 ratio.

A dihybrid cross involves a cross between organisms that are both heterozygous for the same two genetic loci. A monohybrid cross is a cross between organisms that are both heterozygous for the same, single genetic locus.
A monohybrid cross produces a single progeny, whereas a dihybrid cross produces two progeny.

questions.comments: A monohybrid cross is a cross between two organisms that are both heterozygous for a particular genetic locus (e.g., gene). For example, Bb X Bb would be a monohybrid cross as both individuals are heterozygous for a single locus (the B locus) that is being studied. A dihybrid cross is a cross between two organisms that are both heterozygous as the same two loci (e.g., genes). For example, if height is controlled by the “H” locus and seed color is controlled by the “C” locus, then the following would be an example of a dihybrid cross: BbCc X BbCc. You would expect to the progeny of a monohybrid cross to exhibit a 3:1 phenotypic ratio (3 individuals exhibiting the dominant phenotype for every one individual exhibiting the recessive phenotype). The progeny of a dihybrid cross should exhibit a 9:3:3:1 phenotypic ratio (9 individuals exhibiting both dominant phenotypes, for every 3 individuals exhibiting the dominant phenotype for trait one and the recessive phenotype for trait two, for every 3 individuals exhibiting the recessive phenotype for trait one and the dominant phenotype for trait two, for every one individual exhibiting the recessive phenotypes for both traits).
questions.raw_html_comments: A monohybrid cross is a cross between two organisms that are both heterozygous for a particular genetic locus (e.g., gene). For example, Bb X Bb would be a monohybrid cross as both individuals are heterozygous for a single locus (the B locus) that is being studied. A dihybrid cross is a cross between two organisms that are both heterozygous as the same two loci (e.g., genes). For example, if height is controlled by the “H” locus and seed color is controlled by the “C” locus, then the following would be an example of a dihybrid cross: BbCc X BbCc. You would expect to the progeny of a monohybrid cross to exhibit a 3:1 phenotypic ratio (3 individuals exhibiting the dominant phenotype for every one individual exhibiting the recessive phenotype). The progeny of a dihybrid cross should exhibit a 9:3:3:1 phenotypic ratio (9 individuals exhibiting both dominant phenotypes, for every 3 individuals exhibiting the dominant phenotype for trait one and the recessive phenotype for trait two, for every 3 individuals exhibiting the recessive phenotype for trait one and the dominant phenotype for trait two, for every one individual exhibiting the recessive phenotypes for both traits).

questions.raw_html_question: A sexually reproducing animal has two unlinked genes, one for head shape (H) and one for tail length (T). Its genotype is HhTt. Which of the following genotypes is possible in a gamete from this organism?
questions.question: A sexually reproducing animal has two unlinked genes, one for head shape (H) and one for tail length (T). Its genotype is HhTt. Which of the following genotypes is possible in a gamete from this organism?

options.text: HhTt
tt
Hh
HT

questions.comments: The animal is diploid, and thus has two copies of each chromosome. One copy of one of its chromosomes carries an H allele, and the homologous copy of that chromosome carries an h allele of the gene for head shape. A different chromosome carries a T allele, and the homologous chromosome for that chromosome carries a t allele, for the tail length gene. The gametes produced by this animal will be haploid, meaning that they will have only one set of chromosomes, and therefore only one allele of each gene. The gametes produced could have any of the following genotypes: HT, Ht, hT or ht. They can NOT be tt, Hh or HhTt, because then they would have two copies of the tail length gene and no copies of the head shape gene (if tt), two copies of the head shape gene and no copies of the tail length gene (if Hh), or two copies of both genes (if HhTt).
questions.raw_html_comments:
The animal is diploid, and thus has two copies of each chromosome. One copy of one of its chromosomes carries an H allele, and the homologous copy of that chromosome carries an h allele of the gene for head shape. A different chromosome carries a T allele, and the homologous chromosome for that chromosome carries a t allele, for the tail length gene. The gametes produced by this animal will be haploid, meaning that they will have only one set of chromosomes, and therefore only one allele of each gene. The gametes produced could have any of the following genotypes: HT, Ht, hT or ht.

They can NOT be tt, Hh or HhTt, because then they would have two copies of the tail length gene and no copies of the head shape gene (if tt), two copies of the head shape gene and no copies of the tail length gene (if Hh), or two copies of both genes (if HhTt).

questions.question: In a particular plant, leaf color is controlled by gene locus D. Plants with at least one allele D have dark green leaves, and plants with the homozygous recessive dd genotype have light green leaves. A true-breeding dark-leaved plant is crossed with a light-leaved one, and the F1 offspring is allowed to self-pollinate. Which of the plants will be true-breeding?

options.text: 1 only
2 and 3 only
1 and 2 only
1 and 4 only

questions.comments: Plants that are “true breeding” are homozygous for the gene that controls the character being studied, meaning that they have two copies of the same allele of that gene. The F2 plants represented by box 1 are DD, and so are homozygous for the D allele. The F2 plants represented by box 2 are Dd, and thus are heterozygous. The F2plants represented by box 3 are dD, and thus are also heterozygous. The F2plants represented by box 4 are dd, and thus are homozygous for the dallele. So, the plants represented by boxes 1 and 4 are homozygous and so will be true breeding.

questions.raw_html_question: Why did the F1 offspring of Mendel's classic pea cross always look like one of the two parental varieties?
questions.question: Why did the F1 offspring of Mendel's classic pea cross always look like one of the two parental varieties?

options.text: Each allele affected phenotypic expression.
One phenotype was completely dominant over another.
The traits blended together during fertilization.
No genes interacted to produce the parental phenotype.

questions.comments: Mendel studied alleles where one allele was completely dominant to the other. For example, the allele of the flower color gene that causes a purple color is completely dominant to the allele that causes a white color. So, progeny that inherited two purple alleles or one purple allele and one white allele looked exactly like the parent that had two purple alleles or a purple allele and a white allele (i.e. they all had purple flowers). Progeny that inherited two white alleles had white flowers, just like the parent that had two white alleles.

questions.raw_html_question: What was the most significant conclusion that Gregor Mendel drew from his experiments with pea plants?
questions.question: What was the most significant conclusion that Gregor Mendel drew from his experiments with pea plants?

options.text: Recessive genes occur more frequently in the F1generation than do dominant ones.
Genes are composed of DNA.
There is considerable genetic variation in garden peas.
Traits are inherited in discrete units, and are not the results of "blending."

questions.comments: Before Mendel’s work, many people thought that the traits exhibited by progeny were a result of the “blending” of the traits of the parents. Mendel’s work showed that this is not true. Instead, we inherit genes from our parents that determine our traits. In many cases one allele of a particular gene is dominant to another allele, so that progeny only exhibit the trait of the dominant allele. For example, children who inherit one allele for blue eyes and one allele for brown eyes have brown eyes, not eyes that are halfway between blue and brown.

questions.raw_html_question: In the cross AaBbCc × AaBbCc, what is the probability of producing the genotype AABBCC?
questions.question: In the cross AaBbCc × AaBbCc, what is the probability of producing the genotype AABBCC?
questions.comments: Both individuals are heterozygous for all three genes. They will have an equal chance of producing offspring with each of the following genotypes for the first gene: AA, Aa, aA and aa. Therefore, ¼ of their offspring will be AA. Similarly, ¼ of their offspring will be BB and ¼ will be CC. To determine the chances that a particular offspring is AA, BB and CC, we need to multiply: ¼ X ¼ X ¼ = 1/64.

If we consider each gene separately, AAis being crossed with Aa. The progeny will thus be an equal mixture of AAand Aa, and all will exhibit the dominant phenotype (trait) for gene A. BBis being crossed with bb. The progeny will all be Bb and will all exhibit the dominant phenotype for gene B. Cc is being crossed with Cc. questions.raw_html_question:
An AABbccDdEeFF
individual is crossed with an individual with the genotype AaBBCCDdEeff. What is the probability that their offspring will have the genotype AaBBCcddEEFf?
questions.question: An AABbccDdEeFFindividual is crossed with an individual with the genotype AaBBCCDdEeff. What is the probability that their offspring will have the genotype AaBBCcddEEFf?
questions.comments: To obtain the overall probability; multiply the individual probabilities for each locus. For example, all of the offspring will inherit a copy of “A” from the first parent and ½ will inherit a copy of “A” from the second parent and ½ will inherit a copy of “a” from the second parent. So, ½ the offspring will be AA and ½ will be Aa. Similarly, ½ the offspring will be BB and ½ will be Bb. For the third gene, all the offspring will inherit a copy of “c” from the first parent and all will inherit a copy of “C” from the second parent, so all the offspring will be Cc. For the 4th gene, ½ the offspring will inherit “D” and ½ will inherit “d” from the 1stparent, and ½ the offspring will inherit “D” and ½ will inherit “d” from the 2nd parent. As a result, the offspring will consist of an equal mixture of: DD, Dd, dD and dd, meaning that ¼ of the offspring will be dd. Similarly, the probability of an offspring being EE is also ¼. Because all the offspring will inherit a copy of “F” from parent 1, and all the offspring will inherit a copy of “f” from parent 2, there is a 100% probability that their offspring will be Ff. So, if you multiply all of these probabilities, you get: (1/2)(1/2)(1)(1/4)(1/4)(1) = 1/64.

questions.raw_html_question: Two true-breeding stocks of pea plants are crossed. One parent has red, axial flowers and the other has white, terminal flowers; all F1 individuals have red, axial flowers. The genes for flower color and location assort independently. Among the F2 offspring, what is the probability of plants with white axial flowers?
questions.question: Two true-breeding stocks of pea plants are crossed. One parent has red, axial flowers and the other has white, terminal flowers; all F1 individuals have red, axial flowers. The genes for flower color and location assort independently. Among the F2 offspring, what is the probability of plants with white axial flowers?
questions.comments: Plants that are “true breeding” are homozygous for the gene that controls the character being studied, meaning that they have two copies of the same allele of that gene. The fact that all the F1 plants have red, axial flowers means that the red allele of the flower-color gene is dominant and the axial allele of the flower-type gene is dominant. If we represent the red and white alleles of the flower color gene as R and r, respectively, and the axial and terminal alleles of the flower type gene as Tand t, respectively, the cross the original parent plants was: RRTTx rrtt. Therefore, the all the F1 plants will be RrTt. A cross between two F1 plants (RrTt X RrTt) will yield an equal mix of F2 progeny with the following genotypes for the flower color gene: RR, Rr, rR and rr. The ¼ of the plants that are rr will have white flowers. The cross between two F1plants will yield an equal mix of F2 progeny with the following genotypes for the flower-type gene: TT, Tt, tT and tt. The ¾ of the plants that are TT, Tt or tT will have axial flowers. Therefore, ¼ X ¾ = 3/16 of the plants will have white axial flowers.

questions.raw_html_question: The pedigree below is for a family, some of whose members exhibit the dominant trait, W. Affected individuals are indicated by a dark square or circle. What is the likelihood that the progeny of IV-3 and IV-4 will have the trait?
questions.question: The pedigree below is for a family, some of whose members exhibit the dominant trait, W. Affected individuals are indicated by a dark square or circle. What is the likelihood that the progeny of IV-3 and IV-4 will have the trait?
questions.comments: The dominant trait is W. Affected individuals are represented by dark squares or circles and unaffected individuals are represented by open squares or circles. An individual (I-2) who is Ww is shown as being affected. Thus, we know that the dominant allele, W, causes individuals to be affected. Because IV-4 is not affected, IV-4 must be ww. IV-3 is affected, which could be due to being WW or Ww. We can determine that IV-3 must be Ww, because IV-3 has a parent who is not affected. This parent must therefore be ww, meaning that IV-3 must have inherited a w allele from that parent. Therefore, the cross is: Ww X ww. This cross will result in an equal mixture of progeny that are Ww (and are affected) and ww (and are not affected). Therefore, 50% of the progeny of IV-3 and IV-4 will be affected.

questions.raw_html_question: Human blood groups are governed by three alleles, A, B, and O. A and B are codominant and O is recessive to both. If a woman with type O blood is expecting a child. Her husband is type A. Both the woman's father and her husband's father had type B blood. What is the probability that the child will have type O blood?
questions.question: Human blood groups are governed by three alleles, A, B, and O. A and B are codominant and O is recessive to both. If a woman with type O blood is expecting a child. Her husband is type A. Both the woman's father and her husband's father had type B blood. What is the probability that the child will have type O blood?
questions.comments: IB represents the B blood type allele, IArepresents the A blood type allele and i represents the O blood type allele. Because the woman has blood type O, she must be ii. The husband has blood type A, but must be a carrier of the i allele, as his father was B. (His father did not give him a B allele or he would have blood type AB, so his father must have given him a recessive i allele.) The cross is therefore: ii x IAi, which has yields a 50% probability that the child will be ii, or type O.

questions.raw_html_question: Michelle and Keith are apparently normal, but their daughter was born with alkaptonuria, an inherited metabolic disorder. If alkaptonuria is like most other human hereditary disorders, the probability of their next child being born with alkaptonuria is _____.
questions.question: Michelle and Keith are apparently normal, but their daughter was born with alkaptonuria, an inherited metabolic disorder. If alkaptonuria is like most other human hereditary disorders, the probability of their next child being born with alkaptonuria is _____.
questions.comments: Most genetic disorders are recessive. The fact that Michelle and Keith don’t exhibit the disorder is further evidence that this trait is recessive. The fact that their daughter has the trait indicates that they are both carriers of the disease. Therefore they are both heterozygous, and the probability of another child inheriting the recessive (disease causing) allele from both of them is ½ X ½ = ¼.

questions.question: Flower color in snapdragons is an example of incomplete dominance. When a red-flowered plant is crossed with a white-flowered plant, the F1 generation has pink flowers. If a pink-flowered plant is crossed with another pink-flowered plant, the progeny plants will be _____.

options.text: 25% white and 75% red
100% red

questions.comments: A plant that is homozygous for the “red” allele is crossed with a plant that is homozygous for the “white” allele to produce an F1 plant that is pink, and has one copy each of the red and white alleles. If two of these pink flowered F1 plants are crossed to each other, they will produce equal numbers of progeny with the following allele combinations: red red (will have red flowers), red white (will have pink flowers), white red (will have pink flowers), white white (will have white flowers). Therefore, breeding the F1hybrids of the snapdragon cross produces F2 offspring, with a phenotypic ratio of 1 red: 2 pink: 1 white.

questions.raw_html_question: Radish flowers may be red, purple, or white. A cross between a red-flowered plant and a white-flowered plant yields all-purple offspring. The part of the radish we eat may be oval or long, with long being the dominant characteristic. If true-breeding red long radishes are crossed with true-breeding white oval radishes, which of the following phenotypic ratios would be expected in the F2 generation?
questions.question: Radish flowers may be red, purple, or white. A cross between a red-flowered plant and a white-flowered plant yields all-purple offspring. The part of the radish we eat may be oval or long, with long being the dominant characteristic. If true-breeding red long radishes are crossed with true-breeding white oval radishes, which of the following phenotypic ratios would be expected in the F2 generation?
questions.comments: The fact that a cross between radishes with red and white flowers yields all-purple offspring tells us that the red and white alleles of the flower color gene (C) must exhibit incomplete dominance, so that a red/white heterozygote has a phenotype intermediate to that of red/red or white/white homozygotes (i.e. Cc heterozygotes have purple flowers). In contrast, the long allele of the radish shape gene (S) is dominant over the oval allele. All the F1 progeny from a cross between a plant that is true breeding (homozygous) for the red allele of the flower color gene and the long allele of the radish shape gene and a plant that is homozygous for the white allele of the flower color gene and the oval allele of the radish shape gene will be heterozygous for both genes. Therefore, the cross between two F1 plants can be represented as: CcSs X CcSs. This cross will result in an equal mix of progeny that are: CC(will have red phenotype), Cc (will have purple phenotype), cC (will have purple phenotype) or cc (will have white phenotype) for the flower color gene. So, ¼ of the F2 plants will have red flowers, ½ will have purple flowers and ¼ will have white flowers. For the radish shape gene, the F2 progeny will be an equal mix of the following genotypes: SS, Ss, sS and ss. The ¾ of the F2progeny that are SS, Ss or sS will have long radishes. The ¼ of the F2 progeny that are ss will have oval radishes. Therefore, the probabilities for each phenotypic combination of flower color and radish shape are as follows:Red long: ¼ X ¾ = 3/16Red oval: ¼ X ¼ = 1/16Purple long: ½ X ¾ = 3/8 = 6/16Purple oval: ½ X ¼ = 1/8 = 2/16White long: ¼ X ¾ = 3/16White oval: ¼ X ¼ = 1/16In order of most to least common: 6/16, 3/16, 3/16, 2/16, 1/16, 1/16. Therefore, the phenotypic ratio can be written as: 6:3:3:2:1:1
questions.raw_html_comments:
The fact that a cross between radishes with red and white flowers yields all-purple offspring tells us that the red and white alleles of the flower color gene (C) must exhibit incomplete dominance, so that a red/white heterozygote has a phenotype intermediate to that of red/red or white/white homozygotes (i.e. Cc heterozygotes have purple flowers). In contrast, the long allele of the radish shape gene (S) is dominant over the oval allele. All the F1 progeny from a cross between a plant that is true breeding (homozygous) for the red allele of the flower color gene and the long allele of the radish shape gene and a plant that is homozygous for the white allele of the flower color gene and the oval allele of the radish shape gene will be heterozygous for both genes.

Therefore, the cross between two F1 plants can be represented as: CcSs X CcSs. This cross will result in an equal mix of progeny that are: CC
(will have red phenotype), Cc (will have purple phenotype), cC (will have purple phenotype) or cc (will have white phenotype) for the flower color gene. So, ¼ of the F2 plants will have red flowers, ½ will have purple flowers and ¼ will have white flowers. For the radish shape gene, the F2 progeny will be an equal mix of the following genotypes: SS, Ss, sS and ss. The ¾ of the F2
progeny that are SS, Ss or sS will have long radishes. The ¼ of the F2 progeny that are ss will have oval radishes.

Therefore, the probabilities for each phenotypic combination of flower color and radish shape are as follows:
Red long: ¼ X ¾ = 3/16
Red oval: ¼ X ¼ = 1/16
Purple long: ½ X ¾ = 3/8 = 6/16
Purple oval: ½ X ¼ = 1/8 = 2/16
White long: ¼ X ¾ = 3/16
White oval: ¼ X ¼ = 1/16

In order of most to least common: 6/16, 3/16, 3/16, 2/16, 1/16, 1/16. Therefore, the phenotypic ratio can be written as: 6:3:3:2:1:1

questions.raw_html_question: Two plants are crossed, resulting in offspring with a 3:1 ratio for a particular trait. What does this suggest?
questions.question: Two plants are crossed, resulting in offspring with a 3:1 ratio for a particular trait. What does this suggest?

options.text: that the parents were true-breeding for contrasting traits
that the parents were both heterozygous for a single trait
that a blending of traits has occurred
that the trait shows incomplete dominance

questions.comments: This result suggests that both parents are heterozygous for the trait. If the dominant allele of the trait is “D”, and the recessive allele is “d”, that means both parents are Dd and produce an equal mixture of progeny with the following genotypes (= allele combinations): DD, Dd, dD and dd. The first three genotypes will produce the dominant phenotype (observable trait) and the fourth will produce the recessive phenotype. Therefore, the offspring will have a 3:1 ratio for the trait. If one of the parents was homozygous, you would see a different ratio of traits among the offspring. For example, if one parent was DD and the other was Dd, the offspring would be an equal mix of DD and Dd. In that case, all the progeny would exhibit the dominant trait. If one parent was dd and the other was Dd, half the progeny would be dd and the other half would be Dd. In that case, ½ the progeny would exhibit the dominant trait and the other ½ would exhibit the recessive trait.

In that case, ½ the progeny would exhibit the dominant trait and the other ½ would exhibit the recessive trait.

questions.raw_html_question: If a heterozygous plant is allowed to self-pollinate, what proportion of the offspring will also be heterozygous?
questions.question: If a heterozygous plant is allowed to self-pollinate, what proportion of the offspring will also be heterozygous?

options.text: all of them

questions.comments: Remember that a heterozygous plant will have copies of two different alleles of the gene in question, whereas a homozygous plant will have two copies of the same allele of the gene in question (either two copies of the dominant allele, or two copies of the recessive allele). One-quarter of the offspring will be homozygous for the dominant allele, one-quarter will be homozygous for the recessive allele, and the remaining half will be heterozygous. For example, in the Punnett square shown below, the dominant allele is represented by “D”, and the recessive allele is represented by “d”. Half of the egg cells will contain “D” and half will contain “d”. Similarly, half of the sperm cells will contain “D” and half will contain “d”. Each egg cell has an equal chance of combining with each sperm cell. Therefore, the probability of any one type of egg cell combining with any one type of sperm cell is ½ X ½ = ¼. Two of these combinations (D X d and d X D) result in production of a heterozygous offspring. So, ¼ + ¼ = ½ of the progeny will be heterozygous.
questions.raw_html_comments: Remember that a heterozygous plant will have copies of two different alleles of the gene in question, whereas a homozygous plant will have two copies of the same allele of the gene in question (either two copies of the dominant allele, or two copies of the recessive allele). Half of the egg cells will contain “D” and half will contain “d”. Similarly, half of the sperm cells will contain “D” and half will contain “d”. Each egg cell has an equal chance of combining with each sperm cell. Therefore, the probability of any one type of egg cell combining with any one type of sperm cell is ½ X ½ = ¼. Two of these combinations (D X d and d X D) result in production of a heterozygous offspring. So, ¼ + ¼ = ½ of the progeny will be heterozygous.

questions.raw_html_question: Why did Mendel continue some of his experiments to the F2 or F3 generation?
questions.question: Why did Mendel continue some of his experiments to the F2 or F3 generation?

options.text: to obtain a larger number of offspring on which to base statistics
to distinguish which alleles were segregating
to observe whether or not the dominant trait would reappear
to observe whether or not a recessive trait would reappear
to be able to describe the frequency of recombination

questions.comments: For most of his experiments, Mendel crossed two individuals that were each homozygous for different alleles of a particular character. For example, he crossed plants that were homozygous for the purple (P) allele of the flower color gene with plants that were homozygous for the white (p) allele of the flower color gene. All the F1 progeny thus had the Pp genotype and all had purple flowers, because the purple allele is dominant. If Mendel had stopped with the F1 generation, he would not have known whether the plants simply didn’t inherit the white allele, or whether the effects of the white allele were masked by the presence of a purple allele. By crossing two F1 plants that were Pp, he got a 1:2:1 ratio of F2plants with the following genotypes: PP, Pp and pp. The pp plants had white flowers, demonstrating that the white allele wasn’t lost, its effect was simply masked by the presence of the purple allele.

questions.raw_html_question: How many unique gametes could be produced through independent assortment by an individual with the genotype AaBbCCDdEE?
questions.question: How many unique gametes could be produced through independent assortment by an individual with the genotype AaBbCCDdEE?
questions.comments: This question asks you to consider 5 genes, labeled A through E. The individual in question has the same allele for two of the genes. In other words, the individual has two copies of the C allele and two copies of the E allele. So, all the gametes produced by this individual will inherit a copy of the C allele of the C gene and the E allele of the E gene. In contrast, the individual has two different alleles of each of the other 3 genes. For each of those three genes, a gamete can inherit either the dominant allele (shown with an upper-case letter) or the recessive allele (shown with a lower-case letter). So, the possible combinations of the alleles for those three genes are: ABD, ABd, AbD, Abd, aBD, aBd, abD and abd. So, this individual can produce gametes with 8 different genotypes.

questions.raw_html_question:
Drosophila (fruit flies) usually have long wings, but mutations in the BT
gene can result in bent wings and mutations in the VG gene can result in vestigial wings. If flies that are heterozygous for both the bent wing gene and the vestigial wing gene are mated, what is the probability of offspring with bent wings only? Note that the mutant alleles of both genes are recessive.
questions.question: Drosophila (fruit flies) usually have long wings, but mutations in the BTgene can result in bent wings and mutations in the VG gene can result in vestigial wings. If flies that are heterozygous for both the bent wing gene and the vestigial wing gene are mated, what is the probability of offspring with bent wings only? Note that the mutant alleles of both genes are recessive.
questions.comments: The wild-type alleles of both genes are represented by “+”. The cross can be written as follows: +bt+vg X +bt+vg. For the BT gene, there will be an equal mixture of progeny with each of the following genotypes: ++, +b, b+ and bb. Because the mutant allele is recessive, only the ¼ of the progeny that are bb will have bent wings. Of the ¼ of the progeny that have bent wings, ¼ will also be homozygous for the mutant allele of the VG gene, and thus will also have vestigial wings. In other words, ¼ X ¼ of the progeny will have both bent and vestigial wings. The probability of offspring with bent wings only is therefore: 1/4 - 1/16 = 3/16.
questions.raw_html_comments: The wild-type alleles of both genes are represented by “+”. The cross can be written as follows: +bt+vg X +bt+vg. For the BT gene, there will be an equal mixture of progeny with each of the following genotypes: ++, +b, b+ and bb. Because the mutant allele is recessive, only the ¼ of the progeny that are bb will have bent wings. Of the ¼ of the progeny that have bent wings, ¼ will also be homozygous for the mutant allele of the VG gene, and thus will also have vestigial wings. In other words, ¼ X ¼ of the progeny will have both bent and vestigial wings. The probability of offspring with bent wings only is therefore: 1/4 - 1/16 = 3/16.

questions.raw_html_question: The primary role of oxygen in cellular respiration is to
questions.question: The primary role of oxygen in cellular respiration is to

options.text: combine with carbon, forming CO2.

questions.raw_html_question:
In the reaction shown below

CH4 + 2 O2 → CO2 + energy + 2 H2O
questions.question: In the reaction shown below  CH4 + 2 O2 → CO2 + energy + 2 H2O

options.text: CH4 and O2 are reduced
CH4 is oxidized and O2 is reduced
CH4 and O2 are oxidized
CH4 is reduced and O2 is oxidized

questions.comments: The substance that is “gaining” an electron, either through the complete transfer of an electron from one atom to another or through a shift in the sharing of a pair of electrons in a covalent bond, has its charge reduced and so is said to have been “reduced”. In contrast, the substance that is (partially or entirely) “losing” an electron will have its charge increased (because electrons are negatively charged), and so is said to have been oxidized. In this example, the oxygen atoms in O2 are neutrally charged (i.e. they are uncharged). The oxygen atoms in H2O have a partial negative charge because oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen, so the electrons that form a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom will spend more of their time closer to the oxygen atom, giving the oxygen atom in a water molecule a partial negative charge. So, in going from O2, to H2O, the oxygen atoms go from uncharged to having a partial negative charge, so their charge is reduced. In the case of the CH4 (i.e. methane) molecule, the carbon atom in this molecule forms covalent bonds with hydrogen atoms. The bonds between the carbon atom and the hydrogen atoms are usually considered to be nonpolar, because carbon is only slightly more electronegative than hydrogen, but the fact that carbon is a bit more electronegative than hydrogen means that the electrons forming those bonds will actually spend just a bit more of their time closer to the carbon atom than to the hydrogen atom. So, the carbon atom in CH4 will be close to neutrally charged (i.e. uncharged) but, if anything, will carry a very slight negative charge. In contrast, in CO2 the covalent bonds between the carbon atom and the oxygen atoms are polar, as oxygen is significantly more electronegative than carbon. Consequently the electrons forming those bonds will spend more of their time near the oxygen atoms than near the carbon atom, leaving the carbon atom with a partial positive charge. So, the carbon atom in CH4 goes from being close to uncharged in CH4 to carrying a partial positive charge in CO2, meaning that the carbon atom is oxidized during this reaction.
questions.raw_html_comments: The substance that is “gaining” an electron, either through the complete transfer of an electron from one atom to another or through a shift in the sharing of a pair of electrons in a covalent bond, has its charge reduced and so is said to have been “reduced”. In contrast, the substance that is (partially or entirely) “losing” an electron will have its charge increased (because electrons are negatively charged), and so is said to have been oxidized. In this example, the oxygen atoms in O2 are neutrally charged (i.e. they are uncharged). The oxygen atoms in H2O have a partial negative charge because oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen, so the electrons that form a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom will spend more of their time closer to the oxygen atom, giving the oxygen atom in a water molecule a partial negative charge. So, in going from O2, to H2O, the oxygen atoms go from uncharged to having a partial negative charge, so their charge is reduced. In the case of the CH4 (i.e. methane) molecule, the carbon atom in this molecule forms covalent bonds with hydrogen atoms. The bonds between the carbon atom and the hydrogen atoms are usually considered to be nonpolar, because carbon is only slightly more electronegative than hydrogen, but the fact that carbon is a bit more electronegative than hydrogen means that the electrons forming those bonds will actually spend just a bit more of their time closer to the carbon atom than to the hydrogen atom. So, the carbon atom in CH4 will be close to neutrally charged (i.e. uncharged) but, if anything, will carry a very slight negative charge. In contrast, in CO2 the covalent bonds between the carbon atom and the oxygen atoms are polar, as oxygen is significantly more electronegative than carbon. Consequently the electrons forming those bonds will spend more of their time near the oxygen atoms than near the carbon atom, leaving the carbon atom with a partial positive charge. So, the carbon atom in CH4 goes from being close to uncharged in CH4 to carrying a partial positive charge in CO2, meaning that the carbon atom is oxidized during this reaction.

questions.raw_html_question:
In the reaction shown below

Na and Cl → Na+ and Cl-
questions.question: In the reaction shown below  Na and Cl → Na+ and Cl-

options.text: Na and Cl are the reducing agents
Na is the reducing agent and Cl is the oxidizing agent
Na is the oxidizing agent and Cl is the reducing agent
Na and Cl are the oxidizing agents

questions.comments: In a redox (reduction-oxidation) reaction, the substance that is partially or entirely giving up one or more electrons is known as the “reducing agent”, because the negatively charged electron that is moving all or part of the way to another atom will reduce the charge on that atom. In contrast, the substance that is partially or entirely acquiring an electron is known as the “oxidizing agent” because the partial or entire removal of an electron from an atom will cause that atom to be oxidized (i.e. have its charged increased). So, in the reaction shown below, the sodium (Na) atom is being oxidized, and is acting as the reducing agent for the chlorine (Cl) atom. Conversely, the chlorine atom is being reduced and is acting as the oxidizing agent for the sodium atom.

questions.raw_html_question: Why is less ATP produced by anaerobic respiration than by aerobic respiration?
questions.question: Why is less ATP produced by anaerobic respiration than by aerobic respiration?

options.text: All of these answers are correct.
Anaerobic respiration does not make use of an electron transport chain.
Anaerobic respiration does not make use of the citric acid cycle.
Anaerobic respiration uses a final electron acceptor that is less electronegative than O2, which is used as the final electron acceptor in aerobic respiration.

questions.comments: Both aerobic and anaerobic respiration make use of glycolysis, the citric acid cycle and an electron transport chain. However, an important difference between aerobic and anaerobic respiration is that O2 is used as the final electron acceptor for the electron transport chain used in aerobic respiration. The electron transport chain used in anaerobic respiration uses something other than O2 as the final electron acceptor (e.g. sulfate). Because O2 is more electronegative than the final electron acceptors used during anaerobic respiration, more energy is released during aerobic respiration than during anaerobic respiration.

questions.comments: "Substrate-level phosphorylation" is one of two mechanisms we have discussed for generating ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate (the other being chemiosmosis, as part of oxidative phosphorylation or photophosphorylation). In substrate-level phosphorylation, a phosphate group is transferred from a substrate molecule (e.g. a phosphorylated food molecule) to ADP (remember that "ADP" stands for "adenine diphosphate", meaning that ADP has two phosphate groups) to ATP (remember that "ATP" stands for "adenine triphosphate", meaning that ATP has three phosphate groups)

questions.question: Phosphofructokinase is an allosteric enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of fructose 6-phosphate to fructose 1,6-bisphosphate, an early step of glycolysis. In the presence of oxygen, an increase in the amount of ATP in a cell would be expected to

options.text: inhibit the enzyme and thus slow the rates of glycolysis and the citric acid cycle.
activate the enzyme and thus slow the rates of glycolysis and the citric acid cycle.
inhibit the enzyme and thus increase the rates of glycolysis and the citric acid cycle.
activate the enzyme and increase the rates of glycolysis and the citric acid cycle.

questions.comments: Remember that respiration is an important part of catabolism (where larger, more complex and energy-rich molecules are broken down to smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules). Catabolic reactions result in the release of free energy. In the case of respiration, some of that free energy is used to do the work of forming ATP. If the cell already has plenty of ATP, there is no need for it to form more. So, cells evolved so that ATP acts as an allosteric inhibitor of many of the enzymes of catalysis. Inhibition of phosphofructokinase by ATP is an example of this phenomenon.

questions.comments: The atoms in O2 are neutrally charged (i.e. they are uncharged). The oxygen atoms in H2O have a partial negative charge because oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen, so the electrons that form the covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom will spend more of their time closer to the oxygen atom, giving the oxygen atom in a water molecule a partial negative charge. So, in going from O2, to H2O, the oxygen atoms go from uncharged to having a partial negative charge, so their charge is reduced. In the case of the C6H12O6 (e.g. glucose) molecule, the carbon atoms in this molecule mostly form covalent bonds to other carbon atoms, to hydrogen atoms and to hydroxyl groups (one carbon atom will also form a double bond to an oxygen atom, forming either a ketone or aldehyde group). The bonds between carbon atoms and hydrogen atoms are usually considered to be nonpolar, because carbon is only slightly more electronegative than hydrogen, but the fact that carbon is a bit more electronegative than hydrogen means that the electrons forming those bonds will spend a bit more of their time closer to the carbon atom than to the hydrogen atom. Hydroxyl groups are somewhat more electronegative than carbon atoms, so the electrons forming the covalent bonds between carbon atoms and hydroxyl groups will spend a bit more of their time near the hydroxyl group. The overall effect will be for the carbon atoms in C6H12O6 to be close to neutrally charged (i.e. uncharged). Consequently the electrons forming these bonds will spend more of their time near the oxygen atoms than near the carbon atom, leaving the carbon atom with a partial positive charge. So, the carbon atoms go from being essentially uncharged in C6H12O6 to carrying a partial positive charge in CO2, meaning that the carbon atoms are oxidized during this reaction.

questions.raw_html_question: The ATP made during fermentation is generated by which of the following?
questions.question: The ATP made during fermentation is generated by which of the following?

options.text: substrate-level phosphorylation
oxidative phosphorylation
aerobic respiration
chemiosmosis

questions.raw_html_question: In the absence of oxygen, yeast cells can obtain energy by fermentation, resulting in the production of
questions.question: In the absence of oxygen, yeast cells can obtain energy by fermentation, resulting in the production of

options.text: ATP, NADH, and pyruvate.
ATP, CO2, and lactate.
ATP, CO2, and ethanol (ethyl alcohol).
ATP, pyruvate, and oxygen.

questions.comments: If a cell is carrying out glycolysis in the absence of sufficient oxygen, the NADH formed during glycolysis must be “re-cycled” back to NAD+so that glycolysis can continue to occur. In cells carrying out anaerobic respiration, recycling of NADH to NAD+ occurs by an electron transport chain that uses a final electron acceptor that is something other than oxygen (e.g. sulfate). In cells carrying out fermentation, the fermentation reaction results in conversion of the NADH formed during glycolysis back to NAD+, so that the reactions of glycolysis can continue to occur. So, there is no net production of NADH in cells carrying out fermentation. Similarly, the pyruvate formed by glycolysis is converted to some other form (typically ethanol or lactate) during fermentation. Whether a cell produces ethanol or lactate or something else via fermentation depends on the cell. Yeast cells undergoing fermentation form ethanol. Muscle cells undergoing fermentation produce lactate (also known as lactic acid).

questions.comments: Remember that electrons have more energy, the further they are from the nucleus. So, when an electron moves closer to the nucleus, that electron loses (releases) energy. Also, remember that when something is “reduced”, what that means is that its charge is reduced. Because electrons are negatively charged, when an atom gains an electron or an electron moves closer to an atom, the atom is “reduced” because it’s charge is reduced.

questions.raw_html_question: When a molecule of NAD<sup>+</sup> (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) gains a hydrogen atom (not a proton), the molecule becomes
questions.question: When a molecule of NAD+ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) gains a hydrogen atom (not a proton), the molecule becomes

options.text: oxidized.
dehydrogenated.
hydrolyzed.
reduced.

questions.comments: The hydrogen atom gained by the NAD+ will include an electron. That electron will participate in forming a covalent bond between hydrogen and NAD+. The second electron needed to form that covalent bond will come from NAD+. Because NAD+ is more electronegative than hydrogen, the pair of electrons forming the covalent bond between NAD+ and hydrogen will spend more of their time near NAD+. As a consequence, NAD+ will have a partial gain in the number of electrons that are near it at any given moment. You can think of this as NAD+ having partially taken the electron from the hydrogen atom, since the electron from the hydrogen atom will spend more time near NAD+ than near the hydrogen. Since NAD+ is partially gaining an electron, and electrons are negatively charged, the charge on the NAD+ molecule will be partially reduced by gaining a hydrogen atom.

So, electrons associated with hydrogen have a lot of potential energy that can be released as those electrons move to more electronegative atoms.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following most accurately describes what happens along the electron transport chain?
questions.question: Which of the following most accurately describes what happens along the electron transport chain?

options.text: Energy of the electrons increases at each step.
Each electron carrier alternates between being reduced and being oxidized.
ATP is generated at each step.
Molecules in the chain give up some of their potential energy.

questions.comments: As one electron after another moves down the electron transport chain, each component of the chain first gains an electron from the preceding component and then gives up that electron (or electrons) to the following component. So, each electron carrier alternates between acquiring electron(s) and donating electrons, so that each electron carrier alternates between being reduced (when it gains electrons) and being oxidized (when it gives up electrons). Note that ATP is not generated at any of the steps of the electron transport chain. Instead, some of the energy released as electrons move to progressively more electronegative carriers is used to form a proton gradient. During chemiosmosis, the energy stored in this proton gradient is used to “drive” ATP synthesis by ATP synthase. Also note that, as electrons move to progressively more electronegative carriers, the energy of the electrons is DECREASING (with some of that released energy being used to form the proton gradient). Molecules in the electron transport chain aren’t really giving up some of their potential energy, as their potential energy is cycling up and down as they acquire and then donate electrons.
questions.raw_html_comments: As one electron after another moves down the electron transport chain, each component of the chain first gains an electron from the preceding component and then gives up that electron (or electrons) to the following component. So, each electron carrier alternates between acquiring electron(s) and donating electrons, so that each electron carrier alternates between being reduced (when it gains electrons) and being oxidized (when it gives up electrons). Note that ATP is not generated at any of the steps of the electron transport chain. Instead, some of the energy released as electrons move to progressively more electronegative carriers is used to form a proton gradient. During chemiosmosis, the energy stored in this proton gradient is used to “drive” ATP synthesis by ATP synthase. Also note that, as electrons move to progressively more electronegative carriers, the energy of the electrons is DECREASING (with some of that released energy being used to form the proton gradient). Molecules in the electron transport chain aren’t really giving up some of their potential energy, as their potential energy is cycling up and down as they acquire and then donate electrons.

questions.raw_html_question: The molecule that functions as the reducing agent in a redox (or oxidation-reduction) reaction
questions.question: The molecule that functions as the reducing agent in a redox (or oxidation-reduction) reaction

options.text: loses electrons and loses energy
gains electrons and loses energy
gains electrons and gains energy
loses electrons and gains energy

questions.comments: Reducing agents are agents that “reduce” the charge on another atom or molecule. Because electrons are negatively charged, that means that reducing agents transfer electrons (partially or entirely) to other atoms or molecules, which are then reduced. The transfer of electrons from a less electronegative substance to a more electronegative substance is energetically favorable, meaning that the products of the reaction have less energy than the reactants. This is because the molecule or atom that loses an electron loses some of its potential energy. The atom or molecule that gains that electron experiences an increase in its potential energy, but the increase in potential energy of the substance being reduced (i.e. receiving the electron) is of a smaller magnitude than the decrease in potential energy of the substance being oxidized (i.e. giving up the electron).

These little vesicles that result can still transfer electrons from NADH to oxygen and synthesize ATP.  These inside-out membrane vesicles

These little vesicles that result can still transfer electrons from NADH to oxygen and synthesize ATP.  These inside-out membrane vesicles

will hydrolyze ATP to pump protons out of the interior of the vesicle to the exterior.

questions.comments: Because the vesicles are “inside out”, movement of electrons from NADH, through the electron transport chain to oxygen will result in protons being moved from outside of the vesicles to inside of the vesicle. So, the inside of the vesicles will become acidic.

questions.raw_html_question: When an electron moves from one molecule to another molecule that is more electronegative than the first molecule,
questions.question: When an electron moves from one molecule to another molecule that is more electronegative than the first molecule,

options.text: an endergonic reaction has occurred
some of the potential energy that is given up by the electron is lost as heat
all of the potential energy that is given up by the electron may be used to do work
work must be done on the system to allow the electron to move

questions.comments: When an electron moves to a molecule that is more electronegative, that is an energetically favorable (i.e. exergonic, or spontaneous) reaction that results in a release of energy. Whenever energy is transferred or transformed, some of the energy is converted to energy that can no longer be used to do work. So, according to the second law of thermodynamics, it is never possible to use 100% of the energy released during a reaction to do work.

questions.raw_html_question: During cellular respiration, what is the direction of energy flow?
questions.question: During cellular respiration, what is the direction of energy flow?

options.text: Chemical bonds in food – to NADH – to chemical bonds in ATP – to a proton gradient
Chemical bonds in food – to a proton gradient – to NADH – to chemical bonds in ATP
Chemical bonds in food – to a proton gradient – to chemical bonds in ATP – to NADH
Chemical bonds in food – to NADH – to a proton gradient – to chemical bonds in ATP

questions.comments: During glycolysis and the citric acid cycle, some of the energy from the food molecule being catabolized is used to form NADH (and FADH2, which is similar to NADH). During the electron transport phase of oxidative phosphorylation, some of the energy stored in NADH and FADH2 is used to form a proton gradient. During the chemiosmotic phase of oxidative phosphorylation, some of the potential energy stored in the proton gradient is used by ATP synthase to form ATP.

questions.raw_html_question: In prokaryotes, the respiratory electron transport chain is located
questions.question: In prokaryotes, the respiratory electron transport chain is located

options.text: in the cytoplasm.
in the mitochondrial outer membrane.
in the mitochondrial inner membrane.
in the plasma membrane.

questions.comments: Prokaryotes (with a very few exceptions) lack membrane-bound organelles, which include mitochondria. So, you should realize that prokaryotes cannot carry out electron transport in mitochondria, as they lack mitochondria. In order for the electron transport chain to do the work of generating a proton (H+) gradient, the electron has to be located in a membrane (i.e. the components of the electron transport chain need to move protons across a membrane, as the proton gradient needs to be across a membrane). The only membrane available in the vast majority of prokaryotes is the plasma membrane.

questions.raw_html_question: Substrate-level phosphorylation accounts for approximately what percentage of the ATP formed directly by the reactions of glycolysis?
questions.question: Substrate-level phosphorylation accounts for approximately what percentage of the ATP formed directly by the reactions of glycolysis?
questions.comments: All of the ATP formed during glycolysis and the citric acid cycle is formed by substrate-level phosphorylation. Remember that substrate-level phosphorylation refers to the transfer of a phosphate from one molecule (the “substrate”) to ADP, to form ATP. In contrast, all of the ATP formed during oxidative phosphorylation is formed by chemiosmotic phosphorylation, where ATP synthase uses energy from a proton gradient to form ATP from ADP and phosphate.

questions.raw_html_question: Drugs known as uncouplers facilitate diffusion of protons across the membrane.  When such a drug is added, what will happen to ATP synthesis and oxygen consumption, if the rates of glycolysis and the citric acid cycle stay the same?
questions.question: Drugs known as uncouplers facilitate diffusion of protons across the membrane.  When such a drug is added, what will happen to ATP synthesis and oxygen consumption, if the rates of glycolysis and the citric acid cycle stay the same?

options.text: Both ATP synthesis and oxygen consumption will increase
ATP synthesis will decrease; oxygen consumption will stay the same
Both ATP synthesis and oxygen consumption will decrease
ATP synthesis will increase; oxygen consumption will decrease

questions.comments: Uncouplers will allow protons to move down their electrochemical gradient without “powering” ATP synthase. As a result, less ATP will be produced. IF (as stated in the question) the rates of glycolysis and the citric acid cycle stay the same, oxygen consumption will also remain the same as the rate of oxygen consumption is dependent on the rate of electron transport from NADH and FADH2, down the electron transport chain, to oxygen.

questions.raw_html_question: If your muscles used alcohol fermentation instead of lactic acid fermentation, which of the following might occur?
questions.question: If your muscles used alcohol fermentation instead of lactic acid fermentation, which of the following might occur?

options.text: Your cells would make more ATP under anaerobic conditions.
Your cells would recycle less NADH to NAD+ in anaerobic conditions.
Your cells would not make ATP under anaerobic conditions.
You might become drunk during an intense workout.

questions.comments: During intense workouts, your body cannot supply oxygen quickly enough to some of your muscle cells and so those muscle cells have to generate ATP by glycolysis combined with fermentation. The type of fermentation normally carried out by muscle cells is lactic acid fermentation, meaning that the pyruvate produced from glucose by glycolysis is converted to lactic acid, while NADH is converted to NAD+. If your body used alcohol fermentation instead of lactic acid fermentation, your muscle cells would produce alcohol instead of lactic acid when they weren’t getting enough oxygen.

ATP synthase will hydrolyze ATP and pump protons into the matrix.

questions.comments: This is not something we discussed in class, but I included this question to make the point that ATP synthase catalyzes the following reaction in BOTH directions: ADP + Pi → ATP and ATP → ADP + PiSo, if there is already a lot of ATP in the matrix, and the proton gradient is low, ATP synthase will catalyze the process that is the reverse of what we discussed in class. In other words, instead of using the energy from protons moving down their electrochemical gradient to produce ATP, it will use ATP to move protons UP their electrochemical gradient.

questions.raw_html_question:
What is the oxidizing agent in the following reaction?
Pyruvate + NADH + H+ → Lactate + NAD+
questions.question: What is the oxidizing agent in the following reaction? Pyruvate + NADH + H+ → Lactate + NAD+

options.text: NADH
pyruvate
NAD+
lactate

questions.comments: In the reaction above, you can most easily see that NADH is being oxidized as it is converted to positiviely charged NAD+, so it's clear its charge increases. If NADH is being oxidized, the electrons it is losing must be going somewhere. Looking at the reaction, the only place they can be going is to pyruvate and H+, as they combine to form lactate. So, pyruvate must be taking electrons from NADH, meaning that pyruvate must be oxidizing NADH.

questions.raw_html_question: A molecule that is phosphorylated
questions.question: A molecule that is phosphorylated

options.text: has an increased chemical reactivity, it is primed to do cellular work.
has a decreased chemical reactivity, it is less likely to provide energy for cellular work.
is unchanged in its capacity to do cellular work.
has less energy than before its phosphorylation and therefore less energy for cellular work.

questions.comments: The chemical bond between a phosphate group and the rest of the molecule to which the phosphate group is attached is generally a high-energy bond. When a molecule is “phosphorylated”, that means the molecule has gained a phosphate group. So, a phosphorylated molecule has gained a high-energy bond. The presence of that high-energy bond increases the amount of potential energy stored within the phosphorylated molecule, giving the phosphorylated molecule an increased capacity to do work (by using up its increased amount of potential energy).
