questions.raw_html_question: When a glucose molecule loses a hydrogen atom as the result of an oxidation-reduction reaction, the molecule becomes
questions.question: When a glucose molecule loses a hydrogen atom as the result of an oxidation-reduction reaction, the molecule becomes

options.text: reduced.
hydrogenated.
hydrolyzed.
oxidized.

questions.comments: Note that the question says that the glucose molecule is losing a hydrogen atom, not a hydrogen ion. So, the glucose molecule is losing the electron associated with the hydrogen atom. Because hydrogen is the least electronegative of the elements we’ve discussed, when hydrogen forms a covalent bond with an atom of one of the other elements we’ve discussed, the pair of electrons forming that bond will spend more of their time nearer the atom to which the hydrogen atom is attached. When the covalent bond between the other atom and hydrogen is broken in such a way that the nucleus of the hydrogen atom and its electron are removed, the atom to which the hydrogen was attached now has sole possession of one of the two electrons that formed the covalent bond, but has completely lost any share of possession of the electron that went with the hydrogen atom. So, overall, the atom to which the hydrogen was attached has fewer electrons in close proximity after the hydrogen atom leaves than before. For example, consider a covalent bond formed between two atoms of “X”:X : XNote that the pair of electrons that forms the covalent bond (represented by the colon in this example) are equally close to each atom of X. So, the atoms are sharing these two electrons equally. So, each X atom has ½ of each of the two electrons, or the equivalent of exactly one electron from the pair.Now consider a bond between “X” and hydrogen, where “X” is more electronegative than hydrogen: X : HNote that the pair of electrons that forms the covalent bond (represented by the colon in this example) are closer to X than to the hydrogen atom. So, if each of the two electrons that form the covalent bond between X and hydrogen spend 60% of their time close to X and 40% close to the hydrogen, than that is like X having possession of 1.2 electrons and hydrogen having possession of 0.8 electrons. If the hydrogen atom leaves the XH molecule, you are left with:X .In other words, X now has possession of 1 electron from the 2 that were forming the bond between X and hydrogen. So, in terms of the bond between X and hydrogen, X went from having the equivalent of 1.2 electrons to having just one. That means X was oxidized when it lost the hydrogen atom. Because hydrogen is the least electronegative of the elements we’ve discussed, whenever a molecule loses a hydrogen atom (hydrogen ATOM, not hydrogen ION), that molecule will have been oxidized. One final point: Although hydrogen is the least electronegative element we’ve discussed, remember that covalent bonds between carbon and hydrogen are still classified as being nonpolar covalent bonds (even though they aren’t 100% nonpolar), because carbon isn’t that much more electronegative than hydrogen.

Note that the question says that the glucose molecule is losing a hydrogen atom, not a hydrogen ion. So, the glucose molecule is losing the electron associated with the hydrogen atom. Because hydrogen is the least electronegative of the elements we’ve discussed, when hydrogen forms a covalent bond with an atom of one of the other elements we’ve discussed, the pair of electrons forming that bond will spend more of their time nearer the atom to which the hydrogen atom is attached. When the covalent bond between the other atom and hydrogen is broken in such a way that the nucleus of the hydrogen atom and its electron are removed, the atom to which the hydrogen was attached now has sole possession of one of the two electrons that formed the covalent bond, but has completely lost any share of possession of the electron that went with the hydrogen atom. So, overall, the atom to which the hydrogen was attached has fewer electrons in close proximity after the hydrogen atom leaves than before.

For example, consider a covalent bond formed between two atoms of “X”:
X : X
Note that the pair of electrons that forms the covalent bond (represented by the colon in this example) are equally close to each atom of X. So, the atoms are sharing these two electrons equally. So, each X atom has ½ of each of the two electrons, or the equivalent of exactly one electron from the pair.
Now consider a bond between “X” and hydrogen, where “X” is more electronegative than hydrogen:
X : H
Note that the pair of electrons that forms the covalent bond (represented by the colon in this example) are closer to X than to the hydrogen atom. So, if each of the two electrons that form the covalent bond between X and hydrogen spend 60% of their time close to X and 40% close to the hydrogen, than that is like X having possession of 1.2 electrons and hydrogen having possession of 0.8 electrons.
If the hydrogen atom leaves the XH molecule, you are left with:
X .
In other words, X now has possession of 1 electron from the 2 that were forming the bond between X and hydrogen. So, in terms of the bond between X and hydrogen, X went from having the equivalent of 1.2 electrons to having just one. That means X was oxidized when it lost the hydrogen atom. Because hydrogen is the least electronegative of the elements we’ve discussed, whenever a molecule loses a hydrogen atom (hydrogen ATOM, not hydrogen ION), that molecule will have been oxidized.

One final point: Although hydrogen is the least electronegative element we’ve discussed, remember that covalent bonds between carbon and hydrogen are still classified as being nonpolar covalent bonds (even though they aren’t 100% nonpolar), because carbon isn’t that much more electronegative than hydrogen.

questions.raw_html_question: Brown fat cells produce a protein called thermogenin in their mitochondrial inner membrane. Thermogenin is a channel for facilitated transport of protons across the membrane. What will occur in the brown fat cells when they produce thermogenin?
questions.question: Brown fat cells produce a protein called thermogenin in their mitochondrial inner membrane. Thermogenin is a channel for facilitated transport of protons across the membrane. What will occur in the brown fat cells when they produce thermogenin?

options.text: ATP synthesis and heat generation will both decrease.
ATP synthesis will increase, and heat generation will decrease.
ATP synthesis will decrease, and heat generation will increase.
ATP synthesis and heat generation will both increase.

questions.comments: Thermogenin will allow protons to move down their electrochemical gradient without moving through, and thus “powering”, ATP synthase. As a result, less ATP will be produced. Heat generation will increase because cells will increase their rate of respiration, in an attempt to produce a sufficient amount of ATP. Because much of the energy released from food molecules during respiration is turned into heat, this increased rate of respiration will result in increased heat production.

questions.comments: The substance that is “gaining” an electron, either through the complete transfer of an electron from one atom to another or through a shift in the sharing of a pair of electrons in a covalent bond, has its charge reduced and so is said to have been reduced. In contrast, the substance that is “losing” an electron will have its charge increased (because electrons are negatively charged), and so is said to have been oxidized. In this example, sodium (Na) transferred an electron to chlorine (Cl), so the sodium atom was oxidized (its charge increased because it lost a negatively charged electron) and the chlorine atom was reduced (its charge was reduced because it gained a negatively charged electron).

questions.raw_html_question: When an electron moves from one molecule to another molecule that is more electronegative
questions.question: When an electron moves from one molecule to another molecule that is more electronegative

options.text: the electron gains potential energy
the electron loses potential energy
the electron loses kinetic energy
the electron gains kinetic energy

questions.comments: Kinetic energy is energy due to movement. Potential energy is energy that is stored in an object that is not due to movement. The energy an electron has as a result of its position in or near different molecules to which it is attracted is potential energy. Molecules that are more electronegative attract electrons more strongly. So, electrons lose potential energy when they move closer to more electronegative molecules. This is similar to an object losing gravitational potential energy when it moves closer to objects of high mass.

questions.raw_html_question: When skeletal muscle cells continue to do work under conditions of insufficient oxygen (e.g. anaerobic exercise), they become fatigued and painful. This is now known to be caused by
questions.question: When skeletal muscle cells continue to do work under conditions of insufficient oxygen (e.g. anaerobic exercise), they become fatigued and painful. This is now known to be caused by

options.text: buildup of pyruvate.
increase in ethanol.
increase in sodium ions.
buildup of lactate.

questions.comments: When you are exercising really hard, your body may not be able to supply oxygen to some of your muscles quickly enough for the cells in those muscles to carry out aerobic respiration. In that case, those muscle cells will still carry out glycolysis. The NADH produced by glycolysis will not be able to be converted back to NAD+ by oxidative phosphorylation, due to the lack of oxygen. So, NADH needs to be converted back to NAD+ by a different process, namely fermentation. In fermentation, the pyruvate produced during glycolysis is converted to another molecular form, lactate (also called lactic acid) in the case of muscle cells and ethanol in the case of yeast cells (think beer!). The build up of lactic acid in your muscles is part of what causes them to become sore. Fermentation also results in NAD+ being converted back to NADH.

The build up of lactic acid in your muscles is part of what causes them to become sore. Fermentation also results in NAD+ being converted back to NADH.

questions.raw_html_question:
In the reaction shown below

C6H12O6 + 6 O2 → 6 CO2 + energy + 6 H2O
questions.question: In the reaction shown below  C6H12O6 + 6 O2 → 6 CO2 + energy + 6 H2O

options.text: C6H12O6 and O2 are oxidized
C6H12O6 is reduced and O2 is oxidized
C6H12O6 is oxidized and O2 is reduced
C6H12O6 and O2 are reduced

questions.comments: The substance that is “gaining” an electron, either through the complete transfer of an electron from one atom to another or through a shift in the sharing of a pair of electrons in a covalent bond, has its charge reduced and so is said to have been “reduced”. In contrast, the substance that is (partially or entirely) “losing” an electron will have its charge increased (because electrons are negatively charged), and so is said to have been oxidized. In this example, the oxygen atoms in O2are neutrally charged (i.e. they are uncharged). The oxygen atoms in H2O have a partial negative charge because oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen, so the electrons that form a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom will spend more of their time closer to the oxygen atom, giving the oxygen atom in a water molecule a partial negative charge. So, in going from O2, to H2O, the oxygen atoms go from uncharged to having a partial negative charge, so their charge is reduced. In the case of the C6H12O6 (e.g. glucose) molecule, the carbon atoms in this molecule mostly form covalent bonds to other carbon atoms, to hydrogen atoms and to hydroxyl groups (one carbon atom will also form a double bond to an oxygen atom, forming either a ketone or aldehyde group). The bonds between two carbon atoms are nonpolar. The bonds between carbon atoms and hydrogen atoms are usually considered to be nonpolar, because carbon is only slightly more electronegative than hydrogen, but the fact that carbon is a bit more electronegative than hydrogen means that the electrons forming those bonds will spend a bit more of their time closer to the carbon atom than to the hydrogen atom. Hydroxyl groups are somewhat more electronegative than carbon atoms, so the electrons forming the covalent bonds between carbon atoms and hydroxyl groups will spend a bit more of their time near the hydroxyl group. The overall effect will be for the carbon atoms in C6H12O6 to be close to neutrally charged (i.e. uncharged). In contrast, in CO2 the covalent bonds between the carbon atom and the oxygen atoms are polar, as oxygen is significantly more electronegative than carbon. Consequently the electrons forming these bonds will spend more of their time near the oxygen atoms than near the carbon atom, leaving the carbon atom with a partial positive charge. So, the carbon atoms go from being essentially uncharged in C6H12O6 to carrying a partial positive charge in CO2, meaning that the carbon atoms are oxidized during this reaction.

So, in going from O2, to H2O, the oxygen atoms go from uncharged to having a partial negative charge, so their charge is reduced.

questions.raw_html_question: It is possible to prepare vesicles from portions of the inner mitochondrial membrane. Which one of the following processes could still be carried on by this isolated inner membrane?
questions.question: It is possible to prepare vesicles from portions of the inner mitochondrial membrane. Which one of the following processes could still be carried on by this isolated inner membrane?

options.text: oxidative phosphorylation
reduction of NAD+
both the citric acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation
glycolysis and fermentation

questions.comments: Glycolysis occurs in the cytosol and the citric acid cycle occurs in the matrix of the mitochondria, so the proteins that carry out these processes would not be present in vesicles made from the inner membrane of the mitochondria (the proteins present in the matrix would "float away" as the membranes were broken open, pieces of them turned inside out, and then re-sealed). In contrast, such vesicles would have all the components necessary for oxidative phosphorylation, since these components are all part of the inner membrane of the mitochondrion.

questions.raw_html_question: The transport of pyruvate into mitochondria depends on the proton-motive force across the inner mitochondrial membrane. How does pyruvate enter the mitochondrion?
questions.question: The transport of pyruvate into mitochondria depends on the proton-motive force across the inner mitochondrial membrane. How does pyruvate enter the mitochondrion?

options.text: diffusion
facilitated diffusion
active transport
through a channel

questions.comments: Pyruvate is being transported into the mitochondria, up its concentration gradient. Whenever a substance is transported up its electrochemical gradient, energy is required to drive the process. In this example, that energy is provided by the proton gradient. Transport processes which require an energy source to occur are forms of active transport. In contrast, all types of diffusion processes are examples of passive transport, which do not require energy to occur because in all types of diffusion the substance that is moving is moving down its electrochemical gradient.

questions.raw_html_question: In vertebrate animals, brown fat tissue's color is due to abundant blood vessels and capillaries. White fat tissue, on the other hand, is specialized for fat storage and contains relatively few blood vessels or capillaries. Brown fat cells have a specialized protein that dissipates the proton-motive force across the mitochondrial membranes. Which of the following might be the function of the brown fat tissue?
questions.question: In vertebrate animals, brown fat tissue's color is due to abundant blood vessels and capillaries. White fat tissue, on the other hand, is specialized for fat storage and contains relatively few blood vessels or capillaries. Brown fat cells have a specialized protein that dissipates the proton-motive force across the mitochondrial membranes. Which of the following might be the function of the brown fat tissue?

options.text: to regulate temperature by converting most of the energy from NADH oxidation to heat
to allow other membranes of the cell to perform mitochondrial functions
to allow the animals to regulate their metabolic rate when it is especially hot
to increase the production of ATP

questions.comments: The protein in brown fat that dissipates proton-motive force is doing so by allowing protons to move down their electrochemical gradient without passing through, and thus powering, ATP synthase. As a result, much of the proton gradient, and the potential energy stored in the proton gradient (i.e. the “proton-motive force”), will be lost without “powering” ATP synthase. As a result, less ATP will be produced. Heat generation will increase because cells will increase their rate of respiration, in an attempt to produce a sufficient amount of ATP. Because much of the energy released from food molecules during respiration is turned into heat, this increased rate of respiration will result in increased heat production.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following occur in both aerobic and anaerobic respiration?
questions.question: Which of the following occur in both aerobic and anaerobic respiration?

options.text: an electron transport chain
citric acid cycle
glycolysis
all of these answers are correct

questions.comments: Glycolysis, the citric acid cycle and an electron transport chain all occur during both aerobic and anaerobic respiration. The primary difference between aerobic and anaerobic respiration is that the electron transport chain used during aerobic respiration uses O2 as the final electron acceptor, whereas the electron transport chain used during anaerobic respiration uses something other than O2 (e.g. sulfate) as the final electron acceptor.

questions.raw_html_question: One function of both alcohol fermentation and lactic acid fermentation is to
questions.question: One function of both alcohol fermentation and lactic acid fermentation is to

options.text: reduce NAD+to NADH.
oxidize NADH to NAD+.
reduce FAD+to FADH2.
reduce FADH2to FAD+.

questions.comments: Fermentation is necessary to “re-cycle” the NADH formed during glycolysis to NAD+ so that the reactions of glycolysis can continue.In other words, during glycolysis, NAD+ is converted to NADH. In order for glycolysis to continue, cells need a continuous supply of NAD+. During aerobic respiration, that supply of NAD+ is provided by oxidation of NADH via the electron transport chain. If that isn't possible (e.g. due to oxygen levels being too low), some cells will produce NAD+ from NADH via the reactions of fermentation.

During aerobic respiration, that supply of NAD+ is provided by oxidation of NADH via the electron transport chain. If that isn't possible (e.g. due to oxygen levels being too low), some cells will produce NAD+ from NADH via the reactions of fermentation.

questions.raw_html_question: When an electron moves from
questions.question: When an electron moves from

options.text: the first to the second subunit of the electron transport chain, energy is released that can be used to do work
all of these statements are true
the second to the third subunit of the electron transport chain, energy is released that can be used to do work
NADH to the first subunit of the electron transport chain, energy is released that can be used to do work

questions.comments: Energy is released whenever an electron moves to a more electronegative atom or molecule. Within the electron transport chain, NADH is the least electronegative, the first subunit of the electron transport chain is a bit more electronegative than NADH, the 2nd subunit is a bit more electronegative than the 1st subunit, and so on down the chain until you get to molecules oxygen (O2), which is very electronegative. So, as electrons leave NADH and travel down the electron transport chain to O2, the electrons are moving to progressively more electronegative substances. And, energy is released during each of these electron transfers.

So, as electrons leave NADH and travel down the electron transport chain to O2, the electrons are moving to progressively more electronegative substances. And, energy is released during each of these electron transfers.

questions.comments: These yeast cells will be worthless for producing beer. Also, because they will not be able to regenerate NAD+ from NADH, they won’t be able to produce any energy from glycolysis (or any other process) in the absence of oxygen. So, these mutant yeast cells will only be able to grow aerobically (i.e. in the presence of oxygen).

questions.raw_html_question: Where would you expect the genes that encode the components of the photosynthetic machinery to be located?

questions.comments: Chloroplasts are believed to have evolved from photosynthetic bacteria that survived phagocytosis (i.e. being engulfed) by another cell. So, chloroplasts have their own DNA and the mechanisms needed to transcribe that DNA to form RNA and to translate that RNA to form proteints. Originally, all the genes necessary for a chloroplast functioning were on DNA in the chloroplast. Over the course of evolution, some of those genes have moved to the nucleus and become part of the nuclear DNA. So, some of the genes that are responsible for making components of the photosynthetic machinery are located in the nuclear DNA and some are located in the chloroplast DNA.

options.text: facilitated diffusion
transport via channel proteins
transport via carrier proteins
active transport

questions.comments: During electron transport, hydrogen ions are moved UP their electrochemical gradient. Because this is an energetically unfavorable process, it will require an energy input to occur and thus is an example of active transport. Also, remember that all forms of diffusion are passive processes, and that this includes transport via channel proteins and via carrier proteins, which are both examples of facilitated diffusion.

questions.comments: Remember that “reducing agents” act by donating electrons to another substance, causing the charge on that substance to be REDUCED (and hence the name “reducing agent”). questions.raw_html_question:
A spaceship is designed to support animal life for a multiyear voyage to the outer planets of the solar system. Plants will be grown to provide oxygen and to recycle carbon dioxide.
If the power fails and the lights go dark, what will happen to CO2 levels?
questions.question: A spaceship is designed to support animal life for a multiyear voyage to the outer planets of the solar system. Plants will be grown to provide oxygen and to recycle carbon dioxide. If the power fails and the lights go dark, what will happen to CO2 levels?

options.text: CO2will fall because plants will cease to respire in the dark.
CO2will rise as a result of animal respiration only.
CO2will rise as a result of both animal and plant respiration.
CO2will remain balanced because plants will continue to fix CO2in the dark.

questions.comments: If the lights go dark, the plants will be able to continue to carry out the dark reactions of photosynthesis (i.e. the Calvin cycle) for just a little while because the reactions of the Calvin cycle require NADPH and ATP, which are produced during the light reactions of photosynthesis. So, after just a short time the plants will stop carrying out all of the reactions of photosynthesis, including using CO2 to make sugars. So, the plants will no longer be using up CO2. Plants, as well as animals, need to carry out respiration to generate ATP and NADH for use in many cellular processes. So, both plants and animals (people!) on board the ship will continue to generate CO2 through respiration. So, CO2 levels on the ship will rise as a result of respiration by both plants and animals.

questions.raw_html_question: When a pigment molecule in a light-harvesting complex absorbs the energy from a photon of light, an electron in the pigment molecule becomes “excited”.  What does this mean?
questions.question: When a pigment molecule in a light-harvesting complex absorbs the energy from a photon of light, an electron in the pigment molecule becomes “excited”.  What does this mean?

options.text: The electron has achieved a higher-energy state, meaning that it is located closer to the nucleus.
The electron has acquired a greater charge.
The electron has achieved a higher-energy state, meaning that it is located further from the nucleus.
The electron has acquired greater speed, meaning greater kinetic energy.

questions.comments: Remember that electrons have more potential energy the further they are from the nucleus. This is similar to objects having greater gravitational potential energy the further they are from the ground.
questions.raw_html_comments: Remember that electrons have more potential energy the further they are from the nucleus. This is similar to objects having greater gravitational potential energy the further they are from the ground.

questions.raw_html_question: During the process of photosynthesis,
questions.question: During the process of photosynthesis,

options.text: less than 100% of the energy captured from sunlight is transformed into potential energy in the form of covalent bonds and then into potential energy in the form of a hydrogen ion gradient
100% of the energy captured from sunlight is transformed into potential energy in the form of a hydrogen ion gradient and then into potential energy in the form of covalent bonds
less than 100% of the energy captured from sunlight is transformed into potential energy in the form of a hydrogen ion gradient and then into potential energy in the form of covalent bonds
100% of the energy captured from sunlight is transformed into potential energy in the form of covalent bonds and then into potential energy in the form of a hydrogen ion gradient

questions.comments: First, realize that transferring 100% of the energy from sunlight to any form of energy that can be used to do work (i.e. the potential energy stored in a hydrogen ion gradient or in covalent bonds) would be a violation of the second law of thermodynamics, which states that in any energy transfer some of the energy is used to increase entropy and that the energy that goes towards increasing entropy can no longer be used to do work. So, less than 100% of the energy from light may be transferred to a form of energy that can do work. Next, realize that energy from light is used to form a hydrogen ion gradient and that energy from that hydrogen ion gradient is then used to drive synthesis of ATP (which has a lot of energy stored in its covalent bonds). So, some of the energy from light is used to form a hydrogen ion gradient and some of the energy from the hydrogen ion gradient is transferred to potential energy in the covalent bonds of ATP molecules.

questions.raw_html_question: Besides CO<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O, to produce sugars through the reactions of the Calvin cycle cells also require
questions.question: Besides CO2 and H2O, to produce sugars through the reactions of the Calvin cycle cells also require

options.text: ATP as an energy source to “drive” the otherwise endergonic reaction and NADPH as a reducing agent.
ATP as an energy source to “drive” the otherwise endergonic reaction and NADPH as an oxidizing agent.
ATP as an energy source to “drive” the otherwise exergonic reaction and NADPH as a reducing agent.
ATP as an energy source to “drive” the otherwise exergonic reaction and NADPH as an oxidizing agent.

questions.comments: To remember the difference between “endergonic” and “exergonic”, focus on the first part of each word. With endergonic, think of energy entering the system as the free energies of the products are greater than the free energies of the reactants. With exergonic, think of energy exiting the system as the free energies of the products are less than the free energies of the reactants. Because the reactions of photosynthesis are endergonic (there is more free energy stored in the sugar molecules produced via photosynthesis than in the CO2 and H2O molecules from which they are made), they require a source of free energy (light energy) to occur. Also, remember that “reducing agents” act by donating electrons to another substance, causing the charge on that substance to be REDUCED (and hence the name “reducing agent”). Oxidizing agents do the opposite. Namely they remove electrons from another substance, causing the charge on that substance to increase. The carbon in CO2 is reduced as that carbon is used to form sugar molecules.

questions.comments: Remember that electrons are transferred from water to photosystem II, and then to photosystem I. In other words, photosystem II functions before photosystem I. The reason the photosystems are numbered as they are is because of the order in which they were discovered, not the order in which they act in photosynthesis. Also remember that the electrons that are transported during the light reactions end up transferred at the end of the light reactions to NADP+ to form NADPH. That NADPH then acts as an electron donor during the reactions of the Calvin cycle.

questions.raw_html_question: During the metabolic processes of cell respiration and photosynthesis, the complexes that are components of the electron transport chain

options.text: act as reducing agents
act as oxidizing agents
both oxidize and reduce during electron transport
donate electrons

questions.comments: A component of an electron transport chain will first receive an electron from the component immediately preceding it (i.e. the component that is slightly less electronegative), and will then pass that electron on to the next component in the chain (i.e. the component that is slightly more electronegative than it). So, each component of an electron transport chain alternates between receiving and donating electrons, and thus between acting as an oxidizing agent (when it receives an electron) and a reducing agent (when it donates an electron, causing the substance to which the electron was donated to have a REDUCED charge).
questions.raw_html_comments: A component of an electron transport chain will first receive an electron from the component immediately preceding it (i.e. the component that is slightly less electronegative), and will then pass that electron on to the next component in the chain (i.e. the component that is slightly more electronegative than it). So, each component of an electron transport chain alternates between receiving and donating electrons, and thus between acting as an oxidizing agent (when it receives an electron) and a reducing agent (when it donates an electron, causing the substance to which the electron was donated to have a REDUCED charge).

questions.raw_html_question: The enzyme (ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase oxygenase, or “Rubisco”) that attaches CO<sub>2</sub> to a 5-carbon long sugar to form a 6-carbon long molecule,
questions.question: The enzyme (ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase oxygenase, or “Rubisco”) that attaches CO2 to a 5-carbon long sugar to form a 6-carbon long molecule,

questions.comments: RUBISCO is an extremely slow enzyme, catalyzing only about 3 reactions per second. So, a lot of molecules of RUBISCO are needed to get the job of fixing sufficient amounts of carbon dioxide done. RUBISCO does not use energy from ATP. Also remember that RUBISCO, like all enzymes, does not convert endergonic reactions to exergonic reactions, nor does it cause reactions to be spontaneous (i.e. to have a negative ∆G).

So, a lot of molecules of RUBISCO are needed to get the job of fixing sufficient amounts of carbon dioxide done. RUBISCO does not use energy from ATP. Also remember that RUBISCO, like all enzymes, does not convert endergonic reactions to exergonic reactions, nor does it cause reactions to be spontaneous (i.e. to have a negative ∆G).

questions.raw_html_question: Suppose the interior of the thylakoids of isolated chloroplasts were made acidic and then transferred in the dark to a pH 8 solution. What would be likely to happen?
questions.question: Suppose the interior of the thylakoids of isolated chloroplasts were made acidic and then transferred in the dark to a pH 8 solution. What would be likely to happen?

options.text: The isolated chloroplasts will generate oxygen gas.
The isolated chloroplasts will make ATP.
The Calvin cycle will be activated.
Cyclic photophosphorylation will occur.

questions.comments: During the light reactions of photosynthesis, a proton gradient is formed across the thylakoid membrane such that there is a higher concentration of protons (and thus a lower pH) inside the interior of the thylakoid than outside of it, in the stroma. The treatment described above would mimic this, as it would cause there to be a higher concentration of protons inside of the thylakoids than in the stroma. Consequently, ATP synthase would be able to use energy from this proton gradient to synthesize ATP.

questions.comments: The pigment molecules in the light-harvesting complexes absorb energy from a photon of light, causing one of their electrons of become “excited” (i.e. achieve a higher-energy state, meaning that the electron is further from the nucleus). Energy is then transferred via “resonance energy transfer” from one pigment molecule to another, until it reaches one of two special chlorophyll a molecules in the reaction-center complex.

questions.raw_html_question: Reduction of NADP<sup>+</sup> occurs during

questions.comments: Reduction of NADP+ to form NADPH occurs during the light reactions of photosynthesis. NADPH is then oxidized to form NADP+ during the Calvin cycle. In contrast, NAD+ is reduced to form NADH during the first two parts of respiration (glycolysis and the citric acid cycle) and the NADH is then oxidized to re-form NAD+ during the third, and last, phase of respiration (oxidative phosphorylation).

questions.raw_html_question: A flask containing photosynthetic green algae and a control flask containing water with no algae are both placed under a bank of lights, which are set to cycle between 12 hours of light and 12 hours of dark. The dissolved oxygen concentrations in both flasks are monitored. Predict what the relative dissolved oxygen concentrations will be in the flask with algae compared to the control flask.
questions.question: A flask containing photosynthetic green algae and a control flask containing water with no algae are both placed under a bank of lights, which are set to cycle between 12 hours of light and 12 hours of dark. The dissolved oxygen concentrations in both flasks are monitored. Predict what the relative dissolved oxygen concentrations will be in the flask with algae compared to the control flask.

options.text: The dissolved oxygen in the flask with algae will be higher in the light, but the same in the dark.
The dissolved oxygen in the flask with algae will always be lower.
The dissolved oxygen in the flask with algae will be higher in the light, but lower in the dark.
The dissolved oxygen in the flask with algae will always be higher.

questions.comments: When the light are on, the algae will produce oxygen through photosynthesis. Regardless of whether the lights are on or off, the algae will also carry out respiration, using up some oxygen. When the lights are on, the net effect will be an increase in oxygen levels in the flask with the algae, as oxygen will be produced via photosynthesis more rapidly than it is used up by respiration. When the lights are off, no oxygen will be produced by photosynthesis and oxygen will continue to be used by the algae for respiration, so there will be a lower concentration of oxygen in the flask with the algae.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements about proton gradients is FALSE?

options.text: A proton gradient is present when the concentration of hydrogen ions is higher on one side of a biological membrane than on the other side
Proton gradients cannot be used to do work
Proton gradients contain potential energy
A proton gradient is present when the concentration of protons is higher on one side of a biological membrane than on the other side

questions.comments: Remember that hydrogen ions and protons are the same thing, as a hydrogen atom consists of a single electron and a nucleus that contains one proton and no neutrons. So, if a hydrogen atom loses its electron, all that is left is a proton. Proton/hydrogen ion gradients contain potential energy that can be used to do work.

questions.raw_html_question: Chemiosmosis

is found only in respiration.

questions.comments: Chemiosmosis refers to the movement of ions across a selectively permeable membrane, down their electrochemical gradient. Proton gradients are formed during both respiration and the light-reactions of photosynthesis. Energy from these proton gradients is then used to form ATP. Oxygen is not generated during chemiosmosis.

questions.raw_html_question: In photosynthesis, “resonance energy transfer” refers to
questions.question: In photosynthesis, “resonance energy transfer” refers to

all of these answers are correct
the transfer of energy from an excited electron in one pigment molecule to an electron in a different pigment molecule
the transfer of energy from an excited proton in one pigment molecule to a proton in a different pigment molecule

questions.comments: During photosynthesis, "resonance energy transfer" refers to the transfer of energy from an excited electron in one pigment molecule to an electron in a different pigment molecule. Remember that the pigment molecules in the light harvesting complexes transfer energy from an excited electron between pigment molecules, and finally to special chlorophyll a molecules in the reaction center, via resonance energy transfer. Only the energy from the excited electron is transferred during this process, not the actual electron. In contrast, special chlorophyll a molecules in the reaction center complexes transfer the actual excited electron to a primary electron acceptor.

questions.raw_html_question: What percentage of living organisms are dependent, directly or indirectly, on food molecules produced via photosynthesis?
questions.question: What percentage of living organisms are dependent, directly or indirectly, on food molecules produced via photosynthesis?

options.text: the vast majority

questions.comments: There are a relatively small percentage of living organisms that exist in ecosystems that are independent of photosynthesis. For example, there are communities of organisms living in deep sea trenches where there are bacteria that are able to produce food molecules from chemosynthesis rather than photosynthesis (e.g. some of these bacteria use energy from H2S rather than from sunlight to produce food molecules). Other organisms in these trenches survive by eating these bacteria, and still other organisms survive by eating the organisms that eat the bacteria.

questions.comments: Puncturing the membrane will not affect the reactions that occur solely in the stroma or in the thylakoid membrane. What will be disrupted is the hydrogen ion gradient that would normally be established across the thylakoid membrane during the light reactions. Disruption of this hydrogen ion gradient will mean that ATP synthase will not be able to use energy from the gradient to synthesize ATP.

questions.raw_html_question: Reduction of oxygen to form water occurs during
questions.question: Reduction of oxygen to form water occurs during

options.text: photosynthesis only.
respiration only.
both photosynthesis and respiration.
photorespiration only.

questions.comments: During respiration, electrons from food molecules are transferred via intermediates to oxygen molecules. The oxygen molecules and electrons than join with protons (= hydrogen ions = H+), forming water molecules. During photosynthesis, energy from light results in generation of a P680+ molecule (i.e. a special chlorophyll a molecule, known as a P680 molecule, which is lacking an electron), which is so electronegative it is able to strip an electron from water, forming oxygen and releasing hydrogen ions.

questions.raw_html_question: As electrons are being transported down the electron transport chain from photosystem II to photosystem I
questions.question: As electrons are being transported down the electron transport chain from photosystem II to photosystem I

options.text: some of the energy that is released is stored in the form of covalent bonds
some of the energy that is released is used to generate a proton gradient
some of the energy that is released is used to form ATP
all of the energy that is released is used to generate a proton gradient

questions.comments: Some of the energy released during electron transport is used to do the work of forming a proton (i.e. hydrogen ion) gradient). Some of the energy stored in that gradient is then used to do the work of forming ATP, meaning that some of the energy stored in the gradient is converted to energy stored in the form of covalent bonds in the ATP molecule. Remember that not all of the energy released during transport of electrons down the electron transport chain can be used to form a proton gradient, as that would be a violation of the 2nd law of thermodynamics. According to this law, whenever energy is transferred or transformed, the amount of entropy in the universe decreases and, consequently, the amount of energy in the universe that is able to do work decreases. So, only some of the energy released during electron transport can be used to do the work of building a proton gradient.

questions.raw_html_question: The reactions of the Calvin cycle are
questions.question: The reactions of the Calvin cycle are

options.text: endergonic, and thus may proceed spontaneously without a source of free energy
exergonic, and thus may proceed spontaneously without a source of free energy
endergonic, and thus require a source of free energy to occur
exergonic, and thus require a source of free energy to occur

questions.comments: To remember the difference between “endergonic” and “exergonic”, focus on the first part of each word. With endergonic, think of energy entering the system as the free energies of the products are greater than the free energies of the reactants. With exergonic, think of energy exiting the system as the free energies of the products are less than the free energies of the reactants. Because the reactions of photosynthesis are endergonic (there is more free energy stored in the sugar molecules produced via photosynthesis than in the CO2 and H2O molecules from which they are made), they require a source of free energy (light energy) to occur.

questions.raw_html_question: Which process is most directly driven by light energy?
questions.question: Which process is most directly driven by light energy?

options.text: ATP synthesis
creation of a pH gradient by pumping protons across the thylakoid membrane
reduction of NADP+molecules
removal of electrons from chlorophyll molecules

questions.comments: The energy from light is captured by pigment molecules in a light-harvesting complex. The captured energy causes one of the electrons in the pigment molecule to become “excited”, meaning that the electron has increased energy as a result of being further from the nucleus. The energy from the excited electron is then passed to another pigment molecule via “resonance energy transfer”, causing an electron in that molecule to become excited. That energy is then transferred via “resonance energy transfer”, to yet another pigment molecule, causing an electron in that molecule to become excited, and so on. Eventually the energy is transferred to one of two special chlorophyll a molecules in the photosystem II reaction center (a P680 molecule), causing that molecule to actually transfer an excited electron (not just the energy from an excited electron, but the actual electron itself) to a primary electron acceptor. The primary electron acceptor than transfers an electron to the first component in an electron chain. Transfer of electrons down the electron transport chain from photosystem II to photosystem I helps generate a proton gradient. Eventually an electron reaches NADP+, causing it to be reduced and form NADPH. Energy from the proton gradient is used by ATP synthase to help drive ATP synthesis. So, of all the possible answers, the process that is most directly driven by light energy is removal of electrons from chlorophyll.

The captured energy causes one of the electrons in the pigment molecule to become “excited”, meaning that the electron has increased energy as a result of being further from the nucleus. The energy from the excited electron is then passed to another pigment molecule via “resonance energy transfer”, causing an electron in that molecule to become excited. That energy is then transferred via “resonance energy transfer”, to yet another pigment molecule, causing an electron in that molecule to become excited, and so on. Eventually the energy is transferred to one of two special chlorophyll a molecules in the photosystem II reaction center (a P680 molecule), causing that molecule to actually transfer an excited electron (not just the energy from an excited electron, but the actual electron itself) to a primary electron acceptor. The primary electron acceptor than transfers an electron to the first component in an electron chain. Eventually an electron reaches NADP+, causing it to be reduced and form NADPH. Energy from the proton gradient is used by ATP synthase to help drive ATP synthesis. So, of all the possible answers, the process that is most directly driven by light energy is removal of electrons from chlorophyll.

exergonic as the P700+ chlorophyll a molecule is less electronegative than the primary electron acceptor

questions.comments: To remember the difference between “endergonic” and “exergonic”, focus on the first part of each word. With endergonic, think of energy entering the system as the free energies of the products are greater than the free energies of the reactants. With exergonic, think of energy exiting the system as the free energies of the products are less than the free energies of the reactants. Also remember that transfer of electrons along an electron transport chain is from molecules that are less electronegative (“want” electrons less) to molecules that are more electronegative (“want” electrons less) and is thus an energetically favorable, or exergonic, process.
questions.raw_html_comments: To remember the difference between “endergonic” and “exergonic”, focus on the first part of each word. Also remember that transfer of electrons along an electron transport chain is from molecules that are less electronegative (“want” electrons less) to molecules that are more electronegative (“want” electrons less) and is thus an energetically favorable, or exergonic, process.

questions.raw_html_question: In mechanism, photophosphorylation is most similar to
questions.question: In mechanism, photophosphorylation is most similar to

options.text: oxidative phosphorylation in cellular respiration.
substrate-level phosphorylation in glycolysis.
carbon fixation.
the Calvin cycle.

questions.comments: Photophosphorylation and oxidative phosphorylation are very similar processes, as both involve a flow of electrons along an electron transport chain, with some of the energy released by electrons moving to increasingly more electronegative complexes being used to form a hydrogen ion gradient across a membrane (the chloroplast thylakoid membrane in the case of photophosphorylation and the inner membrane of the mitochondria in the case of oxidative phosphorylation). Also, in both photophosphorylation and oxidative phosphorylation some of the energy in the hydrogen ion gradient is used by ATP synthase to “drive” synthesis of ATP.

Also, in both photophosphorylation and oxidative phosphorylation some of the energy in the hydrogen ion gradient is used by ATP synthase to “drive” synthesis of ATP.

questions.raw_html_question: In the figure, G1 is represented by which numbered part(s) of the cycle?
questions.question: In the figure, G1 is represented by which numbered part(s) of the cycle?

options.text: IV only
III only
II or IV
I or V

questions.comments: You can distinguish between the different phases of the cell cycle based on the amount of DNA per nucleus, as the amount of DNA per nucleus changes over the course of a cell cycle. Nuclei have the lowest amount of DNA during G1, which is represented by I and V in the figure. During the next phase of the cell cycle, the S phase (II in the figure), DNA synthesis occurs and so the amount of DNA per nucleus doubles during S phase. The amount of DNA per nucleus does not change during the next phase of the cell cycle, the G2phase (III in the figure). During mitosis, the nucleus divides with each of the resulting daughter nuclei receiving half of the DNA. So, during mitosis (IV in the figure), the amount of DNA per nuclei decreases to half of what it was during G2.

questions.raw_html_question: A particular cell has half as much DNA as some other cells in a mitotically active tissue. The cell in question is most likely in
questions.question: A particular cell has half as much DNA as some other cells in a mitotically active tissue. The cell in question is most likely in

options.text: prophase.
metaphase.

questions.comments: The amount of DNA per cell doubles during S phase, as DNA synthesis (replication) takes place. The amount of DNA per cell remains at this level during G2 phase, and then is cut in half during mitosis and remains at that lower level during G1 phase. So, cells that are in G2phase, or prophase or metaphase (sub-phases of mitosis that occur before mitosis is complete and the amount of DNA per cell decreases) have twice as much DNA as cells in G1 phase.

options.text: from metaphase through anaphase
from G1 of interphase through metaphase
from G2 of interphase through metaphase
from interphase through telophase

questions.comments: DNA synthesis occurs during S phase, so that by the end of S phase each chromosome is composed of two chromatids stuck together at a region of the chromosome known as the centromere. G2 phase occurs immediately after S phase. So, two-chromatid chromosomes are found during G2phase. The cohesion protein that hold the two sister chromatids of each chromosome together are cleaved during anaphase. So the last phase during which two-chromatid chromosomes are found is immediately before anaphase, which is during metaphase.

questions.raw_html_question: If there are 20 centromeres in a cell at anaphase, how many chromosomes are there in each daughter cell following cytokinesis?
questions.question: If there are 20 centromeres in a cell at anaphase, how many chromosomes are there in each daughter cell following cytokinesis?
questions.comments: During anaphase the cohesin proteins holding each pair of sister chromatids together are cleaved, allowing the sister chromatids to separate and become independent chromosomes. If there are 20 centromeres in a cell during anaphase, that means that there were 10 pairs of sister chromatids, each of which has separated to form 20 chromosomes, each with its own centromere. Once cytokinesis is complete, each of the resulting daughter cells should have half of those chromosomes, or 10 chromosomes.

questions.comments: The amounts of cyclin “cycle” during the cell cycle, and are higher during the part of the cell cycle when they act. So, because cyclin E is important for progression of the cell from G1 to S phase, cyclin E concentrations must be high during G1. In contrast, the levels of Cdks do not fluctuate very much during the cell cycle. Instead, Cdk activity is regulated during the cell cycle by the presence or absence of cyclins, as Cdks require cyclins to be active.

questions.raw_html_question: The amount of DNA per chromosome during G<sub>1</sub> of interphase is
questions.question: The amount of DNA per chromosome during G1 of interphase is

options.text: the same as during prophase of mitosis.
the same as during telophase of mitosis.
different in each tissue of an organism.
the same as during G2 of interphase.

questions.comments: The amount of DNA per chromosome is not affected by tissue type. However, the amount of DNA per chromosome will be twice as high in cells where the DNA has replicated but the resulting sister chromatids are still together (i.e. part of the same chromosome) than in cells where sister chromatids have separated. For example, in G1 phase the DNA has not yet replicated. In contrast, G2phase occurs after DNA synthesis but before mitosis. So, during G2phase each chromosome consists of two sister chromatids that are stuck together at the centromere. Therefore, chromosomes in cells in G2 phase have twice as much DNA as chromosomes in cells in G1 phase. Prior to telophase the sister chromatids separate, becoming independent chromosomes. Consequently the amount of DNA per chromosome for cells in telophase is the same as for cells in G1, but half as much as for cells in G2.

questions.raw_html_question: Measurements of the amount of DNA per nucleus were taken on a large number of cells from a growing fungus. The measured DNA levels ranged from 3 to 6 picograms per nucleus. In which stage of the cell cycle did the nucleus contain 6 picograms of DNA?
questions.question: Measurements of the amount of DNA per nucleus were taken on a large number of cells from a growing fungus. The measured DNA levels ranged from 3 to 6 picograms per nucleus. In which stage of the cell cycle did the nucleus contain 6 picograms of DNA?

options.text: G1
G2
S
G0

questions.comments: DNA replication (or synthesis) occurs during the “S”, or “Synthesis” phase of the cell cycle. So, cells in S phase would have between 3 and 6 picograms of DNA per nucleus. The G1 phase occurs before S phase and the G0 phase is a non-dividing phase that cells enter if they are unable to pass the G1 checkpoint. Therefore, when these fungal cells are in G0 or G1, they will not have replicated their DNA and so will have 3 picograms of DNA/nucleus. The G2phase occurs after the S phase (i.e. after the cells have completed DNA replication, doubling the amount of DNA they contained in G1 phase from 3 to 6 picograms/nucleus), but before the amount of DNA is reduced back down to 3 picograms/nucleus by the cell division that occurs after G2, during the process of mitosis.

Therefore, when these fungal cells are in G0 or G1, they will not have replicated their DNA and so will have 3 picograms of DNA/nucleus. The G2
phase occurs after the S phase (i.e. after the cells have completed DNA replication, doubling the amount of DNA they contained in G1 phase from 3 to 6 picograms/nucleus), but before the amount of DNA is reduced back down to 3 picograms/nucleus by the cell division that occurs after G2, during the process of mitosis.

questions.raw_html_question: Why do chromosomes coil during mitosis?

to allow the chromosomes to fit within the nuclear envelope

questions.comments: Although chromosomes do need to form more compact structures to fit within nuclei, the coiling that occurs during mitosis condenses the chromosomes beyond what is need for the chromosomes to fit within the nucleus. Centromeres are not formed by chromosome coiling and chromosome coiling is not what holds sister chromatids together. Instead, the coiling that occurs during mitosis is necessary to allow the chromosomes to align in the middle of the cell and then to move apart during mitosis.

questions.raw_html_question: Starting with a fertilized egg (zygote), a series of five cell divisions would produce an early embryo with how many cells?
questions.question: Starting with a fertilized egg (zygote), a series of five cell divisions would produce an early embryo with how many cells?
questions.comments: The number of cells doubles with each round of cell division. So, after one cell division the fertilized egg (= a single cell) has divided two form two cells. In the next (second) round of cell division, each of those two cells divides so that the zygote now has a total of 4 cells. During the third round of cell division each of those 4 cells divides, giving rise to a zygote with 8 cells. During the fourth round of cell division each of those 8 cells divides, giving rise to a zygote with 16 cells. During the fifth round of cell division each of those 16 cells divides, giving rise to a zygote with 32 cells.

questions.raw_html_question: A group of cells is assayed for DNA content immediately following mitosis and is found to have an average of 8 picograms of DNA per nucleus. How many picograms would be found at the end of S and the end of G2?

questions.comments: DNA replication (or synthesis) occurs during the “S”, or “Synthesis” phase of the cell cycle. So, at the end of S phase, the cells would have completed DNA replication and would have twice as much DNA in their nucleus (i.e. 16 picograms) as they did immediately following mitosis. G2phase occurs after S phase and before mitosis/nuclear division causes the amount of DNA per nucleus to be cut in half. So, cells in G2 phase, like cells in S phase, will have twice as much DNA per nucleus as cells that have just completed mitosis (i.e. they will have 16 picograms of DNA per nucleus).

questions.comments: Prior to DNA replication, the cell has four chromosomes. Each of those chromosomes will replicate during S phase, forming four pairs of sister chromatids. During anaphase, separase cleaves the cohesin proteins holding each of the four pairs of sister chromatids together, allowing the sister chromatids to separate and become eight independent chromosomes. By telophase (which occurs immediately after anaphase), each daughter nucleus will have received one copy of each chromosome, meaning that each of the daughter nuclei will have 4, separate chromosomes.

questions.raw_html_question: In the figure, at which of the numbered regions would you expect to find cells at metaphase?

options.text: III only

questions.comments: Metaphase is one of the sub-phases of mitosis. DNA replication occurs earlier in the cell cycle, during S phase. During metaphase, the pairs of sister chromatids align at the center of the cell, but do not separate until the next sub-phase of mitosis, anaphase. Therefore, the average amount of DNA per nucleus for cells during metaphase is twice the amount of DNA per nucleus found during G1 phase. Therefore, the amount of DNA per nucleus for cells at metaphase is best represented by region III in the figure. Please note that this question is asking specifically about metaphase. If the question was asking about the entire process of mitosis, the correct answer would be region IV of the diagram, as this region shows the decrease in the amount of DNA per nucleus that occurs later in mitosis, during anaphase.

questions.raw_html_question: If cells in the process of dividing are subjected to colchicine, a drug that interferes with the formation of the spindle apparatus, at which stage will mitosis be arrested?

options.text: interphase

metaphase

questions.comments: At the “M” (for metaphase) checkpoint the cell checks to make sure that kinetochore microtubules are attached to the kinetochore of each of its chromatids. If the cells were subjected to colchicine, the spindle apparatus would not have formed and the cells would not be able to pass the M checkpoint. Therefore the cells would arrest in metaphase.

questions.raw_html_question: In the cells of some organisms, mitosis occurs without cytokinesis. This will result in
questions.question: In the cells of some organisms, mitosis occurs without cytokinesis. This will result in

options.text: cells lacking nuclei.

questions.comments: Typically the mitotic phase is divided into two, partially overlapping sub-phases. Nuclear division occurs during mitosis and division of the cytoplasm to form two daughter cells occurs during cytokinesis. So, if a cell undergoes one round of mitosis without undergoing cytokinesis, that means that the nucleus of that cell divides but the cell itself does not divide, leaving a single cell with two nuclei.

questions.raw_html_question: The table shows data obtained from a study of the length of time spent in each phase of the cell cycle by cells of three eukaryotic organisms designated beta, delta, and gamma. Of the following, the best conclusion concerning the difference between the S phases for beta and gamma is that
questions.question: The table shows data obtained from a study of the length of time spent in each phase of the cell cycle by cells of three eukaryotic organisms designated beta, delta, and gamma. Of the following, the best conclusion concerning the difference between the S phases for beta and gamma is that

options.text: beta is a plant cell and gamma is an animal cell.
gamma contains 48 times more DNA and RNA than beta.
beta cells reproduce asexually.
gamma contains more DNA than beta.

questions.comments: The table shows that beta and gamma cells spend approximately equal amounts of time in G1, G2 and M, but that the S phase (the DNA synthesis phase) takes twice as long for gamma as for beta cells. So, this data indicates that most phases of the cell cycle occur equally quickly in cells from both beta and gamma, but that DNA synthesis takes longer in cells from gamma. The most logical explanation for these findings is that cells from gamma have about twice as much DNA as cells from beta.

questions.comments: During anaphase the sister chromatids separate, becoming independent chromosomes. These independent chromosomes then move towards centrosomes on opposite sides of the cell. questions.raw_html_question: In the figure, which number represents DNA synthesis?
questions.question: In the figure, which number represents DNA synthesis?

options.text: II
IV
III
I

questions.comments: You can distinguish between the different phases of the cell cycle based on the amount of DNA per nucleus, as the amount of DNA per nucleus changes over the course of a cell cycle. Nuclei have the lowest amount of DNA during G1, which is represented by I and V in the figure. During the next phase of the cell cycle, the S phase (II in the figure), DNA synthesis occurs and so the amount of DNA per nucleus doubles during S phase. The amount of DNA per nucleus does not change during the next phase of the cell cycle, the G2phase (III in the figure). During mitosis, the nucleus divides with each of the resulting daughter nuclei receiving half of the DNA. So, during mitosis (IV in the figure), the amount of DNA per nuclei decreases to half of what it was during G2.

questions.raw_html_question: If there are 20 chromatids in a cell, how many centromeres are there?
questions.question: If there are 20 chromatids in a cell, how many centromeres are there?
questions.comments: A “chromatid” is one copy of a newly copied chromosome that is still joined to the other copy (chromatid) by a single centromere. Therefore, there is one centromere for every pair of sister chromatids. Therefore, if there are 20 chromatids (= 10 pairs of sister chromatids), there are 10 centromeres.

questions.comments: You can distinguish between the different phases of the cell cycle based on the amount of DNA per nucleus, as the amount of DNA per nucleus changes over the course of a cell cycle. Nuclei have the lowest amount of DNA during G1, which is represented by I and V in the figure. The amount of DNA per nucleus does not change during the next phase of the cell cycle, the G2 phase (III in the figure). During mitosis, the nucleus divides with each of the resulting daughter nuclei receiving half of the DNA. So, the early part of mitosis (i.e. the sub-phases of mitosis that occur prior to nuclear division, such as prophase) are represented by III in the figure and the latter stages of mitosis (during which nuclear division is occurring, resulting in the amount of DNA/nucleus being cut to half of what it was during G2) are represented by IV in the figure.

quiz_title: SQ topic 13

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following occurs in meiosis but not in mitosis?
questions.question: Which of the following occurs in meiosis but not in mitosis?

options.text: condensation of chromatin
production of daughter cells
chromosome replication
synapsis of chromosomes

questions.comments: Chromosome replication occurs prior to meiosis I and prior to mitosis. Meiosis I, meiosis II and mitosis all result in the production of daughter cells. Chromosome condensation needs to occur during both mitosis and meiosis, to allow chromosomes to move around the cell without becoming tangled and breaking. In contrast, synapsis only occurs during meiosis I. Remember that synapsis is when homologous chromosomes become stuck together by proteins of the synaptonemal complex during prophase I.
questions.raw_html_comments: Chromosome replication occurs prior to meiosis I and prior to mitosis. Meiosis I, meiosis II and mitosis all result in the production of daughter cells. Chromosome condensation needs to occur during both mitosis and meiosis, to allow chromosomes to move around the cell without becoming tangled and breaking. In contrast, synapsis only occurs during meiosis I. Remember that synapsis is when homologous chromosomes become stuck together by proteins of the synaptonemal complex during prophase I.

questions.raw_html_question: If a horticulturist breeding gardenias succeeds in having a single plant with a particularly desirable set of traits, which of the following would be her most probable and efficient route to establishing a line of such plants?
questions.question: If a horticulturist breeding gardenias succeeds in having a single plant with a particularly desirable set of traits, which of the following would be her most probable and efficient route to establishing a line of such plants?

options.text: Backtrack through her previous experiments to obtain another plant with the same traits.
Breed this plant with another plant with much weaker traits.
Force the plant to self-pollinate to obtain an identical one.
Clone the plant asexually to produce an identical one.

questions.comments: By cloning the plant the gardener will obtain plants that are genetically identical to the original plant, and therefore share the desirable traits of the original plant. Forcing the plant to self-pollinate won’t result in a genetically identical plant. For example, if the plant was heterozygous for a particular gene (i.e. if the original plant has different alleles of a particular gene), causing the plant to self-pollinate will result in a mixture of progeny plants, where some of the progeny plants are homozygous for one of the two alleles, some progeny plants are homozygous for the other allele and some progeny plants are heterozygous (i.e. have one copy of each of the two alleles of the gene). So, self-pollination will not result in plants that are genetically identical to the original plant and can therefore be counted on to have the same desirable traits as the original plant. Similarly, breeding the plant to a plant with weaker traits will likely result in progeny plants that are not as desirable as the original plant. Back-tracking to create another similar plant is too much work and is unlikely to result in a plant that is completely identical to the original plant.

So, self-pollination will not result in plants that are genetically identical to the original plant and can therefore be counted on to have the same desirable traits as the original plant. Similarly, breeding the plant to a plant with weaker traits will likely result in progeny plants that are not as desirable as the original plant. Back-tracking to create another similar plant is too much work and is unlikely to result in a plant that is completely identical to the original plant.

questions.raw_html_question: How do cells at the completion of meiosis compare with cells that have replicated their DNA and are just about to begin meiosis?
questions.question: How do cells at the completion of meiosis compare with cells that have replicated their DNA and are just about to begin meiosis?

options.text: They have the same number of chromosomes and half the amount of DNA.
They have half the number of chromosomes and one-fourth the amount of DNA.
They have half the number of chromosomes and half the amount of DNA.
They have half the amount of cytoplasm and half the amount of DNA.

questions.comments: During meiosis I, one of each pair of homologous chromosomes ends up in each daughter cells. So, at the completion of meiosis I the resulting daughter cells have half as much DNA and half as many chromosomes as a cell that has replicated its DNA and is about to begin meiosis. At the completion of meiosis II, the pair of sister chromatids making up each chromosome separate, with each daughter cell receiving one of the chromatids, which are each now independent chromosomes. As a result, the number of chromosomes per cell does not decrease during meiosis II, but the amount of DNA per cell is again cut in half. Therefore, the overall process of meiosis I and II results in a 4-fold reduction in the amount of DNA per cell and a 2-fold reduction in the number of chromosomes per cell.
questions.raw_html_comments: During meiosis I, one of each pair of homologous chromosomes ends up in each daughter cells. So, at the completion of meiosis I the resulting daughter cells have half as much DNA and half as many chromosomes as a cell that has replicated its DNA and is about to begin meiosis. At the completion of meiosis II, the pair of sister chromatids making up each chromosome separate, with each daughter cell receiving one of the chromatids, which are each now independent chromosomes. As a result, the number of chromosomes per cell does not decrease during meiosis II, but the amount of DNA per cell is again cut in half. Therefore, the overall process of meiosis I and II results in a 4-fold reduction in the amount of DNA per cell and a 2-fold reduction in the number of chromosomes per cell.

questions.raw_html_question: A certain (hypothetical) organism is diploid, has either blue or orange wings as the consequence of one of its genes on chromosome 12, and has either long or short antennae as the result of a second gene on chromosome 19, as shown in the figure below. If a certain female of this species has one chromosome 12 with a blue allele of the wing color gene and another chromosome 12 with an orange allele of the wing color gene, and has both number 19 chromosomes with short alleles of the antennae length gene, she will produce which of the following egg types?
questions.question: A certain (hypothetical) organism is diploid, has either blue or orange wings as the consequence of one of its genes on chromosome 12, and has either long or short antennae as the result of a second gene on chromosome 19, as shown in the figure below. If a certain female of this species has one chromosome 12 with a blue allele of the wing color gene and another chromosome 12 with an orange allele of the wing color gene, and has both number 19 chromosomes with short alleles of the antennae length gene, she will produce which of the following egg types?

options.text: one-half blue short and one-half orange short gene eggs
three-fourths blue short and one-fourth orange short gene eggs
only blue short gene eggs
only orange short gene eggs

questions.comments: A diploid organism has two sets of chromosomes, meaning that it has two copies of each gene in its somatic cells (remember that somatic cells are all the cells in an organism, except for the gametes and the cells that produce the gametes). Slightly different versions of the same gene are known as “alleles”. So, for each gene, a diploid organism can have either two copies of the same allele or two different alleles of that gene. During meiosis, the pairs of homologous chromosomes separate and the daughter cells that result at the end of meiosis have only one set of chromosomes and therefore only one allele of each gene. In this example, the female in question has different alleles of the wing color gene but the same (short) allele of the antennae length gene. Therefore, half the egg cells produced by this female will have one copy of the blue allele of the wing color gene and the other half of the egg cells will have one copy of the orange allele. Because this female only has the short allele of the antennae length gene, all the egg cells produced by this female will have one copy of the short allele of the antennae length gene on chromosome 19.

During meiosis, the pairs of homologous chromosomes separate and the daughter cells that result at the end of meiosis have only one set of chromosomes and therefore only one allele of each gene. In this example, the female in question has different alleles of the wing color gene but the same (short) allele of the antennae length gene. Therefore, half the egg cells produced by this female will have one copy of the blue allele of the wing color gene and the other half of the egg cells will have one copy of the orange allele. Because this female only has the short allele of the antennae length gene, all the egg cells produced by this female will have one copy of the short allele of the antennae length gene on chromosome 19.

questions.raw_html_question: Chromatids are separated from each other.
questions.question: Chromatids are separated from each other.

options.text: The statement is true for meiosis II only.
The statement is true for mitosis and meiosis I.
The statement is true for mitosis and meiosis II.
The statement is true for mitosis only.

questions.comments: Sister chromatids separate from each other during both mitosis and meiosis II. In contrast, homologous chromosomes (each consisting of a pair of sister chromatids) separate from each other during meiosis I.

questions.raw_html_question: You have isolated DNA from three different cell types of an organism, determined the relative DNA content for each type, and plotted the results on the graph shown below. Which sample might represent a newly formed zygote?
questions.question: You have isolated DNA from three different cell types of an organism, determined the relative DNA content for each type, and plotted the results on the graph shown below. Which sample might represent a newly formed zygote?

options.text: III
I
either I or II
II

questions.comments: Somatic cells are all the cells in an organism, except for the gametes and the cells that give rise to the gametes. The amount of DNA per somatic cells doubles during S phase, as the cells replicate their DNA. The amount of DNA remains at this level throughout G2 phase, and then is cut in half part way through mitosis as the cell divides and each of the resulting daughter cells receives half of the DNA. So, somatic cells in G1 and G0 (remember that G0 is the phase that G1 cells enter if they don’t pass the checkpoint at the end of G1 that would allow them to enter the S phase) have half as much DNA as somatic cells during G2 and the first part of mitosis. During meiosis, two rounds of cell division occur with only one round of DNA synthesis. As a result, the gametes formed by meiosis have only half as much DNA as a somatic cell during the G1 or G0 phases, and only a quarter as much DNA as a somatic cell during G2 or the earlier part of mitosis. When two gametes combine to form a zygote, the resulting zygote has twice as much DNA as either gamete, or the same amount of DNA as a somatic cell during G1 or G0. Therefore, sample I represents a newly formed zygote, or somatic cells in G1, G0 or the last part of mitosis. Sample II represents somatic cells in G2 or the earlier part of mitosis. Sample III represents gametes.
