Therefore, sample I represents a newly formed zygote, or somatic cells in G1, G0 or the last part of mitosis. Sample II represents somatic cells in G2 or the earlier part of mitosis. Sample III represents gametes.

questions.raw_html_question: How does the sexual life cycle increase the genetic variation in a species?
questions.question: How does the sexual life cycle increase the genetic variation in a species?

options.text: by decreasing mutation frequency
by increasing gene stability
by allowing crossing over
by changing the number of genes different offspring receive

questions.comments: The sexual life cycle doesn’t affect the number of genes each offspring inherits (offspring will have the same number of genes as each of their parents), gene stability or mutational frequency. In contrast, crossing over allows for the mixing of different alleles of different genes. For example, a daughter cell might receive alleles of one gene from its paternal “grandmother” and its maternal “grandmother”, but receive alleles of a different gene on the same chromosome from its paternal “grandfather” and its maternal “grandmother”.
questions.raw_html_comments: The sexual life cycle doesn’t affect the number of genes each offspring inherits (offspring will have the same number of genes as each of their parents), gene stability or mutational frequency. In contrast, crossing over allows for the mixing of different alleles of different genes. For example, a daughter cell might receive alleles of one gene from its paternal “grandmother” and its maternal “grandmother”, but receive alleles of a different gene on the same chromosome from its paternal “grandfather” and its maternal “grandmother”.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following happens at the conclusion of meiosis I?
questions.question: Which of the following happens at the conclusion of meiosis I?

options.text: Sister chromatids are separated.
The chromosome number per cell is conserved.
Four daughter cells are formed.
Homologous chromosomes are separated.

questions.comments: Homologous chromosomes are separated during meiosis I, with one of each pair of homologous chromosomes ending up in a different daughter cell. As a result, the number of chromosomes per cell is cut in half. Sister chromatids separate during meiosis II. The overall process of meiosis I and II results in formation of 4 cells.
questions.raw_html_comments: Homologous chromosomes are separated during meiosis I, with one of each pair of homologous chromosomes ending up in a different daughter cell. As a result, the number of chromosomes per cell is cut in half. Sister chromatids separate during meiosis II. The overall process of meiosis I and II results in formation of 4 cells.

questions.raw_html_question: For a species with a haploid number of 23 chromosomes, how many different combinations of maternal and paternal chromosomes are possible for the gametes?
questions.question: For a species with a haploid number of 23 chromosomes, how many different combinations of maternal and paternal chromosomes are possible for the gametes?

options.text: about 8 million

questions.comments: Even if crossing over does not occur, many different chromosomal combinations are possible. For example, if a species has a haploid number of 2 chromosomes and no crossing over occurs, the following 4 combinations are possible for the gametes: homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2. If a species has a haploid number of 3 chromosomes, the following 8 combinations are possible: homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3.Basically, for each chromosome a gamete can inherit either of the two homologs. The number of possible combinations is thus equal to: 2n, where “n” = the haploid number of chromosomes. 223 = 8,388,608

options.text: meiosis II
prophase I
anaphase II
asexual reproduction

questions.comments: Chiasmata are points where crossing over has occurred between pairs of homologous chromosomes. Crossing over occurs, and chiasmata are thus formed, during prophase of meiosis I.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is a true statement about sexual vs. asexual reproduction?
questions.question: Which of the following is a true statement about sexual vs. asexual reproduction?

options.text: Asexual reproduction, but not sexual reproduction, is characteristic of plants and fungi.
Sexual reproduction requires that parents be diploid.
In sexual reproduction, individuals transmit 50% of their genes to each of their offspring.
In asexual reproduction, offspring are produced by fertilization without meiosis.

questions.comments: Many plant and fungal species make use of both asexual and sexual reproduction. Asexual reproduction occurs without fertilization (e.g. by mitosis). It is true that during sexual reproduction parents transmit 50% of their genes to their offspring. This happens because during the process of meiosis the parents produce germ cells (either sperm or egg cells) each of which contain only 50% of the DNA present in the somatic (non-germ) cells of the parent. However, sexual reproduction does NOT require that the parents be diploid. For example, if the parents are tetraploid (i.e. contain four sets of chromosomes), meiosis will result in the production of germ cells that are diploid (i.e. contain two sets of chromosomes).
questions.raw_html_comments: Many plant and fungal species make use of both asexual and sexual reproduction. Asexual reproduction occurs without fertilization (e.g. by mitosis). It is true that during sexual reproduction parents transmit 50% of their genes to their offspring. This happens because during the process of meiosis the parents produce germ cells (either sperm or egg cells) each of which contain only 50% of the DNA present in the somatic (non-germ) cells of the parent. However, sexual reproduction does NOT require that the parents be diploid. For example, if the parents are tetraploid (i.e. contain four sets of chromosomes), meiosis will result in the production of germ cells that are diploid (i.e. contain two sets of chromosomes).

questions.raw_html_question: If a cell has completed the first meiotic division and is just beginning meiosis II, which of the following is an appropriate description of its contents?
questions.question: If a cell has completed the first meiotic division and is just beginning meiosis II, which of the following is an appropriate description of its contents?

options.text: It is identical in content to another cell from the same meiosis.
It has half the amount of DNA as the cell that began meiosis.
It has half the chromosomes but twice the DNA of the originating cell.
It has one-fourth the DNA and one-half the chromosomes as the originating cell.

questions.comments: Meiosis results in cell division, with each of the resulting daughter cells receiving ½ of the DNA that was in the cell at the beginning of meiosis. Completion of the first meiotic division therefore results in cells that have half as much DNA as the cell that began meiosis.
questions.raw_html_comments: Meiosis results in cell division, with each of the resulting daughter cells receiving ½ of the DNA that was in the cell at the beginning of meiosis. Completion of the first meiotic division therefore results in cells that have half as much DNA as the cell that began meiosis.

questions.raw_html_question: A certain (hypothetical) organism is diploid, has either blue or orange wings as the consequence of one of its genes on chromosome 12, and has either long or short antennae as the result of a second gene on chromosome 19, as shown in the figure below. A female with a paternal set of one orange allele of the wing color gene and one long allele of the antennae length gene and a maternal set comprised of one blue allele of the wing color gene and one short allele of the antennae length gene is expected to produce which of the following types of eggs after meiosis?
questions.question: A certain (hypothetical) organism is diploid, has either blue or orange wings as the consequence of one of its genes on chromosome 12, and has either long or short antennae as the result of a second gene on chromosome 19, as shown in the figure below. A female with a paternal set of one orange allele of the wing color gene and one long allele of the antennae length gene and a maternal set comprised of one blue allele of the wing color gene and one short allele of the antennae length gene is expected to produce which of the following types of eggs after meiosis?

options.text: All eggs will have paternal types of gene combinations.
Each egg has a one-fourth chance of having either blue long, blue short, orange long, or orange short combinations.
All eggs will have maternal types of gene combinations.
Half the eggs will have maternal and half will have paternal combinations.

questions.comments: A diploid organism has two sets of chromosomes, meaning that it has two copies of each gene in its somatic cells (remember that somatic cells are all the cells in an organism, except for the gametes and the cells that produce the gametes). Slightly different versions of the same gene are known as “alleles”. So, for each gene, a diploid organism can have either two copies of the same allele or two different alleles of that gene. During meiosis, the pairs of homologous chromosomes separate and the daughter cells that result at the end of meiosis have only one set of chromosomes and therefore only one allele of each gene. In this example, the female in question has different alleles (blue and orange) of the wing color gene and different alleles (short and long) of the antennae length gene. Therefore, half the egg cells produced by this female will have one copy of the blue allele of the wing color gene and the other half of the egg cells will have one copy of the orange allele. In addition, half the egg cells produced by this female will have one copy of the short allele of the antennae length gene and the other half of the egg cells will have one copy of the long allele of the antennae length gene. Because the wing color and antennae length genes are on different chromosomes, which allele of the wing color gene is inherited by a particular egg cell will not be affected by which allele of the antennae length gene is inherited by that egg cell. As a result, half of the cells will inherit the orange allele of the wing color gene and half of those cells (or ¼ of the total daughter cells) will inherit the short allele of the antennae length gene and the other half of those cells (or ¼ of the total daughter cells) will inherit the long allele of the antennae length gene. Similarly, half of the cells will inherit the blue allele of the wing color gene and half of those cells (or ¼ of the total daughter cells) will inherit the short allele of the antennae length gene and the other half of those cells (or ¼ of the total daughter cells) will inherit the long allele of the antennae length gene.
questions.raw_html_comments: A diploid organism has two sets of chromosomes, meaning that it has two copies of each gene in its somatic cells (remember that somatic cells are all the cells in an organism, except for the gametes and the cells that produce the gametes). Slightly different versions of the same gene are known as “alleles”. So, for each gene, a diploid organism can have either two copies of the same allele or two different alleles of that gene. As a result, half of the cells will inherit the orange allele of the wing color gene and half of those cells (or ¼ of the total daughter cells) will inherit the short allele of the antennae length gene and the other half of those cells (or ¼ of the total daughter cells) will inherit the long allele of the antennae length gene. questions.raw_html_question: If the DNA content of a diploid cell in the G1 phase of the cell cycle is x, then the DNA content of a single cell at metaphase of meiosis II would be
questions.question: If the DNA content of a diploid cell in the G1 phase of the cell cycle is x, then the DNA content of a single cell at metaphase of meiosis II would be

options.text: x.

questions.comments: Prior to meiosis I, cells go through S phase and so their DNA is replicated, leaving them with twice the amount of DNA found in a cell during G1 phase. During meiosis I, homologous chromosomes separate, with the resulting daughter cells each receiving one of each pair of homologous chromosomes. Therefore, at the end of meiosis I the daughter cells have the same amount of DNA as a cell in the G1 phase. Metaphase of meiosis II occurs prior to the separation of sister chromatids and cell division that occur later in meiosis II. Therefore, cells at metaphase of meiosis II still have the same amount of DNA as cells in G1.
questions.raw_html_comments: Prior to meiosis I, cells go through S phase and so their DNA is replicated, leaving them with twice the amount of DNA found in a cell during G1 phase. During meiosis I, homologous chromosomes separate, with the resulting daughter cells each receiving one of each pair of homologous chromosomes. Therefore, at the end of meiosis I the daughter cells have the same amount of DNA as a cell in the G1 phase. Metaphase of meiosis II occurs prior to the separation of sister chromatids and cell division that occur later in meiosis II. Therefore, cells at metaphase of meiosis II still have the same amount of DNA as cells in G1.

questions.raw_html_question: After telophase I of meiosis, the chromosomal makeup of each daughter cell is
questions.question: After telophase I of meiosis, the chromosomal makeup of each daughter cell is

options.text: diploid, and the chromosomes are each composed of a single chromatid.
haploid, and the chromosomes are each composed of a single chromatid.
haploid, and the chromosomes are each composed of two chromatids.
diploid, and the chromosomes are each composed of two chromatids.

questions.comments: During anaphase I, homologous chromosomes move to opposite sides of the cell. During telophase I, one chromosome from each pair of homologous chromosomes thus ends up in a different daughter cell. Therefore, each daughter cell has only one chromosome from each pair of homologous chromosomes and is thus haploid. At this point, each chromosome consists of a pair of sister chromatids. The sister chromatids come apart during anaphase II.
questions.raw_html_comments: During anaphase I, homologous chromosomes move to opposite sides of the cell. During telophase I, one chromosome from each pair of homologous chromosomes thus ends up in a different daughter cell. Therefore, each daughter cell has only one chromosome from each pair of homologous chromosomes and is thus haploid. At this point, each chromosome consists of a pair of sister chromatids. The sister chromatids come apart during anaphase II.

questions.raw_html_question: Meiosis II is similar to mitosis in that
questions.question: Meiosis II is similar to mitosis in that

options.text: the chromosome number is reduced.
DNA replicates before the division.
sister chromatids separate during anaphase.
the daughter cells are diploid.

questions.comments: Sister chromatids separate during anaphase of both mitosis and meiosis II. DNA replication occurs prior to meiosis I, but not before meiosis II. Because two rounds of cell division but only one round of DNA replication occurs during meiosis, the cells produced at the end of meiosis are haploid. In contrast, during mitosis the cell undergoes both one round of DNA synthesis and one round of cell division. Therefore, the daughter cells produced by mitosis are diploid and have the same chromosome number as the starting cell.
questions.raw_html_comments: Sister chromatids separate during anaphase of both mitosis and meiosis II. DNA replication occurs prior to meiosis I, but not before meiosis II. Because two rounds of cell division but only one round of DNA replication occurs during meiosis, the cells produced at the end of meiosis are haploid. In contrast, during mitosis the cell undergoes both one round of DNA synthesis and one round of cell division. Therefore, the daughter cells produced by mitosis are diploid and have the same chromosome number as the starting cell.

questions.raw_html_question: To view and analyze human chromosomes as a cell is dividing, which of the following is/are required?
questions.question: To view and analyze human chromosomes as a cell is dividing, which of the following is/are required?

DNA stain and a light microscope
radioactive staining
electron microscope

questions.comments: Because DNA molecules are so small, a microscope is needed to visualize them. However, electron microscopy cannot be used to visualize living cells as the process of preparing samples for electron microscopy kills the samples. Therefore, it is necessary to use a light microscope. In addition, as DNA is hard to see through a microscope, some kind of DNA stain is necessary.
questions.raw_html_comments: Because DNA molecules are so small, a microscope is needed to visualize them. However, electron microscopy cannot be used to visualize living cells as the process of preparing samples for electron microscopy kills the samples. Therefore, it is necessary to use a light microscope. In addition, as DNA is hard to see through a microscope, some kind of DNA stain is necessary.

questions.raw_html_question: In the human species, all somatic cells have 46 chromosomes. Which of the following can also be true?
questions.question: In the human species, all somatic cells have 46 chromosomes. Which of the following can also be true?

options.text: Some adult humans have 90 chromosomes in every cell.
Some adult humans have 23 chromosomes in every cell.
Some adult humans have 69 chromosomes in every cell.
A plant species (privet shrubs) has 46 chromosomes per cell.

questions.comments: Different plant species have different number of chromosomes per cell. It is certainly possible for some plant species to have 46 chromosomes per cell. However, it is not possible for humans to have 23, 69 or 90 chromosomes per cell. Such a large alteration in chromosome number (e.g. due to a mistake made during meiosis) would be fatal.
questions.raw_html_comments: Different plant species have different number of chromosomes per cell. It is certainly possible for some plant species to have 46 chromosomes per cell. However, it is not possible for humans to have 23, 69 or 90 chromosomes per cell. Such a large alteration in chromosome number (e.g. due to a mistake made during meiosis) would be fatal.

questions.raw_html_question: In human somatic cells, chromosomes are arranged in 23 pairs. If we choose one of these pairs, such as pair 14, which of the following do the two chromosomes of the pair have in common?
questions.question: In human somatic cells, chromosomes are arranged in 23 pairs. If we choose one of these pairs, such as pair 14, which of the following do the two chromosomes of the pair have in common?

options.text: Length and position of the centromere only.
Length only.
Length, centromere position, and traits coded for by their genes.
Length, centromere position, and DNA sequences.

questions.comments: Pairs of homologous chromosomes are chromosomes where one chromosome of each pair is inherited from the mother and the other is inherited from the father. The chromosomes in a pair of homologous chromosomes are almost identical. They contain the same genes, but have slightly different versions (“alleles”) of most genes. As a result, each chromosome from a pair of homologous chromosomes will have the same length and centromere position. Because they have the same genes, they will also have in common the traits coded for by those genes. However, because they will have different alleles of most of their genes, they will not have identical DNA sequences.
questions.raw_html_comments: Pairs of homologous chromosomes are chromosomes where one chromosome of each pair is inherited from the mother and the other is inherited from the father. The chromosomes in a pair of homologous chromosomes are almost identical. They contain the same genes, but have slightly different versions (“alleles”) of most genes. As a result, each chromosome from a pair of homologous chromosomes will have the same length and centromere position. Because they have the same genes, they will also have in common the traits coded for by those genes. However, because they will have different alleles of most of their genes, they will not have identical DNA sequences.

questions.raw_html_question: Independent assortment of chromosomes is a result of
questions.question: Independent assortment of chromosomes is a result of

options.text: the random distribution of the sister chromatids to the two daughter cells during anaphase II.
the random nature of the fertilization of ova by sperm.

the random and independent way in which each pair of homologous chromosomes lines up at the metaphase plate during meiosis I, the random nature of the fertilization of ova by sperm, the random distribution of the sister chromatids to the two daughter cells during anaphase II, and the relatively small degree of homology shared by the X and Y chromosomes.
the random and independent way in which each pair of homologous chromosomes lines up at the metaphase plate during meiosis I.

questions.comments: During meiosis I, pairs of homologous chromosomes line up together in the center of the cell, at the metaphase plate. How each pair of chromosomes orient is random, meaning that the paternal chromosome of one pair might be nearer the top of the cell while the maternal chromosome of a different pair might be nearer the top of the cell. As a result, the maternal and paternal chromosomes of each pair assort independently into the daughter cells. This is known as “independent assortment of chromosomes”.
questions.raw_html_comments: During meiosis I, pairs of homologous chromosomes line up together in the center of the cell, at the metaphase plate. How each pair of chromosomes orient is random, meaning that the paternal chromosome of one pair might be nearer the top of the cell while the maternal chromosome of a different pair might be nearer the top of the cell. As a result, the maternal and paternal chromosomes of each pair assort independently into the daughter cells. This is known as “independent assortment of chromosomes”.

questions.comments: During anaphase I of meiosis, homologous chromosomes separate, with the sister chromatids of each chromosome remaining attached to each other. As a result, each of the daughter cells receives one of each pair of homologous chromosomes, each of which will consist of a pair of sister chromatids that are still stuck together. Then, during anaphase II of meiosis, the sister chromatids of separate. This situation is shown in figure V.

questions.raw_html_question: How many different combinations of maternal and paternal chromosomes can be packaged in gametes made by an organism with a diploid number of 8 (2n = 8)?
questions.question: How many different combinations of maternal and paternal chromosomes can be packaged in gametes made by an organism with a diploid number of 8 (2n = 8)?
questions.comments: Even if crossing over does not occur, many different chromosomal combinations are possible in different gametes. For example, if a species has a haploid number of 2 chromosomes and no crossing over occurs, the following 4 combinations are possible for the gametes: homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2. If a species has a haploid number of 3 chromosomes, the following 8 combinations are possible: homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3.Basically, for each chromosome a gamete can inherit either of the two homologs. The number of possible combinations is thus equal to: 2n, where “n” = the haploid number of chromosomes. In this example, the organism has a diploid number of 8 chromosomes, and therefore a haploid number of 4 chromosomes. 24 = 16
questions.raw_html_comments:
Even if crossing over does not occur, many different chromosomal combinations are possible in different gametes. For example, if a species has a haploid number of 2 chromosomes and no crossing over occurs, the following 4 combinations are possible for the gametes:
homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2;
homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2;
homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2;
homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2.


If a species has a haploid number of 3 chromosomes, the following 8 combinations are possible:
homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “1” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “1” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “1” of chromosome 3; homolog “2” of chromosome 1 + homolog “2” of chromosome 2 + homolog “2” of chromosome 3.

questions.raw_html_question: A human cell containing 22 autosomes and a Y chromosome is
questions.question: A human cell containing 22 autosomes and a Y chromosome is

options.text: an egg.
a zygote.
a sperm.
a somatic cell of a male.

questions.comments: “Autosomes” are chromosomes that are not sex chromosomes (e.g. not X or Y chromosomes). Somatic cells are all the cells in an organism except for the gametes (egg and sperm cells) and the cells that produce the gametes. In a diploid organism, such as a human, somatic cells have two sets of chromosomes and gametes have only one set. Human somatic cells have 22 pairs of autosomes and one pair of sex chromosomes. Gametes have only one set of autosomes and one sex chromosome. Sperm cells can have either an X or a Y chromosome for their sex chromosome. In contrast, all egg cells have an X chromosome. A zygote, which results from fertilization of an egg cell by a sperm cell, has 22 pairs of autosomes (so 44 autosomes) and two sex chromosomes, as do somatic cells of a male.
questions.raw_html_comments: “Autosomes” are chromosomes that are not sex chromosomes (e.g. not X or Y chromosomes). A zygote, which results from fertilization of an egg cell by a sperm cell, has 22 pairs of autosomes (so 44 autosomes) and two sex chromosomes, as do somatic cells of a male.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following might result in a human zygote with 45 chromosomes?
questions.question: Which of the following might result in a human zygote with 45 chromosomes?

options.text: failure of the egg nucleus to be fertilized by the sperm
an error in the alignment of chromosomes on the metaphase plate
an error in either egg or sperm meiotic anaphase
fertilization of a 23 chromosome human egg by a 22 chromosome sperm of a closely related species

questions.comments: During meiosis homologous chromosome pairs separate during anaphase I and sister chromatids separate during anaphase II. A mistake in either process could lead to formation of an egg cell with one less chromosome. For example, one pair of homologous chromosomes might not completely separate and so might move towards the same end of the cell during anaphase I. If that happens, one of the resulting cells would not have a copy of either homologous chromosome after cytokinesis I occurs. Alternatively, a pair of sister chromatids might fail to separate and so end up moving to the same end of the cell during anaphase II. If that happens, one of the resulting cells will be not have a copy of either sister chromatid after completion of cytokinesis II. In contrast, if an egg cell isn’t fertilized it will have 23 chromosomes and will not develop into a zygote. Similarly, human egg cells cannot be fertilized by sperm cells from other species.

If that happens, one of the resulting cells will be not have a copy of either sister chromatid after completion of cytokinesis II. questions.comments: During meiosis homologous chromosome pairs separate during anaphase I and sister chromatids separate during anaphase II. Alternatively, a pair of sister chromatids might fail to separate and so end up moving to the same end of the cell during anaphase II. If that happens, both sister chromatids will end up in the same cell after completion of cytokinesis II.

questions.raw_html_question: A certain (hypothetical) organism is diploid, has either blue or orange wings as the consequence of one of its genes on chromosome 12, and has either long or short antennae as the result of a second gene on chromosome 19, as shown in the figure below. A particular female's number 12 chromosomes both have the blue allele of the wing color gene and number 19 chromosomes both have the long allele of the antennae length gene. As cells in her ovaries undergo meiosis, her resulting eggs (ova) may have which of the following?
questions.question: A certain (hypothetical) organism is diploid, has either blue or orange wings as the consequence of one of its genes on chromosome 12, and has either long or short antennae as the result of a second gene on chromosome 19, as shown in the figure below. A particular female's number 12 chromosomes both have the blue allele of the wing color gene and number 19 chromosomes both have the long allele of the antennae length gene. As cells in her ovaries undergo meiosis, her resulting eggs (ova) may have which of the following?

options.text: either one blue or one orange allele in addition to either one long or one short allele
one chromosome 12 with one blue allele of the wing color gene and one chromosome 19 with one long allele of the antennae length gene
either two number 12 chromosomes with blue alleles or two with orange alleles
either two number 19 chromosomes with long alleles or two with short alleles

questions.comments: A diploid organism has two sets of chromosomes, meaning that it has two copies of each gene in its somatic cells (remember that somatic cells are all the cells in an organism, except for the gametes and the cells that produce the gametes). Slightly different versions of the same gene are known as “alleles”. So, for each gene, a diploid organism can have either two copies of the same allele or two different alleles of that gene. During meiosis, the pairs of homologous chromosomes separate and the daughter cells that result at the end of meiosis have only one set of chromosomes and therefore only one allele of each gene. In this example, the female in question has two copies of the same allele for both genes being studied. As a result, every gamete (egg cell) produced by that female will have one blue allele of the wing color gene on chromosome 12 and one long allele of the antennae length gene on chromosome 19.

During meiosis, the pairs of homologous chromosomes separate and the daughter cells that result at the end of meiosis have only one set of chromosomes and therefore only one allele of each gene. In this example, the female in question has two copies of the same allele for both genes being studied. As a result, every gamete (egg cell) produced by that female will have one blue allele of the wing color gene on chromosome 12 and one long allele of the antennae length gene on chromosome 19.

options.text: The statement is true for mitosis and meiosis I.
The statement is true for mitosis and meiosis II.
The statement is true for mitosis.
The statement is true for meiosis I.

questions.comments: Mitosis results in production of daughter cells that are clones of each other, meaning that they carry the same DNA. In contrast, during meiosis I each daughter cells receives only one of each pair of homologous chromosomes carried by the original cell. Therefore the daughter cells produced by meiosis I end up with different DNA.

questions.raw_html_question: A given organism has 46 chromosomes in its somatic cells. We can therefore conclude which of the following?
questions.question: A given organism has 46 chromosomes in its somatic cells. We can therefore conclude which of the following?

options.text: It must be sexually reproducing.
It must be an animal.
Its gametes must have 23 chromosomes.
It must be human.

questions.comments: Somatic cells are all the cells in an organism except for the gametes (i.e. sperm and egg cells) and the cells that give rise to the gametes. Regardless of whether an organism is diploid (i.e. has two sets of chromosomes in each somatic cell), tetraploid (i.e. has four sets of chromosomes in each somatic cell), etc., the gametes produced by that organism will have half as many chromosomes as the somatic cells produced by that organism. Therefore, if the organism has 46 chromosomes in its somatic cells, it will have 23 chromosomes in its gametes. In contrast, the fact that an organism has 46 chromosomes in its somatic cells does not mean that the organism must be human or some kind of animal. A number of species, including both animal and plant species, have somatic cells with 46 chromosomes. Also, because diverse species have somatic cells with 46 chromosomes, the fact that an organism has 46 chromosomes does not mean that the organism must reproduce sexually.
questions.raw_html_comments: Somatic cells are all the cells in an organism except for the gametes (i.e. sperm and egg cells) and the cells that give rise to the gametes. Therefore, if the organism has 46 chromosomes in its somatic cells, it will have 23 chromosomes in its gametes. questions.raw_html_question: You have isolated DNA from three different cell types of an organism, determined the relative DNA content for each type, and plotted the results on the graph shown below. Which sample might represent an animal cell in the G2 phase of the cell cycle?
questions.question: You have isolated DNA from three different cell types of an organism, determined the relative DNA content for each type, and plotted the results on the graph shown below. Which sample might represent an animal cell in the G2 phase of the cell cycle?

options.text: both I and II
III
II
I

questions.comments: Somatic cells are all the cells in an organism, except for the gametes and the cells that give rise to the gametes. The amount of DNA per somatic cells doubles during S phase, as the cells replicate their DNA. The amount of DNA remains at this level throughout G2 phase, and then is cut in half part way through mitosis as the cell divides and each of the resulting daughter cells receives half of the DNA. So, somatic cells in G1 and G0 (remember that G0 is the phase that G1 cells enter if they don’t pass the checkpoint at the end of G1 that would allow them to enter the S phase) have half as much DNA as somatic cells during G2 and the first part of mitosis. During meiosis, two rounds of cell division occur with only one round of DNA synthesis. As a result, the gametes formed by meiosis have only half as much DNA as a somatic cell during the G1 or G0 phases, and only a quarter as much DNA as a somatic cell during G2 or the earlier part of mitosis. Therefore, sample I represents somatic cells in G1, G0 or the last part of mitosis. Sample II represents somatic cells in G2 or the earlier part of mitosis. Sample III represents gametes.
questions.raw_html_comments: Somatic cells are all the cells in an organism, except for the gametes and the cells that give rise to the gametes. The amount of DNA per somatic cells doubles during S phase, as the cells replicate their DNA. The amount of DNA remains at this level throughout G2 phase, and then is cut in half part way through mitosis as the cell divides and each of the resulting daughter cells receives half of the DNA. So, somatic cells in G1 and G0 (remember that G0 is the phase that G1 cells enter if they don’t pass the checkpoint at the end of G1 that would allow them to enter the S phase) have half as much DNA as somatic cells during G2 and the first part of mitosis. During meiosis, two rounds of cell division occur with only one round of DNA synthesis. As a result, the gametes formed by meiosis have only half as much DNA as a somatic cell during the G1 or G0 phases, and only a quarter as much DNA as a somatic cell during G2 or the earlier part of mitosis. Therefore, sample I represents somatic cells in G1, G0 or the last part of mitosis. Sample II represents somatic cells in G2 or the earlier part of mitosis. Sample III represents gametes.

questions.comments: If a diploid cell of this species has 42 chromosomes, that means cells of this species usually have 21 pairs of homologous chromosomes. If something happens to make a cell triploid, that means that the cell will now have 3, rather than the normal 2, sets of chromosomes. So, the cell will have 63 chromosomes, with 21 groups of homologs chromosomes, with 3 chromosomes per group.

questions.raw_html_question: If an organism is diploid and a certain gene found in the organism has 18 known alleles (variants), then any given organism of that species can/must have which of the following?
questions.question: If an organism is diploid and a certain gene found in the organism has 18 known alleles (variants), then any given organism of that species can/must have which of the following?

at most, 2 alleles for that gene

questions.comments: Alleles are different versions of the same gene that differ slightly in their DNA sequences. A diploid organism has two sets of chromosomes, meaning that it has two copies of each gene. Therefore, for any particular gene a diploid organism can have two copies of the same allele of that gene or one copy of each of two different alleles. The fact that there are 18 known alleles of a particular gene does not provide us with any information regarding the number of chromosomes possessed by the organism being studied.

questions.raw_html_question: Independent assortment of chromosomes occurs.
questions.question: Independent assortment of chromosomes occurs.

options.text: The statement is true for meiosis I only.
The statement is true for mitosis only.
The statement is true for meiosis I and meiosis II.
The statement is true for meiosis II only.

questions.comments: During meiosis I, pairs of homologous chromosomes line up together in the center of the cell, at the metaphase plate. How each pair of chromosomes orient is random, meaning that the paternal chromosome of one pair might be nearer the top of the cell while the maternal chromosome of a different pair might be nearer the top of the cell. As a result, the maternal and paternal chromosomes of each pair assort independently into the daughter cells. This is known as “independent assortment of chromosomes”.
questions.raw_html_comments: During meiosis I, pairs of homologous chromosomes line up together in the center of the cell, at the metaphase plate. How each pair of chromosomes orient is random, meaning that the paternal chromosome of one pair might be nearer the top of the cell while the maternal chromosome of a different pair might be nearer the top of the cell. As a result, the maternal and paternal chromosomes of each pair assort independently into the daughter cells. This is known as “independent assortment of chromosomes”.

questions.raw_html_question: The human genome is minimally contained in which of the following?
questions.question: The human genome is minimally contained in which of the following?

options.text: the entire human population
the entire DNA of a single human
each human chromosome
every human cell

questions.comments: Every human cell contains a complete copy of the human genome. A single chromosome would contain only part of the human genome. The complete human genome is contained within the entire DNA of a single human and within the entire human population, but is not MINIMALLY contained within either of these.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is a true statement about sexual vs. asexual reproduction?
questions.question: Which of the following is a true statement about sexual vs. asexual reproduction?

options.text: Asexual reproduction, but not sexual reproduction, is characteristic of plants and fungi.
In asexual reproduction, offspring are produced by fertilization without meiosis.
Asexual reproduction produces only haploid offspring.
In sexual reproduction, individuals transmit 50% of their genes to each of their offspring.

questions.comments: Many plant and fungal species make use of both asexual and sexual reproduction. Asexual reproduction occurs without fertilization (e.g. by mitosis). Asexual reproduction results in offspring that are genetically identical to the parent, and so contain as much DNA as the parent. Therefore, if the parent was diploid, the offspring produced via asexual reproduction will also be diploid. It is true that during sexual reproduction parents transmit 50% of their genes to their offspring. This happens because during the process of meiosis the parents produce germ cells (either sperm or egg cells) each of which contain only 50% of the DNA present in the somatic (non-germ) cells of the parent.
questions.raw_html_comments: Many plant and fungal species make use of both asexual and sexual reproduction. Asexual reproduction occurs without fertilization (e.g. by mitosis). Asexual reproduction results in offspring that are genetically identical to the parent, and so contain as much DNA as the parent. Therefore, if the parent was diploid, the offspring produced via asexual reproduction will also be diploid. It is true that during sexual reproduction parents transmit 50% of their genes to their offspring. This happens because during the process of meiosis the parents produce germ cells (either sperm or egg cells) each of which contain only 50% of the DNA present in the somatic (non-germ) cells of the parent.

questions.raw_html_question:
Which of the following steps takes place in both mitosis and meiosis?

1.  Formation of four new nuclei, each with half the chromosomes present in the parental nucleus

2.  Alignment of homologous chromosomes at the metaphase plate

3.  Separation of sister chromatids

4.  Separation of the homologs; no uncoupling of the centromere

5.  Synapsis; chromosomes moving to the middle of the cell in pairs
questions.question: Which of the following steps takes place in both mitosis and meiosis? 1.  Formation of four new nuclei, each with half the chromosomes present in the parental nucleus 2.  Alignment of homologous chromosomes at the metaphase plate 3.  Separation of sister chromatids 4.  Separation of the homologs; no uncoupling of the centromere 5.  Synapsis; chromosomes moving to the middle of the cell in pairs

options.text: 2 and 3 only

questions.comments: Mitosis results in formation of daughter cells with the same number of chromosomes found in the parental nucleus. Homologous chromosomes align at the metaphase plate during meiosis, but not during mitosis. Separation of sister chromatids occurs both during mitosis and meiosis II. Separation of homologous chromosomes with sister chromatids still stuck together at the centromere occurs during meiosis I, but not during mitosis. Synapsis occurs only during meiosis.
questions.raw_html_comments: Mitosis results in formation of daughter cells with the same number of chromosomes found in the parental nucleus. Homologous chromosomes align at the metaphase plate during meiosis, but not during mitosis. Separation of sister chromatids occurs both during mitosis and meiosis II. Separation of homologous chromosomes with sister chromatids still stuck together at the centromere occurs during meiosis I, but not during mitosis. Synapsis occurs only during meiosis.

questions.comments: Grades in BIOL 1009 are determined using "guaranteed point cutoffs". This means that every student in the course who earns more than a certain number of points is guaranteed to receive at least a certain letter grade. In other words, the cutoffs will NOT be raised, even if that means that every student earns a final course grade of "A". The course syllabus describes the number of points that may be earned for each course activity and lists the number of points that need to be earned (i.e. the "guaranteed point cutoffs") in order to earn different final course grades. Please note that grades are NOT curved in BIOL 1009. You can download a copy of the course syllabus from the course Canvas page.

Scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on exams or plagiarism, is not tolerated in this course. BIOL 1009 is a required course for almost all students taking it. questions.question: Scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on exams or plagiarism, is not tolerated in this course. BIOL 1009 is a required course for almost all students taking it. Because scholastic dishonesty is not tolerated in this course, students found to have committed scholastic dishonesty, such as cheating on an exam:

options.text: will receive a grade of "0" on the exam or assignment affected by the dishonesty and will be reported to the university's Office of Community Standards.
will be given an opportunity to make up some or all of the points they lost by getting a "0" on an exam or other assignment.
will be given a second chance if they promise not to do it again.

questions.raw_html_question: Regarding the online quizzes:
questions.question: Regarding the online quizzes:

options.text: If you forget the deadline for a quiz, you can take it late
If you are about to submit a quiz right before the deadline and the power or internet goes out (i.e. something happens that was completely outside of your control), you can take the quiz late
If you are sick when a quiz is due, you can take it late

Quizzes must be completed on time, by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. For that reason, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. That way, if you forget a quiz or your internet quits or something, you will not have to take a zero on a quiz.

questions.comments: Quizzes must be taken on time by the dates listed on the last page of the course syllabus. Because “stuff happens”, each student's three lowest quiz scores will automatically be dropped. So, if you do miss a quiz for any reason, that quiz will simply count as one of your three dropped quizzes and you won't have to take a zero on that quiz. To avoid missing quizzes, it is strongly recommended that you take each quiz at least once at least a day before that quiz is due. Conversely, it is strongly recommended that you NOT wait until shortly before a quiz is due to attempt it for the first time. Remember, you can take each quiz up to three times with only your highest score counting, so it makes sense to take each quiz at least once a day or two before it's due so it won't matter so much if it slips your mind the day it's due.

questions.raw_html_question: A hypothesis
questions.question: A hypothesis

options.text: is a prediction scientists make based on many careful observations
is a tentative answer to a question
is the same thing as a theory
is a specific question formulated by scientists after making many careful observations

questions.comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. Ideally, hypothesis-based science is carried out in the following steps: 1) Make observations. 2) Ask a question about those observations. 3) Form one or more hypotheses (= tentative answers to the question). 4) Make predictions based on the hypotheses. 5) Test predictions (e.g. by doing experiments). 6) Determine whether the results of the tests do or do not falsify the hypothesis. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.
questions.raw_html_comments: A hypothesis is a tentative answer to a question. NOTE: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead, depending on the results, tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false.

questions.raw_html_question: A hypothesis
questions.question: A hypothesis

options.text: can NOT be proven to be correct
can be proven to be correct or incorrect, depending on experimental results
can be proven to be correct
can NOT be proven to be correct or incorrect, regardless of experimental results

questions.comments: It is not possible to PROVE that a hypothesis is correct. Instead the results of tests (experiments) may only show that a particular hypothesis is false. For example, if your hypothesis for why a flashlight isn’t working is that the batteries are dead, you might predict that replacing the batteries will fix the flashlight. If you then test your prediction by replacing the batteries and find that the flashlight still does not work, you have disproven your original prediction that replacing the batteries would fix the flashlight and have thus shown your hypothesis to be incorrect (false). However, if the flashlight works after you replace the batteries, that finding does not prove that your hypothesis was correct. This is because you can still come up with alternative hypotheses for why the flashlight now works. For example, you could hypothesize that the reason the flashlight wasn’t working previously was because the original batteries were inserted incorrectly. Then, when you replaced the batteries, you inserted the new batteries correctly and so fixed the flashlight. If that is the case, then your original hypothesis that the old batteries were dead would be false. The bottom line is that we can never rule out that there might be a different hypothesis that also explains all of the available experimental results and that is actually the correct hypothesis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements best distinguishes hypotheses from theories in science?

options.text: Hypotheses usually are relatively narrow in scope; theories have broad explanatory power.

questions.comments: Neither theories nor hypotheses can be proven correct beyond a shadow of a doubt. Although theories are supported by a large body of evidence, they sometimes need to be modified as new data become available. Theories are broader in scope than hypotheses.

questions.raw_html_question: Experimentation is only one part of the process of scientific inquiry, but it is a very important step because it
questions.question: Experimentation is only one part of the process of scientific inquiry, but it is a very important step because it

options.text: gives the investigator a systematic, unbiased result
allows rejection of a hypothesis
ensures that the variable being tested is measured without error
ensures that hypotheses can be confirmed with certainty

questions.comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. Therefore, if the prediction is shown to be false, that result indicates that the hypothesis on which the prediction was based is also false. Carrying out experiments does not ensure that a hypothesis will be supported. Because hypotheses are only POSSIBLE answers to questions, many hypotheses turn out to be incorrect. In addition, it is not possible to prove that a hypothesis is correct as there will always be alternative explanations for why testing showed that a particular prediction was correct. Experiments don’t necessarily give investigators systematic unbiased results; it depends on how the experiments are designed and conducted. Similarly, it is difficult or impossible to ensure that variables being tested are measured without error.
questions.raw_html_comments: Experiments are designed to test predictions. The prediction being tested is based on a hypothesis. questions.comments: The carbon atom will form one covalent bond with each of the 4 hydrogen atoms. Each of the pairs of electrons forming these covalent bonds will be in one of the 4 orbitals that lie within the 2nd electron shell, and that point towards the 4 corners of a tetrahedron. This gives the molecule a roughly pyramidal shape.

options.text: neither a compound nor a molecule

questions.comments: Molecules are substances that consist of two or more atoms joined by covalent bonds. This definition applies to water, as water molecules consist of two hydrogen atoms, each joined to an oxygen atom by a covalent bond. questions.comments: All of these answers are correct. A mole is 6.02 X 1023. A hydrogen atom weighs one Dalton so one mole of hydrogen atoms weighs 1 g. One mole of hydrogen molecules (H2) weighs 2 g. This is because hydrogen molecules have the formula: H2. questions.raw_html_question: What is the pH of a solution with a hydroxyl ion [OH<sup>-</sup>] concentration of 10<sup>-4.5 </sup>M?
questions.question: What is the pH of a solution with a hydroxyl ion [OH-] concentration of 10-4.5 M?

options.text: pH 2
pH 12
pH 9.5
pH 4.5

questions.comments: Remember that the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 M (moles per liter) in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydroxyl ion concentration is 10-4.5 M, the hydrogen ion concentration must be 10-14/10-4.5= 10-9.5 M. The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration. The base 10 logarithm of 10-9.5 is -9.5, so the negative logarithm of 10-9.5is 9.5. Therefore, the pH of this solution is 9.5.

questions.raw_html_question: How many covalent bonds do nitrogen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.question: How many covalent bonds do nitrogen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.comments: Nitrogen atoms have 5 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so nitrogen needs to form 3 covalent bonds with other atoms so that it has 3 pairs of electrons that it is sharing via covalent bonds and one pair of electrons that it is not sharing, for a total of 4 pairs of electrons, or 8 total electrons.

The valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has.
The valence shell is the outermost electron shell of an atom.

questions.comments: Each atom has only one valence shell, corresponding to its outermost electron shell. Because the electrons in the valence shell are the outermost electrons and the energy level of an electron increases the further it is from the nucleus, the valence shell is the highest energy electron shell an atom has. Also, because atoms react to complete their valence shells, the valence electrons are primarily responsible for the chemical behavior of atoms.

questions.raw_html_question: What gives rise to the cohesiveness of water molecules?
questions.question: What gives rise to the cohesiveness of water molecules?

options.text: Nonpolar covalent bonds
Hydrogen bonds
Ionic bonds
Hydrophobic interactions

questions.comments: Water molecules stick to each other because the oxygen atom in a water molecule carries a partial negative charge and the two hydrogen atoms each carry a partial positive charge. As a result, the partially positively charged hydrogen atoms of one water molecule are attracted to the partially negatively charged oxygen atoms of other water molecules. The reason that the hydrogen atoms carry partial positive charges and the oxygen atoms carry partial negative charges is that the covalent bonds within a water molecule are polar. Each electron pair forming a covalent bond between an oxygen atom and a hydrogen atom spends more time near oxygen than near hydrogen, as oxygen atoms are more electronegative than hydrogen atoms.

questions.raw_html_question: When a sodium atom and a chlorine atom interact to complete their valence shells
questions.question: When a sodium atom and a chlorine atom interact to complete their valence shells

options.text: an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into a cation and the chlorine atom into an anion and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond
they form 1 polar covalent bond
they form 2 polar covalent bonds
an electron is transferred from sodium to chlorine, turning the sodium atom into an anion and the chlorine atom into a cation and allowing the two atoms to form an ionic bond

questions.comments: Chlorine is so much more electronegative than sodium that, rather than sharing a pair of electrons, the lone electron in the valence (= 3rd) shell of sodium is transferred to chlorine. That leaves the sodium cation with no electrons in the 3rd electron shell and a full set (8) of electrons in the 2nd electron shell. The 1 electron transferred to the chlorine atom is sufficient to complete the valence shell of that atom. Because chlorine now has one more electron than it has protons, the chlorine anion will have a charge of negative 1. Negatively charged ions are called “anions” and positively charged ions are called “cations”.

questions.raw_html_question: The further on average an electron is from the nucleus
questions.question: The further on average an electron is from the nucleus

options.text: the greater its potential energy
the more highly charged it is
the less highly charged it is
the lower its potential energy

questions.comments: The further an electron is from the nucleus, the greater its potential energy. Think of it this way. Negatively charged electrons are attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus. So, it takes work to increase the separation between an electron and the nucleus. Some of the energy spent in doing this work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron. This is conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a hill.

questions.question: The lowest energy mechanism by which a carbon atom may complete its valence shell is to

options.text: transfer the 4 electrons in its valence shell to other atoms or transfer 4 electrons from other atoms to its valence shell
transfer the 2 electrons in its valence shell to other atoms or transfer 2 electrons from other atoms to its valence shell
form 2 covalent bonds with other atoms
form 4 covalent bonds with other atoms

questions.comments: Forming only 2 covalent bonds with other atoms would not be sufficient for a carbon atom to complete its shell, as carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell (= the 2nd electron shell) and 8 electrons are needed to complete that shell. In theory the outermost shell could be completed by transferring 4 electrons from other atoms, but in practice this would leave the carbon atom with 4 more electrons than protons which is very unfavorable energetically. In theory the outermost shell could also be completed by transferring 4 electrons FROM carbon to other atoms, in which case the carbon atom would have no electrons in its 2nd shell and 2 electrons in its 1st shell, which would make the 1st shell its outermost, or valence, shell and that shell would be complete since it only takes 2 electrons to fill the 1st electron shell. However, this situation would leave the carbon atom with 4 less electrons than protons, which is a big difference in the number of electrons and protons and is extremely unstable in this case.
questions.raw_html_comments: Forming only 2 covalent bonds with other atoms would not be sufficient for a carbon atom to complete its shell, as carbon atoms have 4 electrons in their valence shell (= the 2nd electron shell) and 8 electrons are needed to complete that shell. In theory the outermost shell could be completed by transferring 4 electrons from other atoms, but in practice this would leave the carbon atom with 4 more electrons than protons which is very unfavorable energetically. In theory the outermost shell could also be completed by transferring 4 electrons FROM carbon to other atoms, in which case the carbon atom would have no electrons in its 2nd shell and 2 electrons in its 1st shell, which would make the 1st shell its outermost, or valence, shell and that shell would be complete since it only takes 2 electrons to fill the 1st electron shell. However, this situation would leave the carbon atom with 4 less electrons than protons, which is a big difference in the number of electrons and protons and is extremely unstable in this case.

questions.raw_html_question: Depending on how far an electron is moved from the nucleus
questions.question: Depending on how far an electron is moved from the nucleus

options.text: you can decrease its potential energy by any amount
you can decrease its potential energy by only certain amounts
you can increase its potential energy by any amount
you can increase its potential energy by only certain amounts

questions.comments: The potential energy of electrons increases the further they are from the nucleus. However, electrons may only occupy certain defined orbitals that have certain defined average distances from the nucleus and thus certain energy levels. Think of it like a ball being moved up or down a set of steps. If a ball is moved up two steps its energy level will increase twice as much as if it is moved up one step (assuming the steps are of equal height). However, it is not feasible to increase the potential energy of the ball by 0.5 or 1.5 steps.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements about electrons is FALSE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements about electrons is FALSE?

options.text: two electrons may occupy the same electron orbital
electrons are negatively charged
the closer an electron is to the nucleus, the more strongly the electron is attracted to the nucleus and therefore the more potential energy the electron has
electrons are attracted to nuclei by the positive charges of the protons in the nuclei

questions.comments: It is true that the closer an electron is to the nucleus, the more strongly the electron is attracted to the nucleus. However, it is NOT true that an electron has more potential energy when it is closer to the nucleus. In fact, it will have less potential energy the closer it gets to the nucleus. Think of it this way, the further from the earth you send a rocket, the less strongly it is attracted to the earth by gravity, but the more potential energy it has.

questions.raw_html_question: If you make a model of a water molecule, the lines showing the relative positions of the covalent bonds will most closely resemble
questions.question: If you make a model of a water molecule, the lines showing the relative positions of the covalent bonds will most closely resemble

options.text: a straight line
it depends on the water molecule
a “T”
a wide “V”

questions.comments: In a water molecule, each hydrogen atom is connected to the one oxygen atom by a covalent bond. The oxygen atom thus has a complete valence shell, with 2 pairs of electrons shared in covalent bonds and 2 unshared pairs of electrons. Since the 4 orbitals occupied by these 4 pairs of electrons point towards the 4 corners of a tetrahedron, the 2 pairs of electrons that form the 2 covalent bonds will point towards 2 of the corners of a tetrahedron and will thus form roughly a wide “V” shape.

questions.raw_html_question: A solution with a pH of 10 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH<sup>-</sup>]?
questions.question: A solution with a pH of 10 contains what concentration of hydroxyl ions [OH-]?

options.text: 0.01 moles/liter
10-10 moles/liter
0.0001 moles/liter
10 moles/liter

questions.comments: The pH of a solution is equal to the negative logarithm (base 10) of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. In other words, pH = - log [H+]. So, in this case: 10 = - log [H+]. Or, -10 = log [H+]. Or, 10-10 M = [H+]. Furthermore, the concentration of hydroxyl ions times the concentration of hydrogen ions always equals 10-14 in aqueous solutions (at least around room temperature). So, if the hydrogen ion concentration is 10-10M (moles per liter), the hydroxyl ion concentration must be 10-14/10-10= 10-4 M, or 0.0001 M, or 0.0001 moles/liter.

options.text: a compound
a molecule
an anion

questions.comments: Molecules are substances that consist of two or more atoms joined by covalent bonds. This definition applies to oxygen gas, as oxygen gas consists of two oxygen atoms that are joined to each other by two covalent bonds. Compounds are defined as substances consisting of two or more different elements combined in a fixed ratio. Because the atoms in oxygen gas all belong to the same element (oxygen), oxygen gas is not a compound.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements is most broadly true of different elements?
questions.question: Which of the following statements is most broadly true of different elements?

options.text: The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on the electrons in their second electron shell.
The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on their valence electrons.
The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on the electrons in their first electron shell.
The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on the electrons in their third electron shell.

questions.comments: The chemical behavior of atoms is mostly dependent on their valence electrons, which are the electrons in their outermost, or valence, electron shell. Depending on the number of electrons the atoms of a particular element have, the electrons may be sufficient to fill only the 1st electron shell, leaving the 1st shell as the outermost shell. Atoms of elements with more electrons may have sufficient electrons to fill the first electron shell and to partially or fully fill the 2nd shell, but not to place any electrons in the 3rd electron shell. In that case, the 2ndshell would be the outermost shell that has electrons and would thus be the valence shell.

In that case, the 2nd
shell would be the outermost shell that has electrons and would thus be the valence shell.

questions.raw_html_question: How many covalent bonds do hydrogen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.question: How many covalent bonds do hydrogen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.comments: Hydrogen atoms have 1 electron in their valence shell, which is the 1stelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 1stelectron shell is 2, so hydrogen needs to form one covalent bond with another atom in order to fill its valence shell. Alternatively, hydrogen can “fill” its valence shell by transferring its one electron to another atom. You might expect that hydrogen could also fill its valence shell by transferring an electron FROM another atom, but that would leave the hydrogen with 2 electrons and only one proton which, it turns out, is energetically unfavorable.
questions.raw_html_comments:

electron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 1st
electron shell is 2, so hydrogen needs to form one covalent bond with another atom in order to fill its valence shell. Alternatively, hydrogen can “fill” its valence shell by transferring its one electron to another atom. You might expect that hydrogen could also fill its valence shell by transferring an electron FROM another atom, but that would leave the hydrogen with 2 electrons and only one proton which, it turns out, is energetically unfavorable.

questions.raw_html_question: Carbon atoms typically complete their valence shells by
questions.question: Carbon atoms typically complete their valence shells by

options.text: transferring four electrons from other atoms
forming ionic bonds with H+ cations
transferring four electrons to other atoms
forming four covalent bonds with other atoms

questions.comments: Transferring four electrons to other atoms would leave the carbon atom with a charge of plus 4, which would make it quite unstable. Similarly, transferring four electrons from other atoms would leave the carbon atom with a charge of negative 4, which would also make it quite unstable. Instead, carbon atoms complete their valence shell by forming four covalent bonds.

questions.raw_html_question: If two molecules have the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures, the two molecules may be
questions.question: If two molecules have the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures, the two molecules may be

options.text: Geometric isomers
Structural isomers
Enantiomers
All of these answers are correct

questions.comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.comments: Isomers of any type (structural isomers, geometric isomers and enantiomers) must all meet the criteria of having the same number of atoms of the same elements but different structures. Structural isomers have the further criteria that, for two molecules to be structural isomers of each other, they must differ in their covalent partnerships. In contrast, molecules that are geometric isomers or enantiomers do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships. Geometric isomers differ in the arrangement of atoms around a double bond. Enantiomers differ in the arrangement of atoms covalently bound to a central, asymmetric carbon and are mirror images of each other. Please see figure 4.7 in your textbook for a figure showing all three types of isomer.

questions.comments: These two molecules have the same formula (CN2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. In addition, because these molecules do not have 2 carbon atoms joined by a double bond, they cannot be geometric isomers. Instead, they are “enantiomers”. Enantiomers are mirror images of each other and cannot be superimposed on each other. This is quite similar to how our hands are mirror images of each other, but cannot be superimposed on each other. For example, imagine the palms of your hands as being carbon atom and the four fingers on each hand representing covalent bonds to 4 different groups. There is no way to place one hand on the other hand so that all four of your fingers will match up. Note that enantiomers only occur in molecules that have an asymmetric carbon. For a carbon to be asymmetric, it must form covalent bonds to 4 different groups.

questions.raw_html_question: The molecules shown below are best described as
questions.question: The molecules shown below are best described as

options.text: Structural isomers
Geometric isomers
Isotopes
Enantiomers

questions.comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one hydroxyl (OH) group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two hydroxyl (OH) groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two hydroxyl groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the hydroxyl groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.
questions.raw_html_comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2O2H4), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but have different 3-dimensional shapes. questions.question: Identify the asymmetric carbon in this molecule

options.text: It is the 3rd carbon from the left
It is the 2nd carbon from the left
It is the 1st carbon on the left
It is the 4th carbon from the left

questions.comments: Asymmetric carbons are carbons that are covalently bonded to 4 different groups. The 1st carbon on the left in this molecule is bonded to only 3 different groups (a hydrogen atom, an oxygen atom and a hydrocarbon chain). The 3rd carbon is also bonded to only 3 different groups (two hydrogen atoms, a short hydrocarbon chain and the part of the molecule that is to the left of that carbon atom). The 4th carbon from the left is only bound to 3 different groups (2 hydrogen atoms, a methyl group and the rest of the molecule that is to the left of the 4th carbon). The 5th (last) carbon from the left is only bonded to 2 different groups as it forms covalent bonds with 3 hydrogen atoms and the rest of the molecule that is to the left of the 5th carbon. In contrast, the 2nd carbon from the left is bound to 4 different groups: a COH group, a hydrogen atom, an OH group and a short hydrocarbon chain. Each of the four different groups to which the second carbon from the left is bound is shown circled in red in the figure below.

questions.comments: These two molecules have the same formula (C2N2O2H2), meaning they have the same number of atoms of the same elements, but different 3-dimensional shapes. So, they are isomers of some sort. Because they have the same covalent arrangements of their atoms (i.e. which atoms are attached to which other atoms), they are not structural isomers. For example, both carbon atoms in both molecules are attached to one N=O group and one hydrogen atom. However, the two molecules do have different structures. Remember that double covalent bonds are inflexible. So, the above molecules cannot rotate around their double bonds in the way that they could if the two carbon atoms were only joined by single covalent bonds. So, in the molecule on the left, the two N=O groups will always be on the opposite sides of the double bond, whereas the two N=O groups will always be on the same side of the double bond in the molecule on the right. Molecules such as these two, which have the same covalent partnerships but different spatial arrangements, are known as geometric isomers. The molecule on the left, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on opposite sides of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a trans isomer. The molecule on the right, which has the two groups that are not hydrogen atoms (i.e. the N=O groups) on the same side of the double bond between the carbon atoms is known as a cis isomer.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements is FALSE?

options.text: Nucleotides are the monomers from which nucleic acids are formed.
Fatty acids are the monomers from which lipid molecules are formed.
Amino acids are the monomers from which proteins are formed.
Sugars are the monomers from which polysaccharides are formed.

questions.comments: Fatty acids are important in lipid formation, but are not monomers as monomers are simple molecules, many of which are combined to form a polymer. In contrast, fatty acids are fairly large molecules and few of them are used to make a lipid molecule. For example, just two fatty acid molecules are used in the synthesis of a typical membrane lipid molecule (e.g. a phospholipid) and just three fatty acid molecules are used to make a typical lipid molecule in fat (e.g. a triacylglycerol molecule). In addition, monomers are linked together like cars forming a train to form a polymer. In contrast, the fatty acid molecules that are used to form lipids are not joined to each other. For example, the three fatty acid molecules used to form a triacylglycerol molecule (a type of lipid molecule) are each joined separately to different parts of a glycerol molecule. So, remember that lipids are the one type of biological macromolecule we will discuss that are NOT polymers because they are NOT composed of monomers.

questions.raw_html_question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is two monomers long (ok, that wouldn’t really be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?
