questions.comments: You could build 4 different polymers: A-A, B-B, A-B and B-A. You might wonder if A-B and B-A are really the same thing. They are not the same thing because one end of a polymer has a hydrogen attached and the other end of the polymer has a hydroxyl group. In other words, you could write the above molecules as: H-O-A-B-H and H-O-B-A-H, which makes it clear that they are not the same molecule.

questions.raw_html_question: L-methionine and D-methionine are examples of
questions.question: L-methionine and D-methionine are examples of

options.text: geometric isomers
enantiomers
all of these answers are correct
structural isomers

questions.comments: All amino acids except glycine have an asymmetric carbon, meaning a carbon atom that is covalently bound to 4 different groups. In the case of all amino acids except glycine, those groups are: a carboxyl group, an amino group, a hydrogen and an "R" group. The reason that glycine does not have an asymmetric carbon is because the R group of glycine is hydrogen. So, the central carbon of a glycine molecule is only bound to 3 different groups, since it is bound to two hydrogen atoms. Molecules with asymmetric carbons may occur as two different isomers, known as enantiomers. Enantiomers have the same covalent partnerships (i.e. they do NOT differ in which elements are covalently bound to which other elements), but are instead mirror images of each other. L-methionine and D-methionine meet this definition and so are enantiomers. Please see figure 4.7 in your book for a figure illustrating the different types of isomers.

questions.comments: Lipids that contain one or more C=C double bonds are referred to as unsaturated fats or lipids. Triacylglycerols are made by attaching three fatty acid molecules to a glycerol molecule. The fatty acids used in synthesis of triacylglycerols may or may not contain C=C double bonds. Similarly, phospholipids contain two fatty acid molecules, a glycerol molecule and a head group. The fatty acids used in synthesis of phospholipids may or may not contain C=C double bonds.

questions.comments: Glucose and fructose have the same molecular formula (C6H12O6), but different shapes, so you can see that they are isomers of some sort. To determine what type of isomers they represent, first look to see if the two molecules (glucose and fructose), share the same covalent partnerships. If you look at them, you will see that they do not share the same covalent partnerships. For example, the position of the carbon:oxygen double bond (C=O) is different for glucose and fructose. This means that glucose and fructose are examples of structural isomers. The other two types of isomers we studied, geometric isomers and enantiomers, do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.
questions.raw_html_comments: Glucose and fructose have the same molecular formula (C6H12O6), but different shapes, so you can see that they are isomers of some sort. To determine what type of isomers they represent, first look to see if the two molecules (glucose and fructose), share the same covalent partnerships. If you look at them, you will see that they do not share the same covalent partnerships. For example, the position of the carbon:oxygen double bond (C=O) is different for glucose and fructose. This means that glucose and fructose are examples of structural isomers. The other two types of isomers we studied, geometric isomers and enantiomers, do NOT differ in their covalent partnerships.

questions.raw_html_question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?
questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, how many different polymers could you build?

options.text: ~ 1 billion

questions.comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 30 monomers long, and you could use two different types of monomers, “A” and “B”, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 230 = ~ 1,000,000,000

questions.question: If you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long (note that this would be an unusually short polymer), and you could use four different types of monomers, “A”, “B”, “C” and “D”, how many different polymers could you build?

options.text: ~ 1 million

questions.comments: Think of it this way: If you were asked to build a polymer that was just one monomer long (ok, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and you had only “A” and “B” monomers available to use, you would be able to build just two different “polymers”: A and B. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 2 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 4 different “polymers”: AA, AB, BA and BB. If you were asked to build a polymer that was just 3 monomers long (again, that wouldn’t be a polymer, but let’s ignore that for the moment), and had only “A” and “B” monomers available, you would be able to build just 8 different “polymers”: AAA, AAB, ABA, BAA, ABB, BAB. BBA and BBB. Are you seeing a pattern here? The answer to this type of question may be found using the following formula: Number of different polymers that may be formed = XY, where “X” is the number of different types of monomers available and “Y” is the number of monomers in the polymer. So, if you were asked to build a polymer that is 20 monomers long, and you could use four different types of monomers, the number of different polymers you could build would be: 420 = ~ 1 x 1012

questions.raw_html_question: How many water molecules are needed to completely hydrolyze a polymer that is 18 nucleotides long?
questions.question: How many water molecules are needed to completely hydrolyze a polymer that is 18 nucleotides long?
questions.comments: Think of it this way: How many water molecules would be needed to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is just two nucleotides long? You would need just one, to split the one bond joining the two monomers, right? So, how many water molecules would you need to completely hydrolyze a “polymer” that is 3 monomers long? The answer is that you would need 2 water molecules, one to split the bond between the 1stand 2nd monomers and the other to hydrolyze the bond between the 2ndand 3rd monomers. So, you to completely hydrolyze a polymer takes one less water molecule than the number of monomers in the polymer.

and 3rd monomers. So, you to completely hydrolyze a polymer takes one less water molecule than the number of monomers in the polymer.

questions.raw_html_question: A dehydration reaction joins two glucose molecules to form maltose. The formula for glucose is C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>O<sub>6</sub>.  What is the correct formula for maltose?
questions.question: A dehydration reaction joins two glucose molecules to form maltose. The formula for glucose is C6H12O6.  What is the correct formula for maltose?
questions.comments: You are joining two molecules of glucose to form maltose, so maltose will have twice as many atoms of each element as glucose, except that you have to remember that a water molecule is lost during the dehydration reaction. So, maltose will have 12 carbon atoms, but only 22 hydrogen atoms instead of 24 because of the two hydrogen atoms lost during formation of the water molecule. Similarly, maltose will have 11 oxygen atoms instead of 12, as one oxygen atom is used to form the water molecule.

questions.raw_html_question: Cell membranes are asymmetrical.  Which of the following is most likely to explain part of the reason for this asymmetry?
questions.question: Cell membranes are asymmetrical.  Which of the following is most likely to explain part of the reason for this asymmetry?

options.text: Cell membranes communicate signals from one cell to another.
Proteins can only span membranes if they are hydrophobic.
Cell membrane proteins are inserted into the rough ER membrane with a certain orientation as they are being synthesized.
The cell membrane forms a border between different cell types.

questions.comments: Integral membrane proteins are inserted into the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER) as they are being synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER. Because many of these proteins have both hydrophobic regions, which are embedded in the membrane, and hydrophilic regions, which are exposed to the aqueous environment inside or outside of the ER, they are not able to move randomly from one side of the membrane to the other after they are made. For example, if a membrane protein is synthesized such that the last part of the protein that is made is hydrophilic and is exposed on the outside of the ER membrane, that part of that protein will remain on the outside of the ER membrane and then on the outside of the vesicle that transports it to the Golgi, on the outside of the Golgi, on the outside of the vesicle that transports it the plasma membrane and then on the inside (cytoplasmic side) of the plasma membrane. It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.

It should be noted that the lipid compositions of the two halves of a lipid bilayer are not identical either, as lipid molecules very rarely flip-flop from one side of the bilayer to the other and different species of lipid molecules are synthesized in different amounts in the two halves of the bilayer.

questions.raw_html_question: A patient had a serious accident and lost a lot of blood.  In an attempt to replenish body fluids, distilled water, equal to the volume of blood lost, is transferred directly into one of his veins.  What will be the most probable result of this transfusion?
questions.question: A patient had a serious accident and lost a lot of blood.  In an attempt to replenish body fluids, distilled water, equal to the volume of blood lost, is transferred directly into one of his veins.  What will be the most probable result of this transfusion?

options.text: The patient’s red blood cells will shrink because the blood fluid is hypotonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will shrink because the blood fluid is hypertonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will swell, and possibly burst, because the blood fluid is hypotonic compared to the red blood cells.
The patient’s red blood cells will swell, and possibly burst, because the blood fluid is hypertonic compared to the red blood cells.

questions.comments: Pure water, which by definition contains no solutes, will be hypotonic compared to the solution inside of the patient’s red blood cells, which contain lots of solutes. That means that adding pure water to the patient’s blood stream will cause there to be more water molecules interacting with solute molecules inside of the red blood cells than outside. That in turn means that there will be fewer free water molecules inside of the patient’s red blood cells than outside of them. Water will thus flow into the red blood cells, causing the cells to swell and possibly burst.

questions.comments: Plasma membrane proteins are synthesized at the rough ER, which is called the “rough” ER because of all the ribosomes stuck to it. Smooth ER is not involved in the synthesis of plasma membrane proteins. After being synthesized in the rough ER and possibly having carbohydrates added, plasma membrane proteins are transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified and then transported via vesicles to the plasma membrane.

questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question.  The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier.  This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water but not to any ions.  If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, at equilibrium

options.text: there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will have been no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube
there will have been a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”
there will have been no movement of water molecules across the membrane

questions.comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. As a result, more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A and there will therefore be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. That, in turn, means there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until equilibrium is reached.

the cell will burst

questions.comments: Hypotonic solutions have a lower concentration of solutes. As a result, hypotonic solutions have fewer water molecules interacting with solute molecules and therefore have more free water molecules. Free water molecules will thus diffuse into the plant cell, causing it to expand against the cell wall, making it more solid, or turgid.

questions.raw_html_question: The two layers of a lipid bilayer
questions.question: The two layers of a lipid bilayer

options.text: none of these answers are correct
have almost identical lipid compositions as lipid molecules can move freely between the two layers
have both similar lipid and integral membrane protein compositions
are similar in terms of the types and numbers of their integral membrane proteins as proteins can move freely between the two layers

questions.comments: The two layers of a lipid bilayer have different lipid and different protein compositions. Remember that although lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane. Similarly, protein molecules may not be able to move between the two layers of a lipid bilayer.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is one of the ways that the membranes of winter wheat are able to remain fluid when it is extremely cold?

by increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids in the membrane
by increasing the percentage of cholesterol molecules in the membrane
by decreasing the number of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane

questions.comments: Increasing the percentage of unsaturated phospholipids make membranes more fluid, even at lower temperatures, by inhibiting close packing of the fatty acid chains of the molecules, thus disrupting hydrophobic interactions between the molecules. Cholesterol does lower the freezing temperatures of membranes in animal cells, but is not found in plant cells. The percentage of hydrophobic proteins in the membrane has little or no effect on the temperature at which the membrane will freeze.

questions.raw_html_question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question.  The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a semi-permeable barrier.  This semi-permeable barrier is permeable to water and glucose, but not to sucrose.  If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, after the system reaches equilibrium, what changes are observed?
questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question.  The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a semi-permeable barrier.  This semi-permeable barrier is permeable to water and glucose, but not to sucrose.  If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, after the system reaches equilibrium, what changes are observed?

options.text: The concentration of glucose on side A is less than 1 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is less than 1 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is less than 2 M.
The concentration of glucose on side A is 1.5 M and the concentration of sucrose on side A is 2 M.

questions.comments: Because the membrane is permeable to glucose, right after the solutions are added to the U-tube the rate at which glucose molecules move from side B to side A will be higher than the rate at which glucose molecules move from side A to side B. This will continue until the system reaches equilibrium, at which point there will be an equal concentration of glucose molecules on both sides of the tube. As the system started out with 1 l of a 1 M glucose solution and 1 l of a 2 M glucose solution, at equilibrium there will be 2 l of a 1.5 M glucose solution. So, the glucose concentration on both sides of the U-tube at equilibrium will be 1.5 M. Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, the net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A before equilibrium is reached will cause there to be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B, which in turn means that there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A until equilibrium is reached. At that point, there will be more than 1 l of solution on side A and therefore the sucrose concentration will have dropped to less than 2 M on side A.
questions.raw_html_comments: Because the membrane is permeable to glucose, right after the solutions are added to the U-tube the rate at which glucose molecules move from side B to side A will be higher than the rate at which glucose molecules move from side A to side B. This will continue until the system reaches equilibrium, at which point there will be an equal concentration of glucose molecules on both sides of the tube. As the system started out with 1 l of a 1 M glucose solution and 1 l of a 2 M glucose solution, at equilibrium there will be 2 l of a 1.5 M glucose solution. So, the glucose concentration on both sides of the U-tube at equilibrium will be 1.5 M. Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, the net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A before equilibrium is reached will cause there to be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B, which in turn means that there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A until equilibrium is reached. At that point, there will be more than 1 l of solution on side A and therefore the sucrose concentration will have dropped to less than 2 M on side A.

questions.raw_html_question: A lipid molecule that starts on the inside face of the ER membrane (i.e. the side of the ER membrane that is NOT in contact with the cytosol) and is then transported to the plasma membrane will
questions.question: A lipid molecule that starts on the inside face of the ER membrane (i.e. the side of the ER membrane that is NOT in contact with the cytosol) and is then transported to the plasma membrane will

options.text: be evenly distributed between the inside and outside faces of the plasma membrane
most likely end up on the outside (extracellular) face of the plasma membrane
most likely end up on the inside (cytosolic) face of the plasma membrane
it is impossible to tell without knowing more about the lipid molecule

questions.comments: Lipids that are on the inside face of the ER membrane will end up on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the ER, than on the inside face of the Golgi apparatus membrane, then on the inside face of the membrane of vesicles that bud off of the Golgi apparatus and then on the extracellular face of the plasma membrane after the vesicle fuses with the plasma membrane (see figure below, paying special attention to the orientation of the small, green carbohydrates that are attached to the protein molecules in the rough ER to help you keep track of the orientation of membrane components). Also, remember that lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, but that it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.

Also, remember that lipid molecules can diffuse laterally within 1 face of a membrane, but that it is very rare for a lipid molecule to flip-flop from on ½ (face) of a membrane to the other because for that to happen the hydrophilic part of the lipid molecule (e.g. the phosphate and groups attached to the phosphate of a phospholipid molecule) would need to pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane.

questions.raw_html_question: Ions always diffuse across membranes down their
questions.question: Ions always diffuse across membranes down their

options.text: electrochemical gradients
concentration gradients
chemical gradients
electrical gradients

questions.comments: Ions are charged molecules or atoms. They will tend to diffuse down their concentration gradient and down their electrical gradient. For example, a positively charged ion will tend to have a net flow towards the side of the membrane that is more negatively charged. If a positively charged ion is in a higher concentration inside of a cell than outside of the cell, the ion may or may not have a net movement to the outside of the cell because the outsides of cells are positively charged relative to their insides. So, whether a positively charged ion would have a net flow to the outside of a cell would depend on how steep its concentration gradient is relative to how steep its electrical gradient is. The bottom line is that the net movement of an ion is down its electrochemical gradient, which takes into account both the tendency for all substances to move down their concentration gradients along with the tendency for positively charged ions to flow towards the more negatively charged side of a membrane and vice versa.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of carrier proteins in a plasma membrane?
questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of carrier proteins in a plasma membrane?

options.text: They are peripheral membrane proteins.
They always exhibit specificity for a particular type of molecule.
All carrier proteins require the expenditure of cellular energy to function.
All carrier proteins work against diffusion.

questions.comments: Some carrier proteins carry out facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion is diffusion of a molecule down its concentration and/or electrical gradient that is “facilitated” by a carrier protein or channel protein that allows the molecule that is diffusing to pass more quickly through the membrane. Because the molecules being transported are moving down their concentration and/or electrical gradient, carrier proteins that act in facilitated diffusion do not require an energy expenditure. However, other carrier proteins, such as symporters and anti-porters, help carry out active transport and so do require an energy expenditure.

questions.raw_html_question: Glucose diffuses slowly through artificial phospholipid bilayers.  The cells lining the small intestine, however, rapidly move large quantities of glucose from glucose-rich foods into their glucose-poor cytoplasm.  Using this information, which transport mechanism is most probably functioning in the intestinal cells?
questions.question: Glucose diffuses slowly through artificial phospholipid bilayers.  The cells lining the small intestine, however, rapidly move large quantities of glucose from glucose-rich foods into their glucose-poor cytoplasm.  Using this information, which transport mechanism is most probably functioning in the intestinal cells?

options.text: Active transport pumps
Facilitated diffusion
Simple diffusion
Glucoport

questions.comments: The information that glucose diffuses poorly through artificial phospholipid bilayers tells you that glucose will diffuse poorly on its own through cell membranes. Because you are also told that glucose is entering the intestinal cells quickly, this rules out simple diffusion as a possibility. Because glucose is moving down its concentration gradient as it enters the intestinal cells, no energy should be required for its movement which makes active transport of any means in unlikely possibility. “Glucoport” is a made up term, which leaves facilitated diffusion as the most likely possibility. In facilitated diffusion, channel proteins or carrier proteins in the membrane allow specific molecules that do not easily cross membranes on their own to cross membranes rapidly. So, diffusion (which is always a passive process) is “facilitated” by these proteins.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is a form of ACTIVE transport?
questions.question: Which of the following is a form of ACTIVE transport?

options.text: Simple diffusion
Facilitated diffusion by a carrier protein
Transport by a cotransporter
Facilitated diffusion by a channel protein

questions.comments: All types of diffusion are passive processes where molecules move down their concentration and/or electrical gradients. Transport by cotransporters is a form of active transport. Cotransporters work by transporting two different molecules together. One of the molecules being transported is moving down its concentration and/or electrical gradient. The other molecule being transported is moving up its concentration and/or electrical gradient. The energy required to move the molecule that’s moving up its concentration and/or electrical gradient is provided by the molecule moving down its concentration and/or electrical gradient. Example: A cotransporter moving H+ down its electrochemical gradient while moving sucrose up its concentration gradient is using the potential energy that is stored in the form H+ moving down its electrochemical gradient to do the work of moving sucrose up its concentration gradient.
questions.raw_html_comments: All types of diffusion are passive processes where molecules move down their concentration and/or electrical gradients. questions.raw_html_question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question.  The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier.  This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water and glucose, but not to sucrose.  If you add 1 liter of water, 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of water, 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, after the system reaches equilibrium, what changes are observed?
questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question.  The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier.  This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water and glucose, but not to sucrose.  If you add 1 liter of water, 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of water, 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, after the system reaches equilibrium, what changes are observed?

options.text: The water level is higher on side A than on side B.
The molarity of glucose is higher on side A than on side B.
The water level is higher on side B than on side A.
The molarity of glucose is lower on side A than on side B.

questions.comments: Because the glucose molecules can cross the selectively permeable membrane and initially there is a higher concentration of glucose molecules on side B, more glucose molecules will move from side B to side A than from side A to side B. In other words, there will be a net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A. Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, there will be no movement of sucrose molecules. This means that the total concentration of solute molecules (= glucose and sucrose molecules in this example) will become higher on side A than on side B. That means that more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A than on side B. This in turn means that there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. More free water molecules will thus flow through the selectively permeable membrane from side B to side A than from side A to side B. In other words, there will be a net flow of free water molecules from side B to side A. This will raise the water level on side A.
questions.raw_html_comments: Because the glucose molecules can cross the selectively permeable membrane and initially there is a higher concentration of glucose molecules on side B, more glucose molecules will move from side B to side A than from side A to side B. In other words, there will be a net movement of glucose molecules from side B to side A. Because the membrane is not permeable to sucrose, there will be no movement of sucrose molecules. This means that the total concentration of solute molecules (= glucose and sucrose molecules in this example) will become higher on side A than on side B. That means that more water molecules will be interacting with solute molecules on side A than on side B. This in turn means that there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules on side A than on side B. More free water molecules will thus flow through the selectively permeable membrane from side B to side A than from side A to side B. In other words, there will be a net flow of free water molecules from side B to side A. This will raise the water level on side A.

This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water, but not to glucose or sucrose. If you add 3 liters of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, the solution in side A with respect to that in side B is
questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question. The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a selectively permeable barrier. This selectively permeable barrier is permeable to water, but not to glucose or sucrose. If you add 3 liters of an aqueous solution containing 2 moles of sucrose and 1 mole of glucose to side “A” of the tube, and 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose to side “B” of the tube, the solution in side A with respect to that in side B is

options.text: isotonic
hypotonic
hypertonic
saturated

questions.comments: Solution A contains 2 moles of sucrose and one mole of glucose in a volume of 3 liters. That means it has a total of 3 moles of solute molecules in a volume of 3 liters, so solution A is a one molar (= 1 M) solution. Solution B has 1 mole of sucrose and 2 moles of glucose in a volume of 1 liter. That means solution B has a total of 3 moles of solute molecules in a volume of 1 liter, so solution B is a 3 molar (= 3 M) solution. Therefore, solution A is hypotonic (has a lower concentration of solute molecules) with respect to solution B.
questions.raw_html_comments: Solution A contains 2 moles of sucrose and one mole of glucose in a volume of 3 liters. questions.question: Which of the following would likely move through the lipid bilayer of a plasma membrane most rapidly?

options.text: an amino acid
glucose
CO2
K+

questions.comments: Amino acids and K+ are charged molecules. They will therefore pass very poorly through the hydrophobic core of a membrane. Glucose molecules have many polar covalent bonds, due to having many hydroxyl groups. So, glucose molecules will also pass poorly through membranes. In contrast, CO2 is a small molecule that is relatively nonpolar and so will pass through membranes with relative ease.

options.text: are only found in membranes
have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions
have modified carbohydrates
have both positively charged and negatively charged regions

questions.comments: Amphipathic molecules have both hydrophilic (“water loving”) and hydrophobic (“water fearing”) regions. For example, the hydrocarbon chains of phospholipid molecules are hydrophobic whereas the phosphate and other parts of the head group of phospholipid molecules are hydrophilic, so phospholipid molecules are amphipathic molecules.

questions.raw_html_question: A chemical reaction that has a positive ∆G is correctly described as
questions.question: A chemical reaction that has a positive ∆G is correctly described as

exergonic
none of these answers are correct
spontaneous

questions.comments: Reactions that have a positive ∆G (i.e. reactions where the total free energy of the reactants is less than the total free energy of the products) are known as endergonic reactions. Reactions that have a negative ∆G are known as exergonic or spontaneous reactions.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements is representative of the second law of thermodynamics?
questions.question: Which of the following statements is representative of the second law of thermodynamics?

options.text: Conversion of energy from one form to another is always accompanied by some gain of free energy.
Cells require a constant input of energy to maintain their high level of organization.
Every energy transformation by a cell decreases the entropy of the universe.
Without an input of energy, organisms would tend toward decreasing entropy.

questions.comments: According to the 2nd law of thermodynamics the entropy of the universe as a whole is always increasing. Living organisms, such as cells, are able to use energy inputs to maintain a high level of order, and thus a low level of entropy. However, by doing this living organisms cause an increase in the entropy of their surroundings that more than compensates for the decrease in entropy within the organism. So, the total amount of entropy within the universe increases and the 2ndlaw of thermodynamics is not violated.

law of thermodynamics is not violated.

questions.raw_html_question: The mathematical expression for the change in the free energy of a system is ∆G = ∆H – T∆S.  Which of the following is (are) TRUE?
questions.question: The mathematical expression for the change in the free energy of a system is ∆G = ∆H – T∆S.  Which of the following is (are) TRUE?

options.text: ∆S is the change in entropy.
∆H is the change in free energy.
T is the temperature in degrees Celsius.
∆G is the change in enthalpy.

questions.comments: ∆G = the change in the Gibb’s free energy of the system. ∆H = the change in the enthalpy of the system. T = the temperature of the system in degrees Kelvin (zero degrees Kelvin = -273 °C. Zero degrees Kelvin corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches a minimum). ∆S = the change in the entropy of the system.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is TRUE for all exergonic reactions in open systems (e.g. a cell)?
questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for all exergonic reactions in open systems (e.g. a cell)?

options.text: The products have less free energy than the reactants
The products have less entropy than the reactants
The products have less total energy than the reactants
The products have more entropy than the reactants

questions.comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy. Regarding entropy, remember that in an open system, depending on the reaction that occurs, the entropy of the SYSTEM may increase or decrease. However, also remember that, according to the 2nd law of thermodynamics, the entropy of the universe as a whole must always increase. So, if the entropy of the system decreases, that must be balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

questions.raw_html_question: The hydrolysis of ATP:  ATP + H2O → ADP + Pi is exergonic, with a ∆G of -7.3 kcal/mol under standard conditions.  What is the source of the 7.3 kcal/mol released in this reaction?
questions.question: The hydrolysis of ATP:  ATP + H2O → ADP + Pi is exergonic, with a ∆G of -7.3 kcal/mol under standard conditions.  What is the source of the 7.3 kcal/mol released in this reaction?

options.text: breaking the terminal phosphate bond to form ATP

the difference between the potential energy in the bonds of ATP and the water molecule, minus the potential energy in the bonds of ADP and Pi. In other words: (potential energy in bonds of ATP + potential energy in bonds of H2O) – (potential energy in bonds of ADP + potential energy in bonds of Pi) = 7.3 kcal/mol
the increase in entropy from breaking apart ATP
both the energy released from breaking the terminal phosphate bond and the increase in entropy

questions.comments: The definition of an endergonic reaction is a reaction where there is an increase in FREE energy. So, in an endergonic reaction the products of the reaction will have more FREE energy than the reactants used in the reaction. The fact that a reaction is an "endergonic" reaction does NOT tell you what the change in TOTAL energy, as opposed to FREE energy, will be.

questions.comments: The 2nd law of thermodynamics states that the entropy of the universe as a whole must increase. questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is TRUE for ALL exergonic reactions?
questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE for ALL exergonic reactions?

options.text: If the reaction proceeds there will be a net decrease in free energy.
A net input of energy from the surroundings is required for the reactions to proceed.
The reactions are nonspontaneous.
The products have more total energy than the reactants.

questions.comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy. In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system. For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.
questions.raw_html_comments: By definition, exergonic reactions are reactions where the reaction results in a decrease in free energy. In contrast, it is possible for an exergonic reaction to result in an increase in the TOTAL energy of the system. For that to occur, the increase in the total energy of the system must be more than offset by an increase in entropy. Because exergonic reactions are reactions that result in a decrease in free energy, there is no need for an energy input in order for an exergonic reaction to occur.

questions.raw_html_question: Many of the reactions that occur during metabolism are reversible. Given the laws of thermodynamics, how is that possible?
questions.question: Many of the reactions that occur during metabolism are reversible. Given the laws of thermodynamics, how is that possible?

options.text: Even in the same solution, some of the molecules of a particular species may have more energy than others.
These reactions are reversible in theory, but proceed in only one direction so that the laws of thermodynamics are not violated.
The free energy of the system will decrease when the reaction proceeds in one direction, but the total energy of the system will decrease when the reaction proceeds in the other direction.
Energy is used to drive a reversible reaction in one of the two possible directions.

questions.comments: For a reaction to be a spontaneous reaction, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be greater than the free energy of the product molecules, so that free energy decreases as a result of the reaction. So, if you imagine a reaction where “A” is converted to “B”, the conversion of a molecule of A to a molecule of B will be spontaneous if the free energy of molecule A is greater than the free energy of molecule B. So, if on average A molecules have a free energy of 5 kcal/mole and B molecules have a free energy of 4.9 kcal/mole, the average free energy of a molecule of A will be greater than the average free energy of a molecule of B and therefore the conversion of an average molecule of A to an average molecule of B will represent an exergonic, or spontaneous, reaction. However, what we have to realize is that different molecules of A in a solution will have slightly different free energies and different molecules of B will have slightly free different energies. So, if the AVERAGE free energy of a molecule of B is 4.9 kcal/mole, there may be some molecules of B that have a free energy of greater than 5 kcal/mole. Those molecules of B that have a free energy that is greater than 5 kcal/mole can then be converted to molecules of A via a reaction that will be exergonic (spontaneous). Note that this does NOT mean that the conversion of B to A will occur at as high a rate as the conversion of A to B. If there are only a very small number of molecules of B that have a high enough free energy level to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction, the rate of conversion of A to B will be higher than the rate of conversion of B to A. Eventually, the high rate of conversion of A to B will result in there being enough molecules of B with sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction that the rate of conversion of B to A will equal the rate of conversion of A to B. At that point, the reaction will have reached equilibrium and both reactions will occur at the same rate (note that, in this example, at equilibrium there will be more molecules of B than of A, but a smaller percentage of the molecules of B will have sufficient free energy to be converted to A via an exergonic reaction). In addition, there is a tendency for reactions to be reversible because there is greater entropy in a mixture of substances than in a pure substance. In other words, a system that contains a mixture of "A" and "B" molecules will have greater entropy than a system that has just "A" or just "B" molecules.

questions.comments: Reactions, such as dehydration reactions, that result in the formation of one large molecule from multiple small molecules create more order and therefore less entropy. Reactions that break down a large molecule to more than one small molecule (e.g. hydrolysis reactions, respiration, catabolism) create less order in the system and therefore greater entropy.

questions.comments: At equilibrium, the free energy change is zero and no work can be done. So, a cell where most reactions are at equilibrium would not be able to do enough work and so would be dead. Also, the "products" of reversible reactions are frequently converted to other substances or transported to other cellular compartments before they can be metabolized via the reverse reaction, which also prevents many cellular reactions from reaching equilibrium.

questions.comments: Spontaneous reactions are defined as reactions that do not require an energy input to occur. questions.question: Most cells cannot harness heat to perform work because

questions.comments: Heat can only be used to perform work where there is a temperature differential. For example, using heat to cause the air in a piston to expand, allowing the piston to do work, only works if the temperature of the air inside the piston is greater than the temperature of the air outside of the piston. Because the temperature across a cell is generally fairly uniform, cells cannot typically use heat to perform work.

questions.comments: Catabolic pathways are metabolic pathways that result in the breakdown of large biological molecules to simpler molecules. As a result, they increase the entropy of the system. They are also exergonic reactions as the reactant molecules (i.e. the large biological molecules) have greater amounts of free energy than the product molecules (i.e. the smaller molecules that are formed by breaking down the large molecules). Reactions that result in a decrease in free energy are known as exergonic, or “spontaneous”, reactions. Please remember that the fact that a reaction is a “spontaneous” reaction does NOT mean that reaction will occur at a high rate. In fact, the reaction may not occur at all, depending on the height of the activation energy barrier.

Reactions that result in a decrease in free energy are known as exergonic, or “spontaneous”, reactions. Please remember that the fact that a reaction is a “spontaneous” reaction does NOT mean that reaction will occur at a high rate. In fact, the reaction may not occur at all, depending on the height of the activation energy barrier.

questions.raw_html_question: A reaction has a ∆G of -5.6 kcal/mol.  Which of the following would most likely be TRUE?
questions.question: A reaction has a ∆G of -5.6 kcal/mol.  Which of the following would most likely be TRUE?

options.text: The reaction would result in an increase in entropy (S) and a decrease in the energy content (H) of the system.
The reaction would result in products with a greater free energy content than in the initial reactants.
The reaction could be coupled to power an endergonic reaction with a ∆G of +8.8 kcal/mol.
The reaction would result in a decrease in entropy (S) and an increase in the energy content (H) of the system.

questions.comments: ∆G = ∆H – T∆S. If ∆G is a negative number, the products of the reaction must have a lower free energy content than the initial reactants. Also, in order for ∆G to be negative, it is not possible for ∆H to be positive and ∆S to be negative. The energy released by a reaction can only be used to power a reaction that requires an amount of energy to occur that is less than the amount of energy being released.

questions.raw_html_question: At zero degrees Kelvin, in theory,
questions.question: At zero degrees Kelvin, in theory,

options.text: all of these answers are correct
water will be frozen
entropy will reach a minimum value
you will be frozen

questions.comments: 0 degrees Kelvin is known as “absolute zero”. It corresponds to the theoretical temperature at which entropy reaches its minimum value. (In classical theory it was considered the temperature at which molecular motion ceases, but we now know that’s not accurate). 0 degrees Kelvin = -273° C, so both water and you would definitely be frozen solid at that temperature!

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements about biological systems is FALSE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements about biological systems is FALSE?

options.text: The entropy of a biological system can decrease
The total energy in a biological system cannot increase or decrease
The total energy in a biological system can increase
The total energy in a biological system can decrease

questions.comments: Because biological systems are open systems (i.e. they are systems where energy and matter can enter and leave the system), the total energy in a cell may increase or decrease. Similarly, the entropy of a biological system can decrease (and very often does decrease), as long as the decrease in the entropy of the system is balanced by an even greater magnitude increase in the entropy of the rest of the universe.

questions.raw_html_question: When ATP releases some energy, it also releases inorganic phosphate.  What purpose, if any, does this serve in the cell?
questions.question: When ATP releases some energy, it also releases inorganic phosphate.  What purpose, if any, does this serve in the cell?

options.text: It can be added to other molecules in order to activate them.
It can only be used to generate more ATP.
It is released as excretory waste.
It can enter the nucleus and affect gene expression.

questions.comments: The third phosphate in ATP is often transferred to other molecules. Because the covalent bond between the phosphate and the rest of the molecule is a high-energy bond, phosphorylation of a molecule raises the free energy of that molecule. Raising the free energy of a molecule makes it more likely that it can participate in exergonic (spontaneous) reactions as a reactant, since it makes it more likely that the combined free energies of the reactant molecules will be greater than the combined free energies of the product molecules.

Living organisms create lots of entropy after they die and the molecules in their bodies dissociate, which makes up for the decrease in entropy created while they were alive.
Living organisms do not follow the laws of thermodynamics.

questions.comments: The decrease in entropy within the organism is more than balanced by an even greater increase in the entropy of their surroundings. questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following terms best describes the reaction described in the figure below?
questions.question: Which of the following terms best describes the reaction described in the figure below?

options.text: endergonic
allosteric
anabolic
exergonic

questions.comments: The free energy of the reactant molecules (A and B) is greater than the free energy of the product molecules (C and D). So, the reaction of A and B to C and D will result in a decrease in free energy of the system. Reactions where the free energy decreases are known as exergonic reactions. In contrast, reactions where the free energy increases are known as endergonic reactions. In metabolism, catabolic reactions, which breakdown complex, energy-rich molecules to smaller, less energy dense molecules are generally exergonic. In contrast, anabolic reactions, which require an input of energy to convert small molecules to more complex, energy-rich molecules, tend to be endergonic.
questions.raw_html_comments: The free energy of the reactant molecules (A and B) is greater than the free energy of the product molecules (C and D). questions.raw_html_question: During a laboratory experiment you discover that an enzyme-catalyzed reaction has a delta G of -20 kcal/mol. If you double the amount of enzyme in the reaction, what will be the delta G for the new reaction?
questions.question: During a laboratory experiment you discover that an enzyme-catalyzed reaction has a delta G of -20 kcal/mol. If you double the amount of enzyme in the reaction, what will be the delta G for the new reaction?

options.text: +40 kcal/mole
+20 kcal/mole
-40 kcal/mole
-20 kcal/mole

questions.comments: Because enzymes do not change the free energy change of a reaction, delta G will still be -20 kcal/mole. Please note that enzymes DO lower the energy activation barrier, which is the energy barrier that reactant molecules must surmount in order for a reaction to occur. But, enzymes do not change the free energy in the reactant or product molecules and thus do not change the difference between the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.

questions.raw_html_question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following represents the activation energy barrier for the noncatalyzed reaction?
questions.question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following represents the activation energy barrier for the noncatalyzed reaction?

options.text: arrow E
arrow B
arrow A
arrow C

questions.comments: Remember that enzymes act by lowering the activation energy barrier. So, the peak of the red curve represents the energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier in the non-catalyzed reaction and the peak of the black curve represents the amount of energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier for the enzyme catalyzed reaction. Arrow “B” thus represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the enzyme catalyzed reaction to occur. Arrow “C” represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the non-catalyzed reaction to occur.

questions.raw_html_question: You realize that, for a particular reaction to occur, the molecules participating in that reaction need to have a certain minimum free energy level to get over the activation energy barrier.  After measuring the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules, you discover that their average free energy levels are a little below that required to surmount the activation barrier.  Should you be surprised when you then realize that the reaction is occurring, even though it is only occurring at a relatively low rate?
questions.question: You realize that, for a particular reaction to occur, the molecules participating in that reaction need to have a certain minimum free energy level to get over the activation energy barrier.  After measuring the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules, you discover that their average free energy levels are a little below that required to surmount the activation barrier.  Should you be surprised when you then realize that the reaction is occurring, even though it is only occurring at a relatively low rate?

options.text: No, you should not be surprised because you only measured the average free energy levels of the potential reactant molecules. Some of the molecules likely have more than the average amount of free energy, meaning that they have enough free energy to surmount the activation barrier.
Yes, you should be surprised because the chemical reaction is apparently occurring in violation of the laws of thermodynamics.
Yes, you should be surprised because someone must have published inaccurate data regarding the amount of energy needed to surmount the activation barrier.

No, you should not be surprised because the energy level at the top of the activation barrier represents only an average amount of energy. So, the activation barrier will actually be lower for some of the reactant molecules and higher for others.

questions.comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier. If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier. However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels. So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.
questions.raw_html_comments: For a spontaneous reaction to occur, the free energy of the reactant molecules must be sufficient to get over the activation energy barrier. If the activation energy barrier is 7 kcal/mol and the average free energy of the reactant molecules is only 6.9 kcal/mole, the average reactant molecule will have insufficient free energy to get over the activation energy barrier. However, we have to consider that only the AVERAGE free energy of the reactant molecules was measured, and that different reactant molecules in a solution will have slightly different free energy levels. So, some percentage of the reactant molecules will have sufficient free energy to surmount the energy activation barrier.

questions.raw_html_question: If an enzyme is added to a solution where its substrate and product are in equilibrium, what will occur?
questions.question: If an enzyme is added to a solution where its substrate and product are in equilibrium, what will occur?

options.text: The reaction will change from endergonic to exergonic.
The free energy of the system will change.
Nothing; the reaction will stay at equilibrium.
Additional product will be formed.

questions.comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction. Instead, they speed up the rate at which reactions occur by lowering the activation energy barrier. Because enzymes do not change the free energies of the reactant or product molecules, enzymes do not alter the point at which reactants and products will be in equilibrium.
questions.raw_html_comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction. Instead, they speed up the rate at which reactions occur by lowering the activation energy barrier. Because enzymes do not change the free energies of the reactant or product molecules, enzymes do not alter the point at which reactants and products will be in equilibrium.

questions.raw_html_question: Feedback inhibition is used by cells to
questions.question: Feedback inhibition is used by cells to

options.text: slow down the rate at which organisms excrete waste products.
keep from producing unnecessarily high levels of different products.
decrease the free energy change of undesirable reactions.
slow down the rate at which organisms consume food.

questions.comments: Feedback inhibition occurs when an end product of a metabolic pathway binds to, and inhibits, one of the enzymes that catalyzes an early step in that pathway. Feedback inhibition is thus used as a mechanism to slow down pathways that are producing product molecules more quickly than they are needed, so that the product molecules are accumulating in the cell.
questions.raw_html_comments: Feedback inhibition occurs when an end product of a metabolic pathway binds to, and inhibits, one of the enzymes that catalyzes an early step in that pathway. questions.raw_html_question: In contrast to non-competitive inhibitors, competitive inhibitors of enzyme activity
questions.question: In contrast to non-competitive inhibitors, competitive inhibitors of enzyme activity

options.text: always utilize an enzyme's active site.
can NOT have their effects reversed by addition of more substrate.
cause enzymes to denature.

questions.comments: Competitive inhibitors “compete” with substrate molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site. Addition of more substrate does, therefore, help reverse the effects of a competitive inhibitor by allowing the increased number of substrate molecules to occupy the active sites of more of the enzyme molecules. Because competitive inhibitors bind at the enzyme’s active site, they are by definition NOT allosteric regulators, because the definition of an allosteric regulator is a regulator that binds at a site that is distinct from the enzyme’s active site.

questions.comments: Allosteric regulators bind enzymes at locations that are distinct from the enzyme’s active site. Allosteric regulators often act on multi-subunit enzymes. The 3-dimensional shapes of these enzymes often oscillate between more and less active shapes. questions.raw_html_question: The enzyme phosphofructokinase catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to fructose 1,6-bisphosphate and adenosine diphosphate (ADP).  Adenosine monophosphate (AMP) activates the enzyme phosphofructokinase (PFK) by binding at a site distinct from the substrate-binding site.  This is an example of
questions.question: The enzyme phosphofructokinase catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to fructose 1,6-bisphosphate and adenosine diphosphate (ADP).  Adenosine monophosphate (AMP) activates the enzyme phosphofructokinase (PFK) by binding at a site distinct from the substrate-binding site.  This is an example of

options.text: activation by an enzyme cofactor
cooperative activation
allosteric activation
the coupling of exergonic and endergonic reactions

questions.comments: In this example, AMP is binding to a site that is distinct from the active site that it is regulating, which is consistent with AMP acting as an allosteric activator. Note that this is NOT an example of cooperative activation, as cooperative activation occurs when binding of a substrate molecule to the active site of one of the subunits in a multi-subunit enzyme changes the conformations of the other subunits such that they are able to bind substrate molecules more easily. In this example, AMP is not a substrate molecule and it is not binding to any of the active sites of phosphfructokinase (which does happen to be a multi-subunit enzyme).
questions.raw_html_comments: In this example, AMP is binding to a site that is distinct from the active site that it is regulating, which is consistent with AMP acting as an allosteric activator. Note that this is NOT an example of cooperative activation, as cooperative activation occurs when binding of a substrate molecule to the active site of one of the subunits in a multi-subunit enzyme changes the conformations of the other subunits such that they are able to bind substrate molecules more easily. In this example, AMP is not a substrate molecule and it is not binding to any of the active sites of phosphfructokinase (which does happen to be a multi-subunit enzyme).

questions.comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

questions.raw_html_question: Increasing the substrate concentration in an enzymatic reaction could overcome which of the following?
questions.question: Increasing the substrate concentration in an enzymatic reaction could overcome which of the following?

questions.comments: Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor competes with substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme. Increasing the concentration of substrate molecules will help them out compete a competitive inhibitor. In contrast, allosteric inhibitors bind to sites on the enzyme that are distinct from the active site. So, increasing the concentration of substrate molecules will not alleviate allosteric inhibition.

questions.raw_html_question: A solution of starch at room temperature does not readily decompose to form a solution of simple sugars because
questions.question: A solution of starch at room temperature does not readily decompose to form a solution of simple sugars because

options.text: The activation energy barrier cannot be surmounted.
Starch cannot be hydrolyzed in the presence of so much water.
Starch hydrolysis is nonspontaneous.
The hydrolysis of starch to sugar is endergonic.

questions.comments: The hydrolysis of starch to form sugars is a spontaneous process, meaning that it represents in an exergonic reaction (i.e. a reaction where the free energy of the products is less than the free energy of the reactants). The reason that starch hydrolysis does not occur at room temperature is that the activation energy barrier is too high. The starch molecules do not have sufficient energy to assume the required high-energy transitional state for the reaction to occur in the absence of a catalyst.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements regarding enzymes is FALSE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding enzymes is FALSE?

options.text: Enzyme activity can be inhibited if the enzyme is bound by a noncompetitive inhibitor.
Enzymes alter the free energy change (ΔG) of the reactions which they catalyze.
Enzyme function is dependent on the three-dimensional structure or conformation of the enzyme.
Enzyme function is dependent on the pH and temperature of the reaction environment.

questions.comments: The statement that is NOT true is that enzymes alter the free energy change of the reactions which they catalyze. In fact, enzymes do not alter the free energy change of the reactions they catalyze. Instead, they decrease the activation energy needed for the reaction to occur. If the activation energy is decreased, more molecules will have enough energy for the reaction to occur and the reaction will occur more quickly. However, the change in energy for each molecule undergoing the reaction will NOT be affected by the enzyme. Think of it like this: Imagine a bunch of people trying to jump from a bed, over a dresser, onto the floor. If the dresser is very high, not too many people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor. If you lower the dresser, more people will be able to jump over it and make it to the floor. However, the decrease in potential energy will be the same regardless of the height of the dresser, since the decrease in potential energy is dependent (in this example) on the difference between the starting height of each person on the bed and their final height on the floor, which is not affected by the height of the dresser.

questions.raw_html_question: You notice that many of the anabolic reactions in a cell have speeded up.  Upon further characterization of the cell, you are NOT surprised to find that

questions.comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP. So, if ATP levels are high and ADP levels are low, you would expect anabolic reactions to proceed quickly. If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).

questions.comments: Noncompetitive inhibitors bind at sites that are distinct from the active site of the enzyme they inhibit. Binding of a noncompetitive inhibitor causes the enzyme to change its shape in a way that makes the enzyme less effective at catalyzing the conversion of substrate to product. questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements comparing allosteric regulators and non-competitive inhibitors is TRUE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements comparing allosteric regulators and non-competitive inhibitors is TRUE?

options.text: Inhibition by allosteric regulators is irreversible.
Only allosteric regulators bind at a site that is distinct from the active site(s) they are regulating.
Only non-competitive inhibitors bind at a site that is distinct from the active site(s) they are regulating.
Allosteric regulators may increase or decrease an enzyme’s activity level.

questions.comments: Both allosteric regulators and non-competitive inhibitors bind at a site that is distinct from the active site(s) they are regulating (note that, during a particular form of allosteric regulation known as “cooperativity”, the activator – which in this case is a substrate molecule - binds at one of the active sites of a multi-subunit enzyme and in so doing stimulates binding of substrate molecules at OTHER active sites of that enzyme). Binding of allosteric regulators is reversible, not irreversible. Allosteric regulators can act as activators or inhibitors of enzyme activity, whereas non-competitive inhibitors are always inhibitors of enzyme activity.

noncompetitive inhibitors

questions.comments: Competitive inhibitors act by competing (hence the name “competitive” inhibitor) with substrate molecules for binding at the enzyme’s active site. Because of their mechanism of action, the effects of competitive inhibitors may be alleviated by increasing the concentration of substrate molecules, allowing the substrate molecules to occupy a higher percentage of the active sites of the enzyme molecules. Because high substrate concentrations reduce the efficacy (effectiveness) of NSAIDs, you can thus deduce that NSAIDs are competitive inhibitors.

questions.raw_html_question: Hair is extremely flammable, so why doesn’t your hair spontaneously burst into flame?
questions.question: Hair is extremely flammable, so why doesn’t your hair spontaneously burst into flame?

options.text: Burning hair is an endergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.
The molecules in your hair lack sufficient energy at room temperature to overcome the activation energy barrier for this reaction.
Since your hair is generally a mess, burning it would result in a decrease in the total entropy of the universe, which would be a violation of the second law of thermodynamics.
Burning hair is an exergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.

questions.comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going. So, once hair catches fire it will continue to burn.

questions.raw_html_question: Wood does not burst into flame on its own.  Yet, once you start a campfire, the wood continues to burn.  What is going on?
questions.question: Wood does not burst into flame on its own.  Yet, once you start a campfire, the wood continues to burn.  What is going on?

options.text: The burnt part of the wood releases ash and smoke, raising the entropy of the system.
The burnt part of the wood releases ash and smoke, raising the entropy of the products of the reaction.

The combustion of wood is an exergonic process. Once you start the wood burning, heat is released by the burning wood. That heat increases the energy of other molecules in the wood, so that they now have sufficient energy to overcome the activation energy barrier and begin to burn as well.

The combustion of wood is an endergonic process. Once you start the wood burning, heat is released by the burning wood. That heat increases the energy of other molecules in the wood, so that they now have sufficient energy to overcome the activation energy barrier and begin to burn as well.

questions.comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going. So, once a piece of wood begins to burn, it may keep on burning.

In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going. So, once a piece of wood begins to burn, it may keep on burning.

questions.raw_html_question: For the reaction described in the figure shown below, which of the following represents the activation energy barrier for the enzyme-catalyzed reaction?

options.text: arrow B
arrow C
arrow E
arrow A

questions.comments: Remember that enzymes act by lowering the activation energy barrier. So, the peak of the red curve represents the energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier in the non-catalyzed reaction and the peak of the black curve represents the amount of energy needed to overcome the activation energy barrier for the enzyme catalyzed reaction. Arrow “B” thus represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the enzyme catalyzed reaction to occur. Arrow “C” represents the amount of energy molecules A and B need to gain above their normal, average state in order for the non-catalyzed reaction to occur.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following are TRUE for anabolic pathways?
questions.question: Which of the following are TRUE for anabolic pathways?

options.text: They are usually highly spontaneous chemical reactions
They release energy as they degrade polymers to monomers
They do not depend on enzymes
They consume energy to build up polymers from monomers

questions.comments: Anabolic pathways build polymers from monomers. They are endergonic pathways as the free energy of the products (polymers) is greater than the free energy of the reactants (monomers). As a consequence, anabolic pathways are nonspontaneous pathways that require an energy input, such as from ATP, to occur. The reactions in anabolic pathways are catalyzed by enzymes.
questions.raw_html_comments: Anabolic pathways build polymers from monomers. As a consequence, anabolic pathways are nonspontaneous pathways that require an energy input, such as from ATP, to occur. The reactions in anabolic pathways are catalyzed by enzymes.

questions.raw_html_question: In a particular reversible reaction, “A” and “B” may be converted to “C” and “D”, or “C” and “D” may be converted to “A” and “B”.  The direction of this reversible reaction will be determined by
questions.question: In a particular reversible reaction, “A” and “B” may be converted to “C” and “D”, or “C” and “D” may be converted to “A” and “B”.  The direction of this reversible reaction will be determined by

options.text: None of these answers are correct.
the relative concentrations of “A” and “B” versus “C” and “D”
Both “a” and “b” are correct.
whether the enzyme that catalyzes the reaction catalyzes the forward or reverse reactions

questions.comments: Enzymes do not alter the free energy change of a reaction and so do not alter the point at which equilibrium will be reached or the overall direction of the reaction. In contrast, the direction of a reversible reaction will be determined by the relative concentrations of the reactants and products of the reactions, together with the difference in the free energies of the reactant and product molecules.
