questions.raw_html_question: If ATP levels increase and ADP levels decrease
questions.question: If ATP levels increase and ADP levels decrease

options.text: The rates of many catabolic reactions will decrease due to increased allosteric inhibition by ATP.
The rates of many anabolic reactions will increase due to decreased allosteric inhibition by ADP.
All of these answers are correct.
The rates of many anabolic reactions will increase due to increased allosteric activation by ATP.

questions.comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

questions.raw_html_question: Wood is extremely flammable, so why don’t trees spontaneously burst into flame?
questions.question: Wood is extremely flammable, so why don’t trees spontaneously burst into flame?

options.text: The chemical bonds in wood have more potential energy than the chemical bonds in ash.
Burning wood is an endergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.
Burning wood is an exergonic reaction that requires energy from fire to drive it.
At room temperature, the molecules in wood do not have sufficient energy to overcome the activation energy barrier necessary for this reaction to occur.

questions.comments: Remember that, although exergonic reactions are also known as “spontaneous” reactions, the fact that a reaction is “spontaneous” does not mean that it will occur quickly or even that it will occur at all. Exergonic, or spontaneous, reactions are defined as reactions where the free energies of the reactant molecules are higher than the free energies of the product molecules. So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going. So, once a piece of wood begins to burn, it may keep on burning. To remember the difference between exergonic and endergonic, think of free energy exiting the system during an exergonic reaction (where the free energies of the reactants are greater than those of the products) and entering the system during an endergonic reaction (where the free energies of the reactants are less than those of the products).

questions.raw_html_question: Succinate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of succinate to fumarate.  The reaction is inhibited by malonic acid.  Increasing the ratio of succinate to malonic acid reduces the inhibitory effect of malonic acid.  What role does malonic acid play in this reaction?
questions.question: Succinate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of succinate to fumarate.  The reaction is inhibited by malonic acid.  Increasing the ratio of succinate to malonic acid reduces the inhibitory effect of malonic acid.  What role does malonic acid play in this reaction?

options.text: It is a noncompetitive inhibitor.
It is a competitive inhibitor.
It replaces the usual enzyme.
It blocks the binding of fumarate.

questions.comments: Competitive inhibitors compete with substrate (succinate, in this case) molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site. Adding more substrate (e.g. succinate) molecules will alleviate this type of inhibition. In contrast, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to sites that are distinct from the enyzme’s active site. Increasing the substrate concentration does not alleviate inhibition by a noncompetitive inhibitor.
questions.raw_html_comments: Competitive inhibitors compete with substrate (succinate, in this case) molecules for binding to the enzyme’s active site. Adding more substrate (e.g. succinate) molecules will alleviate this type of inhibition. In contrast, noncompetitive inhibitors bind to sites that are distinct from the enyzme’s active site. Increasing the substrate concentration does not alleviate inhibition by a noncompetitive inhibitor.

questions.raw_html_question: Binding of an allosteric regulator to the enzyme it regulates
questions.question: Binding of an allosteric regulator to the enzyme it regulates

options.text: is irreversible.
may occur via covalent bonds.
is at the enzyme’s active site.
may occur via ionic bonds

questions.comments: By definition, allosteric regulators bind enzymes at locations that are distinct from the enzyme’s active site. Binding of allosteric regulators to enzymes is via noncovalent bonds, such as ionic or hydrogen bonds. The binding of an allosteric regulator to an enzyme is always reversible. This is in contrast to noncompetitive inhibitors, which may bind an enzyme via noncovalent bonds and usually bind irreversibly to enzymes. Noncompetitive inhibitors and allosteric regulators do share the trait that they bind at a site that is distinct from the active site they are reuglating.

So, if the reaction occurs, there will be a net decrease in free energy. HOWEVER, for a reaction to occur the chemical bonds in the reactant molecules must be “stretched” into higher energy forms, so that the reactant molecules reach what is known as a “transition state”. The free energies of the reactant molecules in their transition states are higher than the free energies of the reactant molecules in their non-transition states. So, the reactant molecules may not have sufficient energy to achieve their transition states. If that is the case, the reaction will not proceed even though the overall effect of the reaction would be a decrease in free energy. Note that adding energy to some of the reactant molecules, so that those molecules are able to undergo the reaction, will result in a release of energy that may result in more reactant molecules having sufficient energy to surmount the activation energy barrier and undergo the reaction, leading to a further release in energy that allows more reactant molecules to undergo the reaction, and so on. In other words, once a reaction gets going, it may keep going.

questions.comments: Remember that proteins produced for secretion and proteins that will become part of one of the membranes of the endomembrane system are made by bound ribosomes (= ribosomes bound to the rough ER or nuclear envelope). Proteins made by ribosomes attached to the rough ER are transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus where they may be modified. The proteins are next transported via vesicles to their next destination (= the plasma membrane, in the case of secreted proteins). In contrast, “free ribosomes” (= ribosomes that are NOT bound to the rough ER or to the nuclear envelope) produce proteins that float freely in the cytosol or that are transported into the nucleus, mitochondria or chloroplasts.

questions.raw_html_question: Why have plants been referred to as “supracellular” organisms?
questions.question: Why have plants been referred to as “supracellular” organisms?

options.text: Plant cells are able to carry out photosynthesis.
The vast majority of the cells in a plant are connected by plasmodesmata, forming a sort of “super cell”
The cell walls surrounding plant cells make them super strong.
Plant cells tend to be larger than animal cells.

questions.comments: Unicellular organisms are organisms that have only a single cell. Multi-cellular organisms, such as people, are organisms that have multiple cells. Plants have been referred to as “supracellular” organisms because almost all of the cells in a plants are directly connected by pores that run through their cell walls. These pores are called plasmodesmata. Plasmodesmata allow small molecules to diffuse between different cells in a plant without having to cross a plasma membrane. So, most of the cells in a plant can be thought of as being joined together in a giant “super cell”.
questions.raw_html_comments: Unicellular organisms are organisms that have only a single cell. Multi-cellular organisms, such as people, are organisms that have multiple cells. These pores are called plasmodesmata. Plasmodesmata allow small molecules to diffuse between different cells in a plant without having to cross a plasma membrane. So, most of the cells in a plant can be thought of as being joined together in a giant “super cell”.

questions.raw_html_question: What is the reason that linked genes are inherited together?
questions.question: What is the reason that linked genes are inherited together?

options.text: Genes align that way during metaphase I of meiosis.
Alleles are paired together during meiosis.
The number of genes in a cell is greater than the number of chromosomes.
Chromosomes are unbreakable.
They are located close together on the same chromosome.

questions.comments: Linked genes segregate together because they are close to each other on the same chromosome. Consequently the chance of a recombination event occurring between them is small, so they tend to be inherited together.
questions.raw_html_comments: Linked genes segregate together because they are close to each other on the same chromosome. Consequently the chance of a recombination event occurring between them is small, so they tend to be inherited together.

questions.raw_html_question: In humans, male-pattern baldness is controlled by an autosomal gene (= a gene that is found on a chromosome other than an X or Y chromosome) that occurs in two allelic forms. Allele Hn determines nonbaldness, and allele Hb determines pattern baldness. In males, because of the presence of testosterone, allele Hb is dominant over Hn. If a man and woman both with genotype HnHb have a son, what is the chance that he will eventually be bald?
questions.question: In humans, male-pattern baldness is controlled by an autosomal gene (= a gene that is found on a chromosome other than an X or Y chromosome) that occurs in two allelic forms. Allele Hn determines nonbaldness, and allele Hb determines pattern baldness. In males, because of the presence of testosterone, allele Hb is dominant over Hn. If a man and woman both with genotype HnHb have a son, what is the chance that he will eventually be bald?
questions.comments: Remember that “autosomes” are chromosomes that are NOT sex chromosome (i.e. they are chromosomes that are not X or Y chromosomes). As both the mother and father are HnHb, their children will be an equal mix of: HbHb, HnHb, HbHn and HnHn. Because the Hb allele causes baldness and is dominant in males, the 75% of the males that are HbHb, HnHb or HbHnwill be bald.
questions.raw_html_comments:
Remember that “autosomes” are chromosomes that are NOT sex chromosome (i.e. they are chromosomes that are not X or Y chromosomes). As both the mother and father are HnHb, their children will be an equal mix of: HbHb, HnHb, HbHn and HnHn. Because the Hb allele causes baldness and is dominant in males, the 75% of the males that are HbHb, HnHb or HbHn
will be bald.

All the male progeny will inherit a black allele from their mother and so will have black fur. All the female progeny will inherit a black allele from their mother and an orange allele from their father and so will be tortoiseshell.

questions.comments: Independent alignment of homologous chromosomes, crossing over, and random fertilization of gametes are all processes that occur in sexual fertilization and serve to increase genetic variation in a population by recombining alleles to generate new genotypes in individuals and new raw material for natural selection to act on.

questions.raw_html_question: Inactivation of one of the two X chromosomes in females occurs early during embryo development. A random X chromosome is inactivated in each cell present during the period during which inactivation occurs. As a consequence
questions.question: Inactivation of one of the two X chromosomes in females occurs early during embryo development. A random X chromosome is inactivated in each cell present during the period during which inactivation occurs. As a consequence

options.text: ½ the cells in a female embryo become unviable, and need to be replaced by mitosis of neighboring cells.
females are a mosaic of two types of cell, those with the active X chromosome derived from the father and those with the active X chromosome derived from the mother.
different cells in a female embryo contain different X chromosomes
all of these answers are correct

questions.comments: All somatic cells in humans who are biologically female have two X chromosomes. So that biological females don't produce twice as much protein from genes on the X chromosome as biological males, during development a random X chromosome in each cell is inactivated in biological females. Because which of the two X chromosomes is inactivated is random for every cell, in some cells the X chromosome that was inherited from the biological father is inactivated whereas in other cells the X chromosome that was inherited from the biological mother is inactivated. As a result, different cells have different X chromosomes inactivated, causing biological females to be genetic mosaics.
questions.raw_html_comments: All somatic cells in humans who are biologically female have two X chromosomes. Because which of the two X chromosomes is inactivated is random for every cell, in some cells the X chromosome that was inherited from the biological father is inactivated whereas in other cells the X chromosome that was inherited from the biological mother is inactivated. As a result, different cells have different X chromosomes inactivated, causing biological females to be genetic mosaics.

questions.question: Why are individuals with an extra chromosome 21, which causes Down syndrome, more numerous than individuals with an extra chromosome 3 or chromosome 16?

questions.raw_html_question: A genetic defect in humans results in the absence of sweat glands in the skin. Some men have this defect all over their bodies, but in women it is usually expressed in a peculiar way: A woman with this defect typically has small patches of skin with sweat glands and other patches without sweat glands. In women, the pattern of sweat-gland distribution can best be explained by _____.
questions.question: A genetic defect in humans results in the absence of sweat glands in the skin. Some men have this defect all over their bodies, but in women it is usually expressed in a peculiar way: A woman with this defect typically has small patches of skin with sweat glands and other patches without sweat glands. In women, the pattern of sweat-gland distribution can best be explained by _____.

options.text: X chromosome inactivation
a homeobox
an operon
a mutation
RNA splicing

questions.comments: This pattern suggests that a gene on the X chromosome is involved in the production of sweat glands. Inactivation of one of the two X chromosomes in females occurs early during embryo development. A random X chromosome is inactivated in each cell present during the period during which inactivation occurs. As a consequence females are a mosaic of two types of cell, those with the active X chromosome derived from the father and those with the active X chromosome derived from the mother. If a female has one X chromosome that directs sweat-gland production and one that does not, then the cells where the X chromosome that directs sweat-gland production is inactivated won’t produce sweat glands, whereas the cells were the X chromosome that does not direct sweat-gland production is inactivated will produce sweat glands.
questions.raw_html_comments: This pattern suggests that a gene on the X chromosome is involved in the production of sweat glands. A random X chromosome is inactivated in each cell present during the period during which inactivation occurs. As a consequence females are a mosaic of two types of cell, those with the active X chromosome derived from the father and those with the active X chromosome derived from the mother. If a female has one X chromosome that directs sweat-gland production and one that does not, then the cells where the X chromosome that directs sweat-gland production is inactivated won’t produce sweat glands, whereas the cells were the X chromosome that does not direct sweat-gland production is inactivated will produce sweat glands.

questions.raw_html_question: In werewolves (hypothetically), pointy ears (P) are dominant over round ears (p). The gene is on the X chromosome. (Sex determination in werewolves is the same as for "other" humans.) A certain female werewolf has pointy ears even though her father had round ears. What percentage of her sons will have round ears if she mates with a werewolf with round ears?
questions.question: In werewolves (hypothetically), pointy ears (P) are dominant over round ears (p). The gene is on the X chromosome. (Sex determination in werewolves is the same as for "other" humans.) A certain female werewolf has pointy ears even though her father had round ears. What percentage of her sons will have round ears if she mates with a werewolf with round ears?
questions.comments: The female werewolf must be heterozygous, because her father has round ears. Each of her sons has a 50% chance of inheriting the round allele from her. All of the sons will inherit a Y chromosome, rather than an X chromosome from their father. Therefore, 50% of the sons will have round ears.
questions.raw_html_comments: The female werewolf must be heterozygous, because her father has round ears. Each of her sons has a 50% chance of inheriting the round allele from her. All of the sons will inherit a Y chromosome, rather than an X chromosome from their father. Therefore, 50% of the sons will have round ears.

questions.raw_html_question: A “Barr body” is
questions.question: A “Barr body” is

options.text: an inactive X chromosome
an inactive Y chromosome
an active Y chromosome
an active X chromosome

questions.comments: Early during embryo development in females, the XIST gene becomes active on one of the two X chromosomes. The X chromosome on which the XIST gene becomes active is random, and is different for different cells in the embryo. When the XIST gene becomes active, it is transcribed and its transcript (RNA) attaches to the X chromosome that made it. Interaction of the RNA from the XIST gene initiates inactivation of that X chromosome. The inactive X chromosome condenses, forming what is known as a “Barr body”.
questions.raw_html_comments: Early during embryo development in females, the XIST gene becomes active on one of the two X chromosomes. The X chromosome on which the XIST gene becomes active is random, and is different for different cells in the embryo. When the XIST gene becomes active, it is transcribed and its transcript (RNA) attaches to the X chromosome that made it. Interaction of the RNA from the XIST gene initiates inactivation of that X chromosome. The inactive X chromosome condenses, forming what is known as a “Barr body”.

questions.raw_html_question: X-linked genes differ from Y-linked genes in which of the following ways?
questions.question: X-linked genes differ from Y-linked genes in which of the following ways?

options.text: Only X-linked genes are technically sex-linked because Y-linked genes affect characteristics unrelated to sex.
Although the X and Y chromosomes carry genes that determine sexual characteristics, there are not corresponding regions of homology for genes located on each chromosome.
Though most X-linked genes determine sex, Y-linked genes control for characters unrelated to sex.
Sons and daughters have equal probabilities in inheriting a recessive allele of an X-linked gene from their mother, but only sons can inherit rare Y-linked genetic disorders from their father.
Sons and daughters can inherit alleles of X-linked genes from fathers proportionally but only sons inherit alleles of Y-linked genes from their fathers.

questions.comments: Mothers can pass X-linked recessive alleles to both sons and daughters with equal probability. Because sons only inherit the one X chromosome from their mothers, they will express the recessive trait; the phenotype of daughters will depend on which X-linked allele they inherit from their fathers. Only sons inherit the Y chromosomes from their fathers, so Y-linked genetic disorders, although rare, will only affect sons.
questions.raw_html_comments: Mothers can pass X-linked recessive alleles to both sons and daughters with equal probability. Because sons only inherit the one X chromosome from their mothers, they will express the recessive trait; the phenotype of daughters will depend on which X-linked allele they inherit from their fathers. Only sons inherit the Y chromosomes from their fathers, so Y-linked genetic disorders, although rare, will only affect sons.

questions.raw_html_question: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by a sex-linked recessive allele. Its victims are almost invariably boys, who usually die before the age of 20. Why is this disorder almost never seen in girls?
questions.question: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by a sex-linked recessive allele. Its victims are almost invariably boys, who usually die before the age of 20. Why is this disorder almost never seen in girls?

options.text: A sex-linked allele cannot be passed from mother to daughter.
Nondisjunction occurs in males but not in females.
To express an X-linked recessive allele, a female must have two copies of the allele.
The allele is carried on the Y chromosome.
Sex-linked traits are never seen in girls.

questions.comments: To express an X-linked recessive allele, a female must have two copies of the allele. Because this mutation is relatively rare, it will be quite unlikely for a girl to inherit two copies of this rare allele. Moreover, males carrying the allele have less of an opportunity to have offspring.

Because many of the mutant alleles that cause sex-linked traits are homozygous, a female will only exhibit the trait if she has two mutant copies of the allele. Because males only have one X chromosome, they only need to inherit one mutant allele of genes on the X chromosome to exhibit a recessive trait.

questions.raw_html_question: Red-green color blindness is a sex-linked recessive trait in humans. Two people with normal color vision have a color-blind son. What are the genotypes of the parents?
questions.question: Red-green color blindness is a sex-linked recessive trait in humans. Two people with normal color vision have a color-blind son. What are the genotypes of the parents?

options.text: XCXC and XCY
XcXc and XcY
XCXc and XCY
XcXc and XCY
XCXC and XcY

questions.comments: Remember that the recessive trait is denoted by a lower-case letter and the dominant trait is denoted by an upper-case letter. The gene that controls color-blindness (C) is located on the X chromosome. Because the father is not color blind, he must have a normal, dominant allele of the gene on his one X chromosome, and so is XCY. Because the son is color-blind, he must have inherited the mutant, recessive allele of the gene from his mother. Because his mother is not color-blind, she must have a wild-type, dominant allele of the gene. Therefore the mother is XCXc.

questions.raw_html_question: _____ is usually less severe than _____, and _____ species have been observed in plants, fish, amphibians, and even mammals.
questions.question: _____ is usually less severe than _____, and _____ species have been observed in plants, fish, amphibians, and even mammals.

options.text: Aneuploidy ... polyploidy ... aneuploid
Polyploidy ... aneuploidy ... polyploid
Nondisjunction ... disjunction ... nondisjunctional
Monosomy ... trisomy ... monosomic
Trisomy ... monosomy ... trisomic

questions.comments: Polyploidy is when an organism has more than two sets of chromosomes. For example, a triploid organism will have three copies of each chromosome. In contrast, aneuploidy is when an organism has an abnormal number of chromosomes for its species. Aneuploidy does not include cases where the individual has one or complete sets of additional chromosomes. Polyploidy appears to disrupt genetic balance less than aneuploidy, and it has been observed among animals and especially plants.

questions.raw_html_question: Women (and all female mammals) have one active X chromosome per cell instead of two. What causes this?
questions.question: Women (and all female mammals) have one active X chromosome per cell instead of two. What causes this?

options.text: inactivation of the XIST gene on the X chromosome derived from the male parent
the removal of methyl (CH3) groups from the X chromosome that will remain active
crossover between the XIST gene on one X chromosome and a related gene on an autosome
modification of the XIST gene so that it is active only on one X chromosome, which then becomes inactive
activation of the XIST gene on the Y chromosome, which then inactivates one of the X chromosomes

questions.comments: Early during embryo development in females, the XIST gene becomes active on one of the two X chromosomes. The X chromosome on which the XIST gene becomes active is random, and is different for different cells in the embryo. When the XIST gene becomes active, it is transcribed and its transcript (RNA) attaches to the X chromosome that made it. Interaction of the RNA from the XIST gene initiates inactivation of that X chromosome. The inactive X chromosome condenses, forming what is known as a “Barr body”.

questions.raw_html_question: A red-eyed female fly was crossed with a white-eyed male fly. All the F<sub>1</sub> offspring had red eyes. Two of these red-eyed F1 generation flies were crossed to each other. The F2 generation included both red- and white-eyed flies. Remarkably, all the white-eyed flies were male. What was the explanation for this result?
questions.question: A red-eyed female fly was crossed with a white-eyed male fly. All the F1 offspring had red eyes. Two of these red-eyed F1 generation flies were crossed to each other. The F2 generation included both red- and white-eyed flies. Remarkably, all the white-eyed flies were male. What was the explanation for this result?

options.text: Other male-specific factors influence eye color in flies.
The gene involved is on the Y chromosome.
The gene involved is on the X chromosome.
The gene involved is on an autosome, but only in males.
Other female-specific factors influence eye color in flies.

questions.comments: The gene is on the X chromosome and the allele that causes white eyes is recessive. The F1 flies were the result of a cross between a mother that was homozygous for the red allele and a father that had the white allele on his one X chromosome. Therefore, all the F1females inherited one red allele (from their mother) and one white allele (from their father). All the F1 males inherited one red allele (from their mother) and inherited a Y chromosome (rather than a 2nd X chromosome) from their father. As the red allele is dominant, all the F1flies had red eyes. In the F2 generation, all the female flies inherited the red allele from their father, and therefore had red eyes, regardless of which allele they inherited from their mother. In contrast, all the male F2 flies inherited a Y chromosome from their father and either a red or a white allele on the X chromosome from their mother. Therefore, 50% of the male F2 flies, but 0% of the female F2 flies, had white eyes.
questions.raw_html_comments:
The gene is on the X chromosome and the allele that causes white eyes is recessive. The F1 flies were the result of a cross between a mother that was homozygous for the red allele and a father that had the white allele on his one X chromosome. Therefore, all the F1

Therefore, 50% of the male F2 flies, but 0% of the female F2 flies, had white eyes.

questions.raw_html_question: Cinnabar eyes is a sex-linked recessive characteristic in fruit flies. If a female having cinnabar eyes is crossed with a wild-type male, what percentage of the F1 males will have cinnabar eyes?
questions.question: Cinnabar eyes is a sex-linked recessive characteristic in fruit flies. If a female having cinnabar eyes is crossed with a wild-type male, what percentage of the F1 males will have cinnabar eyes?
questions.comments: Because cinnabar is a recessive trait, a female with cinnabar eyes must be homozygous for the cinnabar allele. Therefore, 100% of her progeny will inherit a cinnabar allele from her. Because males inherit a Y chromosome, rather than an X chromosome, from their fathers, the male progeny of this cross will all have just one, cinnabar, allele of this gene and will thus exhibit the cinnabar trait.

All of the offspring have combinations of traits that match one of the two parents.
Abnormal meiosis has occurred.
Independent assortment is hindered

questions.comments: If two genes are on different chromosomes, they will segregate randomly. For example, an individual that is Aa for a gene on chromosome 1 and Bb for a gene on chromosome 2 will produce gametes where 50% of the gametes that receive a copy of the “A” allele receive a copy of the “B” allele and the other 50% of the gametes that receive a copy of the “A” allele receive a copy of the “b” allele.

quiz_title: SQ topic 16

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following enzymes initiates the synthesis of a new nucleotide chain during DNA replication?
questions.question: Which of the following enzymes initiates the synthesis of a new nucleotide chain during DNA replication?

options.text: DNA polymerase I
DNA polymerase III
DNA polymerase II
primase

questions.comments: DNA polymerases only add nucleotides to the end of an existing nucleotide chain. So, DNA synthesis is initiated by an enzyme called primase, which catalyzes the formation of a short RNA primer, using the DNA molecule being copied as a template. DNA polymerase III is then able to catalyze the addition of deoxyribonucleotides to the 3’ end of the RNA primer. Different DNA polymerases (DNA polymerase I in E. coli) then remove the RNA primers and fill in the resulting gaps with deoxyribonucleotides.
questions.raw_html_comments: DNA polymerases only add nucleotides to the end of an existing nucleotide chain. So, DNA synthesis is initiated by an enzyme called primase, which catalyzes the formation of a short RNA primer, using the DNA molecule being copied as a template. DNA polymerase III is then able to catalyze the addition of deoxyribonucleotides to the 3’ end of the RNA primer. Different DNA polymerases (DNA polymerase I in E. coli) then remove the RNA primers and fill in the resulting gaps with deoxyribonucleotides.

questions.comments: “Chromatin” the mixture of DNA and proteins that forms a chromosome. The first order structure of chromatin is a “nucleosome”. A nucleosome consists of double-stranded DNA wrapped around a group of proteins known as “histones”. Nucleosomes than associated to form a more compact structure, known as a 30-nm fiber. Loops form in the 30-nm fiber to create an even more dense structure.

questions.raw_html_question: How do some scientists feel that telomerase might be used to slow the aging process?
questions.question: How do some scientists feel that telomerase might be used to slow the aging process?

options.text: If telomerase activity was increased in our cells, the rate at which our chromosomes lengthen as we age might be decreased.
If telomerase activity was decreased in our cells, the rate at which our chromosomes shorten as we age might be decreased.
If telomerase activity was decreased in our cells, the rate at which our chromosomes lengthen as we age might be decreased.
If telomerase activity was increased in our cells, the rate at which our chromosomes shorten as we age might be decreased.

questions.comments: Because DNA polymerases can only add nucleotides to an existing nucleotide chain, an RNA primer is used to initiate DNA synthesis. Once that RNA primer is removed from the end of a linear chromosome, there is no mechanism to completely fill in the missing nucleotides at the end of a linear chromosome (i.e. the telomere). So, in most cells, our chromosomes get shorter with each round of DNA replication. There is some evidence that suggests that this shortening of our chromosomes is one of the processes that cause us to age. An enzyme known as “telomerase” is able to partially or fully restore the lengths of telomeres. Telomerase is especially active in germline cells, so that the chromosomes that people pass onto their children are approximately as long as the chromosomes they received from their parents. Some scientists feel that if we increased the activity of telomerase in the rest of our cells, all of our cells would maintain chromosomes of approximately their original length and the negative effects of chromosome (telomere) shortening that contribute towards aging would be reduced. In fact, although this hypothesis has not yet been tested in humans, telomere extension in mice and worms has been shown to reverse some signs of aging.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following enzymes removes the RNA nucleotides from the primer and adds equivalent DNA nucleotides to the 3' end of DNA fragments resulting from DNA replication of one of the two DNA strands?
questions.question: Which of the following enzymes removes the RNA nucleotides from the primer and adds equivalent DNA nucleotides to the 3' end of DNA fragments resulting from DNA replication of one of the two DNA strands?

options.text: primase
DNA polymerase III
helicase
DNA polymerase I

questions.comments: Primase catalyzes the synthesis of short RNA “primers”. DNA polymerase III than catalyzes the extension of those primers, adding deoxyribonucleotides to the 3’ end of the RNA primer and forming DNA in the 5’ to 3’ direction. In E. coli, DNA polymerase I removes the RNA primers and fills in the resulting gaps. DNA ligase catalyzes the formation of covalent bonds between the ends of adjacent DNA fragments (i.e. Okazaki fragments), resulting in formation of a single, long DNA molecule.

questions.raw_html_question: Cytosine makes up 42% of the nucleotides in a sample of DNA from an organism. Approximately what percentage of the nucleotides in this sample will be thymine?
questions.question: Cytosine makes up 42% of the nucleotides in a sample of DNA from an organism. Approximately what percentage of the nucleotides in this sample will be thymine?
questions.comments: Remember that C and G base pair and that A and T base pair. So, if the DNA sample is 42% cytosine, it must also be 42% guanine, because base pairing of cytosine and guanine requires that they be present in equal concentration. That means that 16% (100% - 42% - 42%) of the DNA sample must consist of A and T. Because A and T base pair with each other, they need to be present in equal amounts. So, the DNA sample must have 8% adenine and 8% thymine.

questions.raw_html_question:
What would be the sequence of the DNA molecule made by replication of the DNA molecule shown below?

5’ TTCCGGA 3’
questions.question: What would be the sequence of the DNA molecule made by replication of the DNA molecule shown below?5’ TTCCGGA 3’

options.text: 5’ AAGGCCT 3’
5’ TCCGGAA 3’
5’ UCCGGAA 3’
5’ AAGGCCU 3’

questions.comments: Remember that nucleic acid chains bind with what is known as an “anti-parallel” arrangement, meaning that the 5’ end of one chain is hydrogen-bonded to the 3’ end of the other chain, and vice versa. Also remember that G and C base pair and that A and T base pair. Finally, remember that “U” is used in RNA, not DNA. So, after DNA replication, the double stranded DNA molecule will look like: 5’ TTCCGGA 3’3’ AAGGCCT 5’ So, the molecule that is synthesized is: 3’ AAGGCCT 5’ Writing this backwards, so that the new DNA molecule is written out in the conventional 5’ to 3’ direction, the molecule that is synthesized is: 5’ TTCCGGA 3’
questions.raw_html_comments:
Remember that nucleic acid chains bind with what is known as an “anti-parallel” arrangement, meaning that the 5’ end of one chain is hydrogen-bonded to the 3’ end of the other chain, and vice versa. Also remember that G and C base pair and that A and T base pair. Finally, remember that “U” is used in RNA, not DNA. So, after DNA replication, the double stranded DNA molecule will look like:

5’ TTCCGGA 3’
3’ AAGGCCT 5’

So, the molecule that is synthesized is: 3’ AAGGCCT 5’

Writing this backwards, so that the new DNA molecule is written out in the conventional 5’ to 3’ direction, the molecule that is synthesized is: 5’ TTCCGGA 3’

questions.raw_html_question: What is the role of DNA ligase during DNA replication?

options.text: It catalyzes the lengthening of telomeres.
It unwinds the parental double helix.
It synthesizes RNA nucleotides to make a primer.
It joins DNA fragments together.

questions.comments: Primase catalyzes the synthesis of short RNA “primers”. DNA polymerase III than catalyzes the extension of those primers, adding deoxyribonucleotides to the 3’ end of the RNA primer and forming DNA in the 5’ to 3’ direction. DNA polymerase I removes the RNA primers and fills in the resulting gaps. DNA ligase catalyzes the formation of covalent bonds between the ends of adjacent DNA fragments (i.e. Okazaki fragments), resulting in formation of a single, long DNA molecule.

questions.raw_html_question: Cytosine makes up 38% of the nucleotides in a sample of DNA from an organism.  Approximately what percentage of the nucleotides in this sample will be thymine?
questions.question: Cytosine makes up 38% of the nucleotides in a sample of DNA from an organism.  Approximately what percentage of the nucleotides in this sample will be thymine?
questions.comments: Remember that C and G base pair and that A and T base pair. So, if the DNA sample is 38% cytosine, it must also be 38% guanine, because base pairing of cytosine and guanine requires that they be present in equal concentration. That means that 24% (100% - 38% - 38%) of the DNA sample must consist of A and T. Because A and T base pair with each other, they need to be present in equal amounts. So, the DNA sample must have 12% adenine and 12% thymine.

Also remember that, when forming an RNA molecule using a DNA molecule as a template, an “A” RNA nucleotide will base pair with a “T” DNA nucleotide; a “G” RNA nucleotide will base pair with a “C” DNA nucleotide; a “C” RNA nucleotide will base pair with a “G” DNA nucleotide; a “U” RNA nucleotide will base pair with an “A” DNA nucleotide So, Original molecule = 3’ C C T A G G C T G C A A T C C 5'New, RNA primer = --------------- 5’ A C G U U A G G 3’

questions.comments: Remember that nucleic acid chains bind with what is known as an “anti-parallel” arrangement, meaning that the 5’ end of one chain is hydrogen-bonded to the 3’ end of the other chain, and vice versa. Also remember that G and C base pair and that A and T base pair. Finally, remember that “U” is used in RNA, not DNA. So, after DNA replication, the double stranded DNA molecule will look like: 5’ AAGGCTT 3’3’ TTCCGAA 5’ So, the molecule that is synthesized is: 3’ TTCCGAA 5’ Writing this backwards, so that the new DNA molecule is written out in the conventional 5’ to 3’ direction, the molecule that is synthesized is: 5’ AAGCCTT 3’

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following would you expect of a eukaryote lacking telomerase?
questions.question: Which of the following would you expect of a eukaryote lacking telomerase?

options.text: a high probability of somatic cells becoming cancerous
inability to repair thymine dimers
increased rates of DNA mutations
a reduction in chromosome length in gametes

questions.comments: The ends of linear chromosomes are known as “telomeres”. Because DNA polymerases can only add nucleotides to the 3’ end of an existing nucleotide chain, and the RNA primers formed by primase need to be removed from chromosomes, the ends of chromosomes (the telomeres) get a little shorter with each round of cell division/DNA replication. However, the lengths of the telomeres are restored in germline cells (the cells that produce egg and sperm cells), so that telomeres don’t get shorter from generation to generation. So, if a eukaryote lacked telomerase, chromosome length would be reduced in its gametes.

questions.raw_html_question: Suppose you are provided with an actively dividing culture of E. coli bacteria to which radioactive thymine has been added. What would happen if a cell replicates once in the presence of this radioactive base?

options.text: All four bases of the DNA would be radioactive.

DNA in both daughter cells would be radioactive.
Neither of the two daughter cells would be radioactive.

questions.comments: Replication of double stranded DNA molecules occurs by the “semi-conservative” method. In this method, the two DNA strands of the original double-stranded DNA molecule unwind and are copied, so that the two resulting double-stranded DNA molecules each consist of a DNA strand from the original double-stranded DNA molecule (a “parental” strand) and a newly synthesized DNA strand (the “daughter” strand). So, if a bacterial cell replicates once, each of the two resulting cells will inherit a double-stranded DNA molecule where one strand is composed of the original parental DNA and the other strand will consist of newly synthesized DNA, which, because it was synthesized in the presence of radioactive nucleotides, will be radioactively labeled.

questions.comments: The two strands of a double-stranded DNA molecule are held together by hydrogen bonds between the nitrogenous bases of the nucleotides. In RNA, the nitrogenous bases of guanine and cytosine interact to form three hydrogen bonds and the nitrogenous bases of adenine and uracil interact to form two hydrogen bonds. In the figure shown below, the hydrogen bonds are indicated by the red dotted lines between the bases.

Which pattern in the figure shown below would you expect if the DNA was replicated in a conservative manner?
questions.question: A space probe returns with a culture of a microorganism found on a distant planet. Analysis shows that it is a carbon-based life-form that has DNA. You grow the cells in 15N medium for several generations and then transfer them to 14N medium and grown them for another generation. Which pattern in the figure shown below would you expect if the DNA was replicated in a conservative manner?

options.text: C
E
B

questions.comments: DNA replication by a conservative, rather than the normal semi-conservative, model would mean that replication of a double-stranded DNA molecule would result in formation of two double-stranded DNA molecules, one of which would consist of two “parental” (i.e. original) DNA strands and the other of which would consist of two “daughter” (i.e. new) DNA strands. So, in the example shown above, the double-stranded DNA molecule that would consist of two parental DNA strands would have a weight equal to the weight of DNA synthesized entirely using 15N. In contast, the double-stranded DNA molecule that would consist of two daughter DNA strands would have a weight equal to the weight of DNA synthesized entirely using 14N.

questions.raw_html_question: You briefly expose bacteria undergoing DNA replication to radioactively labeled nucleotides. When you centrifuge the DNA isolated from the bacteria, the DNA separates into two classes. One class of labeled DNA includes very large molecules (thousands or even millions of nucleotides long), and the other includes short stretches of DNA (several hundred to a few thousand nucleotides in length). These two classes of DNA probably represent
questions.question: You briefly expose bacteria undergoing DNA replication to radioactively labeled nucleotides. When you centrifuge the DNA isolated from the bacteria, the DNA separates into two classes. One class of labeled DNA includes very large molecules (thousands or even millions of nucleotides long), and the other includes short stretches of DNA (several hundred to a few thousand nucleotides in length). These two classes of DNA probably represent

options.text: leading strands and Okazaki fragments.
leading strands and RNA primers.
Okazaki fragments and RNA primers.
lagging strands and Okazaki fragments.

questions.comments: The short DNA fragments likely represent Okazaki fragments. Okazaki fragments are the short DNA fragments that are made as the lagging DNA strand is synthesized. Remember that nucleotide chains are always synthesized in the 5’ to 3’ direction and that DNA polymerases only add nucleotides to the end of an existing nucleotide chain. So, DNA synthesis is initiated by an enzyme called primase, which catalyzes the formation of a short RNA primer, using the DNA molecule being copied as a template. DNA polymerase III then catalyzes the addition of deoxyribonucleotides to the 3’ end of the RNA primer. So, short nucleotide chains are formed during synthesis of the lagging strand. In contrast, synthesis of the other DNA strand, the “leading” strand, can occur continuously. So, the very large DNA molecules are likely to consist of leading strands.
questions.raw_html_comments: The short DNA fragments likely represent Okazaki fragments. Okazaki fragments are the short DNA fragments that are made as the lagging DNA strand is synthesized. Remember that nucleotide chains are always synthesized in the 5’ to 3’ direction and that DNA polymerases only add nucleotides to the end of an existing nucleotide chain. So, DNA synthesis is initiated by an enzyme called primase, which catalyzes the formation of a short RNA primer, using the DNA molecule being copied as a template. DNA polymerase III then catalyzes the addition of deoxyribonucleotides to the 3’ end of the RNA primer. So, short nucleotide chains are formed during synthesis of the lagging strand. In contrast, synthesis of the other DNA strand, the “leading” strand, can occur continuously. So, the very large DNA molecules are likely to consist of leading strands.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following will happen to your chromosomes as you become older?
questions.question: Which of the following will happen to your chromosomes as you become older?

options.text: The frequency of mutations will become smaller as DNA repair enzymes do their job.
Your chromosomes will become shorter.
All of these answers are correct.
Your DNA will accumulate segments of RNA that are left over from the work of primase.

questions.comments: As we age, our chromosomes become shorter because cells are not fully able to replicate the ends of linear chromosomes (i.e. the telomeres). As we age, the frequency of mutations in our DNA is likely to become greater, not smaller. RNA fragments are unlikely to accumulate in your DNA as such RNA fragments will be removed by special DNA polymerases.
questions.raw_html_comments: As we age, our chromosomes become shorter because cells are not fully able to replicate the ends of linear chromosomes (i.e. the telomeres). As we age, the frequency of mutations in our DNA is likely to become greater, not smaller. RNA fragments are unlikely to accumulate in your DNA as such RNA fragments will be removed by special DNA polymerases.

Which of the results in the figure shown below would be expected after one round of DNA replication in the presence of 14N?
questions.question: In the late 1950s, Meselson and Stahl grew bacteria in a medium containing "heavy" nitrogen (15N) and then transferred them to a medium containing 14N. Which of the results in the figure shown below would be expected after one round of DNA replication in the presence of 14N?

options.text: D
C
E
B

questions.comments: Replication of double-stranded DNA molecules occurs by what is known as the “semi-conservative” model. The DNA strands in the original double-stranded DNA molecule are known as the “parental” DNA strands. The DNA strands that are made by copying the parental DNA strands are known as the “daughter” DNA strands. According to the semiconservative model of DNA replication, each parental DNA strand is copied. So, after DNA replication occurs, each of the two resulting double-stranded DNA molecules consists of one parental DNA strand and one daughter DNA strand. In the example above, the nitrogen atoms in each of the parental DNA strands will be 15N, whereas the nitrogen atoms in each of the daughter strands will be 14N. Since each of the double-stranded DNA molecules that will be present after a round of replication will consist of one parental and one daughter DNA strand, each of these DNA molecules will have a weight that is half way in between the weight of DNA made entirely from 15N and the weight of DNA made entirely from 14N.
questions.raw_html_comments: Replication of double-stranded DNA molecules occurs by what is known as the “semi-conservative” model. The DNA strands in the original double-stranded DNA molecule are known as the “parental” DNA strands. The DNA strands that are made by copying the parental DNA strands are known as the “daughter” DNA strands. According to the semiconservative model of DNA replication, each parental DNA strand is copied. So, after DNA replication occurs, each of the two resulting double-stranded DNA molecules consists of one parental DNA strand and one daughter DNA strand. In the example above, the nitrogen atoms in each of the parental DNA strands will be 15N, whereas the nitrogen atoms in each of the daughter strands will be 14N. Since each of the double-stranded DNA molecules that will be present after a round of replication will consist of one parental and one daughter DNA strand, each of these DNA molecules will have a weight that is half way in between the weight of DNA made entirely from 15N and the weight of DNA made entirely from 14N.

questions.raw_html_question: If a DNA sample were composed of 10% thymine, what would be the percentage of guanine?
questions.question: If a DNA sample were composed of 10% thymine, what would be the percentage of guanine?
questions.comments: Remember that C and G base pair and that A and T base pair. So, if the DNA sample is 10% thymine, it must also be 10% adenine, because base pairing of thymine and adenine requires that they be present in equal concentration. That means that 80% (100% - 10% - 10%) of the DNA sample must consist of G and C. Because G and C base pair with each other, they need to be present in equal amounts. So, the DNA sample must have 40% guanine and 40% cytosine.

questions.raw_html_question: Will the chromosomes you pass onto your children be shorter than your chromosomes?
questions.question: Will the chromosomes you pass onto your children be shorter than your chromosomes?

options.text: Hopefully not, because telomerase will restore the telomeres in your germline cells (the cells that produce egg or sperm cells) to approximately their original length.
No, because DNA repair enzymes will fill in any missing gaps at the ends of your chromosomes.
Yes, because DNA repair enzymes do not function properly in germline cells (the cells that produce egg or sperm cells).
Yes, because DNA polymerase is not able to fully replicate the ends of chromosomes.

questions.comments: Because DNA polymerases can only add nucleotides to an existing nucleotide chain, an RNA primer is used to initiate DNA synthesis. Once that RNA primer is removed from the end of a linear chromosome, there is no mechanism to completely fill in the missing nucleotides at the end of a linear chromosome (i.e. the telomere). So, in most cells, our chromosomes get shorter with each round of DNA replication. However, an enzyme known as “telomerase” is able to partially of fully restore the lengths of telomeres. Telomerase is especially active in germline cells, so that the chromosomes that people pass onto their children are approximately as long as the chromosomes they received from their parents. So, while the chromosomes in most of your cells will get shorter as you age, the chromosomes you pass onto your children should have their original lengths.

questions.comments: Replication of double-stranded DNA molecules occurs by what is known as the “semi-conservative” model. The DNA strands in the original double-stranded DNA molecule are known as the “parental” DNA strands. The DNA strands that are made by copying the parental DNA strands are known as the “daughter” DNA strands. According to the semiconservative model of DNA replication, each parental DNA strand is copied. So, after one round of DNA replication occurs, each of the two resulting double-stranded DNA molecules will consist of one parental DNA strand and one daughter DNA strand. In the example above, after one round of DNA replication, the nitrogen atoms in each of the parental DNA strands will be 15N, whereas the nitrogen atoms in each of the daughter strands will be 14N. So, each of the two double-stranded DNA molecules present after the first round of DNA replication will have on DNA strand made using 15N and one DNA strand made using 14N. When the second round of DNA replication takes place, the DNA strands made using 15N (i.e. the DNA strands made before the experiment started) will be replicated using 14N, so that the resulting double-stranded DNA molecules will consist of a parental DNA strand made using 15N and a daughter strand made using 14N. These double-stranded DNA molecules will have a weight that is half way in between the weight of DNA made entirely from 15N and the weight of DNA made entirely from 14N. Also during the second round of DNA replication, the DNA strands made using 14N (i.e. the DNA strands synthesized in the first round of DNA replication after the experiment began) will be replicated using 14N, so that the resulting double-stranded DNA molecules will consist of two DNA strands, both made using 14N. These double-stranded DNA molecules will have the weight of DNA made entirely from 14N. So, half of the DNA molecules will have a weight that is half way between the weight of DNA made entirely from 15N and DNA made entirely from 14N. The other half of the DNA molecules will have the weight of DNA molecules made entirely from 14N.
questions.raw_html_comments:

The DNA strands that are made by copying the parental DNA strands are known as the “daughter” DNA strands. According to the semiconservative model of DNA replication, each parental DNA strand is copied.

So, after one round of DNA replication occurs, each of the two resulting double-stranded DNA molecules will consist of one parental DNA strand and one daughter DNA strand. In the example above, after one round of DNA replication, the nitrogen atoms in each of the parental DNA strands will be 15N, whereas the nitrogen atoms in each of the daughter strands will be 14N. So, each of the two double-stranded DNA molecules present after the first round of DNA replication will have on DNA strand made using 15N and one DNA strand made using 14N.

When the second round of DNA replication takes place, the DNA strands made using 15N (i.e. the DNA strands made before the experiment started) will be replicated using 14N, so that the resulting double-stranded DNA molecules will consist of a parental DNA strand made using 15N and a daughter strand made using 14N. These double-stranded DNA molecules will have a weight that is half way in between the weight of DNA made entirely from 15N and the weight of DNA made entirely from 14N.

Also during the second round of DNA replication, the DNA strands made using 14N (i.e. the DNA strands synthesized in the first round of DNA replication after the experiment began) will be replicated using 14N, so that the resulting double-stranded DNA molecules will consist of two DNA strands, both made using 14N. These double-stranded DNA molecules will have the weight of DNA made entirely from 14N.

So, half of the DNA molecules will have a weight that is half way between the weight of DNA made entirely from 15N and DNA made entirely from 14N. The other half of the DNA molecules will have the weight of DNA molecules made entirely from 14N.

questions.raw_html_question: An Okazaki fragment has which of the following arrangements?
questions.question: An Okazaki fragment has which of the following arrangements?

options.text: 3' RNA nucleotides, DNA nucleotides 5'
DNA polymerase I, DNA polymerase III
5' DNA to 3'

questions.comments: Okazaki fragments are the short DNA fragments that are made as the lagging DNA strand is synthesized. Remember that nucleotide chains are always synthesized in the 5’ to 3’ direction and that DNA polymerases only add nucleotides to the end of an existing nucleotide chain. So, DNA synthesis is initiated by an enzyme called primase, which catalyzes the formation of a short RNA primer, using the DNA molecule being copied as a template. DNA polymerase III then catalyzes the addition of deoxyribonucleotides to the 3’ end of the RNA primer. So, the short nucleotide chains that are formed during synthesis of the lagging strand (and the long nucleotide chain that is formed during synthesis of the leading strand) consists of RNA nucleotides (ribonucleotides) at the 5’ end and DNA nucleotides (deoxyribonucleotides) at the 3’ end.
questions.raw_html_comments: Okazaki fragments are the short DNA fragments that are made as the lagging DNA strand is synthesized. So, DNA synthesis is initiated by an enzyme called primase, which catalyzes the formation of a short RNA primer, using the DNA molecule being copied as a template. DNA polymerase III then catalyzes the addition of deoxyribonucleotides to the 3’ end of the RNA primer. So, the short nucleotide chains that are formed during synthesis of the lagging strand (and the long nucleotide chain that is formed during synthesis of the leading strand) consists of RNA nucleotides (ribonucleotides) at the 5’ end and DNA nucleotides (deoxyribonucleotides) at the 3’ end.

DNA polymerase can join new nucleotides only to the 3' end of a growing strand.

questions.comments: Because DNA replication always occurs in the 5’ to 3’ direction, at each DNA replication fork multiple RNA primers will be needed for replication of one of the parental DNA strands at that fork, whereas replication of the other parental DNA strand at that fork will require only one RNA primer. The DNA strand that is synthesized using multiple RNA primers is known as the “lagging” strand whereas the DNA strand that can be synthesized using only one primer at the DNA fork is known as the “leading” strand. The short DNA fragments that are formed during synthesis of the lagging strand are known as “Okazaki” fragments. As DNA replication proceeds, specific DNA polymerases (DNA pol I in E. coli) remove the RNA primers at the beginning of each Okazaki fragment and fill in the resulting gaps with deoxyribonucleotides. DNA ligase then attaches the Okazaki fragments together.

options.text: 5’ AAATTCC 3’

questions.comments: The template strand of a DNA molecule is the strand that is hydrogen bonded to complementary ribonucleotides during the formation of an RNA molecule. So, the sequence of the RNA molecule will be complementary to the sequence of the DNA template strand. Also, remember that nucleotide chains base pair with an anti-parallel arrangement, meaning that the 5’ end of one molecule is base paired with the 3’ end of the other molecule, and vice versa. Finally, remember that RNA molecules contain U in place of T. So, if the template strand is template strand: 5’ TTTAAGG 3’complementary strand (RNA): 3’ AAAUUCC 5’If we now write the sequence of the RNA molecule in the more normal 5’ to 3’ orientation (in other words, if we now write the sequence of the RNA molecule backwards to what it is above), we see that the sequence of the RNA molecule will be: 5’ CCUUAAA 3’

questions.raw_html_question: A particular triplet of bases in the coding strand of a gene is TTT.  If an mRNA is made from this gene, the anticodon on the tRNA that will bind the codon on the mRNA is
questions.question: A particular triplet of bases in the coding strand of a gene is TTT.  If an mRNA is made from this gene, the anticodon on the tRNA that will bind the codon on the mRNA is

options.text: TTT.
UUU.
GGG.
AAA.

questions.comments: The two DNA strands that form a gene are known as the coding and template strands. The template strand is the strand to which ribonucleotides hydrogen bond during the formation of an RNA molecule. So, the RNA molecule will be the complement of the template strand. The coding strand is also the complement of the template strand. Therefore, the mRNA molecule will have the same sequence as the coding strand of the DNA, with the exception that T will be replaced with U in the RNA molecule. The anticodon that binds an RNA molecule will be the complement of that molecule. What does this all mean? If the coding sequence is TTT, the sequence of the mRNA will be UUU. The sequence of the anticodon that binds this codon on the mRNA will therefore be AAA.

questions.question: A peptide has the sequence NH2-phe-pro-lys-gly-phe-pro-COOH. Which of the following sequences in the coding strand of the DNA would code for this peptide?

options.text: 3' UUU-CCC-AAA-GGG-UUU-CCC 5’
5' TTT-CCC-AAA-GGG-TTT-CCC 3’
5' GGG-AAA-TTT-AAA-CCC-ACT-GGG 3’
3' AUG-AAA-GGG-TTT-CCC-AAA-GGG 5’

questions.comments: The template strand is the strand to which ribonucleotides hydrogen bond during formation of a new RNA molecule. So, the RNA molecule will have a sequence that is complementary to the sequence of the template strand. The coding DNA strand hydrogen bonds with the template strand, meaning that the sequence of the coding strand is also complementary to the template strand. Because the RNA molecule and the coding strand are both complementary to the template strand, the nucleotide sequences of the RNA molecule and the coding strand are the same, with the exception that U is substituted for T in the RNA molecule. Probably the easiest way to figure out the answer to this question is to first realize that two of the possible answers have U’s in their sequences. Both of these answers must therefore be incorrect because DNA molecules have T rather than U. To determine which of the remaining two possible answers is the correct one, we can determine which amino acids would be specified by coding strands with the sequences shown in these two possible answers. For example, if the coding strand has a nucleotide sequence of: 5' GGG-AAA-TTT-AAA-CCC-ACT-GGG 3’, the nucleotide sequence of the corresponding RNA molecule will be as shown below (remember that RNA molecules have U instead of T).Sequence of coding strand = 5’ GGG-AAA-TTT-AAA-CCC-ACT-GGG 3’Sequence of RNA molecule = 5’ GGG-AAA-UUU-AAA-CCC-ACU-GGG 3’ Using the table showing the genetic code, we see that the first codon in this RNA molecule (GGG) codes for glycine. So, we know that this answer is incorrect. If we now determine what amino acid sequence is specified by the nucleotide sequence listed in the remaining possible answer, we find:Sequence of coding strand = 5’ TTT-CCC-AAA-GGG-TTT-CCC 3’Sequence of RNA molecule = 5’ UUU-CCC-AAA-GGG-UUU-CCC 3’ Using the table showing the genetic code, we see that the first codon in this RNA molecule (UUU) specifies phenylalanine, so this might be the correct answer. We next see that the second codon of this RNA molecule (CCC) specifies proline, which is still consistent with the sequence of the polypeptide listed in the question. The 3rd codon of this mRNA molecule (AAA) specifies lysine, the 4thcodon (GGG) specifies glycine, the 5th codon (UUU) specifies phenylalanine and the 6th codon (CCC) specifies proline. So, we have found the correct answer.NH2-phe-pro-lys-gly-phe-pro-COOH

questions.raw_html_question: A transfer RNA (#1) attached to the amino acid lysine enters the ribosome. The lysine binds to the growing polypeptide on the other tRNA (#2) in the ribosome already.  Where does tRNA #2 move to after this bonding of lysine to the polypeptide?
questions.question: A transfer RNA (#1) attached to the amino acid lysine enters the ribosome. The lysine binds to the growing polypeptide on the other tRNA (#2) in the ribosome already.  Where does tRNA #2 move to after this bonding of lysine to the polypeptide?

options.text: E site
exit tunnel
P site
A site

questions.comments: When a new, charged tRNA enters the ribosome, it enters at the A (amino acyl) site of the ribosome. At that point in time, the tRNA to which the growing polypeptide is attached is in the P (peptidyl tRNA) site of the ribosome. In this example, the tRNA to which the growing polypeptide is attached is tRNA #2. After the new, charged tRNA (tRNA #1 in this question) enters the A site of the ribosome, the ribosome catalyzes the breaking of the covalent bond connecting the polypeptide with the tRNA in the P site (= tRNA #2) and then catalyzes to formation of a new covalent bond between the polypeptide and the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the A site (lysine in this example). After that happens, the ribosome shifts position along the mRNA molecule such that the tRNA that was in the P site (tRNA #2) is now in the E site, and the tRNA that was in the A site (tRNA #1, which now has the growing polypeptide chain attached to it) is now in the P site. The tRNA (tRNA #2) which is now in the E (exit) site now leaves the ribosome. A new, charged tRNA enters the A site, and the whole process is repeated.
questions.raw_html_comments: When a new, charged tRNA enters the ribosome, it enters at the A (amino acyl) site of the ribosome. At that point in time, the tRNA to which the growing polypeptide is attached is in the P (peptidyl tRNA) site of the ribosome. In this example, the tRNA to which the growing polypeptide is attached is tRNA #2. After the new, charged tRNA (tRNA #1 in this question) enters the A site of the ribosome, the ribosome catalyzes the breaking of the covalent bond connecting the polypeptide with the tRNA in the P site (= tRNA #2) and then catalyzes to formation of a new covalent bond between the polypeptide and the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the A site (lysine in this example). After that happens, the ribosome shifts position along the mRNA molecule such that the tRNA that was in the P site (tRNA #2) is now in the E site, and the tRNA that was in the A site (tRNA #1, which now has the growing polypeptide chain attached to it) is now in the P site. The tRNA (tRNA #2) which is now in the E (exit) site now leaves the ribosome. A new, charged tRNA enters the A site, and the whole process is repeated.

questions.raw_html_question: What is meant by the statement that “the genetic code is redundant”?
questions.question: What is meant by the statement that “the genetic code is redundant”?

options.text: Most amino acids are specified by more than one codon.
Most tRNA molecules can bind a few different amino acids.
The anticodon on a tRNA molecule can bind several codons that are similar in sequence.
All of these answers are correct.

questions.comments: When we say that the genetic code is redundant, what we mean is that most amino acids are specified by more than one codon. For example, there are six different codons that all specify the amino acid leucine. It is not true that most tRNA molecules can bind a few different amino acids. In fact, each tRNA molecule can bind only one amino acid. It is true that the anticodons of some tRNAs are able to base pair with multiple codons that have almost identical sequences. However, this phenomenon is referred to as “wobble”.

For example, there are six different codons that all specify the amino acid leucine. It is not true that most tRNA molecules can bind a few different amino acids. In fact, each tRNA molecule can bind only one amino acid. It is true that the anticodons of some tRNAs are able to base pair with multiple codons that have almost identical sequences. However, this phenomenon is referred to as “wobble”.

questions.raw_html_question: Transcription in eukaryotes requires which of the following in addition to RNA polymerase?
questions.question: Transcription in eukaryotes requires which of the following in addition to RNA polymerase?

options.text: the protein product of the promoter
several transcription factors (TFs)
start and stop codons
aminoacyl synthetase

questions.comments: Promoters are DNA sequences at the beginnings of genes where transcription factors and RNA polymerase bind to form an initiation complex. Transcription begins as the transcription complex moves along the mRNA, from the promoter towards the coding region of the gene. So, promoter sequences are not transcribed and so are also not translated to form a protein. Start and stop codons play important roles in initiating and terminating TRANSLATION, rather than TRANSCRIPTION. Aminoacyl tRNA synthetases play important roles during translation, rather than transcription.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements about RNA processing is FALSE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements about RNA processing is FALSE?

options.text: Exons are cut out before mRNA leaves the nucleus.
Nucleotides may be added at both ends of the RNA.
RNA splicing can be catalyzed by spliceosomes.
Ribozymes may function in RNA splicing.

questions.comments: Introns, rather than exons, are removed from eukaryotic mRNA molecules before they leave the nucleus. It is true that nucleotides may be added at both ends of an RNA molecule, as a special nucleotide is added to the 5’ ends of eukaryotic mRNA molecules to form a 5’ cap and a string of A nucleotides are added to the 3’ ends of eukaryotic mRNA molecules to form a poly A tail. Ribozymes (RNA molecules that function as enzymes) can function in RNA splicing and spliceosomes can catalyze RNA splicing.

options.text: 5’UACGCAU 3’
5’ AUGCGUA 3’
5’ TACGCAT 3’
5’ TACGCAT 3’

questions.comments: The template strand of a DNA molecule is the strand that is hydrogen bonded to complementary ribonucleotides during the formation of an RNA molecule. So, the sequence of the RNA molecule will be complementary to the sequence of the DNA template strand. Also, remember that nucleotide chains base pair with an anti-parallel arrangement, meaning that the 5’ end of one molecule is base paired with the 3’ end of the other molecule, and vice versa. Finally, remember that RNA molecules contain U in place of T. So, if the template strand is template strand: 5’ ATGCGTA 3’complementary strand (RNA): 3’ UACGCAU 5’If we now write the sequence of the RNA molecule in the more normal 5’ to 3’ orientation (in other words, if we now write the sequence of the RNA molecule backwards to what it is above), we see that the sequence of the RNA molecule will be: 5’ UACGCAU 3’

questions.raw_html_question: A particular triplet of bases in the coding strand of a gene is AAA.  If an mRNA is made from this gene, the anticodon on the tRNA that will bind the codon on the mRNA is
questions.question: A particular triplet of bases in the coding strand of a gene is AAA.  If an mRNA is made from this gene, the anticodon on the tRNA that will bind the codon on the mRNA is

options.text: AAA.
TTT.
UUA.
UUU.

questions.comments: The two DNA strands that form a gene are known as the coding and template strands. The template strand is the strand to which ribonucleotides hydrogen bond during the formation of an RNA molecule. So, RNA molecules will be the complement of the template strand. The coding strand is also the complement of the template strand. Therefore, the mRNA molecule will have the same sequence as the coding strand of the DNA, with the exception that T will be replaced with U in the RNA molecule. The anticodon that binds an RNA molecule will be the complement of that molecule. What does this all mean? If the coding sequence is AAA, the sequence of the mRNA will also be AAA. The sequence of the anticodon that binds this codon on the mRNA will therefore be UUU.

Therefore, the mRNA molecule will have the same sequence as the coding strand of the DNA, with the exception that T will be replaced with U in the RNA molecule. The anticodon that binds an RNA molecule will be the complement of that molecule.

What does this all mean? If the coding sequence is AAA, the sequence of the mRNA will also be AAA. The sequence of the anticodon that binds this codon on the mRNA will therefore be UUU.

questions.raw_html_question: A single aminoacyl tRNA synthetase can typically recognize
questions.question: A single aminoacyl tRNA synthetase can typically recognize

options.text: just one amino acid, but several tRNAs
multiple amino acids and multiple tRNAs
multiple amino acids, but just one tRNA
just one amino acid and just one tRNA

questions.comments: A particular aminoacyl tRNA synthetase will recognize only one amino acid. However, it will recognize all of the tRNAs that have anticodons that are complementary (i.e. can hydrogen bond) with codons that specify that amino acid. For example, a particular aminoacyl tRNA synthetase can recognize, and use as a substrate, only the amino acid leucine. However, that same aminoacyl tRNA synthetase will be able to recognize, and use as substrates, all of the tRNAs that have anticodons that are complementary to the six codons that specify leucine.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following types of mutation, resulting in an error in the mRNA just after the AUG start of translation, is likely to have the LEAST serious effect on the polypeptide product?
questions.question: Which of the following types of mutation, resulting in an error in the mRNA just after the AUG start of translation, is likely to have the LEAST serious effect on the polypeptide product?

options.text: a deletion of one nucleotide
a deletion of two nucleotides
a deletion of three nucleotides
a deletion of four nucleotides

questions.comments: The WORST mutations that were listed are the deletion of 1, 2 or 4 nucleotides. The reason for this is that such mutations will cause what is known as a “frame shift”. A frame shift mutation causes all the codons (“words”) to be read incorrectly. For example, if a particular DNA sequence has codons as follows: ATG AGG CCC TTT, removing the first two nucleotides would change the codons to: GAG GCC CTT etc. These frame shifted codons would specify different amino acids than the non frame shifted codons, so that the amino acid sequence of the polypeptide made from the mutated gene would be almost completely different than the amino acid sequence of the polypeptide made from a gene that is not mutated. Removing 1 or 4 nucleotides will also cause a frame shift mutation. In contrast, deleting 3 consecutive nucleotides will not cause a frame shift, and so the mutated gene will produce a polypeptide that is almost identical in sequence to the polypeptide produced by the unmutated gene, but will just be missing one amino acid, or will have one amino acid that is substituted for two different amino acids (depending on which 3 nucleotides are deleted). Such a small change in amino acid sequence may have only a small affect on the folding of the polypeptide into the correct 3-dimensional shape, and the polypeptide may still be able to carry out most or all of its normal functions.

questions.raw_html_question: How many different amino acids could be specified if codons were two nucleotides in length?
questions.question: How many different amino acids could be specified if codons were two nucleotides in length?
questions.comments: If codons were two nucleotides long, any of the four nucleotides (A, C, G or T/U) could occupy the 1st position of the codon and any of the four nucleotides could occupy the 2nd position of the codon. The total number of codons that could thus be formed would be: 4 x 4 = 16, meaning that a maximum of 16 different amino acids could be specified if codons were only two nucleotides long. Because there are actually 20 amino acids, codons need to be more than two nucleotides long to specify all of them (i.e. codons need to be 3 nucleotides long to be able to specify all 20 amino acids).

questions.raw_html_question: Scientists sometimes transfer genes from one species to a different species.  What property of the genetic code typically allows these genes to produce a protein of the same amino acid sequence in the new species as they did in the original species?
questions.question: Scientists sometimes transfer genes from one species to a different species.  What property of the genetic code typically allows these genes to produce a protein of the same amino acid sequence in the new species as they did in the original species?

options.text: the genetic code is non-ambiguous
the genetic code is almost universal
the genetic code is redundant
the genetic code exhibits wobble

questions.comments: When we say that the genetic code is almost universal, what we mean is that almost all organisms use the same codons to specify the same amino acids. In other words, “ATG” will specify the amino acid methionine in almost every organism. Because of this, a gene that is transferred from one species to another will almost always code for a protein of the same amino acid sequence in the new species as in the original species from which the gene came. When we say that the genetic code is redundant, what we mean is that most amino acids are specified by more than one codon. For example, there are six different codons that all specify the amino acid leucine. When we say that the genetic code is non-ambiguous, what we mean is that each codon specifies only one amino acid. So, multiple codons can specify the same amino acid, but a given codon only specifies a single amino acid. When we say that the genetic code exhibits wobble, what we mean is that the anticodons of some tRNAs are able to base pair with multiple codons that have almost identical sequences. In cases where a tRNA can base pair with multiple codons, each of the codons the tRNA can base pair with will specify the same amino acid. So, “wobble” does NOT cause the genetic code to be ambiguous. A particular tRNA will always help insert the same amino acid into a polypeptide, it’s just that the tRNA may act at more than one codon that specifies that particular amino acid.
