questions.raw_html_question: What are the coding segments of a stretch of eukaryotic DNA called?
questions.question: What are the coding segments of a stretch of eukaryotic DNA called?

options.text: Exons
Introns
Replicons
Transcriptons

questions.comments: The coding segments of a stretch of eukaryotic DNA are known as exons. The DNA sequences that lie between the exons of a gene are known as “intervening” sequences, or “introns”. Introns are excised (removed, or “spliced out”) during processing of pre-mRNAs, so that mature mRNAs do not contain introns. Note that the DNA sequences that code for the 5’ and 3’ untranslated regions of mRNAs are considered to be parts of exons, even though they are not translated, because they do still code for part of a mature mRNA molecule.

Note that the DNA sequences that code for the 5’ and 3’ untranslated regions of mRNAs are considered to be parts of exons, even though they are not translated, because they do still code for part of a mature mRNA molecule.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following mutations would be most likely to have a harmful effect on an organism?
questions.question: Which of the following mutations would be most likely to have a harmful effect on an organism?

options.text: a single nucleotide deletion in the middle of an intron
a single nucleotide insertion downstream of, and close to, the start of the coding sequence
a single nucleotide insertion near the end of the coding sequence
a deletion of three nucleotides near the middle of a gene

questions.comments: A deletion of a single nucleotide in the middle of an intron is unlikely to have a deleterious effect as introns are removed from mRNA molecules prior to translation. A deletion of 3 nucleotides in the middle of a gene will cause the mutated gene to produce a polypeptide that is missing one amino acid. Such a polypeptide may still be able to fold correctly so that it has at least close to its normal 3-dimensional shape and is able to carry out most or all of its normal functions. A single nucleotide insertion near the start of the coding sequence of a gene is more likely to be deleterious than a single nucleotide insertion near the end of the coding sequence. The reason for this is that a single nucleotide insertion will cause a frame shift mutation in the gene. A frame shift mutation causes all the codons (“words”) to be read incorrectly from the point of the mutation to the end of the gene. For example, if a particular DNA sequence has codons as follows: ATG AGG CCC TTT, inserting a G nucleotide at the beginning of the sequence would change the codons to: GAT GAG GCC CCT etc. These frame shifted codons would specify different amino acids than the non frame shifted codons, so that the amino acid sequence of the polypeptide made from the part of the mutated gene following the mutation would be almost completely different than the amino acid sequence of the polypeptide made from a gene that is not mutated. If the insertion occurs further 3’ in the gene, fewer codons will be affected by the insertion. For example, if a G nucleotide is inserted after the 9th nucleotide in the DNA sequence shown above, the codons for that mutated DNA would now read: ATG AGG CCC GTT etc. So, the codons that are 5’ of the insertion site would not be affected by the insertion.
questions.raw_html_comments:

A deletion of 3 nucleotides in the middle of a gene will cause the mutated gene to produce a polypeptide that is missing one amino acid. Such a polypeptide may still be able to fold correctly so that it has at least close to its normal 3-dimensional shape and is able to carry out most or all of its normal functions.

A single nucleotide insertion near the start of the coding sequence of a gene is more likely to be deleterious than a single nucleotide insertion near the end of the coding sequence. The reason for this is that a single nucleotide insertion will cause a frame shift mutation in the gene. A frame shift mutation causes all the codons (“words”) to be read incorrectly from the point of the mutation to the end of the gene. If the insertion occurs further 3’ in the gene, fewer codons will be affected by the insertion. For example, if a G nucleotide is inserted after the 9th nucleotide in the DNA sequence shown above, the codons for that mutated DNA would now read: ATG AGG CCC GTT etc. So, the codons that are 5’ of the insertion site would not be affected by the insertion.

questions.raw_html_question: During translation, after the ribosome breaks the bond between the growing polypeptide chain and the tRNA in the P site and then forms a covalent (peptide) bond between the growing polypeptide chain and the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the A site,
questions.question: During translation, after the ribosome breaks the bond between the growing polypeptide chain and the tRNA in the P site and then forms a covalent (peptide) bond between the growing polypeptide chain and the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the A site,

options.text: the tRNA that was in the P site is now in the A site and leaves the ribosome
the tRNA that was in the P site is now in the E site and binds another amino acid
the tRNA that was in the P site is now in the E site and leaves the ribosome
the tRNA that was in the P site is now in the A site and binds another amino acid

questions.comments: When a new, charged tRNA enters the ribosome, it enters at the A (amino acyl) site of the ribosome. At that point in time, the tRNA to which the growing polypeptide is attached is in the P (peptidyl tRNA) site of the ribosome. After the new, charged tRNA enters the A site of the ribosome, the ribosome catalyzes the breaking of the covalent bond connecting the polypeptide with the tRNA in the P site and then catalyzes to formation of a new covalent bond between the polypeptide and the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the A site. After that happens, the ribosome shifts position along the mRNA molecule such that the tRNA that was in the P site is now in the E site, and the tRNA that was in the A site is now in the P site. The tRNA that is now in the E (exit) site now leaves the ribosome. A new, charged tRNA enters the A site, and the whole process is repeated.
questions.raw_html_comments: When a new, charged tRNA enters the ribosome, it enters at the A (amino acyl) site of the ribosome. The coding strand will be complementary to the template strand. So, both the coding strand of the gene and the RNA made from that gene will be complementary to the template strand of the gene. questions.raw_html_question: When the ribosome reaches a stop codon on the mRNA, no corresponding tRNA enters the A site. If the translation reaction were to be experimentally stopped at this point, which of the following would you be able to isolate?
questions.question: When the ribosome reaches a stop codon on the mRNA, no corresponding tRNA enters the A site. If the translation reaction were to be experimentally stopped at this point, which of the following would you be able to isolate?

options.text: an assembled ribosome with a separated polypeptide
an assembled ribosome with a polypeptide attached to the tRNA in the P site
separated ribosomal subunits, a polypeptide, and free tRNA
separated ribosomal subunits with a polypeptide attached to the tRNA

questions.comments: Normally, when the ribosome reaches a stop codon on the mRNA, the stop codon will be aligned with the A (aminoacyl) site of the ribosome. A protein called a “release factor” will bind the stop codon in the A site. When this happens, the polypeptide chain attached to the tRNA in the ribosome P site is cleaved from the tRNA and the translation assembly (e.g. the ribosome, tRNA and mRNA) comes apart. In this experiment, this process was arrested, meaning that no release factor was allowed to enter the A site. As a consequence, the polypeptide will still be attached to the tRNA in the P site and the ribosome will not have dissociated from the mRNA molecule.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following types of mutation, resulting in an error in the mRNA just after the AUG start of translation, is likely to have the LEAST serious effect on the polypeptide product?
questions.question: Which of the following types of mutation, resulting in an error in the mRNA just after the AUG start of translation, is likely to have the LEAST serious effect on the polypeptide product?

options.text: an insertion of four nucleotides
an insertion of two nucleotides
an insertion of one nucleotide
an insertion of three nucleotides

questions.comments: The WORST mutations that were listed are the insertion of 1, 2 or 4 nucleotides. The reason for this is that such mutations will cause what is known as a “frame shift”. A frame shift mutation causes all the codons (“words”) to be read incorrectly. For example, if a particular DNA sequence has codons as follows: ATG AGG CCC TTT, adding two nucleotides (e.g. adding two G nucleotides to the beginning of the molecule) would change the codons to: GGA TGA GGC CCT etc. These frame shifted codons would specify different amino acids than the non frame shifted codons, so that the amino acid sequence of the polypeptide made from the mutated gene would be almost completely different than the amino acid sequence of the polypeptide made from a gene that is not mutated. Inserting 1 or 4 nucleotides will also cause a frame shift mutation. In contrast, inserting 3 nucleotides will not cause a frame shift, and so the mutated gene will produce a polypeptide that is almost identical in sequence to the polypeptide produced by the unmutated gene. The polypeptide produced by this mutated gene will just have one extra amino acid and possibly, depending on exactly where the 3 nucleotides are inserted, one amino acid that is switched to a different amino acid. Such a small change in amino acid sequence may have only a small affect on the folding of the polypeptide into the correct 3-dimensional shape, and the polypeptide may still be able to carry out most or all of its normal functions.

questions.raw_html_question: How many different amino acids could be specified if codons were four nucleotides in length?
questions.question: How many different amino acids could be specified if codons were four nucleotides in length?
questions.comments: If codons were four nucleotides long, any of the four nucleotides (A, C, G or T/U) could occupy the 1st position of the codon and any of the four nucleotides could occupy the 2nd, 3rd and 4thpositions of the codon. The total number of codons that could thus be formed would be: 4 x 4 x 4 x 4 = 256, meaning that a maximum of 256 different amino acids could be specified if codons were four nucleotides long. Because there are actually only 20 amino acids, codons do not need to be four nucleotides long to specify all of them (i.e. codons only need to be 3 nucleotides long to be able to specify all 20 amino acids).

questions.raw_html_question: Given the locally unwound double strand below, in which direction does the RNA polymerase move?
questions.question: Given the locally unwound double strand below, in which direction does the RNA polymerase move?

options.text: 5' → 3' along the complementary strand
5' → 3' along the template strand
3' → 5' along the complementary strand
3' → 5' along the template strand

questions.comments: Remember that RNA polymerase, like DNA polymerase, adds nucleotides to the 3’ end of the growing nucleotide chain. Also remember that RNA polymerase uses the DNA template strand as its template, meaning that the ribonucleotides of the RNA molecule will be hydrogen bonded with the deoxyribonucleotides of the template strand. Finally, remember that the template strand and the RNA molecule will be hydrogen bonded in an antiparallel arrangement, meaning that the 5’ end of the template strand will be hydrogen bonded with the 3’ end of the RNA molecule and the 3’ end of the template strand be hydrogen bonded with the 5’ end of the RNA molecule. Putting this all together, RNA polymerase will begin synthesis of a new RNA molecule by adding ribonucleotides that are hydrogen bonded with the 3’ end of the template strand, as these ribonucleotides will thus form the 5’ end of the RNA strand. The RNA polymerase will then move in the 3’ to 5’ direction along the template strand, so that it can add ribonucleotides to the growing RNA molecule in the 5’ to 3’ direction.

questions.raw_html_question: During translation (polypeptide elongation), charged tRNAs enter the ribosome at the
questions.question: During translation (polypeptide elongation), charged tRNAs enter the ribosome at the

options.text: E site
A site

questions.comments: During elongation of a polypeptide, when a new, charged tRNA enters the ribosome, it enters at the A (amino acyl) site of the ribosome. At that point in time, the tRNA to which the growing polypeptide is attached is in the P (peptidyl tRNA) site of the ribosome. After the new, charged tRNA enters the A site of the ribosome, the ribosome catalyzes the breaking of the covalent bond connecting the polypeptide with the tRNA in the P site and then catalyzes to formation of a new covalent bond between the polypeptide and the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the A site. After that happens, the ribosome shifts position along the mRNA molecule such that the tRNA that was in the P site is now in the E site, and the tRNA that was in the A site is now in the P site. The tRNA that is now in the E (exit) site now leaves the ribosome. A new, charged tRNA enters the A site, and the whole process is repeated. Note that during initiation of translation, the initiator tRNA, with methionine attached to it, ends up in the P site of the ribosome.

questions.comments: When the ribosome reaches a stop codon on the mRNA, the stop codon will be aligned with the A (aminoacyl) site of the ribosome. Normally, a tRNA with an appropriate anticodon binds the mRNA codon that is aligned with the A site of the ribosome. However, when the codon that is aligned with the A site is a stop codon, a protein called a “release factor” will bind the stop codon in the A site instead of a tRNA. When this happens, the polypeptide chain attached to the tRNA in the ribosome P site is cleaved from the tRNA and the translation assembly (e.g. the ribosome, tRNA and mRNA) comes apart.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE?

options.text: All of these statements are true.
5’ and 3’ untranslated regions (UTRs) are parts of exons, but do not code for proteins.
Many eukaryotic genes have “intervening” sequences, or introns, that do not code for proteins.
Many eukaryotic primary mRNA molecules have “intervening” sequences, or introns, that do not code for proteins.

questions.comments: The noncoding regions of both genes and the primary mRNA molecules made from those genes are known as “intervening” sequences, or “introns”. Similarly, the coding regions of both genes and the RNA molecules made from genes are known as “exons” (sort of short for “expressed sequence”). Although 5’ and 3’ untranslated regions (UTRs) do not code for proteins, they are still part of the mature mRNA molecule and so are still considered to be part of exons rather than introns (introns are removed during formation of mature mRNA molecules).

questions.comments: The template strand of a DNA molecule is the strand that is hydrogen bonded to complementary ribonucleotides during the formation of an RNA molecule. So, the sequence of the RNA molecule will be complementary to the sequence of the DNA template strand. Also, remember that nucleotide chains base pair with an anti-parallel arrangement, meaning that the 5’ end of one molecule is base paired with the 3’ end of the other molecule, and vice versa. Finally, remember that RNA molecules contain U in place of T. So, if the template strand is 5’ GGT 3’, the complementary strand will have the sequence: 3’ CCA 5’

questions.raw_html_question: For the DNA molecule shown below, where would the promoter be located?
questions.question: For the DNA molecule shown below, where would the promoter be located?

options.text: at the 5’ end of the newly made RNA
to the left of the template strand
at the 3' end of the newly made RNA
to the right of the template strand

questions.comments: Remember that RNA polymerase, like DNA polymerase, adds nucleotides to the 3’ end of the growing nucleotide chain. Also remember that RNA polymerase uses the DNA template strand as its template, meaning that the ribonucleotides of the RNA molecule will be hydrogen bonded with the deoxyribonucleotides of the template strand. Finally, remember that the template strand and the RNA molecule will be hydrogen bonded in an antiparallel arrangement, meaning that the 5’ end of the template strand will be hydrogen bonded with the 3’ end of the RNA molecule and the 3’ end of the template strand be hydrogen bonded with the 5’ end of the RNA molecule. Putting this all together, RNA polymerase will begin synthesis of a new RNA molecule by adding ribonucleotides that are hydrogen bonded with the 3’ end of the template strand, as these ribonucleotides will thus form the 5’ end of the RNA strand. So, the promoter (the DNA sequence where the RNA polymerase binds) must be to the right of the template strand.

Putting this all together, RNA polymerase will begin synthesis of a new RNA molecule by adding ribonucleotides that are hydrogen bonded with the 3’ end of the template strand, as these ribonucleotides will thus form the 5’ end of the RNA strand. questions.raw_html_question: During translation,
questions.question: During translation,

options.text: the growing polypeptide chain is transferred from the tRNA in the E ribosome site to the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the A ribosome site.
the growing polypeptide chain is transferred from the tRNA in the P ribosome site to the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the E ribosome site.
the growing polypeptide chain is transferred from the tRNA in the A ribosome site to the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the P ribosome site.
the growing polypeptide chain is transferred from the tRNA in the P ribosome site to the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the A ribosome site.

questions.comments: During elongation of a polypeptide, when a new, charged tRNA enters the ribosome, it enters at the A (amino acyl) site of the ribosome. At that point in time, the tRNA to which the growing polypeptide is attached is in the P (peptidyl tRNA) site of the ribosome. After the new, charged tRNA enters the A site of the ribosome, the ribosome catalyzes the breaking of the covalent bond connecting the polypeptide with the tRNA in the P site and then catalyzes to formation of a new covalent bond between the polypeptide and the amino acid attached to the tRNA in the A site. After that happens, the ribosome shifts position along the mRNA molecule such that the tRNA that was in the P site is now in the E site, and the tRNA that was in the A site is now in the P site. The tRNA that is now in the E (exit) site now leaves the ribosome. A new, charged tRNA enters the A site, and the whole process is repeated.

questions.raw_html_question: What is meant by the statement that “the genetic code is not ambiguous”?
questions.question: What is meant by the statement that “the genetic code is not ambiguous”?

options.text: All of these answers are correct.
Each amino acid is specified by just one codon.
Each codon specifies just one amino acid.
Compared with DNA, RNA has ribose instead of deoxyribose and uracil instead of thymine, preventing mixing up of DNA and RNA

questions.comments: The statement that the genetic code is not ambiguous refers to the fact that each codon specifies just a single amino acid. It is not true that each amino acid is specified by one a single codon. In fact, most amino acids are specified by multiple codons, so that the genetic code is considered to be “redundant”. Although it is true that, compared with DNA, RNA has ribose instead of deoxyribose and uracil instead of thymine, preventing mixing up of DNA and RNA, this has nothing to do with the fact that the genetic code is not ambiguous.

questions.raw_html_question: You are studying the polypeptides produced by a particular human gene, and notice that about half of the polypeptides have a molecular mass of 200 kDa and the other half have a molecular mass of 150 kDa.  One of your hypotheses for why this gene might produce proteins of different molecular masses might be
questions.question: You are studying the polypeptides produced by a particular human gene, and notice that about half of the polypeptides have a molecular mass of 200 kDa and the other half have a molecular mass of 150 kDa.  One of your hypotheses for why this gene might produce proteins of different molecular masses might be

options.text: The gene is more heavily transcribed in some cells than in others.

The primary transcripts encoded by the gene undergo alternative splicing and the different mature mRNAs that result encode proteins with different numbers of exons and thus different molecular masses.

questions.comments: The gene is likely to be more heavily (i.e. frequently) transcribed in some cells than in others, but this won’t affect the size of the polypeptide molecules produced by this gene in those cells. The transcripts produced by the gene may also be more heavily (i.e. frequently) translated in some cells than in others, but this won’t affect the size of the polypeptide molecules produced by the transcripts.

questions.raw_html_question: Why do neural cells have different characteristics than skin cells?
questions.question: Why do neural cells have different characteristics than skin cells?

options.text: Different genes are expressed in neural than in skin cells.
Different genes are present in neural than in skin cells.
Neural cells have more copies of some genes and skin cells have more copies of other cells.
Genes are expressed at higher levels in neural cells, which are very active, than in skin cells, which play primarily a structural role.

questions.comments: All of the cells in our bodies, with a few exceptions, contain the same DNA and therefore the same genes. Similarly, the copy number of the genes in our cells is the same for different cells. However, only a fraction of our genes are expressed in any given cell, and different genes are expressed in different cells. In general, all cells express some proteins at high levels, it’s just that different cells will not express all of the same proteins at high levels.

questions.raw_html_question: In eukaryotes, transcriptional activators
questions.question: In eukaryotes, transcriptional activators

options.text: may bind specific DNA sequences associated with genes and increase the affinity of RNA polymerase for the promoters for those genes.

may bind specific DNA sequences associated with genes and decrease the affinity of RNA polymerase for the promoters for those genes.
may bind specific DNA sequences associated with genes and decrease the affinity of ribosomes for the promoters for those genes.

questions.comments: Eukaryotic transcriptional activators get their name from the fact that they “activate” (increase) transcription of the genes they regulate. They do this by increasing the affinity of RNA polymerase for the promoter(s) of the gene(s) they regulate. In contrast, transcriptional repressors get their name from the fact that they “repress” (decrease) transcription of the genes they regulate. They do this by decreasing the affinity of RNA polymerase for the promoter(s) of the gene(s) they regulate. RNA polymerase, not ribosomes, bind promoters.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements comparing regulation of the lac and trp operons is TRUE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements comparing regulation of the lac and trp operons is TRUE?

options.text: The lac repressor protein is stabilized in its inactive shape by binding its corepressor (allolactose), whereas the trp repressor protein is stabilized in its active shape by binding its inducer (tryptophan).

The lac repressor protein is stabilized in its inactive shape by binding its inducer (allolactose), whereas the trp repressor protein is stabilized in its active shape by binding its corepressor (tryptophan).

The lac repressor protein is stabilized in its active shape by binding its inducer (allolactose), whereas the trp repressor protein is stabilized in its inactive shape by binding its corepressor (tryptophan).

The lac repressor protein is stabilized in its active shape by binding its corepressor (allolactose), whereas the trp repressor protein is stabilized in its inactive shape by binding its inducer (tryptophan).

questions.comments: When trying to remember the difference between inducers and corepressors of repressor proteins, remember that these small molecules are NOT named because of how they affect the activity of the repressor protein. Instead, they are named because of how they affect the rate of transcription of the genes in the operon(s) they help regulate. So, “inducers” are called inducers because scientists used to think that they “induce” (i.e. “turn on”) expression of the genes in the operons they help regulate. We now know that what inducers actually do is to stabilize repressor proteins in their inactive form. By stabilizing repressor proteins in their inactive form, inducers keep the repressor proteins from binding to the operator sequences and preventing transcription. So, in a sense, inducers allow gene transcription to proceed by turning off a repressor. Corepressors work in kind of the opposite way. Corepressors stabilize the repressor proteins with which they interact in their active form. So, when the correct corepressor is present in a cell, the repressor protein with which it interacts will bind to it and be stabilized in its active form. The active repressor/corepressor complex will then bind the operator sequence, preventing transcription of the genes in the operon by RNA polymerase. So, the name “corepressor” refers to the fact that corepressors help repress transcription of the genes in the operon.

So, when the correct corepressor is present in a cell, the repressor protein with which it interacts will bind to it and be stabilized in its active form. The active repressor/corepressor complex will then bind the operator sequence, preventing transcription of the genes in the operon by RNA polymerase. So, the name “corepressor” refers to the fact that corepressors help repress transcription of the genes in the operon.

questions.raw_html_question: Within a cell, the amount of protein made using a given mature mRNA molecule depends partly on
questions.question: Within a cell, the amount of protein made using a given mature mRNA molecule depends partly on

options.text: the presence of certain transcription factors.
the degree of DNA methylation.
the number of introns present in the mRNA.
the rate at which the mRNA is degraded.

questions.comments: The degree of DNA methylation and the presence of certain transcription factors will affect the rate at which the DNA molecule is transcribed to form RNA, but will not affect the rate at which the mRNA made from that molecule is translated to form protein. Similarly, the number of introns may affect the rate at which the primary transcript is processed to form a mature mRNA, but since the introns will no longer be present in the mature mRNA will have no effect on the rate at which the mRNA molecule is translated to form protein. In contrast, the rate at which the mRNA molecule is degraded will affect the amount of protein made by that mRNA molecule. If it is degraded very quickly, it may have been translated only once or twice. If it is degraded very slowly, it may have had time to have been translated many times before being degraded.

We now know that what inducers actually do is to stabilize repressor proteins in their inactive form. By stabilizing repressor proteins in their inactive form, inducers keep the repressor proteins from binding to the operator sequences and preventing transcription. So, in a sense, inducers allow gene transcription to proceed by turning off a repressor. Corepressors work in kind of the opposite way. Corepressors stabilize the repressor proteins with which they interact in their active form. So, when the correct corepressor is present in a cell, the repressor protein with which it interacts will bind to it and be stabilized in its active form. The active repressor/corepressor complex will then bind the operator sequence, preventing transcription of the genes in the operon by RNA polymerase. So, the name “corepressor” refers to the fact that corepressors help repress transcription of the genes in the operon.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is the best definition of a gene that is being “expressed”?
questions.question: Which of the following is the best definition of a gene that is being “expressed”?

options.text: A gene that is producing lots of RNA is being expressed.
A gene that is part of chromatin that is open and accessible to transcription factors and RNA polymerase is being expressed.
A gene that is producing lots of protein is being expressed.
A gene that is producing its final product (protein or non-coding RNA) in a functional form is being expressed.

questions.raw_html_question: Gene expression in eukaryotes is NOT regulated by
questions.question: Gene expression in eukaryotes is NOT regulated by

options.text: how efficiently RNA molecules are processed
how efficiently proteins are transported to their correct cellular destinations
mRNA stability
how efficiently trans-inducer molecules are transported to the correct part of the nucleus

questions.comments: Gene expression in eukaryotes is regulated in just about every way imaginable. However, there is no such thing as “trans-inducer” molecules.
questions.raw_html_comments: Gene expression in eukaryotes is regulated in just about every way imaginable. However, there is no such thing as “trans-inducer” molecules.

questions.raw_html_question: A mutation that inactivates the function of a repressor protein involved in the regulation of a bacterial operon would result in
questions.question: A mutation that inactivates the function of a repressor protein involved in the regulation of a bacterial operon would result in

options.text: irreversible binding of the repressor protein to the mRNA.
inactivation of the RNA polymerase.
continuous transcription of the structural genes in the operon.
inhibition of transcription of the structural genes in the operon.

questions.comments: In general, a bacterial operon will be transcribed by RNA polymerase unless an active repressor protein is able to bind to the operator sequence, blocking transcription of the genes in the operon by RNA polymerase. If the mutation inactivates the function of the repressor protein, the repressor protein will never be able to bind the operator sequence and block transcription. Consequently, the genes of the operon will always be transcribed.
questions.raw_html_comments: In general, a bacterial operon will be transcribed by RNA polymerase unless an active repressor protein is able to bind to the operator sequence, blocking transcription of the genes in the operon by RNA polymerase. If the mutation inactivates the function of the repressor protein, the repressor protein will never be able to bind the operator sequence and block transcription. Consequently, the genes of the operon will always be transcribed.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following mutations would make it impossible for a bacterial cell to metabolize lactose?
questions.question: Which of the following mutations would make it impossible for a bacterial cell to metabolize lactose?

options.text: A mutation in the promoter for the lac operon such that it can no longer bind RNA polymerase
All of these answers are correct.
A mutation in the gene encoding the lac repressor protein such that the lac repressor protein can no longer bind to the operator
A mutation in the operator for the lac operon such that it can no longer bind with lac repressor protein

questions.comments: For a bacterial cell to be able to metabolize lactose, it needs to express the genes of the lac operon as these genes encode the enzymes necessary for metabolizing lactose. In order for the genes of the lac operon to be transcribed, RNA polymerase needs to be able to bind the promoter for the lacoperon. In contrast, mutations that remove the ability of the lac repressor protein to bind the lac operator sequence will actually cause an INCREASE in the rate at which the genes of the lac operon are transcribed, because lac repressor will no longer be able to block transcription of the lac genes by RNA polymerase.

operon. In contrast, mutations that remove the ability of the lac repressor protein to bind the lac operator sequence will actually cause an INCREASE in the rate at which the genes of the lac operon are transcribed, because lac repressor will no longer be able to block transcription of the lac genes by RNA polymerase.

questions.raw_html_question: A mutation that inactivates the regulatory (repressor) gene of a repressible operon in an E. coli cell would result in
questions.question: A mutation that inactivates the regulatory (repressor) gene of a repressible operon in an E. coli cell would result in

options.text: complete inhibition of transcription of the structural gene controlled by that regulator.
irreversible binding of the repressor to the operator.
inactivation of RNA polymerase by alteration of its active site.
continuous transcription of the structural gene controlled by that regulator.

questions.comments: The regulatory gene of a repressible operon would be the gene that encodes the repressor protein for that operon. If the cell can’t make that repressor protein, the cell will have no way of turning off transcription of the genes regulated by that repressor protein. So, the genes in the operon controlled by that repressor protein will be transcribed all of the time.
questions.raw_html_comments: The regulatory gene of a repressible operon would be the gene that encodes the repressor protein for that operon. So, the genes in the operon controlled by that repressor protein will be transcribed all of the time.

questions.raw_html_question: The tryptophan operon is a repressible operon that is
questions.question: The tryptophan operon is a repressible operon that is

options.text: turned off only when glucose is present in the growth medium.
permanently turned on.
turned off whenever tryptophan is added to the growth medium.
turned on only when tryptophan is present in the growth medium.

questions.comments: The genes in the tryptophan (trp) operon encode enzymes that are used to make tryptophan. So, cells only want to express these genes when the cells are low in tryptophan. This means that cells turn off expression of the genes of the trp operon whenever substantial amounts of tryptophan are present in the cell. The mechanism by which this occurs is that tryptophan itself is a corepressor for the repressor protein for the trp operon. When there are lots of tryptophan molecules in a cell, the tryptophan molecules will interact with the repressor protein for the trp operon, causing the repressor protein to be stabilized in its active form. The active repressor/corepressor complex will then bind the operator nucleotide sequence for the trpoperon, blocking transcription of the gene contained within the trpoperon by RNA polymerase.

The active repressor/corepressor complex will then bind the operator nucleotide sequence for the trp
operon, blocking transcription of the gene contained within the trp
operon by RNA polymerase.

questions.raw_html_question: Increasing the affinity of RNA polymerase for the promoter of a particular gene will
questions.question: Increasing the affinity of RNA polymerase for the promoter of a particular gene will

questions.raw_html_question: There is a mutation in the lac repressor gene that results in production of an altered lac repressor protein known as a “super-repressor” because it represses the lac operon permanently. Which of these would characterize such a mutant?
questions.question: There is a mutation in the lac repressor gene that results in production of an altered lac repressor protein known as a “super-repressor” because it represses the lac operon permanently. Which of these would characterize such a mutant?

options.text: It cannot bind to the inducer.
It makes molecules that bind to one another.
It cannot bind to the operator.
It cannot make a functional repressor.

questions.comments: Normal (unmutated) lac repressor protein is most stable in its active form. Active lac repressor protein binds the operator DNA sequence for the lac operon, blocking transcription of the genes of the lac operon by RNA polymerase. When allolactose is present, normal lac repressor protein binds the allolactose (its inducer) and is stabilized in its inactive form, meaning that it is unable to bind the operator sequence and block gene transcription. If the mutation makes it so that the “super repressor” protein is unable to bind allolactose, than even when allolactose is present the “super-repressor” protein will be unable to bind the allolactose and be stabilized in its inactive form. So, even in the presence of allolactose, the “super repressor” protein will always be more stable in its active form and will bind the lac operator sequence and block transcription of the lac operon.
questions.raw_html_comments: Normal (unmutated) lac repressor protein is most stable in its active form. When allolactose is present, normal lac repressor protein binds the allolactose (its inducer) and is stabilized in its inactive form, meaning that it is unable to bind the operator sequence and block gene transcription. If the mutation makes it so that the “super repressor” protein is unable to bind allolactose, than even when allolactose is present the “super-repressor” protein will be unable to bind the allolactose and be stabilized in its inactive form. So, even in the presence of allolactose, the “super repressor” protein will always be more stable in its active form and will bind the lac operator sequence and block transcription of the lac operon.

questions.raw_html_question: “Alternative splicing” refers to
questions.question: “Alternative splicing” refers to

options.text: slightly different sets of exons being present in different mature mRNA molecules made from a single gene.
the polycistronic mRNA made by a prokaryotic organism being cut to form different polypeptides.
slightly different sets of introns being present in different mature mRNA molecules made from a single gene.
different sets of chromatin modifications being cut from different genes.

questions.comments: Alternative splicing is a mechanism that is commonly used by eukaryotes to allow their genes to produce multiple, related, proteins. Approximately 95% of human genes that have more than one exon are thought to make use of alternative splicing. For example, the troponin T gene has 5 exons. All 5 exons, plus the introns between the exons, are present in each primary RNA transcript made from the gene. However, different primary RNA transcripts from this gene are spliced in slightly different ways (i.e. the undergo “alternative splicing”). Some of the primary RNA transcript molecules are spliced such that the mature mRNA transcript has exons 1, 2, 3 and 5. Other primary RNA transcript molecules are spliced such that the mature mRNA transcript has exons 1, 2, 4 and 5.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements about the lac operon is TRUE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements about the lac operon is TRUE?

options.text: When lac repressor protein binds allolactose, it is stabilized in its inactive shape, preventing transcription of the genes of the lac operon from occurring.
When lac repressor protein binds allolactose, it is stabilized in its active shape, allowing transcription of the genes of the lac operon to proceed.
When lac repressor protein binds allolactose, it is stabilized in its active shape, preventing transcription of the genes of the lac operon from occurring.
When lac repressor protein binds allolactose, it is stabilized in its inactive shape, allowing transcription of the genes of the lac operon to proceed.

questions.comments: When a repressor protein is in its active shape, the active repressor protein will bind its operator blocking transcription of the genes in that operon by RNA polymerase. When a repressor protein is in its inactive shape, it will be unable to bind its operator sequence and RNA polymerase will be able to transcribe the genes in that operon. Allolactose, which is made from lactose, is the repressor for the lac repressor protein. When cells have lots of lactose, its desirable for the cells to transcribe the genes of the lac operon as those genes are needed to metabolize lactose. So, if a cell has lots of lactose, a small percentage of that lactose will be converted to allolactose. That allolactose will interact with the lac repressor protein, causing the lac repressor protein to be stabilized in its inactive form. Once the lac repressor protein is in its inactive form, it is not able to bind the lac operator DNA sequence and block transcription of the lac operon by RNA polymerase. So, RNA polymerase does transcribe those genes.
questions.raw_html_comments: When a repressor protein is in its active shape, the active repressor protein will bind its operator blocking transcription of the genes in that operon by RNA polymerase. When a repressor protein is in its inactive shape, it will be unable to bind its operator sequence and RNA polymerase will be able to transcribe the genes in that operon. Once the lac repressor protein is in its inactive form, it is not able to bind the lac operator DNA sequence and block transcription of the lac operon by RNA polymerase. So, RNA polymerase does transcribe those genes.

questions.raw_html_question: If a particular operon encodes enzymes for making an essential amino acid and is regulated like the trp operon, then
questions.question: If a particular operon encodes enzymes for making an essential amino acid and is regulated like the trp operon, then

options.text: the amino acid inactivates the repressor.
the amino acid turns on transcription of the operon.
the amino acid acts as a corepressor.
the repressor is active in the absence of the amino acid.

questions.comments: The amino acid will act as a corepressor. Remember that corepressors (and inducers) are NOT named because of how they affect the activity of the repressor protein. Instead, they are named because of how they affect the rate of transcription of the genes in the operon(s) they help regulate. Corepressors stabilize the active form of the repressor proteins with which they interact. So, when the correct corepressor is present in a cell, the repressor protein with which it interacts will bind to it and be stabilized in its active form. The active repressor/corepressor complex will then bind the operator sequence, preventing transcription of the genes in the operon by RNA polymerase. So, the name “corepressor” refers to the fact that corepressors help repress transcription of the genes in the operon. Also, think about the fact that a cell only wants to make the enzymes that allow it to synthesize a particular amino acid when the cell has only low amounts of that amino acid. So, cells want to be set up in such a way that the presence of significant amounts of that amino acid represses transcription of the genes that encode the enzymes for making more of that amino acid. So, you want the amino acid to act as a corepressor.

So, the name “corepressor” refers to the fact that corepressors help repress transcription of the genes in the operon.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is most likely to have a small protein called ubiquitin attached to it?
questions.question: Which of the following is most likely to have a small protein called ubiquitin attached to it?

options.text: a regulatory protein that requires sugar residues to be attached
an mRNA that is leaving the nucleus to be translated
a protein involved in glycine biosynthesis in a cell with lots of glycine
a cell surface protein that requires transport from the ER

questions.comments: One of the main functions of ubiquitin is to bind to proteins that need to be degraded (broken down). Of the choices listed in the possible answers, a protein involved in glycine synthesis in a cell with lots of glycine is a protein that is not needed by the cell and so one that might well be targeted for degradation.

questions.raw_html_question: If a researcher moves the lac operator to a position upstream from the promoter for the lac operon, what would occur?
questions.question: If a researcher moves the lac operator to a position upstream from the promoter for the lac operon, what would occur?

options.text: The repressor will not be able to bind to the operator.
The lac operon will be expressed continuously.
The lac operon will function normally.
The repressor will no longer be made.

questions.comments: Normally operator sequences lie between promoter sequences (where RNA polymerase binds) and the structural genes of the operon. This arrangement means that, if active repressor protein is bound to the operator sequence, it will physically block the movement of RNA polymerase along the mRNA molecule towards the structural genes of the operon. So, the normal placement of the operator sequence between the promoter sequence and the structural genes of the operon is necessary for its function. If you move the operator sequence so that it is on the far side of the the promoter from the structural genes, even if active repressor protein binds the operator sequence, it won’t be in the right place to be able to block transcription of the structural genes.Normal situation:Promoter sequences (where RNA polymerase binds)----operator sequences (where active repressor protein binds)---structural genesSituation after research moves the lac operator sequences:Operator sequences (where active repressor protein binds)----promoter sequences (where RNA polymerase binds)----structural genes.See how, in the artificial case, even if active repressor protein is bound to the operator sequences it won’t be between RNA polymerase and the genes to be transcribed and therefore won’t be able to prevent RNA polymerase from being able to transcribe the genes all of the time?
questions.raw_html_comments:
Normally operator sequences lie between promoter sequences (where RNA polymerase binds) and the structural genes of the operon. This arrangement means that, if active repressor protein is bound to the operator sequence, it will physically block the movement of RNA polymerase along the mRNA molecule towards the structural genes of the operon. So, the normal placement of the operator sequence between the promoter sequence and the structural genes of the operon is necessary for its function. If you move the operator sequence so that it is on the far side of the the promoter from the structural genes, even if active repressor protein binds the operator sequence, it won’t be in the right place to be able to block transcription of the structural genes.

Normal situation:
Promoter sequences (where RNA polymerase binds)----operator sequences (where active repressor protein binds)---structural genes

Situation after research moves the lac operator sequences:

Operator sequences (where active repressor protein binds)----promoter sequences (where RNA polymerase binds)----structural genes.

See how, in the artificial case, even if active repressor protein is bound to the operator sequences it won’t be between RNA polymerase and the genes to be transcribed and therefore won’t be able to prevent RNA polymerase from being able to transcribe the genes all of the time?

questions.raw_html_question: A lack of which molecule would result in the cell's inability to "turn off” genes?
questions.question: A lack of which molecule would result in the cell's inability to "turn off” genes?

options.text: inducer
promoter
operon
corepressor

questions.comments: “Operons” are clusters of genes that are under the control of a single regulatory sequence (e.g. a promoter sequence). Removing an operon would thus result in the genes of that operon being off permanently, rather than being unable to be turned off. Similarly, promoters are nucleotide sequences near genes where RNA polymerase binds and starts the process of transcribing the gene(s) to form an RNA molecule. When trying to remember the difference between inducers and corepressors of repressor proteins, remember that these small molecules are NOT named because of how they affect the activity of the repressor protein. Instead, they are named because of how they affect the rate of transcription of the genes in the operon(s) they help regulate. So, “inducers” are called inducers because scientists used to think that they “induce” (i.e. “turn on”) expression of the genes in the operons they help regulate. We now know that what inducers actually do is to stabilize repressor proteins in their inactive form. By stabilizing repressor proteins in their inactive form, inducers keep the repressor proteins from binding to the operator sequences and preventing transcription. So, in a sense, inducers allow gene transcription to proceed by turning off a repressor. Corepressors work in kind of the opposite way. Corepressors stabilize the repressor proteins with which they interact in their active form. So, when the correct corepressor is present in a cell, the repressor protein with which it interacts will bind to it and be stabilized in its active form. The active repressor/corepressor complex will then bind the operator sequence, preventing transcription of the genes in the operon by RNA polymerase. So, the name “corepressor” refers to the fact that corepressors help repress transcription of the genes in the operon.

questions.raw_html_question: Operons
questions.question: Operons

options.text: contain structural genes, promoters and an operator region.
are generally involved in lactose metabolism.
are found only in eukaryotes.
are composed of many genes on different chromosomes.

questions.comments: Operons are clusters of genes that are under the control of a single regulatory sequence (e.g. a promoter sequence). Operons are very common in prokaryotes but are rare in eukaryotes. Operons contain multiple genes, which must all be located next to each other so that all of the genes in the operon can be transcribed from a single promoter (so the genes that make up a particular operon can NOT be on different chromosomes). Although there are operons that contain genes involved in lactose metabolism, lacoperons are just one of many many different operons found in prokaryotic cells

operons are just one of many many different operons found in prokaryotic cells

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is an example of post-transcriptional control of gene expression?
questions.question: Which of the following is an example of post-transcriptional control of gene expression?

options.text: the folding of DNA to form heterochromatin (densely packed chromatin)
the binding of transcription factors to a promoter
the addition of methyl groups to cytosine bases of DNA
the removal of introns and alternative splicing of exons

questions.comments: Post-transcriptional regulation refers to regulation that occurs after DNA has been transcribed to form a primary RNA. DNA modifications affect chromatin packing and the ease with which particular genes can be transcribed, so they are NOT examples of post-transcriptional regulation. Similarly, the folding of DNA to form heterochromatin affects transcription rates, and so is not a form of post-transcriptional regulation. The binding of transcription factors to a promoter affects binding of RNA polymerase to the promoter and thus transcription of the gene and is thus not an example of post-transcriptional regulation. The removal of introns and alternative splicing of exons ARE examples of post-transcriptional regulation, as these are processes that occur AFTER a transcription to form a primary transcript has occurred.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements comparing mRNAs produced by prokaryotes versus eukaryotes is TRUE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements comparing mRNAs produced by prokaryotes versus eukaryotes is TRUE?

options.text: Mature prokaryotic mRNAs often code for multiple polypeptides whereas mature eukaryotic mRNAs typically code for only one polypeptide.
Mature eukaryotic mRNAs often code for multiple polypeptides whereas mature prokaryotic mRNAs typically code for only one polypeptide.
Mature prokaryotic and mature eukaryotic mRNAs typically code for only one polypeptide.
Mature prokaryotic and mature eukaryotic mRNAs often code for multiple polypeptides.

questions.comments: In eukaryotes, precursor mRNAs, or pre-mRNAs (also known as primary RNAs), can code for more than one slightly different polypeptides as a result of alternative splicing of the pre-mRNAs to form slightly different mature mRNAs. However, mature eukaryotic mRNAs only code for a single polypeptide. In contrast, mature prokaryotic mRNAs often code for multiple, completely different, polypeptides.Figure of typical prokaryotic mRNA that codes for more than one polypeptide:Figure of typical, eukaryotic precursor (or primary) mRNA that undergoes alternative splicing to form slightly different mature eukaryotic mRNAs, that code for slightly different polypeptides.

questions.raw_html_question: Muscle cells differ from nerve cells mainly because they
questions.question: Muscle cells differ from nerve cells mainly because they

options.text: contain different genes.
use different genetic codes.
have unique ribosomes.
express different genes.

questions.comments: With few exceptions, all of the cells in our bodies contain the same DNA, and therefore contain the same genes. However, different genes are expressed at different levels in different cell types. All the cells in our bodies use the same genetic code and, for the most part, the same ribosomes.

questions.raw_html_question: A single gene is known to code for three different, but related, proteins.  This could be due to which of the following?
questions.question: A single gene is known to code for three different, but related, proteins.  This could be due to which of the following?

options.text: alternative RNA splicing
premature mRNA degradation
use of different enhancers
differential transport

questions.comments: Alternative splicing is a mechanism that is commonly used by eukaryotes to allow their genes to produce multiple, related, proteins. Approximately 95% of human genes that have more than one exon are thought to make use of alternative splicing. For example, the troponin T gene has 5 exons. All 5 exons, plus the introns between the exons, are present in each primary RNA transcript made from the gene. However, different primary RNA transcripts from this gene are spliced in slightly different ways (i.e. the undergo “alternative splicing”). Some of the primary RNA transcript molecules are spliced such that the mature mRNA transcript has exons 1, 2, 3 and 5. Other primary RNA transcript molecules are spliced such that the mature mRNA transcript has exons 1, 2, 4 and 5.

Other primary RNA transcript molecules are spliced such that the mature mRNA transcript has exons 1, 2, 4 and 5.

mutations that result in deletion of several nucleotides and of changes in DNA modifications
changes in both DNA and histone modifications

questions.comments: Epigenetic inheritance is defined as inheritance of modifications to chromatin (either the DNA or the proteins that make up chromatin) that do NOT include alterations in the actual nucleotide sequence of the DNA. So, mutations that result in deletion or addition of nucleotides, or substituting one nucleotide for a different nucleotide, are NOT examples of epigenetic changes.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements about the DNA in one of your brain cells is certainly TRUE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements about the DNA in one of your brain cells is certainly TRUE?

options.text: Many genes are grouped into operon-like clusters.
Most genes lie immediately downstream of an operator sequence.
It is the same as the DNA in one of your heart cells.
The majority of genes are likely to be transcribed.

questions.comments: All of the cells in our bodies, with a few exceptions, contain the same DNA and therefore the same genes. However, only a fraction of our genes are expressed in any given cell, and different genes are expressed in different cells. Operons are common in prokaryotes, but rare in eukaryotes. Similarly, operator sequences are associated with prokaryotic rather than eukaryotic genes.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following would NOT be considered a gene that is being expressed?
questions.question: Which of the following would NOT be considered a gene that is being expressed?

options.text: A gene that is producing rRNA, but no protein.
A gene that is producing mRNA, but no protein.
All of these answers are correct.
A gene that is producing tRNA, but no protein.

questions.comments: A gene that is producing its final product (protein or non-coding RNA) in a functional form is being expressed. So, because the final product of a gene that encodes an mRNA is a protein, a gene that is producing mRNA but no protein is not considered to be expressed. In contrast, the final product of genes that encode tRNAs and rRNAs are the RNA molecules, because these RNAs are not translated to form proteins. So, a gene that is expressing an rRNA or a tRNA is considered to be expressed.
questions.raw_html_comments: A gene that is producing its final product (protein or non-coding RNA) in a functional form is being expressed. So, because the final product of a gene that encodes an mRNA is a protein, a gene that is producing mRNA but no protein is not considered to be expressed. In contrast, the final product of genes that encode tRNAs and rRNAs are the RNA molecules, because these RNAs are not translated to form proteins. So, a gene that is expressing an rRNA or a tRNA is considered to be expressed.

questions.raw_html_question: A friend of yours is asked to conduct experiments to determine why a particular polypeptide is present in much higher levels in heart cells than in neural cells.  She carefully measures the levels of mature mRNA from the gene that encodes the polypeptide and determines that heart and neural cells contain the same levels of the mature mRNA.  She next measures the rate at which the mature mRNA that encodes the polypeptide is translated and finds that rates of translation of that mRNA are the same in heart and neural cells.  Your friend now has no idea why the polypeptide is present at higher levels in heart versus neural cells and asks your advice on what to do next.  What advice should you give her?
questions.question: A friend of yours is asked to conduct experiments to determine why a particular polypeptide is present in much higher levels in heart cells than in neural cells.  She carefully measures the levels of mature mRNA from the gene that encodes the polypeptide and determines that heart and neural cells contain the same levels of the mature mRNA.  She next measures the rate at which the mature mRNA that encodes the polypeptide is translated and finds that rates of translation of that mRNA are the same in heart and neural cells.  Your friend now has no idea why the polypeptide is present at higher levels in heart versus neural cells and asks your advice on what to do next.  What advice should you give her?

options.text: You should remind her that histone acetylation may also affect protein levels.

You should remind her that the levels of a polypeptide are determined not only by how frequently the mRNA encoding that polypeptide is translated, but also by the rate at which the polypeptide is degraded. So, she should consider conducting some experiments to determine whether the polypeptide is degraded more rapidly in neural cells than in heart cells.
You should remind her that differences in the rates at which primary RNA molecules are processed can affect protein levels.
You should advise her to give up as research is hopeless and she will make more money as an investment banker anyways.

questions.raw_html_question: Two genetically identical fruit flies (Drosophila) are exposed to very different environmental conditions. If you studied the polypeptides present in both flies, what would you expect to find?
questions.question: Two genetically identical fruit flies (Drosophila) are exposed to very different environmental conditions. If you studied the polypeptides present in both flies, what would you expect to find?

options.text: All of these answers are correct.
Some of the primary polypeptides produced by one of the flies have undergone alternative splicing by proteasomes to form slightly different mature polypeptides.
Some polypeptides are far more active in one of the fruit flies than in the other one.
Some of the polypeptides in one of the fruit flies exhibit minor variations in amino acid sequence compared to the amino acid sequences of the corresponding polypeptides produced by the other fly.

questions.comments: Environmental conditions affect the levels at which certain genes are expressed. However, environmental conditions are not going to affect the nucleotide sequences of genes and therefore won’t affect the nucleotide sequences of the mRNAs made from those genes or the amino acid sequences of the polypeptides made from the mRNA. Finally, Pre-mRNAs, rather than polypeptides, undergo alternative splicing. Proteasomes are involved in protein degradation, but proteasomes don't splice together different parts of polypeptides. Instead, they chew up into little pieces (i.e. degrade) polypeptides that are marked for degradation by the addition of ubiquitin polypeptides.

questions.raw_html_question: Allolactose, an isomer of lactose, is formed in small amounts from lactose. An E. coli cell is presented for the first time with the sugar lactose (containing allolactose) as a potential food source. Which of the following occurs when the lactose enters the cell?
questions.question: Allolactose, an isomer of lactose, is formed in small amounts from lactose. An E. coli cell is presented for the first time with the sugar lactose (containing allolactose) as a potential food source. Which of the following occurs when the lactose enters the cell?

options.text: Allolactose binds to the regulator gene.
The repressor protein attaches to the regulator.
Allolactose binds to the repressor protein.
The repressor protein and allolactose bind to RNA polymerase.

questions.comments: Allolactose is the inducer of the repressor protein that regulates the lac operon. When allolactose is present, lac repressor proteins will bind allolactose. Binding of an allolactose molecule stabilizes a lac repressor protein molecule in its inactive form. As a result, the inactive lac repressor protein is unable to bind the lac operator sequence and so can not block transcription of the genes in the lac operon.
questions.raw_html_comments: Allolactose is the inducer of the repressor protein that regulates the lac operon. When allolactose is present, lac repressor proteins will bind allolactose. As a result, the inactive lac repressor protein is unable to bind the lac operator sequence and so can not block transcription of the genes in the lac operon.

questions.raw_html_question: If an experimenter moves the repressor gene (lac I) for the lac operon, along with its promoter, to a position some several thousand base pairs away from its normal position in the lac operon, which will you expect to occur?
questions.question: If an experimenter moves the repressor gene (lac I) for the lac operon, along with its promoter, to a position some several thousand base pairs away from its normal position in the lac operon, which will you expect to occur?

options.text: The repressor will no longer bind to the inducer.
The repressor will no longer be made.
The lac operon will be expressed continuously.
The lac operon will function normally.

questions.comments: The lac repressor gene encodes the lac repressor protein. The ability of the repressor gene to encode the repressor protein won’t be affected by moving the gene, with its promoter, to a different position on the chromosome. So, the promoter of the lac repressor gene will cause the transcribed region of the lac repressor gene to be normally transcribed to produce mRNA. That mRNA will leave the nucleus and be translated in the cytoplasm and the resulting lac repressor protein will enter the nucleus and do its job, regardless of where the lac repressor gene is located on a chromosome.

questions.raw_html_question: Changes in chromatin structure

options.text: may be inherited
may include modifications to histones, but not to DNA
may include modifications to DNA, but not to histones
are important in regulating gene expression in prokaryotes

questions.comments: Chromatin (the mixture of DNA and proteins, such as histones, complexed with the DNA that forms eukaryotic chromosomes) is only found in eukaryotic cells. Changes to the chromatin of eukaryotic cells include changes both to the proteins that form part of chromatin (e.g. acetylation of histone proteins) as well as to the DNA itself (e.g. DNA methylation, which means adding methyl groups to specific nucleotides). Note that when we talk about changes in chromatin structure we are NOT taking about changes in the actual nucleotide sequence of the DNA.

questions.raw_html_question: An experimenter moves the operator for the lactose operon to the far end of the operon (past all of the structural genes in the lactose operon).  Which of the following would likely occur when the cell is exposed to lactose?
questions.question: An experimenter moves the operator for the lactose operon to the far end of the operon (past all of the structural genes in the lactose operon).  Which of the following would likely occur when the cell is exposed to lactose?

options.text: The operon will never be transcribed.
The repressor will no longer bind to the operator.
The structural genes will be transcribed continuously.
The inducer will no longer bind to the repressor.

questions.comments: Normally operator sequences lie between promoter sequences (where RNA polymerase binds) and the structural genes of the operon. This arrangement means that, if active repressor protein is bound to the operator sequence, it will physically block the movement of RNA polymerase along the mRNA molecule towards the structural genes of the operon. So, the normal placement of the operator sequence between the promoter sequence and the structural genes of the operon is necessary for its function. If you move the operator sequence so that it is on the far side of the structural genes from the promoter, even if active repressor protein binds the operator sequence, it won’t be in the right place to be able to block transcription of the structural genes.

questions.raw_html_question: Inheritance of traits not directly involving nucleotide sequences is known as:
questions.question: Inheritance of traits not directly involving nucleotide sequences is known as:

options.text: non-nuclear inheritance
DNA inheritance
epigenetic inheritance
tRNA inheritance

questions.comments: Epigenetic inheritance refers to modifications of the proteins that form part of chromatin (e.g. acetylation of histone proteins) or of the DNA itself (e.g. DNA methylation, which means adding methyl groups to the DNA) that do NOT include changes in the actual nucleotide sequence of the DNA. In order to be considered examples of epigenetic inheritance, these modifications must be heritable (i.e. able to be passed on when chromosomes are replicated and cells divide).

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements about the trp operon is TRUE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements about the trp operon is TRUE?

options.text: When trp repressor protein binds tryptophan, it is stabilized in its active shape, allowing transcription of the genes of the trp operon to proceed.
When trp repressor protein binds tryptophan, it is stabilized in its inactive shape, allowing transcription of the genes of the trp operon to proceed.
When trp repressor protein binds tryptophan, it is stabilized in its active shape, preventing transcription of the genes of the trp operon from occurring.
When trp repressor protein binds tryptophan it is stabilized in its inactive shape, preventing transcription of the genes of the trp operon from occurring.

questions.comments: When a repressor protein is in its active shape, the active repressor protein will bind its operator blocking transcription of the genes in that operon by RNA polymerase. When a repressor protein is in its inactive shape, it will be unable to bind its operator sequence, and RNA polymerase will be able to transcribe the genes in that operon. Tryptophan is the corepressor for the trp repressor protein, meaning that it stabilizes trp repressor in its active form and so helps trp repressor do its job of repressing transcription of the genes in the trp operon. This makes sense if you remember that the genes of the trp operon encode polypeptides needed for synthesis of tryptophan. If a cell already has a lot of tryptophan, why would it want to make proteins whose job it is to make more tryptophan? The answer is that cells do not want to waste resources on making polypeptides for tryptophan biosynthesis if they already have plently of tryptophan. Consequently the system is set up so that tryptophan stabilizes the trp repressor protein in its active shape, so that the trp repressor protein is able to bind the trp operator and block transcription of the trp genes by RNA polymerase.Finally, remember that "inducers" and "co-repressors" are NOT named based on how they affect the repressor proteins with which they interact. Instead, they are named based on how they affect transcription of the genes in the operon they help regulate. So, "inducers" help increase transcription of the genes in the operon they regulate by stabilizing the repressor protein for that operon in its inactive shape. In contrast, "co-repressors" help decrease transcription of the genes in the operon they regulate by stabilizing the repressor protein for that operon in its active shape.
questions.raw_html_comments:
When a repressor protein is in its active shape, the active repressor protein will bind its operator blocking transcription of the genes in that operon by RNA polymerase. When a repressor protein is in its inactive shape, it will be unable to bind its operator sequence, and RNA polymerase will be able to transcribe the genes in that operon. Tryptophan is the corepressor for the trp repressor protein, meaning that it stabilizes trp repressor in its active form and so helps trp repressor do its job of repressing transcription of the genes in the trp operon. This makes sense if you remember that the genes of the trp operon encode polypeptides needed for synthesis of tryptophan. If a cell already has a lot of tryptophan, why would it want to make proteins whose job it is to make more tryptophan? The answer is that cells do not want to waste resources on making polypeptides for tryptophan biosynthesis if they already have plently of tryptophan. Consequently the system is set up so that tryptophan stabilizes the trp repressor protein in its active shape, so that the trp repressor protein is able to bind the trp operator and block transcription of the trp genes by RNA polymerase.

Finally, remember that "inducers" and "co-repressors" are NOT named based on how they affect the repressor proteins with which they interact. Instead, they are named based on how they affect transcription of the genes in the operon they help regulate. So, "inducers" help increase transcription of the genes in the operon they regulate by stabilizing the repressor protein for that operon in its inactive shape. In contrast, "co-repressors" help decrease transcription of the genes in the operon they regulate by stabilizing the repressor protein for that operon in its active shape.

questions.raw_html_question: The SIS8 gene is transcribed to form SIS8 mRNAs.  The SIS8 mRNAs are then translated to form SIS8 polypeptides.  The total number of SIS8 polypeptides present in a cell at a given moment is
questions.question: The SIS8 gene is transcribed to form SIS8 mRNAs.  The SIS8 mRNAs are then translated to form SIS8 polypeptides.  The total number of SIS8 polypeptides present in a cell at a given moment is

options.text: mostly dependent on how active the ribosomes are.
more dependent on the rate at which the SIS8 polypeptides are made (translated) than on the rate at which they are broken down
less dependent on the rate at which the SIS8 polypeptides are made (translated) than on the rate at which they are broken down
equally dependent on the rate at which the SIS8 polypeptides are made (translated) and the rate at which they are broken down

questions.comments: The number of polypeptide molecules from a particular gene that are present in a cell is as dependent on the rate at which they are broken down as on the rate at which they are synthesized. An analogy would be that the amount of money in your bank account is as dependent on how much money you withdraw as on how much money you deposit.

questions.raw_html_question: Most repressor proteins are allosteric. Which of the following binds with the repressor to alter its conformation?
questions.question: Most repressor proteins are allosteric. Which of the following binds with the repressor to alter its conformation?

options.text: cAMP
RNA polymerase
inducer
transcription factor

questions.comments: Inducers are small molecules that are able to interact with, and be bound by, specific repressor proteins. When a repressor protein binds its inducer, the repressor protein is stabilized in its inactive form. As a result, transcription of the genes regulated by the repressor protein/inducer is able to proceed. RNA polymerase binds to promoter sequences and transcribes DNA to form RNA. Transcription factors are proteins that increase (transcriptional activators) or decrease (transcriptional repressors) the affinity of RNA polymerase for the promoters of particular genes. cAMP is a small molecule that affects expression of a number of genes, but is not involved in binding repressor proteins and altering their conformation.

When a repressor protein binds its inducer, the repressor protein is stabilized in its inactive form. As a result, transcription of the genes regulated by the repressor protein/inducer is able to proceed.

RNA polymerase binds to promoter sequences and transcribes DNA to form RNA. questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following, when taken up by the cell, binds to the repressor protein so that the repressor protein no longer binds to the operator?
questions.question: Which of the following, when taken up by the cell, binds to the repressor protein so that the repressor protein no longer binds to the operator?

options.text: inducer
ubiquitin
promoter
corepressor

questions.comments: When trying to remember the difference between inducers and corepressors of repressor proteins, remember that these small molecules are NOT named because of how they affect the activity of the repressor protein. Instead, they are named because of how they affect the rate of transcription of the genes in the operon(s) they help regulate. So, “inducers” are called inducers because scientists used to think that they “induce” (i.e. “turn on”) expression of the genes in the operons they help regulate. We now know that what inducers actually do is to stabilize repressor proteins in their inactive form. By stabilizing repressor proteins in their inactive form, inducers keep the repressor proteins from binding to the operator sequences and preventing transcription. So, in a sense, inducers allow gene transcription to proceed by turning off a repressor. Corepressors work in kind of the opposite way. Corepressors stabilize the repressor proteins with which they interact in their active form. So, when the correct corepressor is present in a cell, the repressor protein with which it interacts will bind to it and be stabilized in its active form. The active repressor/corepressor complex will then bind the operator sequence, preventing transcription of the genes in the operon by RNA polymerase. So, the name “corepressor” refers to the fact that corepressors help repress transcription of the genes in the operon.Promoters are nucleotide sequences near genes where RNA polymerase binds and starts the process of transcribing the gene(s) to form an RNA molecule.Ubiquitin is a small protein that binds to other proteins and, as a result, targets those proteins for degradation. Binding of ubiquitin will typically not affect the ability of a repressor protein to bind to the operator sequence of the gene that the repressor protein helps regulate.
questions.raw_html_comments:
When trying to remember the difference between inducers and corepressors of repressor proteins, remember that these small molecules are NOT named because of how they affect the activity of the repressor protein. Instead, they are named because of how they affect the rate of transcription of the genes in the operon(s) they help regulate. So, “inducers” are called inducers because scientists used to think that they “induce” (i.e. “turn on”) expression of the genes in the operons they help regulate. We now know that what inducers actually do is to stabilize repressor proteins in their inactive form. By stabilizing repressor proteins in their inactive form, inducers keep the repressor proteins from binding to the operator sequences and preventing transcription. So, in a sense, inducers allow gene transcription to proceed by turning off a repressor. Corepressors work in kind of the opposite way. Corepressors stabilize the repressor proteins with which they interact in their active form. So, when the correct corepressor is present in a cell, the repressor protein with which it interacts will bind to it and be stabilized in its active form. The active repressor/corepressor complex will then bind the operator sequence, preventing transcription of the genes in the operon by RNA polymerase. So, the name “corepressor” refers to the fact that corepressors help repress transcription of the genes in the operon.

Promoters are nucleotide sequences near genes where RNA polymerase binds and starts the process of transcribing the gene(s) to form an RNA molecule.

Ubiquitin is a small protein that binds to other proteins and, as a result, targets those proteins for degradation. Binding of ubiquitin will typically not affect the ability of a repressor protein to bind to the operator sequence of the gene that the repressor protein helps regulate.
