questions.raw_html_question: For a repressible operon to be transcribed, which of the following must occur?
questions.question: For a repressible operon to be transcribed, which of the following must occur?

options.text: RNA polymerase and the active repressor must be present.
RNA polymerase must bind to the promoter, and the repressor must be inactive.
RNA polymerase must not occupy the promoter, and the repressor must be inactive.
RNA polymerase cannot be present, and the repressor must be inactive.

questions.comments: For a repressible operon, RNA polymerase will bind to the promoter sequence of the operon and will try to transcribe the genes of the operon. However, if active repressor protein for that operon is bound to the operator DNA sequence for that operon, the repressor protein will physically block transcription of the genes of the operon by RNA polymerase. So, for transcription of the genes of a repressible operon to occur, RNA polymerase needs to bind the promoter sequence of the operon and the repressor protein for that operon must by inactive so that it is unable to bind the operator sequence for the operon and block transcription.

questions.comments: Cells are able to regulate which proteins are targeted for degradation. One of the main ways in which cells target a particular protein for degradation is by adding small polypeptides, known as "ubiquitin" because they are "ubiquitous" in cells, to the protein that is to be degraded. A large complex known as a "proteasome" than degrades the proteins that are marked for degradation by having ubiquitin polypeptides stuck to them.

questions.comments: Proto-oncogenes are normal (i.e. unmutated) genes that promote cell division and/or growth. questions.comments: Proto-oncogenes are normal, unmutated, genes that encode products needed to promote cell division and/or growth. When a proto-oncogene becomes mutated in such a way that its expression is increased, that can help lead to rates of cell division and/or growth that are too high and can increase the chances of a cell becoming cancerous. Proto-oncogenes that are mutated in such a way that there expression is increased are known as “oncogenes”.

Mutations that cause the “antennopedia” gene to be expressed in cells where it should not be expressed cause flies to develop legs where their antennae should be.

questions.raw_html_question: A colleague of yours is asked to develop a strain of mutant mice that will be extremely likely to develop cancer so that these mice can be used to study cancer treatments.  Your colleague causes a mutation in a mouse that causes the mouse to express a proto-oncogene at greatly increased levels.  However, your colleague is disappointed to find the mouse does not have cancer and asks your advice on what he should do next.  What should you tell your colleague?
questions.question: A colleague of yours is asked to develop a strain of mutant mice that will be extremely likely to develop cancer so that these mice can be used to study cancer treatments.  Your colleague causes a mutation in a mouse that causes the mouse to express a proto-oncogene at greatly increased levels.  However, your colleague is disappointed to find the mouse does not have cancer and asks your advice on what he should do next.  What should you tell your colleague?

options.text: You tell your colleague that they made a mistake by increasing expression of the proto-oncogene and that they should instead cause a mutation in a mouse that causes decreased expression of the proto-oncogene. In addition, you remind your colleague that a mutation that decreases the expression of a single proto-oncogene is generally not sufficient to cause cells to become cancerous. They should also cause some mutations in the mouse’s DNA that cause increased expression of some of the mouse’s tumor-suppressor genes.

You remind your colleague that a mutation that increases the expression of a single proto-oncogene is generally not sufficient to cause cells to become cancerous. He should also cause some mutations in the mouse’s DNA that cause increased expression of some of the mouse’s tumor-suppressor genes.

You remind your colleague that a mutation that increases the expression of a single proto-oncogene is generally not sufficient to cause cells to become cancerous. He should also cause some mutations in the mouse’s DNA that cause decreased expression of some of the mouse’s tumor-suppressor genes.

You tell your colleague that they made a mistake by increasing expression of the proto-oncogene and that they should instead cause a mutation in a mouse that causes decreased expression of the proto-oncogene.

questions.comments: Mutations in a single gene are usually not sufficient to cause cancer. Instead, mutations that cause increased expression of at least one proto-oncogene, converting it to an oncogene, and mutations that cause decreased expression of multiple tumor-suppressor genes are usually needed for a cell to become cancerous.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements about how cytoplasmic determinants and induction help control which transcriptional activators are expressed by different cell types is TRUE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements about how cytoplasmic determinants and induction help control which transcriptional activators are expressed by different cell types is TRUE?

options.text: Cytoplasmic determinants are unevenly distributed during cell division, causing the resulting daughter cells to express different combinations of transcriptional activators.
Cytoplasmic determinants are unevenly distributed in egg cells.
All of these statements are true.
Induction causes the cells near the cell producing the inductive agent to express some of the same transcriptional activators.

questions.comments: Cytoplasmic determinants are unevenly distributed in unfertilized egg cells, fertilized egg cells and in the daughter cells resulting from division of an egg cell. Polypeptides, mRNAs and other molecules can act as cytoplasmic determinants. Which cytoplasmic determinants are most abundant in a cell helps determine which subset of genes is expressed in that cell. In induction, a cell produces a substance that ends up on the surface of that cell or is exported from the cell. Neighboring cells that come in contact with that substance are caused (“induced”) to express a particular set of transcriptional activators. So, the cells near a cell that is producing a substance used in induction will be induced to produce some of the same transcriptional activators.
questions.raw_html_comments:

Polypeptides, mRNAs and other molecules can act as cytoplasmic determinants. Which cytoplasmic determinants are most abundant in a cell helps determine which subset of genes is expressed in that cell.

In induction, a cell produces a substance that ends up on the surface of that cell or is exported from the cell. Neighboring cells that come in contact with that substance are caused (“induced”) to express a particular set of transcriptional activators. So, the cells near a cell that is producing a substance used in induction will be induced to produce some of the same transcriptional activators.

questions.comments: Cytoplasmic determinants are unevenly distributed in unfertilized egg cells, fertilized egg cells and in the daughter cells resulting from division of an egg cell. Polypeptides, mRNAs and other molecules can act as cytoplasmic determinants. Which cytoplasmic determinants are most abundant in a cell helps determine which subset of genes is expressed in that cell.

questions.comments: Cytoplasmic determinants can be polypeptides, mRNAs or other molecules that are distributed unequally in the unfertilized egg. This unequal distribution is maintained after the egg is fertilized. When the fertilized egg cell divides, the two daughter cells receive unequal amounts of different cytoplasmic determinants. These different cytoplasmic determinants cause different sets of transcriptional activators to be expressed in the daughter cells. In addition, cells may produce chemical that control (turn on or off) the expression of transcriptional activators in nearby cells in a process known as “induction”.

questions.raw_html_question: Some genes that encode polypeptides that function in DNA repair are known as
questions.question: Some genes that encode polypeptides that function in DNA repair are known as

options.text: oncogenes
tumor-suppressor genes
mutagen genes
proto-oncogenes

questions.comments: The normal function of tumor-suppressor genes is to decrease the rates of cell division and/or growth, or to function in DNA repair or cell adhesion. Mutations in tumor-suppressor genes that act in DNA repair can raise the chances of a cell becoming cancerous because that cell will tend to have an increased number of mutations. Some of those extra mutations may occur in proto-oncogenes, converting them to oncogenes, or in tumor-suppressor genes, decreasing the protection against cancer normally provided by tumor-suppressor genes.The normal function of proto-oncogenes is to produce polypeptides that increase the rate of cell division and/or growth. Mutations that increase the expression of a proto-oncogene can turn it into an oncogene that tends to promote excessive rates of cell division and/or growth and that increases the chances of a cell becoming cancerous.
questions.raw_html_comments:
The normal function of tumor-suppressor genes is to decrease the rates of cell division and/or growth, or to function in DNA repair or cell adhesion. Mutations in tumor-suppressor genes that act in DNA repair can raise the chances of a cell becoming cancerous because that cell will tend to have an increased number of mutations. Some of those extra mutations may occur in proto-oncogenes, converting them to oncogenes, or in tumor-suppressor genes, decreasing the protection against cancer normally provided by tumor-suppressor genes.

The normal function of proto-oncogenes is to produce polypeptides that increase the rate of cell division and/or growth. Mutations that increase the expression of a proto-oncogene can turn it into an oncogene that tends to promote excessive rates of cell division and/or growth and that increases the chances of a cell becoming cancerous.

questions.raw_html_question: Flies with mutant bicoid genes develop posterior structures at both ends.  The bicoid gene product is normally localized to the anterior end of the embryo. If large amounts of the product were injected into the posterior end of a normal (i.e. unmutated) fly embryo, which of the following would occur?
questions.question: Flies with mutant bicoid genes develop posterior structures at both ends.  The bicoid gene product is normally localized to the anterior end of the embryo. If large amounts of the product were injected into the posterior end of a normal (i.e. unmutated) fly embryo, which of the following would occur?

options.text: The embryo would grow extra wings and legs.
The embryo would grow to an unusually large size.
The embryo would probably show no anterior development and die.
Anterior structures would form in both sides of the embryo.

questions.comments: The fact that flies with mutant bicoid genes cannot develop anterior structures indicates that the bicoid protein is necessary for development of bicoid structures. The fact that the bicoid gene product is normally found in the anterior end of the embryo suggests that localization of the bicoid gene product to one end of the embryo may be at least partly responsible for why the embryo normally only develops anterior structures at one end. So, if large amounts of the bicoid gene product were injected into the posterior end of a normal (unmutated) embryo, that embryo would have bicoid gene product at both ends and so might form anterior structures at both ends.

questions.raw_html_question: When they were first sold, aerosol insecticides were highly effective in killing flies and mosquitoes. Now, several decades later, a much smaller proportion of these insects die when sprayed. The reason fewer insects die when they are sprayed is that _____.
questions.question: When they were first sold, aerosol insecticides were highly effective in killing flies and mosquitoes. Now, several decades later, a much smaller proportion of these insects die when sprayed. The reason fewer insects die when they are sprayed is that _____.

options.text: the original spraying has caused a permanent mutation, giving the insects genetic resistance to the spray
many mosquitoes today are descendants of mosquitoes with insecticide-resistant characteristics
None of these responses is correct.
mosquitoes are deliberately adapting themselves to this man-made change in the environment
mosquitoes that survive spraying develop an immunity to the insecticide

questions.comments: Individuals whose characteristics best fit them to their environment are likely to leave more offspring than are less fit individuals. This unequal ability of individuals to survive and reproduce will lead to a gradual change in a population, with favorable characteristics accumulating over the generations. In this case, the original population of mosquitoes included some mosquitoes that had inherited traits that made them more resistant to the insecticides. Those resistant mosquitoes had more progeny that survived, and so the percentage of mosquitoes with the inherited traits that cause insecticide resistance increased in the population.
questions.raw_html_comments: Individuals whose characteristics best fit them to their environment are likely to leave more offspring than are less fit individuals. questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is NOT an observation or inference on which natural selection is based?
questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an observation or inference on which natural selection is based?

options.text: Only a fraction of an individual's offspring may survive.
Poorly adapted individuals never produce offspring.
Species produce more offspring than the environment can support.
There is heritable variation among individuals.
Individuals whose characteristics are best suited to the environment generally leave more offspring than those whose characteristics are less well suited.

questions.comments: Natural selection is based on the following: species produce more offspring than the environment can support, only a fraction of an individual's offspring may survive, there is heritable variation among individuals, and individuals whose characteristics are best suited to the environment generally leave more offspring than those whose characteristics are less well suited. However, poorly adapted individuals may still produce offspring. The difference between poorly adapted individuals and well adapted individuals is that the poorly adapted individuals will produce fewer (but usually not zero) offspring, and/or will produce less successful offspring.

questions.comments: Through the process of natural selection, individuals that have certain inherited traits (adaptations) tend to survive and reproduce at higher rates than other individuals because of those traits. questions.comments: In these diagrams, the tip of each line represents a species. Lines that end before the current time represent species that are extinct. The forks represent common ancestors. The closer a fork is to a particular species, the more recent the ancestor represented by that fork is to that species. In this diagram, Y is the most recent common ancestor for all six of the species depicted. X is an older ancestor of all six species. In contrast, W is the ancestor for only the three species depicted in the top part of the graph, V is the ancestor for only the two species at the very top of the graph and Z is the ancestor for only the three species at the bottom of the graph.

questions.raw_html_question: Members of two different species possess a similar-looking structure that they use in a similar fashion to perform the same function. Which information would best help distinguish between an explanation based on homology versus one based on convergent evolution?
questions.question: Members of two different species possess a similar-looking structure that they use in a similar fashion to perform the same function. Which information would best help distinguish between an explanation based on homology versus one based on convergent evolution?

options.text: Both species are well adapted to their particular environments.
The sizes of the structures in adult members of both species are similar in size.
The two species live at great distance from each other.
The two species share many proteins in common, and the nucleotide sequences that code for these proteins are almost identical.

questions.comments: Remember that similarity in characteristics resulting from a common ancestor is known as “homology”. “Convergent evolution” is the process whereby organisms that are not closely related to each other independently evolve similar traits as a result of having to adapt to similar environments. So, the fact that the two species share many proteins and that these shared proteins are encoded by genes with identical DNA sequences would provide strong evidence that the two species evolved from a recent common ancestor, and that the similar-looking structure is thus due to homology. The fact that the two species live far apart does not provide convincing evidence that the two species are not closely related as it’s possible for members of some species to travel long distances. Also, the fact that the structures are similar in size and that both species are well adapted to their environment doesn’t tell us whether the two species are or are not closely related to each other.
questions.raw_html_comments: Remember that similarity in characteristics resulting from a common ancestor is known as “homology”. “Convergent evolution” is the process whereby organisms that are not closely related to each other independently evolve similar traits as a result of having to adapt to similar environments. So, the fact that the two species share many proteins and that these shared proteins are encoded by genes with identical DNA sequences would provide strong evidence that the two species evolved from a recent common ancestor, and that the similar-looking structure is thus due to homology. The fact that the two species live far apart does not provide convincing evidence that the two species are not closely related as it’s possible for members of some species to travel long distances. Also, the fact that the structures are similar in size and that both species are well adapted to their environment doesn’t tell us whether the two species are or are not closely related to each other.

questions.comments: No matter how DDT application is carried out, any DDT resistant individuals in the population will have an advantage over individuals that are not DDT resistant. questions.comments: If humans and chimpanzees share a common ancestor, it makes sense that they share many similarities, including similar DNA sequences. It is important to note that humans are NOT believed to have evolved from chimpanzees. Instead, humans and chimpanzees are believed both to have evolved from a common ancestor. It should also be noted that convergent evolution is extremely unlikely to have led to two different species having so almost all of their genes have very similar DNA sequences.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following is an example of convergent evolution?
questions.question: Which of the following is an example of convergent evolution?

options.text: Both gymnosperms (cone-bearing plants) and angiosperms (flowering plants) produce seeds.
Cats and bats have similar skeletal configurations in their forelimbs.
Blind cave fish possess remnants of eye structures under their scales.
Dolphins and sharks have a similar fusiform (streamlined) body shape.
Human embryos and fish embryos both have pharyngeal pouches.

questions.comments: Convergent evolution is the evolution of similar features in independent evolutionary lineages. In other words, convergent evolution is when two evolutionary lines evolve similar features (e.g. structures) independently. In this example, dolphins and sharks do not share a recent common ancestor (one is a mammal, one a fish). Therefore, the fact that they have a similar overall body shape can NOT be due to them both having evolved from a common ancestor with a similar body shape. Instead, a more likely explanation is that their similar body form is a result of adaptations to their common environment, which exerts similar pressures on both species.

questions.raw_html_question: In a hypothetical environment, fishes called pike-cichlids are visual predators of algae-eating fish (in other words, they locate their prey by sight). If a population of algae-eaters experiences predation pressure from pike-cichlids, which of the following is least likely to be observed in the algae-eater population over the course of many generations?
questions.question: In a hypothetical environment, fishes called pike-cichlids are visual predators of algae-eating fish (in other words, they locate their prey by sight). If a population of algae-eaters experiences predation pressure from pike-cichlids, which of the following is least likely to be observed in the algae-eater population over the course of many generations?

options.text: selection for nocturnal algae-eaters (active only at night)
selection for larger female algae-eaters, bearing broods composed of more, and larger, young
selection for algae-eaters that are faster swimmers
selection for drab coloration of the algae-eaters

questions.comments: In this scenario, the main selective pressure on the algae-eater fish is to avoid being eaten by the pike-cichlids. As the pike-cichlids locate their prey by sight, the algae-eater fish can reduce their chances of being eaten by being harder to see (by becoming more drab colored and/or moving around mostly at night) and/or by becoming faster swimmers. In contrast, becoming bigger would likely make them easier to see, and therefore more likely to be eaten.

An earthquake results in the formation of a canyon, splitting a population of toads apart.
A fire drastically reduces the size of a white-tailed deer population. The remaining individuals spread out throughout the remaining forest.
A small population of humans colonizes a newly formed island.
Genes are shuffled by the crossing over of chromosomes during meiosis.

questions.comments: “Gene flow” is the transfer of alleles between populations. Wind blowing pollen from one plant population to another is a good example of gene flow. Over several generations, the two populations will become more similar.
questions.raw_html_comments: “Gene flow” is the transfer of alleles between populations. Wind blowing pollen from one plant population to another is a good example of gene flow. Over several generations, the two populations will become more similar.

questions.raw_html_question: Tay-Sachs disease, which is lethal, results from having the homozygous recessive condition of the responsible gene. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.question: Tay-Sachs disease, which is lethal, results from having the homozygous recessive condition of the responsible gene. Which of the following statements is true?

options.text: Homozygous dominant individuals will be more likely to reproduce than heterozygous individuals.
In the heterozygous condition, the dominant allele will overcome the recessive allele and only the dominant allele will be passed on to offspring.
Because homozygous recessive individuals die, the recessive allele will eventually be lost from the population.
Only homozygous dominant individuals will be able to survive and reproduce.
Heterozygous individuals will survive and may pass the recessive allele on to their offspring.

questions.comments: The diploid nature of most eukaryotes hides a considerable amount of genetic variation from selection, in the form of recessive alleles in heterozygotes. In this example, the recessive allele that causes Tay-Sachs disease has not been eliminated from the population because people who are heterozygous for this gene are relatively healthy.

questions.raw_html_question: Pathogenic bacteria found in many hospitals are antibiotic resistant. This situation is most likely the result of
questions.question: Pathogenic bacteria found in many hospitals are antibiotic resistant. This situation is most likely the result of

options.text: stabilizing selection.
random selection.
diversifying selection.
directional selection.

questions.comments: Prior to the exposure to the antibiotic, different bacterial cells in the population likely had different degrees of resistance to the antibiotic, due to having slightly different versions (alleles) of certain genes. When the antibiotic was applied, those bacteria that were more resistant survived and reproduced at higher rates than the other bacteria. Over time, that meant that a higher and higher percentage of the bacteria in the population would have a high degree of resistance to the antibiotic. This is an example of “directional selection”, which is selection towards one end of a phenotypic spectrum. In this case, the phenotypic spectrum is different degrees of antibiotic resistance and the end of the spectrum that is being selected for is the end that is the most resistant.
questions.raw_html_comments: Prior to the exposure to the antibiotic, different bacterial cells in the population likely had different degrees of resistance to the antibiotic, due to having slightly different versions (alleles) of certain genes. Over time, that meant that a higher and higher percentage of the bacteria in the population would have a high degree of resistance to the antibiotic. This is an example of “directional selection”, which is selection towards one end of a phenotypic spectrum. In this case, the phenotypic spectrum is different degrees of antibiotic resistance and the end of the spectrum that is being selected for is the end that is the most resistant.

questions.question: Assume a population in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium for a character trait with these genotypic frequencies: AA = 0.25, Aa = 0.50, and aa = 0.25. questions.comments: The new frequencies of the three genotypes are: AA = 0, Aa= 0.66, and aa = 0.33. If there were 100 individuals (carrying 200 alleles), 66/200 alleles would be A and p = 0.33. The frequency of homozygous dominant individuals would then be p2, or 0.11.

questions.raw_html_question: Evolution
questions.question: Evolution

options.text: must happen whenever a population is not well-adapted to its environment.
can happen whenever any of the conditions for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium are not met.
must happen, due to organisms’ innate desire to survive.
requires that populations become better suited to their environments.
requires the operation of natural selection.

questions.comments: Factors other than natural selection, such as genetic drift, can lead to evolution (a change in allele frequency within a population). By definition, a locus (gene) is in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium within a population if the frequencies at which different alleles of that gene are present in the population are not changing. So, evolution occurs within a population when that population is NOT in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

questions.comments: Natural selection in which intermediate phenotypes survive and reproduce more successfully than do extreme phenotypes is known as “stabilizing selection”. So, if the frequency of allele A is represented by p and the frequency of allele a is represented by q, then the frequency with which Aa heterozygotes arise is: p X q + q X p = 2pq.

questions.raw_html_question: In a population in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, 1% of the individuals in a population show the recessive trait of a certain characteristic. In this situation, what is the value of p?

options.text: The answer cannot be determined from the information given.

questions.comments: “q” represents the frequency of the recessive allele. Individuals showing the recessive trait must have two copies of the recessive allele. The frequency at which such individuals occur will be q X q, or q2. In this example, we are told that 1% of the individuals in a population show the recessive trait. Therefore, q2= .01, so q = 0.1. The frequency of the dominant allele is represented by “p”. If there are only two alleles for a particular gene, the frequencies of the two alleles must be equal to 1. Therefore, q + pmust be equal to 1. If q + p = 1, then p = 1 – q. In this example q = 0.1, so p = 1 − 0.1 = 0.9

questions.raw_html_question: The allele for brown eyes (B) is found within a population at a frequency of 0.7; the allele for blue eyes (b) at a frequency of 0.3. If the conditions for the Hardy-Weinberg law are satisfied, what will be the expected frequency of heterozygous (Bb) individuals?
questions.question: The allele for brown eyes (B) is found within a population at a frequency of 0.7; the allele for blue eyes (b) at a frequency of 0.3. If the conditions for the Hardy-Weinberg law are satisfied, what will be the expected frequency of heterozygous (Bb) individuals?
questions.comments: If the conditions of the Hardy-Weinberg law are satisfied, that means that the frequencies of the alleles and genotypes in a population will remain constant from generation to generation, provided that only Mendelian segregation and recombination of alleles are at work. In other words, nothing such as sexual selection is occurring. That means that the frequency of different genotypes in the population can be expressed as: p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1, where p is the frequency of the dominant allele (0.7 in this example), q is the frequency of the recessive allele (0.3 in this example) and p2 therefore represents the fraction of individuals who are homozygous for the dominant allele, 2pq represents the fraction of individuals who are heterozygous and q2 represents the fraction of individuals who are homozygous for the recessive allele. In this example, that means the frequency of heterozygous (Bb) individuals = 2pq = 2 x 0.7 X 0.3 = 0.42.
questions.raw_html_comments:
If the conditions of the Hardy-Weinberg law are satisfied, that means that the frequencies of the alleles and genotypes in a population will remain constant from generation to generation, provided that only Mendelian segregation and recombination of alleles are at work. In other words, nothing such as sexual selection is occurring.

In this example, that means the frequency of heterozygous (Bb) individuals = 2pq = 2 x 0.7 X 0.3 = 0.42.

questions.raw_html_question: In peas, a gene controls flower color such that R = purple and r = white. In an isolated pea patch, there are 36 purple-flowering plants and 64 white-flowering plants. Assuming Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, what is the value of q for this population?
questions.question: In peas, a gene controls flower color such that R = purple and r = white. In an isolated pea patch, there are 36 purple-flowering plants and 64 white-flowering plants. Assuming Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, what is the value of q for this population?
questions.comments: By convention, dominant alleles are represented by a capital letter (R in this example) and recessive alleles are represented by lower-case letters (r in this case). The frequency of the dominant allele is represented by p and the frequency of the recessive allele is represented by q. Because the recessive allele codes for white flowers, we know that all the white flowering plants must be homozygous for the recessive allele, or rr. The frequency with which plants of the rr genotype will occur is represented by q X q, or q2. If 64 out of a total of 100 plants are white flowering, that means white flowering plants are 64% of the population. In other words, white flowering plants occur with a frequency of 0.64. Therefore q2= 0.64, and q = 0.8.
questions.raw_html_comments:

questions.raw_html_question: In a Hardy-Weinberg population with two alleles, A and a, that are in equilibrium, the frequency of allele a is 0.2. What is the percentage of the population that is heterozygous for this allele?
questions.question: In a Hardy-Weinberg population with two alleles, A and a, that are in equilibrium, the frequency of allele a is 0.2. What is the percentage of the population that is heterozygous for this allele?
questions.comments: If there are only two alleles, the frequencies of those alleles must add up to 1. If the frequency of allele a is 0.2, that means the frequency of allele A must be: 1- 0.2 = 0.8. Heterozygotes (Aa) can arise two ways: a sperm cell of genotype A may combine with an egg cell of genotype a, or a sperm cell of genotype a may combine with an egg cell of genotype A. So, the frequency with which heterozygotes will occur in this example is: 0.8 X 0.2 + 0.2 X 0.8 = 0.16 + 0.16 = 0.32. So the percentage of the population that is heterozygous for this allele will be 32%.

questions.raw_html_question:
According to the logistic growth equation
dN/dt = rmaxN(K-N)/K
questions.question: According to the logistic growth equation dN/dt = rmaxN(K-N)/K

options.text: the birth rate (b) approaches zero as N approaches K.
the population grows exponentially when K is small.
the number of individuals added per unit time is greatest when N is close to zero.
the per capita growth rate (r) increases as N approaches K.
population growth is zero when N equals K.

questions.comments: The logistic model of population growth assumes there is a maximum population size that the environment can support and that population growth slows as the population approaches that carrying capacity. In this model, the change in population size (dN) over time (dt) is represented by rN x (K – N)/ K. In this equation, “r” represents the rate of population growth if growth rates are unlimited by population density, and “N” represents the number of individuals in the population. So, if growth rates were unrestricted (i.e. if growth rates were exponential), dN/dtwould be equal to rN. However, in this example the population growth is not un-limited, it is increasingly restricted as the size of the population nears the carrying capacity (maximum number of individuals that can be supported) of the environment. In other words, the population experiences logistic growth. The carrying capacity of the environment is symbolized by K. The effects on growth rate of the actual size of the population in relation to the carrying capacity are calculated by (K – N)/K. If the size of N is very small in comparison to K (i.e. if the area can support many, many more individuals than are currently present), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to K/K, or 1, and the rate of population growth will be approximately equal to rN. If the size of N is approximately the same as K (i.e. if the number of individuals already present is close to the carrying capacity), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to zero, and their will be little to no population growth.
questions.raw_html_comments:
The logistic model of population growth assumes there is a maximum population size that the environment can support and that population growth slows as the population approaches that carrying capacity. In this model, the change in population size (dN) over time (dt) is represented by rN x (K – N)/ K. In this equation, “r” represents the rate of population growth if growth rates are unlimited by population density, and “N” represents the number of individuals in the population. So, if growth rates were unrestricted (i.e. if growth rates were exponential), dN/dt
would be equal to rN. However, in this example the population growth is not un-limited, it is increasingly restricted as the size of the population nears the carrying capacity (maximum number of individuals that can be supported) of the environment. In other words, the population experiences logistic growth. The carrying capacity of the environment is symbolized by K. The effects on growth rate of the actual size of the population in relation to the carrying capacity are calculated by (K – N)/K. If the size of N is very small in comparison to K (i.e. if the area can support many, many more individuals than are currently present), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to K/K, or 1, and the rate of population growth will be approximately equal to rN. If the size of N is approximately the same as K (i.e. if the number of individuals already present is close to the carrying capacity), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to zero, and their will be little to no population growth.

questions.comments: Postzygotic reproductive barriers are barriers to the production of viable, fertile offspring that occur after formation of the zygote (fertilized egg cell). In this case, the hybrid offspring produced by the different fruit fly species are infertile. Sperm cell being unable to combine with egg cells, groups or organisms being unable to interbreed due to geographical (e.g. growing in forest versus a meadow) or temporal (e.g. being reproductively active in April versus May) differences are examples of prezygotic barriers rather than postzygotic barriers, as they are barriers that prevent formation of the zygote (fertilized egg cell).

questions.question: Kingfish, Louisiana, had a population of 1,100 individuals. They had a birth rate of 12/100, a death rate of 8/100, an emigration (individuals leaving the population) rate of 2/100 and an immigration rate of 0/100. How many people were added to Kingfish's population in one year?
questions.comments: The birth rate of 12/100 should yield 132 new babies (12/100 X 1,100 = 132); the death rate of 8/100 should yield 88 deaths (8/100 X 1,100 = 88); the emigration rate of 2/100 indicates 22 people moved out (2/100 X 1,100 =22). The net gain is 132 - 88 - 22 = 22.

questions.raw_html_question: As N approaches K for a certain population, which of the following is predicted by the logistic equation?
questions.question: As N approaches K for a certain population, which of the following is predicted by the logistic equation?

options.text: The growth rate will not change.
The population will show an Allee effect.
The carrying capacity of the environment will increase.
The population will increase exponentially.
The growth rate will approach zero.

questions.comments: The logistic model of population growth assumes there is a maximum population size that the environment can support and that population growth slows as the population approaches that carrying capacity. In this model, the change in population size (dN) over time (dt) is represented by rN x (K – N)/ K. In this equation, “r” represents the rate of population growth if growth rates are unlimited by population density, and “N” represents the number of individuals in the population. So, if growth rates were unrestricted (i.e. if growth rates were exponential), dN/dtwould be equal to rN. However, in this example the population growth is not un-limited, it is increasingly restricted as the size of the population nears the carrying capacity (maximum number of individuals that can be supported) of the environment. In other words, the population experiences logistic growth. The carrying capacity of the environment is symbolized by K. The effects on growth rate of the actual size of the population in relation to the carrying capacity are calculated by (K – N)/K. If the size of N is approximately the same as K (i.e. if the number of individuals already present is close to the carrying capacity), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to zero, and their will be little to no population growth.
questions.raw_html_comments:

In this model, the change in population size (dN) over time (dt) is represented by rN x (K – N)/ K. In this equation, “r” represents the rate of population growth if growth rates are unlimited by population density, and “N” represents the number of individuals in the population. So, if growth rates were unrestricted (i.e. if growth rates were exponential), dN/dt
would be equal to rN. However, in this example the population growth is not un-limited, it is increasingly restricted as the size of the population nears the carrying capacity (maximum number of individuals that can be supported) of the environment. In other words, the population experiences logistic growth. The carrying capacity of the environment is symbolized by K. The effects on growth rate of the actual size of the population in relation to the carrying capacity are calculated by (K – N)/K. If the size of N is approximately the same as K (i.e. if the number of individuals already present is close to the carrying capacity), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to zero, and their will be little to no population growth.

questions.comments: A “producer” is an organism that produces organic compounds from CO2 by harnessing light energy (photosynthesis) or by oxidizing inorganic chemicals (in chemosynthetic reactions carried out by some prokaryotes). A “ primary consumer” is an herbivore; an organism that eats plants or other animals. A “secondary consumer” is a carnivore that eats herbivores. A “tertiary consumer” is a carnivore that eats other carnivores (i.e. secondary consumers). A “food chain” begins with a producer. Next comes a primary consumer (e.g. a grasshopper), then a secondary consumer (e.g. a lizard) and then a tertiary consumer (e.g. a hawk).

So, according to this concept, an organism of one species is not able to produce viable, fertile offspring with a member of a different species. Therefore, biological species are reproductively isolated. The biological species concept cannot be used to distinguish species among extinct forms of life, as we generally lack information about which of those forms of life were able to breed with other forms and produce viable, fertile offspring.

questions.raw_html_question: A population's carrying capacity
questions.question: A population's carrying capacity

options.text: generally remains constant over time.
can be accurately calculated using the logistic growth model.
can never be exceeded.
may change as environmental conditions change.
increases as the per capita growth rate (r) decreases.

questions.comments: Carrying capacity will change as environmental conditions change. For example, if a drought causes the death of most of the plants on which a particular animal species feeds, the carrying capacity of that environment for that animal species may be significantly decreased. The logistic growth model allows an estimate of growth rates as a function of how close the population is to its carrying capacity, but does not provide an estimate of carrying capacity. Carrying capacities can be somewhat exceeded on a temporary basis. For example, a wolf population may continue to grow and eat all the deer, until the wolf population has exceeded its carrying capacity. However, within a short period of time this situation would likely lead to the deaths of many of the wolves, as they starved to death.

questions.raw_html_question: A population of ground squirrels has an annual per capita birth rate of 0.06 and an annual per capita death rate of 0.02. Calculate an estimate of the number of individuals added to (or lost from) a population of 1,000 individuals in one year.
questions.question: A population of ground squirrels has an annual per capita birth rate of 0.06 and an annual per capita death rate of 0.02. Calculate an estimate of the number of individuals added to (or lost from) a population of 1,000 individuals in one year.

options.text: 120 individuals added
20 individuals lost
400 individuals added
20 individuals added
40 individuals added

questions.comments: The “annual per capita” birth rate is the average number of births in year per individual in the population. So, an annual per capita birth rate of 0.06 works out to: 0.06 births per year per squirrel X 1,000 squirrels = 60 squirrels born in the population in one year. An annual per capita death rate of 0.02 works out to: 0.02 deaths per year per squirrel X 1,000 squirrels = 20 squirrels die in the population in one year. Therefore, on average 40 (60 births – 20 deaths = 40) squirrels will be added to the population in one year.

options.text: Logged, because the disturbed forest affords more resources for increased specific populations to grow.
Old growth, because each of the species is well established and can produce many offspring.
Exponential growth is equally probable in old-growth and logged forests.
Old growth, because of stable conditions that would favor exponential growth of all species in the forest.

questions.comments: Most species in an old growth forest should be present at numbers near the carrying capacity of the forest. As a result, one would expect little population growth in those species. In a forest that has been logged, many trees of certain species have suddenly been removed from the population. The removal of those trees opens up resources (space, nutrients, water, etc) that can now be used by individuals of the same or different species. As a result, in the time soon after logging some species may be able to experience exponential growth rates.

questions.raw_html_question: Logistic growth of a population is represented by dN/dt =
questions.question: Logistic growth of a population is represented by dN/dt =

options.text: rN (K - N)/K
rN/K
rN (K + N)
rN (N - K)/K
rN

questions.comments: The logistic model of population growth assumes there is a maximum population size that the environment can support and that population growth slows as the population approaches that carrying capacity. In this model, the change in population size (dN) over time (dt) is represented by rN x (K – N)/ K. In this equation, “r” represents the rate of population growth if growth rates are unlimited by population density, and “N” represents the number of individuals in the population. So, if growth rates were unrestricted (i.e. if growth rates were exponential), dN/dt would be equal to rN. However, in this example the population growth is not un-limited, it is increasingly restricted as the size of the population nears the carrying capacity (maximum number of individuals that can be supported) of the environment. In other words, the population experiences logistic growth. The carrying capacity of the environment is symbolized by K. The effects on growth rate of the actual size of the population in relation to the carrying capacity are calculated by (K – N)/K. If the size of N is very small in comparison to K (i.e. if the area can support many, many more individuals than are currently present), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to K/K, or 1, and the rate of population growth will be approximately equal to rN. If the size of N is approximately the same as K (i.e. if the number of individuals already present is close to the carrying capacity), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to zero, and their will be little to no population growth.
questions.raw_html_comments: The logistic model of population growth assumes there is a maximum population size that the environment can support and that population growth slows as the population approaches that carrying capacity. In this model, the change in population size (dN) over time (dt) is represented by rN x (K – N)/ K. In this equation, “r” represents the rate of population growth if growth rates are unlimited by population density, and “N” represents the number of individuals in the population. So, if growth rates were unrestricted (i.e. if growth rates were exponential), dN/dt would be equal to rN. However, in this example the population growth is not un-limited, it is increasingly restricted as the size of the population nears the carrying capacity (maximum number of individuals that can be supported) of the environment. In other words, the population experiences logistic growth. The carrying capacity of the environment is symbolized by K. The effects on growth rate of the actual size of the population in relation to the carrying capacity are calculated by (K – N)/K. If the size of N is very small in comparison to K (i.e. if the area can support many, many more individuals than are currently present), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to K/K, or 1, and the rate of population growth will be approximately equal to rN. If the size of N is approximately the same as K (i.e. if the number of individuals already present is close to the carrying capacity), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to zero, and their will be little to no population growth.

questions.raw_html_question: A certain toxic substance that is retained in cells is taken up by plants. The plants are eaten by small fish. The small fish are, in turn, eaten by large fish. The large fish are eaten by very large fish. Which of the following would be safest to eat?
questions.question: A certain toxic substance that is retained in cells is taken up by plants. The plants are eaten by small fish. The small fish are, in turn, eaten by large fish. The large fish are eaten by very large fish. Which of the following would be safest to eat?

options.text: the very large fish
the small fish
the plants
the large fish

questions.comments: In the case of toxic substances that are retained in organisms, it is safest to eat organisms at the lowest possible trophic level. In this example, that would mean that it is safest to eat the plants. The small fish that eat the plants would have a higher concentration of the toxic substance, because each fish would need to eat about 10 pounds of plant material in order to put on one pound of weight. So, the toxins that were present in 10 pounds of plant material would end up concentrated in one pound of fish. It would be even worse to eat the large fish. To produce 1 pound of large fish takes 10 pounds of the small fish on which the large fish feed. So, 1 pound of large fish would contain the amount of toxin present in 10 pounds of small fish, or 100 pounds of plant material. Eating the very large fish would be the worst. One pound of very large fish would contain the amount of toxin present in 10 pounds of the large fish, 100 pounds of the small fish, or 1,000 pounds of the plants.

questions.raw_html_question: Imagine that part of a population of South American finches is blown by a storm onto an island far offshore and manages to survive and reproduce there for a period of 10,000 years. After that period, a climate change results in lower sea levels and the reconnection of the island with the mainland. Members of the formerly isolated island finch population can now interact freely with members of the original mainland population. Which of the following observations would, by itself, lead you to conclude unequivocally that the island finch population had evolved into a distinct species, according to the biological species concept?
questions.question: Imagine that part of a population of South American finches is blown by a storm onto an island far offshore and manages to survive and reproduce there for a period of 10,000 years. After that period, a climate change results in lower sea levels and the reconnection of the island with the mainland. Members of the formerly isolated island finch population can now interact freely with members of the original mainland population. Which of the following observations would, by itself, lead you to conclude unequivocally that the island finch population had evolved into a distinct species, according to the biological species concept?

options.text: Individuals from the different populations frequently direct courtship behavior toward members of the other population.
The island birds all have red feathers, but the mainland birds have green feathers.
Individuals from the different populations sometimes mate with each other, but all of the resulting eggs are sterile.
Hybrid offspring of matings between individuals from the two populations do not look like either parent.
The preferred food of the island birds is quite different from the diet of mainland birds.

questions.comments: The biological species concept defines a species as a population whose members interbreed successfully to produce viable, fertile offspring but who cannot produce viable, fertile offspring with members of other species. In this example, if birds from the different populations are able to mate but the resulting offspring are sterile (infertile), that means the two populations are different species.
questions.raw_html_comments: The biological species concept defines a species as a population whose members interbreed successfully to produce viable, fertile offspring but who cannot produce viable, fertile offspring with members of other species. In this example, if birds from the different populations are able to mate but the resulting offspring are sterile (infertile), that means the two populations are different species.

questions.raw_html_question: A lake community with four trophic levels suddenly suffers from algal blooms. Using the strategy of biomanipulation, an ecologist may propose _____.
questions.question: A lake community with four trophic levels suddenly suffers from algal blooms. Using the strategy of biomanipulation, an ecologist may propose _____.

options.text: removing zooplankton
removing the fourth trophic level in the lake
adding fish that eat zooplankton
removing fish that eat zooplankton

questions.comments: “Trophic levels” are levels in the food chain. In a lake, the first trophic level is composed of cyanobacteria, which produce organic material through photosynthesis. The second trophic level is composed of zooplankton, which eat cyanobacteria. The third trophic level is composed of fish and other organisms that eat zooplankton. In this example, if the predators of zooplankton are removed from the lake, then the population of zooplankton should increase and the population of cyanobacteria should decrease.

questions.comments: Some adaptations may be present in only one or a few populations of a species. The loss of that adaptation may mean that the species is less able to withstand one or more evolutionary pressures, such as certain changes in the environment or exposure to one or more diseases.

questions.raw_html_question: How is habitat fragmentation related to biodiversity loss?
questions.question: How is habitat fragmentation related to biodiversity loss?

options.text: Populations of organisms in fragments are smaller and, thus, more susceptible to extinction.
Fragments generate silt that negatively affects sensitive river and stream organisms.
Less carbon dioxide is absorbed by plants in fragmented habitats.
In fragmented habitats, more soil erosion takes place.
Animals are forced out of smaller habitat fragments.

questions.comments: Habitat fragmentation leads to smaller population sizes. In small populations, genetic drift tends to cause a loss of genetic diversity, making the populations less able to adapt to changing conditions and therefore more likely to go extinct. Genetic drift can also cause undesirable alleles to become “fixed” in the population (i.e. for all members of the population to become homozygous for the undesirable allele).
questions.raw_html_comments: Habitat fragmentation leads to smaller population sizes. questions.raw_html_question: You are confronted with a box of preserved grasshoppers of various species that are new to science and have not been described. Your assignment is to separate them into species. There is no accompanying information as to where or when they were collected. Which species concept will you have to use?
questions.question: You are confronted with a box of preserved grasshoppers of various species that are new to science and have not been described. Your assignment is to separate them into species. There is no accompanying information as to where or when they were collected. Which species concept will you have to use?

options.text: phylogenetic
biological
ecological
morphological

questions.comments: To be able to take a phylogenetic approach, you would need to know about their ancestry. To take a biological approach, you would need to know which grasshoppers could interbreed and produce viable, fertile offspring. To take an ecological approach, you would need to know about their ecological niche (how they interact with the living and non-living components of their environment). As you know none of these things, you would have to use the morphological species concept. The morphological species concept involves studying and comparing the anatomy and other structural features of the different grasshoppers, looking for similarities that might indicate that certain grasshoppers are members of the same species, as well as differences that might indicate that other grasshoppers are members of other species.
questions.raw_html_comments: To be able to take a phylogenetic approach, you would need to know about their ancestry. To take a biological approach, you would need to know which grasshoppers could interbreed and produce viable, fertile offspring. To take an ecological approach, you would need to know about their ecological niche (how they interact with the living and non-living components of their environment). As you know none of these things, you would have to use the morphological species concept. The morphological species concept involves studying and comparing the anatomy and other structural features of the different grasshoppers, looking for similarities that might indicate that certain grasshoppers are members of the same species, as well as differences that might indicate that other grasshoppers are members of other species.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements describes enzyme cooperativity?
questions.question: Which of the following statements describes enzyme cooperativity?

options.text: The reaction of several substrate molecules can be catalyzed simultaneously by the same enzyme.
A multi-enzyme complex contains all the enzymes of a metabolic pathway.

A substrate molecule bound to the active site of one subunit alters the conformation of that subunit and of the other subunits in a multi-subunit enzyme in such a way that the other subunits are able to bind substrate molecules more easily.
A substrate molecule binds to an active site and inhibits cooperation between enzymes in a metabolic pathway.

questions.comments: Cooperativity is a type of allosteric regulation. Cooperativity only occurs in multi-subunit enzymes. Binding of a substrate molecule to the active site of one subunit causes induced fit of that subunit and may also cause the same conformational alteration in the other subunits, allowing the other subunits to bind substrate molecules more easily. Note that this is still a form of allosteric regulation since binding of a substrate molecule at the active site of one subunit causes a change in the function of the protein at a different site (i.e. the active sites of the other subunits).
questions.raw_html_comments: Cooperativity is a type of allosteric regulation. Cooperativity only occurs in multi-subunit enzymes. Binding of a substrate molecule to the active site of one subunit causes induced fit of that subunit and may also cause the same conformational alteration in the other subunits, allowing the other subunits to bind substrate molecules more easily. Note that this is still a form of allosteric regulation since binding of a substrate molecule at the active site of one subunit causes a change in the function of the protein at a different site (i.e. the active sites of the other subunits).

questions.raw_html_question: Speciation

options.text: must begin with the geographic isolation of a small, frontier population.
occurs only by the accumulation of genetic change over vast expanses of time.
occurs at such a slow pace that no one has ever observed the emergence of new species.
can involve changes to a single gene.

questions.comments: Although speciation often occurs very slowly and involves a large number of genetic changes, it can occur very quickly and involve only a single genetic change. Although speciation often occurs in isolated populations, it can also occur in populations that are not geographically isolated from each other. For example, mistakes in cell division can lead to an organism being polyploid (having more than 2 sets of chromosomes). Polyploid organisms are not able to produce fertile offspring when crossed with non-polyploid (e.g. diploid) members of the species from which they evolved.

questions.raw_html_question: In the evolutionary tree shown below, the horizontal axis represents time (present time is on the far right) and the vertical axis represents morphological change. Which of these five species is the extant (i.e., not extinct) species that is most closely related to species X, and why is this so?
questions.question: In the evolutionary tree shown below, the horizontal axis represents time (present time is on the far right) and the vertical axis represents morphological change. Which of these five species is the extant (i.e., not extinct) species that is most closely related to species X, and why is this so?

options.text: V; shared a common ancestor with X most recently
W; shared a common ancestor with X most recently
Y; arose in the same fashion (i.e., at the same tempo) as X
This tree does not provide enough information to answer this question.
Z; shared a common ancestor with X most recently, and arose in the same fashion as X

questions.comments: The most closely related species are those which share the most recent common ancestor. In the tree of life, forks represent a shared common ancestor for all the lines of evolution that subsequently branch from that point. However, in this example the most recent fork that has a line of evolution to X has only one other line of evolution, that leads to an un-named species that is extinct (we can see that it is extinct because its line of evolution ends before the present time). If we go back to the next most recent fork to which X is connected, we see evolutionary lines from that fork leading to W and V. However, W is extinct. Therefore, the extant (non-extinct) species most closely related to X is V.

questions.raw_html_question: If a new species of plant is to be produced by means of allopolyploidy from two parental species that are 2n = 4 and 2n = 8, how many chromosomes would you expect in the somatic cells of the new species?
questions.question: If a new species of plant is to be produced by means of allopolyploidy from two parental species that are 2n = 4 and 2n = 8, how many chromosomes would you expect in the somatic cells of the new species?

options.text: None of the listed responses is correct.

questions.comments: An allopolyploid is a fertile individual that has more than two chromosome sets as a result of two different species interbreeding and combining their chromosomes. In this example, the two gametes that combine would be n = 2 and n = 4. These gametes would combine to produce a hybrid with a total of 6 chromosomes. These 6 chromosomes would NOT consist of 3 pairs of homologous chromosomes. As a result, they would not be able to pair during meiosis and the hybrid would be sterile. In order for the hybrid to be fertile, and thus represent a new species (a new species won’t arise from one or a few hybrid individuals, if they are all sterile), a mitotic or meiotic error that doubles the chromosome number will need to occur. After this doubling the new species will have 12 chromosomes.
questions.raw_html_comments: An allopolyploid is a fertile individual that has more than two chromosome sets as a result of two different species interbreeding and combining their chromosomes. In this example, the two gametes that combine would be n = 2 and n = 4. These gametes would combine to produce a hybrid with a total of 6 chromosomes. These 6 chromosomes would NOT consist of 3 pairs of homologous chromosomes. As a result, they would not be able to pair during meiosis and the hybrid would be sterile. In order for the hybrid to be fertile, and thus represent a new species (a new species won’t arise from one or a few hybrid individuals, if they are all sterile), a mitotic or meiotic error that doubles the chromosome number will need to occur. After this doubling the new species will have 12 chromosomes.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of these should decline in hybrid zones where reinforcement is occurring?
questions.question: Which of these should decline in hybrid zones where reinforcement is occurring?

options.text: speciation
the genetic distinctness of two gene pools
hybrid sterility
gene flow between distinct gene pools
mutation rate

questions.comments: A hybrid zone is a geographic region in which members of different species meet and mate, producing at least some offspring of mixed ancestry. Reinforcement is a process in which natural selection strengthens prezygotic barriers to reproduction, thus reducing the chances of hybrid formation. So, in areas where reinforcement is occurring, the two populations that are interbreeding in the hybrid zone are becoming more genetically distinct, and less able to interbreed. Being less able to interbreed and produce viable, fertile offspring means that there will be less gene flow between the populations.
questions.raw_html_comments: A hybrid zone is a geographic region in which members of different species meet and mate, producing at least some offspring of mixed ancestry. So, in areas where reinforcement is occurring, the two populations that are interbreeding in the hybrid zone are becoming more genetically distinct, and less able to interbreed. Being less able to interbreed and produce viable, fertile offspring means that there will be less gene flow between the populations.

questions.raw_html_question: In models of logistic population growth,
questions.question: In models of logistic population growth,

options.text: only density-dependent factors affect the rate of population growth.
new individuals are added to the population as N approaches K.
new individuals are added to the population most rapidly at the beginning of the population's growth.
the population growth rate slows dramatically as N approaches K.
carrying capacity is never reached.

questions.comments: The logistic model of population growth assumes there is a maximum population size that the environment can support and that population growth slows as the population approaches that carrying capacity. In this model, the change in population size (dN) over time (dt) is represented by rN x (K – N)/ K. In this equation, “r” represents the rate of population growth if growth rates are unlimited by population density, and “N” represents the number of individuals in the population. So, if growth rates were unrestricted (i.e. if growth rates were exponential), dN/dtwould be equal to rN. However, in this example the population growth is not un-limited, it is increasingly restricted as the size of the population nears the carrying capacity (maximum number of individuals that can be supported) of the environment. In other words, the population experiences logistic growth. The carrying capacity of the environment is symbolized by K. The effects on growth rate of the actual size of the population in relation to the carrying capacity are calculated by (K – N)/K. If the size of N is very small in comparison to K (i.e. if the area can support many, many more individuals than are currently present), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to K/K, or 1, and the rate of population growth will be approximately equal to rN. If the size of N is approximately the same as K (i.e. if the number of individuals already present is close to the carrying capacity), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to zero, and their will be little to no population growth.
questions.raw_html_comments:
The logistic model of population growth assumes there is a maximum population size that the environment can support and that population growth slows as the population approaches that carrying capacity. In this model, the change in population size (dN) over time (dt) is represented by rN x (K – N)/ K. In this equation, “r” represents the rate of population growth if growth rates are unlimited by population density, and “N” represents the number of individuals in the population. So, if growth rates were unrestricted (i.e. if growth rates were exponential), dN/dt
would be equal to rN. However, in this example the population growth is not un-limited, it is increasingly restricted as the size of the population nears the carrying capacity (maximum number of individuals that can be supported) of the environment. In other words, the population experiences logistic growth. The carrying capacity of the environment is symbolized by K. The effects on growth rate of the actual size of the population in relation to the carrying capacity are calculated by (K – N)/K. If the size of N is very small in comparison to K (i.e. if the area can support many, many more individuals than are currently present), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to K/K, or 1, and the rate of population growth will be approximately equal to rN. If the size of N is approximately the same as K (i.e. if the number of individuals already present is close to the carrying capacity), then (K – N)/K will be approximately equal to zero, and their will be little to no population growth.

questions.comments: “K-selection” is selection for traits that are sensitive to population density and are favored at high densities. Different species of flora and fauna are likely to be dense on a coral reef, and so K-selection is likely to be important in that situation. In contrast, some species of flora and fauna may be present in only very limited numbers in an abandoned agricultural field (which would have been full of a particular crop species before it was abandoned, and then gradually being taken over by different species after being abandoned), after a hurricane or on a new island.

questions.raw_html_question: In July 2008, the United States had a population of approximately 302,000,000 people. How many Americans were there in July 2009, if the estimated 2008 growth rate was 0.88%?
questions.question: In July 2008, the United States had a population of approximately 302,000,000 people. How many Americans were there in July 2009, if the estimated 2008 growth rate was 0.88%?
questions.comments: If the growth rate is 0.88%, that means 0.88 people are added to the population for every one hundred people currently in the population. Therefore, 0.88 people added/100 people in population X 302,000,000 people in population = 2,657,600 people added. Therefore, after one year there should be: 302,000,000 + 2,657,600 = 304,657,600, or approximately 304,600,000 people in the population.

questions.comments: A “population” is defined as a group of individuals of the same species that live in the same area and interbreed, producing fertile offspring. So I and II are correct. The definition of population does not require that individuals within the population have any particular dispersal pattern, so III is not one of the characteristics of a population.

questions.comments: Density-independent factors such as daily temperatures are unrelated to population size. Also, food availability and accumulation of toxic wastes are more likely to become problems under crowded conditions.

questions.raw_html_question: White-breasted nuthatches and Downy woodpeckers both eat insects that hide in the furrows of bark in hardwood trees. The Downy woodpecker searches for insects by hunting from the bottom of the tree trunk to the top, whereas the white-breasted nuthatch searches from the top of the trunk down. These hunting behaviors best illustrate which of the following ecological concepts?
questions.question: White-breasted nuthatches and Downy woodpeckers both eat insects that hide in the furrows of bark in hardwood trees. The Downy woodpecker searches for insects by hunting from the bottom of the tree trunk to the top, whereas the white-breasted nuthatch searches from the top of the trunk down. These hunting behaviors best illustrate which of the following ecological concepts?

options.text: competitive exclusion
character displacement
bottom-up and top-down hypotheses
resource partitioning

questions.comments: Resource partitioning is the division of environmental resources by coexisting species such that the niche of each species differs by one or more significant factors from the niches of all coexisting species. In this case, the two species of birds make use of slightly different spatial niches. The Downy woodpecker is eating more insects from the bottoms of trees and the nuthatch is getting more insect from the tops of trees.
questions.raw_html_comments: Resource partitioning is the division of environmental resources by coexisting species such that the niche of each species differs by one or more significant factors from the niches of all coexisting species. In this case, the two species of birds make use of slightly different spatial niches. The Downy woodpecker is eating more insects from the bottoms of trees and the nuthatch is getting more insect from the tops of trees.

questions.comments: Dominant species have the highest biomass in a community. Keystone species may not be abundant, but they do have a crucial role in the function of a community.

questions.raw_html_question: Food chains are sometimes short because
questions.question: Food chains are sometimes short because

options.text: only a single species of herbivore feeds on each plant species.
predator species tend to be less diverse and less abundant than prey species.
local extinction of a species causes extinction of the other species in its food chain.
most of the energy in a trophic level is lost as it passes to the next higher level.

questions.comments: Only about 10% of the energy stored in organic matter of a trophic level (a trophic level is one level in the food chain) is converted to organic matter at the next tropic level. The fact that 90% of the energy is “lost” at each level of the food chain tends to prevent food chains from becoming very long.
questions.raw_html_comments: Only about 10% of the energy stored in organic matter of a trophic level (a trophic level is one level in the food chain) is converted to organic matter at the next tropic level. questions.raw_html_question: _____________ is the different feeding relationships in an ecosystem, which determine the route of energy flow and the pattern of chemical cycling.
questions.question: _____________ is the different feeding relationships in an ecosystem, which determine the route of energy flow and the pattern of chemical cycling.

options.text: Commensalism
Mutualism
Predator structure
Trophic structure

questions.comments: Trophic levels are feeding levels within a community. A “producer” is an organism that produces organic compounds from CO2 by harnessing light energy (photosynthesis) or by oxidizing inorganic chemicals (in chemosynthetic reactions carried out by some prokaryotes). A “ primary consumer” is an herbivore; an organism that eats plants or other animals. A “secondary consumer” is a carnivore that eats herbivores. A “tertiary consumer” is a carnivore that eats other carnivores (i.e. secondary consumers). A “trophic structure”, or “food chain”, begins with a producer. Next comes a primary consumer (e.g. a grasshopper), then a secondary consumer (e.g. a lizard) and then a tertiary consumer (e.g. a hawk).
questions.raw_html_comments: Trophic levels are feeding levels within a community. A “producer” is an organism that produces organic compounds from CO2 by harnessing light energy (photosynthesis) or by oxidizing inorganic chemicals (in chemosynthetic reactions carried out by some prokaryotes). A “ primary consumer” is an herbivore; an organism that eats plants or other animals. A “secondary consumer” is a carnivore that eats herbivores. A “tertiary consumer” is a carnivore that eats other carnivores (i.e. secondary consumers). A “trophic structure”, or “food chain”, begins with a producer. Next comes a primary consumer (e.g. a grasshopper), then a secondary consumer (e.g. a lizard) and then a tertiary consumer (e.g. a hawk).

questions.raw_html_question: Approximately how many kg of carnivore biomass can be supported by a field plot containing 1,000 kg of plant material?
questions.question: Approximately how many kg of carnivore biomass can be supported by a field plot containing 1,000 kg of plant material?
questions.comments: Only about 10% of the energy stored in organic matter of a trophic level (a trophic level is one level in the food chain) is converted to organic matter at the next tropic level. If a field contains 1,000 kg of plant material, it could support approximately 100 kg of primary consumers (= herbivores) and 10 kg of secondary consumers (carnivores that eat the herbivores).

questions.comments: Interspecific competition is competition for resources between individuals of two or more species when resources are in short supply. If a field contains 950 kg of plant material, it could support approximately 95 kg of primary consumers (= herbivores), 9.5 kg of secondary consumers (carnivores that eat the herbivores), and 0.95 kg of tertiary consumers (carnivores that eat the carnivores that eat the herbivores).

questions.comments: Transitions in species composition over ecological time represent a process called ecological succession. Because resource availability changes over the course of succession, different species compete better at different stages. Early colonizers with high reproductive rates maintain themselves by constantly colonizing new areas before better competitors can become established in the same place.
questions.raw_html_comments: Transitions in species composition over ecological time represent a process called ecological succession. The trees derive no known benefits from the dwarf mistletoes. Which of the following best describes the interactions between dwarf mistletoes and trees?

options.text: mutualism
competition
parasitism
commensalism

questions.comments: Parasitism: A symbiotic interaction in which one organism, the parasite, derives its nourishment from another organism, the host, which is harmed in the process. Ecologists estimate that at least one-third of all species on Earth are parasites. In this example, because the mistletoe is benefiting from the nutrients it removes from the tree, at the expense of the tree which is thus losing nutrients, the mistletoe is a parasite of the tree.
questions.raw_html_comments: Parasitism: A symbiotic interaction in which one organism, the parasite, derives its nourishment from another organism, the host, which is harmed in the process. Ecologists estimate that at least one-third of all species on Earth are parasites.
