questions.comments: Competitive exclusion: The concept that when populations of two similar species compete for the same limited resources, one population will use the resources more efficiently and have a reproductive advantage that will eventually lead to the elimination of the other population.” Stated another way, two species cannot coexist permanently in a community if their niches are identical. However, species with similar niches can coexist if one or more significant differences in their niches arise through time.

questions.raw_html_question: Extinction is a natural phenomenon. It is estimated that 99% of all species that ever lived are now extinct. Why then do we say that we are now experiencing an extinction (loss of biodiversity) crisis?
questions.question: Extinction is a natural phenomenon. It is estimated that 99% of all species that ever lived are now extinct. Why then do we say that we are now experiencing an extinction (loss of biodiversity) crisis?

options.text: Scientists have finally identified most of the species on Earth and are thus able to quantify the number of species becoming extinct.
Most biodiversity hot spots have been destroyed by recent ecological disasters.
Humans have greater medical needs than at any other time in history, and many potential medicinal compounds are being lost as plant species become extinct.
The current rate of extinction is high and human activities threaten biodiversity at all levels.
Humans are ethically responsible for protecting endangered species.

questions.raw_html_question: Normal, clean rainwater has a pH of ________________, whereas the pH of acid rain is typically in the range of _____________.
questions.question: Normal, clean rainwater has a pH of ________________, whereas the pH of acid rain is typically in the range of _____________.
questions.comments: Normal, clean water is actually somewhat acidic, as it has a pH typically between 5.0 and 5.5, which is below the pH of pure water, which is 7.0. Acid rain is more acidic then normal, clean rain, and has a pH typically between 4.0 and 4.5, although readings as low as 3.0 have been found. Remember that pH is equal to the negative log of the hydrogen ion concentration. So, a lower pH value corresponds with a higher concentration of hydrogen ions.

questions.raw_html_question: Why do imported (non-native) species sometimes cause problems for native species?
questions.question: Why do imported (non-native) species sometimes cause problems for native species?

options.text: The imported species may occupy the same ecological niche as the native species.
The imported species may be more beautiful than the native species.
The imported species may be larger than the native species.
The imported species may be stronger than the native species.

questions.comments: Two species with identical ecological niches cannot coexist in the same community, as one species will be at least a little more effective than the other in utilizing resources. Over time, the species that is best at utilizing the resources will reproduce more quickly than the other species, and the less successful species will become extinct in that community. So, introduction of a non-native species that occupies the same ecological niche will lead to competition for resources between the non-native and native species. If the non-native species is more competitive, the native species will go extinct in that community.
questions.raw_html_comments: Two species with identical ecological niches cannot coexist in the same community, as one species will be at least a little more effective than the other in utilizing resources. questions.raw_html_question: What is believed to have been the greatest factor leading to loss of species in Australia since approximately the 1850s?
questions.question: What is believed to have been the greatest factor leading to loss of species in Australia since approximately the 1850s?

options.text: Pollution of critical water sources
The introduction of rabbits
Global climate change
Over-hunting of key species, such as kangaroos

questions.comments: Rabbits are not native to Australia. They were intentionally brought to Australia in the 1850s by someone who enjoyed hunting rabbits. They escaped his estate. Within 50 years there were a billion rabbits in Australia spread over two-thirds of the continent. Everything on entire farms was completely eaten and livestock production was severely damaged. Rabbits are thought to be the most significant factor leading to species loss in Australia in relatively recent history.

questions.raw_html_question: How many covalent bonds do oxygen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.question: How many covalent bonds do oxygen atoms need to form with other atoms to complete their valence shell?
questions.comments: Oxygen atoms have 6 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2ndelectron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2ndelectron shell is 8, so oxygen needs to form 2 covalent bonds with other atoms so that it has 2 pairs of electrons that it is sharing via covalent bonds and 2 pairs of electrons that it is not sharing, for a total of 4 pairs of electrons, or 8 total electrons.
questions.raw_html_comments:
Oxygen atoms have 6 electrons in their valence shell, which is the 2nd
electron shell. The total number of electrons needed to fill the 2nd
electron shell is 8, so oxygen needs to form 2 covalent bonds with other atoms so that it has 2 pairs of electrons that it is sharing via covalent bonds and 2 pairs of electrons that it is not sharing, for a total of 4 pairs of electrons, or 8 total electrons.

questions.raw_html_question: How many more electrons do hydrogen atoms need to complete their valence shell?
questions.question: How many more electrons do hydrogen atoms need to complete their valence shell?
questions.comments: Hydrogen atoms have 1 electron. This electron goes in the 1stelectron shell. There is only one orbital in the 1st electron shell. Every electron orbital can have a maximum of 2 electrons. So, the maximum number of electrons that can go in the 1st electron shell, and thus the total number of electrons needed to fill the 1st electron shell, is 2. Since hydrogen has 1 to start with, it needs 1 more electron to fill its valence shell.
questions.raw_html_comments:

electron shell. There is only one orbital in the 1st electron shell. Every electron orbital can have a maximum of 2 electrons. So, the maximum number of electrons that can go in the 1st electron shell, and thus the total number of electrons needed to fill the 1st electron shell, is 2. Since hydrogen has 1 to start with, it needs 1 more electron to fill its valence shell.

quiz_title: SQ topics 5-7

questions.raw_html_question: Which structure is the site of the synthesis of protein that may be exported from the cell?
questions.question: Which structure is the site of the synthesis of protein that may be exported from the cell?

options.text: Golgi vesicles
mitochondrion
rough endoplasmic reticulum
smooth endoplasmic reticulum

questions.comments: Secreted proteins are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Remember that the rough ER gets its name from the fact that it has a “rough” appearance when looked at using a microscope. The reason is has a “rough” appearance is because of the ribosomes that are bound to it. After proteins destined for export are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER, vesicles bud off of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and transport those proteins to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified. Vesicles than bud off of the Golgi apparatus and transport the proteins to the plasma membrane. The vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane, releasing the proteins to the outside of the cell.
questions.raw_html_comments:
Secreted proteins are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough endoplasmic reticulum. Remember that the rough ER gets its name from the fact that it has a “rough” appearance when looked at using a microscope. The reason is has a “rough” appearance is because of the ribosomes that are bound to it.
After proteins destined for export are synthesized by ribosomes bound to the rough ER, vesicles bud off of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and transport those proteins to the Golgi apparatus where they are modified. Vesicles than bud off of the Golgi apparatus and transport the proteins to the plasma membrane. The vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane, releasing the proteins to the outside of the cell.

That means there will be a lower concentration of free water molecules inside the vegetable cells, leading to a net flow of water molecules from outside to inside of the cells. This will cause the cells to expand against their cell walls, making the vegetables crisper.

questions.raw_html_question: Why would a doctor inject a dilute salt solution rather than pure water into the bloodstream of a patient who has suffered severe blood loss?
questions.question: Why would a doctor inject a dilute salt solution rather than pure water into the bloodstream of a patient who has suffered severe blood loss?

options.text: Because pure water might cause the patient’s red blood cells to burst.
Because salt will assist in co-transport of needed nutrients into the patient’s cells.
Because salt will help prevent bacterial infections.
Because pure water might cause the patient’s red blood cells to shrink.

questions.comments: Pure water, which by definition contains no solutes, will be hypotonic compared to the solution inside of the patient’s red blood cells, which contain lots of solutes. That means that adding pure water to the patient’s blood stream will cause there to be more water molecules interacting with solute molecules inside of the red blood cells than outside. That in turn means that there will be fewer free water molecules inside of the patient’s red blood cells than outside of them. Water will thus flow into the red blood cells, causing the cells to swell and possibly burst. So, the doctor uses a dilute salt solution to avoid this problem.

questions.raw_html_question: According to the fluid mosaic model of cell membranes, which of the following statements about membrane phospholipids is TRUE?

options.text: They can move laterally along the plane of the membrane.

They frequently flip-flop from one side of the membrane to the other.
The occur in an uninterrupted bilayer, with membrane proteins restricted to the surface of the membrane.

questions.comments: Membrane phospholipids can move laterally in the plane of the membrane but it is rare for them to flip-flop from one side of the membrane to the other because that would require that their phosphate head group, which is quite hydrophilic, pass through the hydrophobic core of the membrane that is formed by the fatty acid chains of the phospholipids. Membrane proteins occur in a “mosaic” and may be embedded in the membrane (integral membrane proteins) or attached to its surface (peripheral membrane proteins).

questions.raw_html_question: The presence of cholesterol in the plasma membranes of some animals

questions.comments: The effects of cholesterol on membrane fluidity are somewhat complicated. At normal body temperatures (i.e. about 98.6°F), cholesterol interacts with phospholipid molecules, restricting their movement and thereby making the membranes less fluid. However, as the temperature drops, cholesterol molecules interfere with the tight packing of the hydrocarbon chains of the phospholipid molecules, making the membranes more fluid (i.e. decreasing the temperature at which membranes lose a lot of their fluidity and so become less functional).

questions.comments: Both allosteric regulators and non-competitive inhibitors bind at a site that is distinct from the active site(s) they are regulating (note that, during a particular form of allosteric regulation known as “cooperativity”, the activator – which in this case is a substrate molecule - binds at one of the active sites of a multi-subunit enzyme and in so doing stimulates binding of substrate molecules at other active sites of that enzyme). Binding of allosteric regulators is reversible. Allosteric regulators can act as activators or inhibitors of enzyme activity, whereas non-competitive inhibitors are always inhibitors of enzyme activity.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following shows the correct changes in thermodynamic properties for a chemical reaction in which amino acids are linked to form a protein?
questions.question: Which of the following shows the correct changes in thermodynamic properties for a chemical reaction in which amino acids are linked to form a protein?
questions.comments: Linking amino acids together to form a protein (a highly ordered molecule) will cause a decrease in the entropy of the system. So, the change in entropy (∆S) will be negative. In addition, because the free energy of the product (a protein) will be greater than the free energies of the amino acids used to form the protein (this is because of the amount of energy stored in the peptide bonds linking the amino acid monomers together), ∆G will be a positive number. From the information given it is not possible to determine whether the change in total energy (∆H) will be positive or negative.

questions.raw_html_question: The pH of the inner thylakoid space and of the stroma have been measured. Which, if any, relationship would you expect to find?

questions.comments: The concentration of H+ within the inner thylakoid space is greater than within the stroma. However, remember that pH = - log [H+]. Because pH equals the NEGATIVE log of the hydrogen ion concentration, the greater the concentration of hydrogen ions, the lower the pH. So, if the concentration of hydrogen ions is greater in the inner thylakoid space, that means that the pH is LOWER in the inner thylakoid space than in the stroma.

questions.raw_html_question: Which of the following statements is TRUE?
questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE?

options.text: Inhibition of catabolic enzymes by ATP is an example of feedback inhibition.
Inhibition of catabolic enzymes by ADP is an example of feedback inhibition.
All of these answers are correct.
Inhibition of anabolic enzymes by ATP is an example of feedback inhibition.

questions.comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP (and activated by ADP). This is an example of feedback inhibition, as a product of the catabolic pathway, namely ATP, is inhibiting enzymes that catalyze early steps in the catabolic pathway. Similarly, many anabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ADP (and activated by ATP). So, ADP (not ATP) acts as a feedback inhibitor of anabolic pathways. If you have trouble remembering the difference between catabolism and anabolism, picture a cat tearing something up to remember that catabolism is the breakdown of large, energy-rich molecules to produce smaller, less energy-rich molecules. Anabolism is the opposite (i.e. production of large, energy-rich molecules from smaller, less complex and less energy-rich molecules).

This is an example of feedback inhibition, as a product of the catabolic pathway, namely ATP, is inhibiting enzymes that catalyze early steps in the catabolic pathway. Similarly, many anabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ADP (and activated by ATP). So, ADP (not ATP) acts as a feedback inhibitor of anabolic pathways.

questions.raw_html_question: How does a noncompetitive inhibitor decrease the rate of an enzyme reaction?
questions.question: How does a noncompetitive inhibitor decrease the rate of an enzyme reaction?

options.text: by changing the free energy of the products
by increasing the activation energy barrier of the reaction
by changing the free energy of the reactants
by changing the free energy of the reaction

questions.comments: Enzymes work by altering the activation energy barrier of reactions. Enzymes do not alter the free energies of reactant or product molecules and thus do not alter the change in free energy that occurs as a result of the reaction. Because enzymes do not alter the free energies of reactant or product molecules and thus do not alter the change in free energy that occurs as a result of the reaction, the factors that alter enzyme activities (e.g. noncompetitive inhibitors) also do not do these things. Instead, a non-competitive inhibitor makes it more difficult for an enzyme to lower the activation energy barrier. In other words, the activation energy barrier in the presence of enzyme + noncompetitive inhibitor is higher than in the presence of enzyme alone.
questions.raw_html_comments: Enzymes work by altering the activation energy barrier of reactions. Enzymes do not alter the free energies of reactant or product molecules and thus do not alter the change in free energy that occurs as a result of the reaction. In other words, the activation energy barrier in the presence of enzyme + noncompetitive inhibitor is higher than in the presence of enzyme alone.

questions.raw_html_question: A possible sequence of nucleotides in the template strand of DNA that would code for the polypeptide sequence phe-leu-ile-val would be
questions.question: A possible sequence of nucleotides in the template strand of DNA that would code for the polypeptide sequence phe-leu-ile-val would be

options.text: 3' AAC-GAC-GUC-AUA 5'.
3' AAA-GAA-TAA-CAA 5'.
3' AAA-AAT-ATA-ACA 5'.
5' AUG-CTG-CAG-TAT 3'.

questions.comments: The template strand is the strand to which ribonucleotides hydrogen bond during formation of a new RNA molecule. So, the sequence of the RNA molecule will be complementary to the sequence of the template strand. Probably the easiest way to figure out the answer to this question is to determine which amino acids would be specified by template strands with the sequences shown in the different possible answers. For example, a template strand with a nucleotide sequence of: 3' AAC-GAC-GUC-AUA 5' would act as a template for formation of an RNA molecule with the sequence shown below (remember that RNA molecules have U instead of T and that nucleotide chains hydrogen bond in an antiparallel arrangement, so that the 5’ end of one molecule is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other molecule and vice versa).Sequence of template strand = 3’ AAC-GAC-GUC-AUA 5’Sequence of RNA molecule = 5’ UUG-CUG-CAG-UAU 3’ Using the table showing the genetic code, we see that the first codon in this RNA molecule (UUG) codes for leucine. So, we know that this answer is incorrect. If we now determine what amino acid sequence is specified by the nucleotide sequence listed as one of the other possible answers we find:Sequence of template strand = 3’ AAA-GAA-TAA-CAA 5’Sequence of RNA molecule = 5’ UUU-CUU-AUU-GUU 3’ Using the table showing the genetic code, we see that the first codon in this RNA molecule (UUU) specifies phenylalanine, so this might be the correct answer. We next see that the second codon of this RNA molecule (CUU) specifies leucine, which is still consistent with the sequence of the polypeptide listed in the question. The 3rd codon of this mRNA molecule (AUU) specifies isoleucine and the 4th codon (GUU) specifies valine. So, we have found the correct answer.

For example, a template strand with a nucleotide sequence of: 3' AAC-GAC-GUC-AUA 5' would act as a template for formation of an RNA molecule with the sequence shown below (remember that RNA molecules have U instead of T and that nucleotide chains hydrogen bond in an antiparallel arrangement, so that the 5’ end of one molecule is hydrogen bonded to the 3’ end of the other molecule and vice versa).

Sequence of template strand = 3’ AAC-GAC-GUC-AUA 5’
Sequence of RNA molecule = 5’ UUG-CUG-CAG-UAU 3’

Using the table showing the genetic code, we see that the first codon in this RNA molecule (UUG) codes for leucine. So, we know that this answer is incorrect. If we now determine what amino acid sequence is specified by the nucleotide sequence listed as one of the other possible answers we find:

Sequence of template strand = 3’ AAA-GAA-TAA-CAA 5’
Sequence of RNA molecule = 5’ UUU-CUU-AUU-GUU 3’

We next see that the second codon of this RNA molecule (CUU) specifies leucine, which is still consistent with the sequence of the polypeptide listed in the question. The 3rd codon of this mRNA molecule (AUU) specifies isoleucine and the 4th codon (GUU) specifies valine. So, we have found the correct answer.

This is due to the presence of noncoding DNA sequences, known as “intervening” sequences, or “introns”. These introns are removed from precursor mRNA (pre-mRNA, also known as primary mRNA) molecules by splicing.

questions.raw_html_question: During certain types of cell division in Drosophila, studies have shown that there is phosphorylation of an amino acid in the tails of histones of gametes. A mutation in flies that interferes with this process results in sterility. Which of the following is the most likely hypothesis?
questions.question: During certain types of cell division in Drosophila, studies have shown that there is phosphorylation of an amino acid in the tails of histones of gametes. A mutation in flies that interferes with this process results in sterility. Which of the following is the most likely hypothesis?

options.text: Histone tail phosphorylation prohibits chromosome condensation.
All proteins in the cell must be phosphorylated.
Any mutation during oogenesis results in sterility.
These oocytes have no histones.

questions.comments: Histones are proteins that form part of chromatin (the mixture of DNA and protein that makes up our chromosomes). Histones are needed to help with chromatin “packing”. Modifications to histones may make the DNA with which those histones are associated more open and accessible to proteins or more closed and less accessible to other proteins, depending on how the histones are modified. So, it makes sense that phosphorylation of an amino acid in a histone would affect chromosome condensation.

quiz_title: SQ midterm 2

questions.raw_html_question: If ATP levels increase and ADP levels decrease
questions.question: If ATP levels increase and ADP levels decrease

options.text: The rates of many catabolic reactions will decrease due to decreased allosteric activation by ADP.
The rates of many catabolic reactions will decrease due to increased allosteric inhibition by ATP.
The rates of many anabolic reactions will increase due to increased allosteric activation by ATP.
All of these answers are correct.

questions.comments: Catabolic pathways tend to produce ATP from ADP whereas anabolic pathways tend to produce ADP from ATP. If ATP levels in the cell are high, it makes sense to slow down catabolic pathways as the cell doesn’t need to be producing more ATP at that point. As a consequence, many catabolic enzymes evolved so that they are inhibited by ATP. For a similar reason, many catabolic enzymes are activated by ADP. Conversely, because anabolic pathways require ATP and generate ADP, many of the enzymes that catalyze anabolic reactions are activated by ATP and inhibited by ADP.

questions.raw_html_question: Which step in the figure shown below is a redox reaction?
questions.question: Which step in the figure shown below is a redox reaction?

options.text: A
B
C
D

questions.comments: Remember that “redox” reaction is short for “reduction-oxidation” reaction. Redox reactions are reactions where an electron is transferred between atoms or molecules, or where the sharing of electrons in covalent bonds is altered. In the example shown above, NAD is partially gaining an electron when it is converted to NADH, because the covalent bond between the NAD and the H will be a polar covalent bond. Because NAD is more electronegative than hydrogen, the pair of electrons that will form the covalent bond between NAD and hydrogen will spend more of their time near NAD. So, the NAD in NADH will carry a partial negative charge and so will have been “reduced” during the reaction carried out in step “C”. Conversely, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate will have been oxidized as it is converted to 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate.

questions.raw_html_question: Why is glycolysis described as having an investment phase and a payoff phase?
questions.question: Why is glycolysis described as having an investment phase and a payoff phase?

options.text: It uses glucose and generates pyruvate.
It both splits molecules and assembles molecules.
It attaches and detaches phosphate groups.
It first uses two stored ATP and then forms four ATP, for a net increase of two ATP.

questions.comments: During the energy investment phase, two molecules of ATP are used to create a sugar molecule with two phosphate groups attached. Because the bonds between phosphate groups and the rest of a molecule are high-energy bonds, this di-phosphorylated molecule is therefore a high-energy molecule. The high energy possessed by the di-phosphorylated molecule allows it to split into two molecules, each of which has three carbon atoms. As these three-carbon molecules are metabolized to form pyruvate, some of the energy that is released is used to form ATP, in the “energy payoff” phase of glycolysis.
questions.raw_html_comments: During the energy investment phase, two molecules of ATP are used to create a sugar molecule with two phosphate groups attached. quiz_title: Quiz 1

questions.raw_html_question: Studies have shown which of the following to be a particularly effective way for most students to learn new material?
questions.question: Studies have shown which of the following to be a particularly effective way for most students to learn new material?

options.text: repeatedly going over their notes about the material
repeatedly going back over textbook readings about the material
repeatedly answering questions about the material

questions.comments: In one study, different groups of students were shown a list of vocabulary words. The students were then divided into three groups. The first group of students kept studying (reading over) the list of vocabulary words. The second group alternated between reading over the list of words and being tested on them. The third group kept being tested on the list of words. The first group of students did the worst on tests of the vocabulary words. Interestingly, the second and third groups of students did about equally well. This study suggests that repeatedly going over and over study questions is generally a more effective method of learning new material than repeatedly going over the reading (either from the textbook or from your notes). (And, going over your notes is likely to be more effective than going over the textbook).

quiz_title: Quiz 2

questions.raw_html_question: When a reversible chemical reaction reaches equilibrium,
questions.question: When a reversible chemical reaction reaches equilibrium,

options.text: the forward and reverse reactions stop
the relative concentrations of reactants and products continues to change
the concentrations of reactants and products are equal
the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate

questions.comments: At equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate. This does not mean that the concentrations of reactants and products are equal. Typically one will be significantly higher than the other. But, the relative concentrations of the reactants and products will cease to change. For example, if A and B are converted to C and D, and C and D are converted to A and B in the reverse reaction, then equilibrium is reached when the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is the same as the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. If the reaction of A and B to form C and D is more energetically favorable than the reaction of C and D to form A and B, equilibrium may not be reached until the concentrations of C and D are significantly higher than the concentrations of A and B. At that point, even though individual molecules of A and B may be more likely to react to form molecules of C and D, because there are so many more molecules of C and D the rate at which molecules of C and D are converted to A and B becomes the same as the rate at which molecules of A and B are converted to C and D. For example, imagine a test tube in which there are 1,000 molecules each of A and B and that 10% of them interact per minute to form C and D. That would mean that the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D is 100 per minute. If the there are 10,000 molecules each of C and D in the test tube and 1% of them react per minute to form A and B, the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B would also be 100 per minute, indicating that the system is at equilibrium. If you removed some of the molecules of C and D from the test tube, right after you removed the C and D the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be unchanged, but the rate of conversion of C and D would decrease. So, the system would no longer be at equilibrium as the rate of conversion of A and B to C and D would be higher than the rate of conversion of C and D to A and B. Because of this, the relative concentrations of A and B versus C and D would also be changing, with C and D increasing relative to A and B. Eventually, the concentrations of C and D would increase enough and the concentrations of A and B would decrease enough so that the rates of the forward and reverse reactions would become equal, meaning that equilibrium would be re-established.
questions.raw_html_comments: At equilibrium, the forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate. This does not mean that the concentrations of reactants and products are equal. Typically one will be significantly higher than the other. But, the relative concentrations of the reactants and products will cease to change. If the reaction of A and B to form C and D is more energetically favorable than the reaction of C and D to form A and B, equilibrium may not be reached until the concentrations of C and D are significantly higher than the concentrations of A and B. At that point, even though individual molecules of A and B may be more likely to react to form molecules of C and D, because there are so many more molecules of C and D the rate at which molecules of C and D are converted to A and B becomes the same as the rate at which molecules of A and B are converted to C and D. questions.raw_html_question: When an electron is moved further from the nucleus
questions.question: When an electron is moved further from the nucleus

options.text: its potential energy may change, depending on how the electron was moved
its potential energy is unchanged
it loses potential energy
it gains potential energy

questions.comments: The further an electron is from the nucleus, the greater its potential energy. Think of it this way. Negatively charged electrons are attracted to the positively charged protons in the nucleus. So, it takes work to increase the separation between an electron and the nucleus. Some of the energy spent in doing this work is stored in the form of increasing the potential energy of the moved electron. This is conceptually similar to increasing the potential energy of a ball by carrying it higher up a hill.

questions.comments: A hydrogen bond forms when a hydrogen covalently bonded to one electronegative atom (such as the oxygen atom in a water molecule) is also attracted to another electronegative atom (such as the oxygen atom in a second water molecule). The pair of electrons shared by the hydrogen atom and the oxygen atom to which the hydrogen atom is covalently bound will spend more time near the nucleus of the oxygen atom than near the nucleus of the hydrogen atom, as oxygen is more electronegative than hydrogen (meaning that oxygen atoms attract electrons more strongly than hydrogen atoms). As a result, the hydrogen atom will have a slight positive charge and the oxygen atom will have a slight negative charge. The slightly positively charged hydrogen atom will then be attracted to the slight positively charged oxygen of another water molecule, forming a hydrogen bond.

questions.raw_html_question:
Use the diagram below to help answer this question.  The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a semi-permeable barrier.  This semi-permeable barrier is permeable to water and to Mg++ and Na+ ions, but not to Cl- ions.  If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2
to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, at equilibrium
questions.question: Use the diagram below to help answer this question.  The diagram shows a U-tube, with the two arms of the tube separated at the bottom by a semi-permeable barrier.  This semi-permeable barrier is permeable to water and to Mg++ and Na+ ions, but not to Cl- ions.  If you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of MgCl2 to side “A” and you add 1 liter of an aqueous solution containing 1 mole of NaCl to side “B”, at equilibrium

options.text: there will have been a net flow of water from side “A” to side “B”
there will have been no movement of water molecules across the membrane
there will have been a net flow of water from side “B” to side “A”
there will have been no net flow of water between the two sides of the tube

questions.comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+ and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. Importantly, there will be a higher concentration of Cl- (which can’t pass the membrane) on side A than on side B. As a result, there will be more free water molecules on side B than on side A. So, there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until the concentration of free water molecules is the same on both sides of the membrane. At that point, free water molecules will still cross the membrane, but the rate at which free water molecules cross from side B to side A will be equal to the rate at which free water molecules cross from side A to side B.
questions.raw_html_comments: MgCl2 and NaCl are both salts that will dissociate into their constituent ions when they come in contact with water. So, the 1 mole of MgCl2 will dissociate to form 1 mole of Mg++ and 2 moles of Cl- and the 1 mole of NaCl will dissociate to form 1 mole of Na+ and 1 mole of Cl-. That means that, immediately after the solutions are added to the two sides of the tube, there will be a higher concentration of solute molecules on side A than on side B. Importantly, there will be a higher concentration of Cl- (which can’t pass the membrane) on side A than on side B. As a result, there will be more free water molecules on side B than on side A. So, there will be a net flow of water molecules from side B to side A, until the concentration of free water molecules is the same on both sides of the membrane. At that point, free water molecules will still cross the membrane, but the rate at which free water molecules cross from side B to side A will be equal to the rate at which free water molecules cross from side A to side B.

questions.raw_html_question: How many more electrons do oxygen atoms need to complete their valence shell?
questions.question: How many more electrons do oxygen atoms need to complete their valence shell?
questions.comments: Oxygen atoms have 8 electrons. 2 of those electrons fill the 1stelectron shell and the other 6 fill 6 of the 8 spots in the 2ndelectron shell, which is outermost shell and thus the valence shell for oxygen. Oxygen thus needs 2 more electrons to fill its valence shell.
questions.raw_html_comments:

electron shell and the other 6 fill 6 of the 8 spots in the 2nd
electron shell, which is outermost shell and thus the valence shell for oxygen. Oxygen thus needs 2 more electrons to fill its valence shell.

quiz_title: Quiz 9

questions.raw_html_question: The pedigree below is for a family, some of whose members exhibit the dominant trait, W. Affected individuals are indicated by a dark square or circle. What is the probability that individual III-1 is Ww?
questions.question: The pedigree below is for a family, some of whose members exhibit the dominant trait, W. Affected individuals are indicated by a dark square or circle. What is the probability that individual III-1 is Ww?
questions.comments: The dominant trait is W. Affected individuals are represented by dark squares or circles and unaffected individuals are represented by open squares or circles. An individual (I-2) who is Ww is shown as being affected. III-1 is affected, which could be due to being WW or Ww. We can determine that III-1 must be Ww, because III-1 has a parent who is not affected. This parent must therefore be ww, meaning that III-1 must have inherited a w allele from that parent. Therefore III-1 must be Ww.

quiz_title: Quiz 10

questions.raw_html_question: According to the “semi-conservative” model of DNA replication,
questions.question: According to the “semi-conservative” model of DNA replication,

options.text: after DNA replication occurs, one of the two double-stranded DNA molecules will consist of two “daughter” DNA strands and the other will consist of two “parental” DNA strands
after DNA replication occurs, each of the two double-stranded DNA molecules will consist of one “daughter” and one “parental” DNA strand

after DNA replication occurs, one of the DNA strands in each double-stranded DNA molecule will consist of a mixture of “daughter” and “parental” DNA and the other DNA strand in each double-stranded DNA molecule will consist of all “daughter” DNA
each of the DNA strands in the double-stranded DNA molecules will consist of partly “parental” DNA and partly “daughter” DNA

questions.comments: Replication of double-stranded DNA molecules occurs by what is known as the “semi-conservative” model. The DNA strands in the original double-stranded DNA molecule are known as the “parental” DNA strands. The DNA strands that are made by copying the parental DNA strands are known as the “daughter” DNA strands. According to the semiconservative model of DNA replication, each parental DNA strand is copied. So, after one round of DNA replication occurs, each of the two resulting double-stranded DNA molecules will consist of one parental DNA strand and one daughter DNA strand.

quiz_title: SQ midterm 3

questions.raw_html_question: A mutant bacterial cell has a defective aminoacyl synthetase that attaches a lysine to tRNAs with the anticodon AAA instead of the normal phenylalanine. The consequence of this for the cell will be that
questions.question: A mutant bacterial cell has a defective aminoacyl synthetase that attaches a lysine to tRNAs with the anticodon AAA instead of the normal phenylalanine. The consequence of this for the cell will be that

options.text: the cell will compensate for the defect by attaching phenylalanine to tRNAs with lysine-specifying anticodons.
none of the options will occur; the cell will recognize the error and destroy the tRNA.
proteins in the cell will include lysine instead of phenylalanine at amino acid positions specified by the codon UUU.
none of the proteins in the cell will contain phenylalanine.

questions.comments: Most amino acids are specified by more than one codon. So, if the tRNAs with the anticodon AAA are charged with lysine instead of phenylalanine, that means that the proteins formed by the mutant organism will have lysine instead of phenylalanine at all places where phenylalanine was specified by AAA. However, the mutant organism will still correctly place phenylalanine at positions in proteins where phenylalanine is specified by one of the other codons that specify phenylalanine.
